Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X1N-WX31-F072-J1X1-00000-00Evening Update: Film company says interference by Ottawa to blame for funding decision on Huawei docudrama; federal leaders hit campaign trail ahead of first debate;Also: Russian police raid more than 150 addresses associated with opposition critic2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexisNATIONALEvening Update: Film company says interference by Ottawa to blame for funding decision on Huawei docudrama; federal leaders hit campaign trail ahead of first debateAlso: Russian police raid more than 150 addresses associated with opposition criticKate HopwoodABSTRACT

Also: Russian police raid more than 150 addresses associated with opposition critic

FULL TEXT

Good evening, let's start with today's top stories:

Canadian film company alleges interference by Ottawa after CMF pulls funding on Huawei docudrama with ties to Stephen Bannon

A Canadian film company is accusing the federal government https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/article-canadian-film-company-alleges-interference-by-ottawa-after-cmf-pulls/ after an arm's-length regulator suspended funding for its completed docudrama about the row between Ottawa and Beijing over the detention of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou.

The Toronto production company, New Realm Studios, said Tuesday that the Canada Media Fund is in breach of a finalized contract and that Ottawa and the CMF are penalizing it for its association with former Donald Trump aide Stephen Bannon, who is helping with U.S. distribution.

According to New Realm, widely disseminated news of Bannon's association with the docudrama prompted discussions between the federal government and the CMF, whose officials subsequently notified the producers of the suspension on Aug. 28.

This is the daily Evening Update newsletter. If you're reading this on the web, or it was forwarded to you from someone else, you can sign up for Evening Update and more than 20 more Globe newsletters on our https://www.theglobeandmail.com/newsletters/?utm_source=Arcnewsletter&utm_medium=onsite&utm_campaign=fixed_positions&utm_term=signuppage&utm_content=eveninging_update_promo .

Federal election 2019: Court ruling on medically assisted death sparks right-to-die debate on campaign trail; Trudeau to be absent from tonight's debate

With the first full day of campaigning https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-assisted-death-decision-sparks-debate-on-campaign-trail/, NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh went the furthest of the federal party leaders in response to a court decision striking down some restrictions to medically assisted deaths by pledging to improve access.

People who need to make the decision to seek an assisted death "for their dignity" should be able to make that choice, Singh said while speaking outside of a hospital in Brampton, Ont.

"Right now, the criteria being too narrow, doesn't allow access to this decision for a lot of people," he said. "I am open to looking at ways to making sure the access is improved and that we do it in a way that respects the dignity of someone to make that choice."

Tonight, Singh and Conservative Party leader Andrew Scheer will be attending a debate in Toronto evening hosted by Maclean's and Citytv, alongside Green Party Leader Elizabeth May. The two-hour debate will be conducted in English and it will focus on four key themes: the economy, foreign policy, Indigenous issues, and energy and the environment. Trudeau will not take part in the debate (Here's Globe and Mail columnist John Ibbitson's https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-justin-trudeau-will-only-debate-if-it-helps-his-chances-what-else/ on that decision from last week: Why would Mr. Trudeau want to attend?).

Russia carries out mass raids on homes, offices of supporters of Kremlin critic Alexey Navalny

Roughly 1,000 Russian police officers, some wearing masks and riot gear, https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-russian-police-carry-out-mass-raids-against-addresses-affiliated-with/ affiliated with opposition leader Alexey Navalny and his Anti-Corruption Foundation in Moscow and 40 other cities across the country today in what experts say is a massive effort to intimidate and punish those involved in recent political unrest. Officers confiscated computers and other equipment and told activists the raids were part of a money-laundering investigation.

As Mark MacKinnon reports from Moscow, the co-ordinated raids come just days after Navalny's supporters showed their growing clout via a municipal election in Moscow, using strategic voting to oust several pro-Kremlin incumbents. Lyubov Sobol, a 31-year-old lawyer who emerged as a https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-the-thorn-in-putins-side-moscow-election-results-a-sign-of-things-to/ over the summer while Navalny was serving a 30-day jail sentence, used her Twitter   https://twitter.com/SobolLubov to warn that Russians needed to pay attention to what was happening. "If you believe that the security forces can only enter Navalny's offices, then you are deeply mistaken," she wrote.

Opinion: (Doug Saunders) - This https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-this-may-be-putins-endgame-says-garry-kasparov-but-its-our-move/, says Garry Kasparov - but it's our move

ALSO ON OUR RADAR

Tonight: The Democratic leadership debate in Houston will have progressives, but virtually no moderates Is the principal goal of the Democrats to defeat Donald Trump, or is it to win long-desired political goals such as a Canada-style health-care plan? David Shribman https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-the-democratic-leadership-debate-in-houston-will-have-progressives/ the contest.

Hudson's Bay posts deeper loss with streamlining efforts still in 'early stages': Hudson's Bay Co. has https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-hudsons-bay-posts-deeper-loss-as-streamlining-efforts-still-in-early/ as it continues to close stores and sell off discounted merchandise in an effort to modernize the offerings of its Bay department store chain and reverse falling sales. The company has been pursuing a strategy of selling off underperforming stores and focusing on its Hudson's Bay and Saks brands. Last month, the company announced it would sell its Lord & Taylor banner to fashion rental service Le Tote Inc. for $132.7-million, and HBC expects the deal to close before the holiday period.

Boris Johnson denies lying to Queen Elizabeth in Brexit crisis: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-boris-johnson-denies-lying-to-queen-elizabeth-in-brexit-crisis/ to Queen Elizabeth over the reasons for suspending the British parliament after a court ruled his decision was unlawful and opponents called for lawmakers to be recalled to discuss Brexit.

All eyes on Connor McDavid's rehabbed left knee as Edmonton Oilers begin camp: The Oilers' star centre https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/article-all-eyes-on-connor-mcdavids-rehabbed-left-knee-as-edmonton-oilers/ and, based on recent precamp practices, injury-free. But he is waiting on the final word from doctors on what his practice regimen will be, and whether he's cleared for contact when players hit the ice Friday.

MARKET WATCH

Canada's main stock index hit an intraday record high on Thursday before easing slightly, as investor confidence was boosted by financial shares, easing of tensions in the U.S.-China trade war and the European Central Bank's move to cut rates. The Toronto Stock Exchange's S&P/TSX composite index closed up 32.14 points to 16,643.28.

On Wall Street, stocks jumped and the S&P 500 came close to an all-time high on positive news on the U.S.-China trade front. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 47.11 points to 27,184.15, the S&P 500 gained 8.77 points to 3,009.7 and the Nasdaq Composite added 24.79 points to 8,194.47.

Got a news tip that you'd like us to look into? E-mail us at tips@globeandmail.com . Need to share documents securely? Reach out via https://sec.theglobeandmail.com/securedrop/ .

TALKING POINTS

The Greens' election chances are being torpedoed - by the Greens

https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-greens-election-chances-are-being-torpedoed-by-the-greens/: "The unity of Canada is not one of the Green's core values? Are you kidding me? A party that actually imagines running the country does not have, as part of its central mandate, nurturing the health of one Canada? That is nuts."

https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-time-for-lazy-governments-to-pick-up-the-slack-as-the-european-central/: Will the European Central Bank's stimulus package work? "Locking in ultraloose monetary policy for several more years may deliver a marginal, but only marginal, lift to the economy and to inflation, which is better than nothing. What would do a better job is a hefty spending package, notably from tightwad Germany, which considers running budget deficits a moral failing."

LIVING BETTER

It's easy to walk into a ceramics store and feel that today's pottery is either rustic, minimal or sappily sentimental. But a group of https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/home-and-design/article-not-your-grandmas-fine-china-todays-porcelain-artists-are-using/ are using technology like 3-D printing to explore unexpected themes from sex to climate change through bold porcelain pieces well-suited to contemporary interiors.

To read more stories from the latest edition of Style Advisor, download the https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/article-read-the-full-style-advisor-september-2019-edition/.

LONG READ FOR A LONG COMMUTE

Silicon Valley's motor city: As big tech adds fuel to a housing crisis, poorer residents live in RVs

Silicon Valley is an economic marvel for its ability to churn out a dizzying array of new technology, but that success has https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-silicon-valleys-motor-city-as-big-tech-adds-fuel-to-a-housing-crisis/: It has helped create a housing shortage so severe that nearly everyone agrees the region is in a crisis. As California-based U.S. correspondent Tamsin McMahon reports, rents in the Valley have risen 50 per cent since 2011, the median home price is in the millions and the consequence is lower-income residents have been pushed out of affordable housing. Many of the main arteries running through the heart of Silicon Valley are lined with row upon row of recreational vehicle, in which many minimum-wage service workers live. The housing crisis has raised a huge question for state and local governments: What happens when an economy is so successful that it churns out thousands more jobs than homes?

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VR3-XXG1-JBSS-S4VB-00000-00Even some capitalists are in favor of breaking up Big Tech2019-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexisEven some capitalists are in favor of breaking up Big TechBy Matt Egan, Julia Horowitz and Charles Riley, CNN BusinessNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- 1. Tech backlash: Even some capitalists fear that Silicon Valley today resembles a playground basketball game: The players are refereeing themselves.

Bill Smead, a Seattle money manager, knows firsthand that things can get out of hand during neighborhood basketball games. And he thinks it's time to crack down on Big Tech.

"We're dealing with a game of far too much importance to have the rules officiated by the players," Smead, the CEO of Smead Capital Management, told CNN Business.

"We are letting them call the fouls," Smead said, "and in the process it's ruining the competitive landscape that is so necessary in this democratic capitalist system."

Although that kind of critique of Silicon Valley is hard to find on Wall Street, it's becoming commonplace on the political left. In fact, some Democrats are running on it.

Senator Elizabeth Warren unveiled a plan earlier this month to break up tech giants like Amazon, Google and Facebook that haul in $25 billion or more in revenue. The presidential candidate's plan would also aim to unwind landmark tech acquisitions, including Amazon's purchase of Whole Foods, Google's takeover of DoubleClick and Facebook's savvy deals for Instagram and WhatsApp

"Today's big tech companies have too much power -- too much power over our economy, our society, and our democracy," Warren wrote in a Medium post. "They've bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else."

Those words were met with eyerolls from some on Wall Street. But not Smead, who explained his position in a letter to clients (after first warning them to grab a "sturdy chair" to sit down on). The money manager supports rewriting the antitrust laws and then either breaking up or regulating Big Tech companies. He broadly supports Warren's plan.

"I love competition," Smead said. "But there are some things that are more important than just competing. And that is the survival of this wonderful system that has succeeded so well."

Smead specifically called out Amazon, Google and Facebook as the prime suspects. He said the problem is that while supply and demand is normally balanced by price, far too often that doesn't happen in today's tech world.

"They have taken price out of social media, search and delivery. How can supply and demand work when there is no price?" Smead said. "It's impossible."

Regulatory risk is rising

Of course, many would argue that the push to crack down on tech is an example of punishing success. Big doesn't have to be bad. And these tech giants were built on American ingenuity.

Nonetheless, Wall Street is starting to grow worried about a looming tech crackdown. Facebook, mired in countless scandals, has watched its stock decline 24% since peaking in July.

What happens next to Big Tech has broad implications. These companies have enormous sway over the stock market. Millions of Americans own them in their 401(k) plans and mutual funds.

Smead, recalling the bursting of the dot-com bubble, is warning his clients to cash in their tech winnings before the backlash arrives.

"Parabolic manias go until they don't," Smead said. "When the mania goes, they get crushed. They don't just go down."

2. Brexit next steps: The European Union has given the United Kingdom three weeks to solve a political riddle that has vexed politicians for nearly three years: Does Britain really want to leave the bloc? And if so, under what terms?

How parliament answers those questions this week could have major implications for financial markets and the UK economy. The potential outcomes remain the same: Leave the European Union with a deal that protects trade, crash out of the bloc or seek another delay to the process.

Brexit has already done major damage to the UK economy. The economy is now 2% smaller than it would have been if the United Kingdom had chosen to remain in the EU, according to the Bank of England.

3. Apple announcement: Apple has a press event scheduled for Monday. It's expected to focus on the launch of its rumored streaming service.

The company quietly launched new gadgets ahead of the event throughout last week. It debuted its next-generation wireless earbuds, as well as a refresh of its iMac line and new versions of the iPad Air and iPad mini.

Investors will watch the reveal closely. Apple's stock rose last week on positive analyst reports and in anticipation of the event.

4. Housing data: A trifecta of US real estate reports are expected Tuesday: US building permits, housing starts and S&P/Case-Shiller US home prices. US consumer confidence comes out the same day.

On Friday, the National Association of Realtors reported that existing US home sales rebounded in February after slipping in January. This was read as an optimistic sign about the health of the US economy.

Analysts will observe whether the pattern holds this week. Some expect the housing market to get a boost from the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady.

5. Lyft goes public: Ride-hailing firm Lyft will make its long-anticipated debut on the Nasdaq this week. Lyft predicted investors would buy the stock for between $62 and $68 a share. The company expects to raise as much as $2.1 billion through the sale of stock.

6. Coming this week:

Monday --- Apple event

Tuesday --- US building permits; US housing starts; S&P/Case-Shiller home prices; McCormick and Carnival earnings

Wednesday --- US balance of trade data; Lululemon earnings

Thursday --- UK consumer confidence; US final estimate Q4 GDP

Friday --- Huawei earnings; Carmax earnings

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 2015 revenues of GBP12.2b, net sales of GBP10.5b and headline diluted EPS of 93.6p. Expects 2016 organic revenue and net sales growth to be 0-5%.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 2015 revenues = GBP12.2b.

2. 2015 net sales = GBP10.5b.

3. 2015 headline diluted EPS = 93.6p.

4. 2015 reported revenue growth = 6%.

5. 2015 constant currency revenue growth = 7.5%.

6. 2015 reported net sales growth = 4.6%.

7. 2015 constant currency net sales growth = 5.8%.

8. 2015 net debt = GBP3.5b.

9. 2016 organic revenue and net sales growth guidance = 0-5%.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

2015 Financials (P.R.)

1. Highlights:

1. 30th anniversary; record year, despite 2H currency headwind.

2. Billings GBP47.6b, up:

1. Constant currency, 4.9%.

2. Like-for-like 4.0%.

1. Advertising growth is ahead of GDP growth this year for fifth straight year.

1. Forecast for advertising pops above GDP forecast in 2017.

1. Lack of pricing power remains headwind as does focus on costs.

1. Eurozone indexing at 80.

2. Eurozone periphery, most stricken of all, indexing at 60.

4. New world, which is faster growth world generally has never gone backwards in advertising in real terms.

1. Its pre-Lehman run rate of 8% real growth a year, slowed now to like 4% real for time being.

3. These Top 10 countries are providing 85% of that and leading China is contributing $7b and USA $5b.

1. Fairly substantial dependence on minority of countries but dependence has lessened slightly with Russia receding and Continental Europe taking up little more of growth.

1. China's linear public television is highly regulated.

2. Stimulated heavy exodus of TV advertising money from traditional TV into online television.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

WILL MAIRS, ANALYST, NOMURA: Will Mairs, Nomura. Three questions. The first one is just on the restructuring charge and that follows on from quite a large one in 2014 of GBP128 million.

So I'm just wondering how recurring should we think that restructuring charge [had been]? Perhaps if you could give us more details on IT, if you think that's going to re-occur. And perhaps also on the severance, if Kantar-related severance will continue or actually if there'll be severance in difference areas of the business.

The second question is just regarding North America. You said that you're gaining quite significant share in that market. I'm just wondering what are you doing different in North America to gain that share and how sustainable that is.

And then the third question is just on general pricing in the market. So I guess you've got all of the media reviews that have taken place, which might put pressure on pricing in the market. But, on the flip side, you're reiterating 30 bps of margin growth. You're seeing Omnicom issue 30 bps as well and all the other agencies different levels of margin growth, which might indicate that pricing pressure isn't quite there. So I'm just wondering how you marry the two between those.

MARTIN SORRELL, CHIEF EXECUTIVE, WPP PLC: Just before Paul answers on restructuring, we have the option of taking exceptional gains and exceptional charges above the line, rather than below the line.

So it's a question of taking advantage, and I would say this quite forthrightly, of significant exceptional gains to do some of the things that, if we were private, and we've discussed this before, if we were private or private equity we would do -- I'll be blunt about it, we would probably be much more aggressive on restructuring than we can do, given the constraints of quarterly or half-yearly or annual reporting.

So I think you don't want to anticipate that it's constant or continuous. We're just taking advantage of the fact that we have exceptional gains to do it.

Do you want to comment on the restructuring costs?

PAUL RICHARDSON, FINANCE DIRECTOR, WPP PLC: I think, if I was to characterize it, I would say that last year was still the continuation of trying to improve Western Continental Europe, this is 2014 I am talking about, really across the portfolio of our brands, quite frankly.

We have made huge strides in Western Continental Europe. Obviously, only the last two years have we seen any sort of revenue growth at all. And, really, ever since 2009 we have been working, I suppose, across the portfolio of countries, across the portfolio of brands.

I think we've seen the benefit of that. It's obviously hard to see in the reported numbers because of the currency impact, but that has generally happened and we're pleased with it.

I think the opportunity, or it's really an operational decision by Kantar to structurally make a change in the way they face clients, was decided upon and, actually, we think could be a model for how our other businesses could operate.

So, for the first time, we are actually delicately trying to combine the consumer insights business of Millward Brown, TNS, Added Value, Lightspeed and the operations center. It's taken us a long time to be comfortable to do this but we actually think it's the best thing for clients in all respects and we're doing it globally across 110 markets.

And I'd say it's probably the most focused, the most targeted structurally, with the key ambition of driving top-line growth.

So that is the characterism (sic) in terms of this year's initiatives.

They have another initiative in terms of the outsourcing of all their media print management business offshore, which is also part of the charge.

So two very specific projects. We actually got external help to help us, professional external help, for the first time. This is a major across the structure initiative, both client-facing personnel and, secondly, obviously, the follow-on of the back office HR, IT.

So that's my characterization.

Secondly, we continue with the GINA project, we call it the GINA project; the phase 1 of our IT infrastructure.

We have finished the transformation and transition costs. We now have 160,000 people on the same email system across the Group, all outsourced to third-party help desks. That's actually been a huge initiative. It's happened in the last 15 months and we are beginning to see the benefits of that going forward.

As Robin Dargue will tell you, we've now got the building blocks in place. We're now tackling and just have gone live with this application development and maintenance of all our back-office systems, and that's a two-year project. The cost will be in the GBP10 million to GBP15 million, nothing that material, to be quite frank with you, of the transition and setup costs.

And then the third stage, which we are not developing at this point, will be all the client-facing systems, of which there are very many still remaining in the operating businesses, to try and get some standardization. This is partly driven by the need for efficiency and also the need for better cyber security and defenses in an ever data-driven world.

So I think the two things have to happen.

So that's the characterization. The IT element going forward, I think, is going to be much less and we are going to see the benefits coming through in the P&L. So that's an overall perspective.

MARTIN SORRELL: You've got a breakdown. We gave a fairly detailed slide on the restructuring costs. And you can see from that that some of it, a significant part of it, is related to data and Europe.

So just picking up, the project name is [One] Kantar and, in fact, what Kantar are doing, which is consolidating their operations on a country-by-country basis, is very similar to what we're doing Group-wise. They're doing it probably on a shorter timeframe but what we're doing Group-wise, or aiming to do Group-wise in the long term.

So what you will see, going back to that horizontality matrix, is increasingly, and I said that the client leaders increasingly that will not be a dotted line, that will be a solid line, or the regional country managers will be more solid, you're going to see more, I'll get myself in trouble for saying this but I'll say it, more power and influence being given to those in the matrix structure and the balance shifting much more to a country level, less to a regional level and much more to a client level. And that's exactly what Kantar are doing.

On the North America differentiation, I think, at the end of the day, Irwin Gotlieb and I, and one or two others, Andrew and others, sat down about three years ago and we laid out companies that we wished to invest in or acquire, with one exception, which was Datalogix, which Oracle bought for a sum that we had a nosebleed on. With that one exception we've done everything on that list.

And I think that, and we would say this, wouldn't I, but I do think that's given us a technological -- I think AppNexus and Xaxis gives us an edge. Google and Facebook are opaque. The margins at Google and Facebook are astronomic. The marginal margins are 100%. You don't know how the algorithms work, so there's a -- and that's why I think the third force, the AOL-Verizon/Microsoft, if that was to get together with Yahoo, that would certainly a third -- I would claim we were a third force, but that certainly would be a third force.

So technology. Data: comScore and Rentrak, and it certainly has touched a nerve. People are very concerned about the lack of measurement, the poor measurement of traditional, the under measurement of traditional and probably the over measurement of digital.

And Facebook, for example, puts great emphasis on outcomes and ROI. And the data has to be independent data that justifies the position. And so Facebook has a very close arrangement now with Nielsen currently on that.

And that's something that increasingly we are going to ensure that comScore has that similar relationship with Facebook to provide alternate data, because clients are investing now a lot of money.

And you know it publicly. And Keith Weed has talked about the three Vs: value, validation and viewability. And he's on the Facebook consumer council. So you've got somebody on your consumer council saying, we've got to have a better measurement.

So I think those -- and then content. I think Vice gives us an edge. I think Media Rights Capital, House of Cards coming out with its fourth series this week; Fullscreen, with its relationship with AT&T and Otter Media, and you see AT&T are now doing their, as I mentioned, their over-the- top; Verizon doing their over-the-top.

So there are some interesting things. Having knowledge in that area doesn't displace talent and pricing but it gives us an advantage.

On the margin thing, you said Omnicom's margins have been flat for the last five years. And it's about time that they indicated they're going to improve them. And, by the way, their revenues have been growing by 5% or 6%. We threw up the numbers. So why is there no margin improvement if your revenues are growing at that level? There's a lot of [flex]. And the margins are about, what, 300 basis points less.

IPG have come from a very low level; still at 11%. And Publicis have come back. Given the issues they've been dealing with, they've come back.

So I think we're very confident about our 30 basis points and being able to do that pre currency, because -- if it is a currency tailwind this year. This time last year we thought there was going to be currency tailwind and it turned after Q2 into a headwind. But, on the assumption it doesn't, that gives us increased confidence in being able to do that. So I think it's achievable.

And then the IT transformation program kicks in as well.

IAN WHITTAKER, ANALYST, LIBERUM: Ian Whittaker, Liberum. Three questions, please. First of all, just actually go back to comments that Paul made, just when he was talking about the constant currency. I think he mentioned that the two most international parts of your business are the advertising media side and then also the data side.

It would seem a little bit odd that, in terms of the branding, healthcare, communications and digitals, that that also wouldn't be so international as well. I'm just wondering if you can talk through perhaps why and whether that actually presents any opportunities for you in the future.

The second -- well, the other two questions on digital. Of -- you're seeing obviously a lot of concern about online ad fraud and what's going on in the quality of online data. Do you think that is leading to a concentration of online ad spending within fewer players, such as Facebook and Google?

And, if that's the case, what's the implications for your business moving forwards? Do you think that's a positive? Or do you think a potential negative is it could increase the power of those players?

And the third one, and it's actually related to Will's question, in terms of, again, your increase in North America. One of the points that you've repeatedly made is the quality of Xaxis, the information that you have, that essentially you're taking a different strategy from other groups.

Do you think that's actually played a part in your significant wins that you've won in North America? You seem to have hit the ball out of the park when it comes to wins -- (multiple speakers)

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, not quite. We'd like to have won P&G in North America, and Coke in North America. That would have been hitting the ball out of the park. I think probably we got to third base. I don't think we hit it out of the park.

IAN WHITTAKER: It's not bad. It's not a bad position. But, in terms of that, do you think that essentially that clients have actually started to realize that and started to realize you do have a differentiated offering?

MARTIN SORRELL: Okay. Do you want to --?

PAUL RICHARDSON: I probably slightly mis-characterized the international nature of our brands globally to try and assist in the technical description of the difference between reported sterling and constant currencies.

All our brands are, obviously, international. The balance is really, how much do they have of the European profit versus the American profit that reported back in 2015 and how it affected the overall margins? So Hill & Knowlton is in 60, 70 markets.

So I think don't take any inference that the brands weren't global. It's just where their weighting of profits has arisen, how it affected the difference between the constant currency and reported margins. So that was what I was trying to explain.

MARTIN SORRELL: On the big two, our relationship with Google, I think, they may think differently, is really good. It's grown from, as I said, GBP2.9 billion to GBP4 billion. If you pro forma in Essence, GBP3.2 billion to GBP4 billion. What do I think it will hit this year? I think it will be over GBP5 billion this year. That's a fairly educated guess.

Why is that? Google search and video, YouTube video, continue to be two very powerful mediums, particularly in high-penetration TV markets. So if you're in Brazil or if you're in Italy or India or not so much China, although Google is in China through Android, often people forget that.

But even, what Adam said, the shift to digital in China presents us with tremendous opportunities, given the position that we have in the Chinese market.

And Google may be, to be blunt, because of some of the challenges that they have from regulation, particularly here in Europe -- Vestager has indicated that she will go further. There was an initially flurry a few weeks ago, go further. The taxation issues probably have made Google probably more responsive and more flexible.

And maybe even the success of Facebook in building their video business and their mobile business and quote-unquote, catching up with Google, probably makes Google a little bit more responsive.

Facebook, I think because they've been so successful, probably, to be blunt, probably a little bit more difficult to deal with. And I think that's not a view that we're alone in having but others would too, if you ask around. My view is that's going to change because I think they will see the benefit and the merit.

For example, on the data point if we had more access to Facebook data, then I think we will be able to justify investments in video and mobile to a greater degree.

So I don't see what you're saying as being a problem. Just think about the portfolio for a minute. If it's $80 billion and $4 billion is coming from Google and $1 billion is coming from Facebook, that's $5 billion.

But I think Brian Wieser takes out the data that I threw out and then tries to extrapolate that or compare that to the Google and Facebook advertising data. Dangerous thing to do because there's a thing called the long tail.

We are not heavily into the long tail. We're into the short tail, if you like. And what Google and Facebook have done have improved the primary demand for digital advertising for search and video by bringing in small and medium-sized companies that never advertised before.

On this Xaxis thing and strategy, it does have some impact. Brian Lesser has now moved up to running GroupM in North America.

That will inevitably position GroupM in North America as a very strong digital -- taking the guy who ran Xaxis and putting him in to run GroupM in North America and Brian Gleason takes over from Brian Lesser. It's all the Brians, with Brian O'Kelley at AppNexus to add to the confusion: B3. And Brian Gleason works on [Xaxis].

So that will make us, I think, even stronger. But I don't want to diminish the importance of talent or pricing.

I think one of the problems, having gone through the media tsunami, I remember one of our clients saying, when I said, what's your biggest problem? He said, the irrational competitor, the one that's doing the worst, making it -- and there's still a lot of irrationality going on.

For example, we won a piece of business, a media piece of business, in North America a few weeks ago and we will only take clients if we can get credit insurance. We wouldn't get credit insurance on this company. And we asked for financial details and the client would not give us the financial details, so we declined to take the business. One of our competitors took it in an instant.

There are some irrational things being done, which you can't -- it's a bit linked to the question about margins and maybe there's some relief. You just cannot plan for the irrationality of it.

So I would say technology, data and content are giving us an advantage.

One other little point. Sometimes clients find what we're talking about too complicated and there's too much change involved and they won't make the change because everything seems to be going okay, or everything is okay and they don't want to disturb the change. So sometimes we see that.

IAN WHITTAKER: Could I just ask a quick follow up, just on the ANA investigation? When's your view on when that should report?

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, we've told the ANA that if any client has an issue they wish to discuss they can have a direct conversation with us. Most of our clients have audit rights. There are no rebates in the US, so we don't think it's an issue.

The ANA have actually requested a meeting with the six agency holding company heads, which I've said I'm happy to go to as long as the other five go as well.

Just as an aside, last year I suggested to the World Federation of Advertisers that we have a meeting, which we had here in London. The six were invited and only two turned up. I was one of them. So I'm quite happy to go to a meeting as long as everybody else is happy to come to too.

ADAM SMITH, FUTURES DIRECTOR, GROUPM, WPP PLC: May I respond to one of Ian's questions? This question about Google and Facebook, GroupM Italy made a wise remark, which was when it comes to defending yourself against fraud and viewability problems, the biggest difference is in media planning, which means the choice of your media partners. And Google and Facebook score strongly there.

DoubleClick is often cited as one of our main technical defenses against ad fraud, along with Integral Ad Science and DoubleVerify. Facebook obviously has a signed-in domain, which is very helpful. And both are good at optimizing to improve viewability; that is viewing persistence. And so those are good reasons to go to quality because it would improve your scores on fraud and viewability.

But the downside is they're walled gardens, as Martin's just mentioned, and the path to purchase is never a linear thing. You can never know enough about your prospects.

We know that what puts people off and causes them to get ad blockers is too many ads and too high frequency. And so we're hoping that our complementary technology, which sits above the walled gardens, makes our advertising more welcome, fundamentally.

JULIEN ROCH, ANALYST, BARCLAYS: Julien Roch, Barclays. The usual three questions. The first one. In a recent interview you said that because of Brexit you were seeing some clients freezing investments. However, we all talk to --

MARTIN SORRELL: Just so we're clear, what I was referring was freezing capital investment. I wasn't referring to ad investments.

JULIEN ROCH: Okay. Clear, then. Second question is on the media review. Amusingly but unsurprisingly, the winners say it's all about quality. The losers say it was all about pricing. So, if you look at the overall impact on the industry, in a one-word answer would you say negative, neutral or positive?

MARTIN SORRELL: The reviews?

JULIEN ROCH: Yes.

MARTIN SORRELL: In terms of pricing?

JULIEN ROCH: Yes.

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, the honest answer is it must be negative. Right? It must be negative.

The other interesting observation is when you ask the losing agency, what were the revenues? Somebody may say they were [50]. When you ask the winning agency what the revenues were, they say it's

[100].

In fact, there's one specific example I can think of where we know the figure was 100 and we know that the winner was getting 50 and those are the actual numbers.

So I think you would be, again, in cloud cuckoo land to suggest that it would be positive. The pressures are there. We've all got to be realistic about it.

Now, if you're talking about like for like is one thing. If you're talking about extensions or additions, it may be different. But, head to head, clients are looking for improvements in pricing. So the honest answer, I think, is neutral at best, negative at worst.

JULIEN ROCH: And the last question is on Kantar. Massive restructuring for the first time --

MARTIN SORRELL: One other thing. What Adam said is also that you've got to look at two communities get affected by this; the agency community and the publisher or media owner. So, whatever the negative is, it's absorbed by both those communities.

JULIEN ROCH: The last question on Kantar. Massive restructuring for the first time in a while and you said it was partially about top line and consumer insight, again, dragged the overall growth down. So, taking into account that --

MARTIN SORRELL: Just so we're clear. So syndicated grew, custom didn't.

JULIEN ROCH: But if you look at the overall business, taking into account the restructuring, how many years before consumer insight gets to 2% to 3%?

And a subsidiary question is, to help get there, isn't it -- don't you have some assets in all of those businesses that don't really belong to WPP, like political polling or whatever, which you could sell to improve the growth rate?

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, where I differ with you on this, I think there are high-growth spots and there are low-growth spots and we've mentioned the difference between syndicated and custom.

You may be right, there are smaller parts but I think you do that by changing the leadership. I don't think you improve it by putting a for-sale sign out over the top of it.

The fact of the matter is in our industry, and the history is littered with examples of this, the moment you put the for-sale sign up the value falls very significantly.

So I don't think that's the way to deal with it. The way to deal with it is try and position the business in the strongest part of the growth. So it might be the fast growth markets, it might be syndicated, whatever it happens to be.

The other thing is that there are the intangible benefits. You just asked me, or I've been asked, why is it that we do well on the media front and in the media reviews? I think it is -- and I said technology, data and content. Well, data's the second one of the three and our assets -- what we get by combining the insights that we have at a TNS or a Millward Brown, in terms of consumer insights or client insights, is very considerable. It gives us actually a very considerable advantage.

JULIEN ROCH: How many years do you think it's going to take until it grows at 2% to 3%? Is that two years turnaround? Or --?

MARTIN SORRELL: As long as it takes. As long as it takes. I think, strategically, it's a really important part of the jigsaw.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Lisa, Goldman Sachs. My first question is on your outlook for the full year of over 3%. I was just wondering how much are you budgeting for rest of the world and especially China? And if we can get any color for other regions that would be helpful.

The second is on the FX impact on your margins. Obviously in 2015 you had a 20 basis points headwind, so why shouldn't we expect at least 20 basis points tailwind for 2015? And if you can explain how that works that would be helpful.

And I guess the last question is on the growth rate you expect for the agencies in general for 2016 compared to the overall advertising market growth, which is about 4.5%. Is it just because the agencies don't benefit from the quadrennial effect? Or is there anything structural --?

MARTIN SORRELL: Just on that point. So if it's 4.5% and you're looking at net sales, you're going to see a difference. If you're looking at revenues, you aren't. Okay? So this is the confusion that sets in. We would get out of this confusion if everybody produced a net sales number.

So you're comparing apples and oranges compared --

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: But the other agencies are --

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, what we said for this year is revenues well over 3%. And the language was very specific. In relation to net sales it was over 3%. So take that in mind.

When you look at 4.5% you've got to adjust the 4.5% because that's worldwide GDP. It's not WPP GDP. And you've got to make that adjustment, whichever way that goes, and then you get to the agency number. What we are saying is we'll grow with the market, basically, at the revenue level.

Do you want to talk about the first point?

PAUL RICHARDSON: So let me talk about the outlook in terms of the mature versus faster growth markets.

If we were to look at our budgets, we are seeing a bounce back in some of the parts of the faster growth regions that were soft, or relatively soft, in 2015. So, for example, Asia Pacific picks up in terms of growth rate. Latin America, which was strong overall last year, remains strong. And where we see, I think, an improvement overall is a relative growth coming back in Eastern Europe and the Middle East and Africa.

So put all those combinations of factors together, we do expect a faster rate of growth from the fast-growth markets in 2016 versus the mature markets.

Some of the Western Continental European markets are not accelerating further than the rate of growth they've seen in 2015. So that's in answer to that one.

In terms of the currency impact on the margins, it's really very difficult to predict.

Just to give you an illustration, so of the GBP50 million of profit that the FX had a negative impact for the year, GBP40 million of it came in the final quarter and that's because we had that swing in currencies.

So the honest answer to you is we won't really know the margin impact of this until we understand what the final quarters 2016 pound versus euro, which will be post Brexit, pound versus dollar rates will be. And only then can we really have a half-intelligent estimate of what it might be, to be quite frank with you.

There is a natural assumption that it should spring back, because the last three years, as Martin said, our constant currency rate of growth has averaged 0.4%. So we've actually improved margin by 1.2%, whereas on a reported basis it's been 0.8%.

But it really does depend, in the quarter, pound versus euro, pound versus dollar, how their relative movements are, specifically that time of year. So it's very hard to predict.

MARTIN SORRELL: And we said this before. We still don't understand, it may sound silly for us to say it but it's about the third or fourth time we've said it in public, we still quite don't understand the reasons for the difference in the pattern of profitability in our business versus the competition.

Now we don't report quarterly on profit numbers, but we do tell you that 40% of our profits or thereabouts have come in Q4. And it's one-third in the first half and two-thirds in the second half, which we reiterated in the release.

Just adding to Paul's comments. Functionally for this year, if you look at the budgets, advertising and media and digital lead the way. Just so we're clear on it.

Functionally just a little bit more detail on the BRICs, which I guess you're really focused on. Brazil will continue to be difficult, although we did well in Brazil last year, and Latin America. I think other countries in Latin America will continue to be difficult, although, as I said, I think Mexico, Argentina, Colombia will probably be better.

Russia will continue to be difficult unless we see some resolution on the Ukraine and sanctions.

India will continue to be very strong. We crossed $500 million of revenue in India last year. We will cross $600 million of revenue in India this year. But, obviously, there are questions raised as to whether Modi can keep it going.

China. Our view is that the growth rate is not 6.5%, 7%; that the economy is growing probably at about 3% or 4%. And I think that will be the situation again this year.

We had a strong January, actually, in China but it's very volatile. This time last year I think we had, if I remember rightly, a weak Q1 and a strong Q2, or maybe it was the other round. Anyway, it's very volatile so difficult to predict.

Now we've got the People's Congress at the moment. We'll be going to the China Development Forum in two or three weeks' time so we'll get a better view about what's happening there. But I think, overall, that's where we are.

Interestingly, if you look at the numbers from last year, the Next 11 the CIVETS and the MIST, as we describe them, actually did far better than the BRICs. They were very strong. So it's the smaller, Indonesia-type markets, Vietnam, Philippines, those markets have been quite strong.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Tom, Citigroup. The first question was on headcount. I know there were some distortions from outsourcing to IBM but headcount was down 2% underlying whilst revenue was up 3%. I'm just interested in whether that's just a mix effect between the different businesses. Or is there some sort of hidden productivity benefit from horizontality that we're not necessarily seeing?

MARTIN SORRELL: It's a nice idea. Maybe we can adopt it.

I think it reflects two things. One is the IBM IT agreement, where we have outsourced. The second thing is, I think, our people are very focused on managing the headcount to growth in revenues or net sales.

And that's the key, at the end of the day, the key thing. We know that when our headcount rises faster than revenues or net sales we get into trouble. And when it doesn't we know that we can manage the business effectively. And that applies to every one of the verticals on that horizontality matrix as well.

So I don't detect yet -- the benefits of horizontality are top-line benefits, really. We get access to better opportunities and we are in the midst of pitching a major horizontality thing this week for a major multinational company. And we'll see. We've got a strong leader on the account. It's well integrated. It's a very strong offer across everything that we do.

The pitch does not cover everything that we do but we've won recently media business in that case and creative, but there'll be some other opportunities. So we'll see.

But I think the benefits, Tom, are not so much on reducing the number of people or improving their effectiveness. It's really on the top line.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I have one follow up, which is probably for Paul. It's on Xaxis. I think you've actually got a forecast for 2016 sales of $1.1 billion. I just wanted to double check two questions on that. One, is that net sales or revenues? And any detail on the growth --?

PAUL RICHARDSON: That would be the revenue number, which is the billings number.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Got it. Okay. And is there a 2015 base for that?

PAUL RICHARDSON: Well, they didn't meet the $1 billion brand diamond, which we were keen that they did. Let's put it that way.

(laughter)

MARTIN SORRELL: So if you assumed about [$920 million,

$940million, something like that.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Okay.

CHRIS COLLETT, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK RESEARCH: Chris Collett, Deutsche. I'm going to do some different and just ask one question, actually, and that's actually about acquisitions. So you made 50 acquisitions last year, indicating that it's going to be a similarï¿½?

MARTIN SORRELL: And investments. There were some tiddly ones. I don't one to diminish those tiddly ones but they were tiddly.

CHRIS COLLETT: So -- and you're indicating a similar sort of pace, perhaps, for this year. At what point do you get to the point where you can't really continue to add to meaningful growth to WPP through acquisitions without also then adding to the complexity of the Group and perhaps making it more difficult for that horizontality because there are so many new businesses coming in for people to learn about?

MARTIN SORRELL: One of the reasons that I put the horizontality matrix in, maybe too heavy but I don't know whether we can get it back on the screen, maybe we can get it back on the screen, actually, as long as those small, medium-sized acquisitions are grafted on to those, the problems occur not out of complexity, not when you add them on -- when you add them horizontally into separate sort of verticals, that's when the problems occur.

As long as you consolidate them in to an existing vertical, I don't think you do get more complex. You may find the Group complex, I don't. You can come -- we were just talking about this yesterday -- you can come to a review. In fact, I invite you to a review.

(laughter) It's two weeks every quarter in New York. You can come. I can reduce for you the whole thing to one sheet of paper. Correct? It's what we do. So one sheet of paper. It's not that complex.

So if you take this, you've got four, eight, 11 verticals there. Okay? And all run by people across the business. And then you have -- where there is, I think, more complexity, actually, is at the client leader/country regional manager.

I think it will get more complex to manage because we're trying to get more horizontal thrusted, if that's the right way of putting it, into the business. We're trying to get people to think not just vertically but take their blinkers off and look at things both at a client level and a country level in this way.

It will get simpler also if we can reduce the regional cost. The clients are certainly trying to take out regional costs; maybe because of zero-based budgeting, maybe because of technology improvements, maybe because McKinsey now recommends you can have a bigger horizontal span of control inside companies because things have improved technologically. I don't know. But it's not that complex.

Now, as long as you can graft on the acquisitions to each and every one of these companies, it's not that complex. And you don't increase the complexity. You'd increase the complexity if you increased the number of verticals.

By the way, you also create amazing problems if you start to muck about with the branding. That's when you start really to get -- because our people look at this and they're more attached to this. The clients are not.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Just back to three questions, if I may. Firstly, on the continued growth in Xaxis. You're talking about 20% growth at Xaxis. There was a survey out this morning from ANA saying that, of the marketers they're surveying, about 30% are wanting to bring more of the programmatic media buying and planning in house. And I was just wondering how you see that trend going ahead.

Secondly, just we talk a lot about Google and Facebook. I'm just wondering about your relationship with Tencent. I understand you've got better access to their data now.

And then, finally, and it's probably too early to give anything but just wondering if there's any indication on February, please?

MARTIN SORRELL: No. Go and ask everybody for January. Somebody wrote this morning, why are we giving out the January number? The answer is because we always do. Right? So as long you go away and get them all to give you January and every month and then we'll oblige. We don't even know what happened in February.

On programmatic, I find that statistic puzzling because our experience is there's less. And, in fact, what I think the press and the analysts, with all due respect, have not picked up is that people that used to do in-house media buying have gone out house. And, in fact, you look at the trends -- and our view is if people do go in house for programmatic, the technological demands and the people demands means it's very short lived.

But what's happening is so rapidly changing that you can't push the technology and improve the technology fast enough and people don't want to work on one client. On programmatic they want to do it across the board.

So if it is true, people often answer polling questions inaccurately, but if it is true, in our view it would be short lived.

The second thing is -- and, by the way, it was Xaxis' offer with Light Reaction and the changes or the additions they've made, give them tremendous flexibility. But, as Xaxis continues to strengthen and you look at Criteo, which is probably the nearest example to Xaxis, they continue to strengthen but, again, with the long tail rather than the short tail.

On Tencent we have a very, very important relationship with them. We'd like it to be even more important. We have access to their data. Ourselves and one other, it's Dentsu, actually, have access to their data. We've set up, with ex-Alibaba executives, an eCommerce company in Alibaba's home town. So it's not just Tencent but Alibaba too.

But the scale, on a worldwide basis -- we were looking at our top 20 media relationships and I don't think they get into the top 17, they would be actually 17 to 20. I think they're in that range. So smaller, global context but growing. And we would like to have more.

We do have two Chinese Board directors, Ruigang Li and Hugo Shong, which, I think, gives us a really good advantage in knowing what's going on in China.

Okay, if that's it, two hours and eight minutes. Thank you very much indeed. Thank you.
