Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:58BD-TYN1-DXH2-62MD-00000-00Event Brief of Q1 2013 NYSE Euronext Earnings Conference Call - Final2013-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis043013sp.792Event Brief of Q1 2013 NYSE EuronextEarnings Conference Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Stephen Davidson - NYSE Euronext,VP of IR . Duncan Niederauer - NYSE Euronext,CEO . Michael Geltzeiler - NYSE Euronext,EVP and CFO . Larry Leibowitz - NYSE Euronext,COO

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Richard Repetto - Sandler O'Neill & Partners,Analyst . Howard Chen - Credit Suisse,Analyst . Chris Allen - Evercore,Analyst . Alex Kramm - UBS,Analyst . Niamh Alexander - Keefe, Bruyette & Woods,Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 1Q13 net revenues of $600m on reported basis and GAAP EPS of $0.52.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 1Q13 net revenues (on reported basis) = $600m. 2. 1Q13 GAAP EPS = $0.52. 3. 1Q13 non-GAAP EPS = $0.57. 4. 1Q13 sequential net revenue growth = 7%. 5. 1Q13 CapEx = $27m. 6. 1Q13-end gross debt = $2.5b.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

1Q13 Business Review (D.N.) 1. Highlights: 1. Benefited from actions taken over past several quarters to improve fundamental earnings power of Co. 2. Saw improved trading volumes in European derivatives franchise. 1. Launched new products. 3. On track to transition UK clearing to ICE Clear Europe by June-end. 1. Focused on realizing value of continental derivatives clearing after 1Q14. 4. Continuing to see strong momentum in Listings business. 1. Achieved 75% market share of tech IPOs on heels of last year's similarly excellent results. 5. Beginning to generate incremental revenue from new market data agreements. 1. Continued to reduce expenses. 1. On track to exceed full-year 2013 guidance. 6. Reduction in share count and other capital management actions taken are beginning to have meaningful impact on earnings. 7. Macro backdrop, stated on last call, showing encouraging signs for global economy. 1. Optimistic that Co. is on slow trend up punctuated by event-driven volatility along the way. 8. Continuing to execute against Project 14 commitments to shareholders. 1. Preparing for combination with ICE. 9. Net result, $0.57 a share. 1. Revenue $600m. 2. Earnings Up: 1. 21% YoverY. 2. 33% QoverQ. 10. Looking to build momentum as Co. moves through 2013 and into proposed combinations with ICE. 2. Progress on Executing Against Strategy: 1. Not taking foot off gas. 2. Launching new derivatives products. 1. In Liffe business, moving out on yield curve. 1. Liffe business in UK has historically been almost entirely focused on short end of curve. 2. Continued to expand with mid-curve options launched last year and Swapnote products that Co. is now offering which moves it further out on to yield curve. 3. Once Co. is in ICE clearinghouse in 2H of this year, expects to launch even more new products. 3. Continues to be focused on maintaining position Co. enjoys in capital formation and Listings business. 1. Number 1 in 2011. 2. Number 1 in 2012. 3. Off to terrific start this year. 4. Success Co. had last year, winning 80% of big tech deals has continued into 2013. 1. Given pipeline Co. can see and deals already won, some of which have not been made public yet, believes that this will continue. 5. About to see result of having revamped all global market data agreements and launching some new products in that business. 1. All these growth initiatives are complemented by accomplishments on efficiency in capital management fronts, which positively impacted results this qtr. 3. FICC Businesses: 1. Nice rebound in NYSELiffe volumes. 1. Up 36% YoverY. 2. FICC product volume in Europe up 53% vs. 1Q12. 2. Flagship Euribor Futures contracts registered all-time high in trading volumes. 1. ADV for 1Q13 was 1.2m contracts, up 82% from 4Q12. 2. Surge in volume was driven by number of key events in Eurozone, including: 1. Early LTRO repayments by banks to ECB in Feb. 2. Uncertainty surrounding Italian elections and Cyprus bailout. 3. Heightened expectations of potential rate cut. 3. Euribor options showed even stronger growth, driven by continued success of innovative mid-curve option products, which reached ADV of 680,000 contracts; up 143% increase from 4Q. 4. Aforementioned euro Swapnote product, which has been focus for growth, had solid start to year. 1. YTD Swapnote volume has traded $27b of notional. 2. By way of reference, CME swap future has traded $19b of notional YTD. 5. Gilts benefiting from quantitative easing by Bank of England. 6. Liffe US Business: 1. Positive volume growth in open interest trends in MSCI product suite with: 1. ADV up 89% YoverY. 2. Open interest up 119% YoverY. 7. Momentum continues to build for futures on DTCC GCF Repo Index. 1. Record volume days in Jan. 1. Avg. daily volume up 56% sequentially. 8. Clearing For UK Derivatives Business: 1. On track to transition to ICE Clear Europe at 2Q-end. 2. All regulatory filings have been submitted. 3. Technology build has been completed. 4. In May, expects to step up technology integration and member testing. 4. Equity Derivatives: 1. US Options: 1. In Jan. 2013, NYSE Amex Options and NYSE Arca Options complex reached their highest monthly combined equity options market share to date of 29.4%. 2. First options exchange to receive SEC approval to begin trading mini options (product designed for retail investor). 1. Launched on 03/18/13. 3. Product innovation and development continued to be focus. 1. Secured semi exclusive licensing agreement with Russell index group. 2. These products began trading this month. 2. FTSE Equity Derivatives: 1. This franchise provided strong start to 1Q with volumes up 29% YoverY. 1. Increase in volumes saw return to trading in core FTSE derivatives franchise. 2. FTSE 100 index options up 86% vs. 1Q12. 3. Combined open interest for FTSE franchise stood 13% above 2012 levels. 5. Cash Equities: 1. Over past few years, objective in cash trading businesses has been to focus on profitability and stabilizing market share. 2. Europe: 1. Maintained share at around 65%. 2. Pricing has been relatively stable. 3. US: 1. Opportunistically looked for ways to increase pricing, which has helped to soften impact of declines in trading volumes and growth in off-exchange trading, which has impacted market share. 4. Two important issues impacting aforementioned businesses. 1. Financial transaction tax (FTT) in Europe. 2. Off-exchange trading in the US. 5. FTT: 1. Commission issued proposal on 02/14/13 for broad-based tax on equities, equity-like products, derivatives, bonds and others, which only applies to those member states but could have extraterritorial impact. 2. In terms of enhanced cooperation group, there is no agreement between 11 countries as to how tax will be collected, on what products it should be collected or how proceeds would be used. 1. Several heads of national debt management agencies, including France and Italy, have publicly warned that FTT could push up yield spreads and increase borrowing costs. 3. Given all these issues, Commission's implementation date of 01/01/14 seems optimistic. 4. Continues to be Co.'s view that this tax as currently outlined would likely destabilize European financial markets, negatively impact returns and increase fees for avg. investors and mutual fund owners, exactly wrong policy at wrong time. 5. Any policy measure that has direct effect of draining liquidity from capital markets is measure that will hurt European entrepreneurs, especially SMEs that need to access markets to finance their growth. 6. Off-exchange Trading: 1. Reached record level of 36%. 1. Up from 34% in 4Q. 2. This is not just about dark pools. 1. Dark pools are only a third of off-exchange trading, other two-thirds is internalization. 3. Plans to continue raising awareness with regard to market quality concerns. 4. Will continue level the playing field advocacy efforts in US. 7. Mary Jo White, new Chair of SEC. 6. Listings: 1. Ranked Number 1 in IPOs YTD 2013 and follow-on proceeds globally. 1. Raised: 1. $12.1b in total global proceeds from 26 IPOs. 2. $48.3b in total global proceeds from 140 follow-on offerings. 2. US: 1. Led market with 17 IPOs, excluding closed end funds. 2. Continued to capture majority of technology-based IPOs. 3. Saw larger deal sizes from larger companies coming to market. 4. Private equity-backed companies which made up about 35% of market YTD. 1. Carve outs and yield-oriented deals drove volume. 2. Listed six of eight private equity-backed IPOs, which raised total of $1.8b or 68% of all proceeds from private equity-backed IPOs. 3. Europe: 1. Welcomed six companies to markets including Infosys, which was first co. to be admitted to trading on markets in London, Paris and New York. 7. New Strategic Paradigm For Technology Business: 1. While market continues to be challenging for technology sales as in 1Q results, market demand for disruptive technology is increasing. 1. Increased dialogue with global trading organizations regarding game-changing service offerings, hosting of matching engines and open connectivity to global markets. 2. Trading community is becoming even more focused on cost optimization. 1. Looking to NYX as trusted partner to provide innovative ways to improve their trading infrastructure models. 3. Regulatory obligations continue to increase, resulting in additional assets required to be traded on exchange. 4. NYSE Technologies: 1. Working closely with customers to address aforementioned needs throughout product and solution suite. 2. Has data center and solution set to be well-positioned to take advantage of this industry shift. 5. Client, Warsaw Stock Exchange successfully completed its migration of its cash and derivatives markets to UTP. 1. Connected to safety network, which will extend their reach across NYX global market data and trading infrastructure. 6. Large-scale Infrastructure Hosting Capabilities: 1. Working with several global trading organizations to provide comprehensive trading infrastructure managed services. 1. These are large recurring revenue transactions. 2. Launched best trades and quotes market data product, which provides substantial cost savings to retail brokerage firms and wealth management organizations that require access to Level 1 data products. 1. Beginning to generate incremental market data revenue that will build through 2H13. 2. Has significant plans for SuperFeed business that will begin to generate additional revenue in 2H. 7. NYXT Business Media Coverage: 1. Focused on executing against aforementioned strategic vision. 2. Working with ICE to explore to leverage this important business capability in new organization, post-merger. 3. As Co. looks to expand capabilities for clients, regularly has discussions with potential partners, clients and industry participants to explore new opportunities to deliver best-in-class solutions for trading community. 4. Always conducted these partnership discussions. 1. Will continue to have discussions with partners, now and in future, traditional and non-traditional. 5. Has exciting business with significant potential that Co. will continue to drive forward. 8. ICE Transaction: 1. Looking at combined business, one sees co. with completely different complexion than one Co. has today. 2. Cash trading segment (most competitive and commoditized part of business), generated 7% of revenues in US and 9% in Europe in 2012. 1. Combined 16% would decline to around 10% of combined co. and even less after envisioned IPO of NYX. 3. More lucrative and competitively stronger derivatives business. 1. 26% of revenues in 2012. 1. Would increase to 44% of revenue base for new co. 4. Almost 50% of pro forma net revenue will be generated from derivatives businesses. 1. This is critical aspect of transaction because of relatively high margin and its impact on overall valuation. 5. Remains confident that companies can unlock significant value and growth, confidence market seems to share. 6. Believes change will be constant in industry for some time to come. 1. Combination brings experience, assets and leadership together that is necessary to drive sustainable growth for investors and clients. 7. Transaction Timeline: 1. Currently working on two parallel tracks. 1. One focused on competition approval process. 2. Other on general transaction requirements that are needed to close deal. 2. On competition side, completed US process with DOJ under Hart-Scott-Rodino Act. 1. Now focusing on European requirements. 3. Last week, received official referral of competition review to European Commission from UK, Portugal and Spain. 1. Now working towards completion of notification of commission know as Form CO, which will serve as basis for competition review. 2. Upon receipt of notification, European Commission will begin Phase 1, which is 25-business day review process. 3. If in-depth investigation of transaction (Phase 2) is required, that would start 90-day clock after that. 4. As learned in past, timelines for these review processes are not guaranteed. 1. Just guiding principles. 2. Subject to further extensions based on circumstances. 5. Already made good progress. 6. Form S-4 has been filed with SEC. 1. Has been deemed effective by SEC as of [today]. 7. On back of aforementioned, NYX and ICE have set date for shareholder vote on 06/03/13. 8. Still believes that this transaction will be finalized in 2H13.

1Q13 Financials (M.G.) 1. Highlights: 1. GAAP EPS $0.52. 1. 1Q12 $0.34. 2. Non-GAAP EPS $0.57. 1. Reflects two primary adjustments. 3. Reported $8m charge for merger expenses and exit costs, primarily related to ICE transaction. 4. Other item was $10m pretax charge to fair value outstanding restricted stock awards resulting from increase in stock price. 5. Following recent shareholder approval of amended plan, outstanding restricted stock awards will again be fixed in value under equity settled accounting rules. 1. 2Q13 equity compensation costs will decline by $10m, hence adjustment. 6. After adjusting for aforementioned items, derived non-GAAP EPS of $0.57 per share. 7. Note: 1. Financial results from this point forward will exclude impact of merger expenses, exit costs, stock-based compensation charge and discrete tax items. 8. Non-GAAP: 1. Net revenues $600m on reported basis. 1. In line with 1Q12. 2. Up 7% vs. 4Q. 3. Increase QoverQ, driven by higher volumes in global derivatives businesses. 2. Reported costs lower by $25m or 6%, driving 12% growth in operating income. 3. Diluted share count declined by 15m shares YoverY from 2012 share repurchase plan, which helped drive EPS growth to 21%. 2. Derivatives: 1. Revenue $201m. 1. Up: 1. 14% YoverY. 2. 26% sequentially, attributable to strong pickup in trading volumes. 2. Euribor Futures volumes, in particular, increased 82%. 1. Arca and Amex options reported growth in market share and ADV. 3. EBITDA margins 56%. 1. Revenue growth on flat costs helped boost. 4. Accounted for 34% of consolidated net revenues. 1. 43% of operating income. 5. Revenue capture for NYSELiffe was lower YoverY and QoverQ, attributed primarily to clients hitting volume tiers with increase in volumes. 6. Capture for US options business higher YoverY and QoverQ, driven by positive mix. 3. Cash Trading & Listings: 1. Accounted for 48% of consolidated net revenues. 1. 47% of operating income. 2. Net revenue $287m. 1. Down 6% vs. 1Q12. 2. Up 2% vs. 4Q12. 3. European cash market share across four primary markets (excluding off-exchange trading volume) 65%. 1. Up from 64% in prior-year. 4. US Cash Equities: 1. Market share across all tapes declined 120 BP YoverY and QoverQ. 5. Off-exchange traded share 36% of US equities market. 1. Up from 34% in prior-year. 6. Global listings revenues (including government services, which Co. reports in other revenues) up 9%. 7. Revenue capture for US cash increased to $0.043 per 100 shares handled for 1Q. 1. 1Q12 $0.042. 2. 4Q12 $0.040. 8. Incremental increase in capture is due to volume mix and minor pricing adjustments on NYSE Arca. 9. Revenue capture for European cash on per transaction basis $0.62. 1. 1Q12 $0.57. 2. 4Q12 $0.58. 3. Increase YoverY was driven by increase in trade size and decision to reduce listing fees for European warrants and increased trading fees. 4. Information Services & Technology Solutions: 1. Accounted for 19% of net revenue. 1. 10% of operating income. 2. Revenue $112m. 1. Down: 1. $9m from 1Q12. 2. $8m sequentially. 3. Sale shortfalls were attributed to absence of any significant new managed services sales. 1. Prior-qtr. had large sales with Russell and ATG in 4Q and Warsaw in 1Q prior-year. 4. Environment continues to be challenging. 1. Believes this business is well-positioned to leverage industry's focus on cost optimization and changing infrastructure models. 5. With new global market data agreements in place. 1. Expects to see technology services revenue growth to accelerate in 2H13. 2. These incremental revenues will begin in 2Q. 1. Expected to grow as year progresses. 5. Progress On Project 14 Cost Efficiency Program: 1. Over past 12 months, reported total OpEx $1,556m. 1. $110m below 2011 base level of $1,666m. 2. Adjusting for currency rates and portfolio changes in discrete investments of $49m, arrived at annualized expense base of $1,522m through 1Q13. 1. $144m below 2011 starting point or 58% of total $250m to be saved by 2014-end. 3. Commitment for P14 savings was originally 65% of $250m by 2013-end. 1. Well on way to exceed this target. 4. Based on positive development of expenses in 1Q and series of savings initiatives planned for this year, including $15m Co. expects to save in 2H13 with its move to ICE Clear Europe, now expects full-year 2013 reported expenses to be less than $1,525m. 6. Cash & Debt Position (as of March-end): 1. Gross debt [at March 29] $2.5b. 1. Basically same level of debt Co. had at year-end, as it didn't have any variable debt that it could pay down with excess cash from qtr. 2. Cash balances grew by $147m. 3. In June, plans to retire remaining $414m of 4.8% US notes. 4. Debt-to-EBITDA leverage ratio decreased to 2.3 times on stronger EBITDA generation. 1. Has been able to use excess cash to retire debt, leverage would have been reduced to 2.2 times. 5. CapEx $27m. 1. Well within guidance of less than $150m for full-year. 6. Last week, Board declared $0.30 quarterly cash dividend for 2Q13. 1. Payable on 06/28/13.

Closing Remarks (D.N.) 1. Summary: 1. 1Q was strong start for Co. in 2013. 2. Saw rebound in trading volumes in European derivatives franchise. 1. Launched some new products. 3. On track to transition UK derivatives business clearing to ICE Clear in Europe by 2Q-end. 4. Listings franchise continues to build momentum by maintaining Number 1 global leadership position and achieving dominant market share of technology IPOs. 5. Expects to begin seeing positive revenue impact of new market data agreements in current qtr. 1. Costs are on track to exceed full-year 2013 cost guidance. 6. Executing against Project 14 commitments. 1. Well into integration planning and regulatory approval processes of combination with ICE. 1. Next milestone for that combination will be shareholder meetings on 06/03/13.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Richard Repetto, Sandler O'Neill.

RICHARD REPETTO, ANALYST, SANDLER O'NEILL & PARTNERS: Good morning, guys. I guess the first question, Duncan, comes from your remarks on market quality. We know or at least it was reported in the media you have met with the SEC with some of the other exchange heads. I think I am aware of you meeting with even some companies as well. But when you talked about what are the remedies if one-third of the TRF volume is -- it looks like you are pointing towards the wholesalers, the other two thirds. What are the remedies besides a trade out rule that you see could bring back the market quality you're talking about?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER, CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: I will start, Rich, and then I will let Leibo add to it as well. So we realize it is a complicated question. This didn't happen overnight. Our point that we keep trying to focus on is that it isn't just about dark pools. If we are talking about dark pools and those are block crossing networks that provide us significantly better customer experience that the public market may not be able to provide, I think there has to be a place for those in market structure in the US.

I think our bigger concern and to be clear we think it is going to have to be a combination of things that would get done. I don't think there is one single thing that would necessarily enhance the market quality but we feel like there is a degradation in market quality, the darker individual stocks seem to get the wider the spread seems to get. We don't think that is a -- we don't think that is a healthy trend and whether it is talking about some kind of a trade out rule that simply requires an internalizer to improve the customer experience in either size or price, the way they have done in Canada and are talking about doing it in Australia or thinking about a rethink of the access fees, there is a whole host of things that could be done.

We realize it took us a long time to get here, it is going to take us a while to kind of reverse the trend if it is even possible but I am encouraged by the fact that a lot of people are at least willing to come to the table to talk about it.

We are meeting with investors, we are meeting with a number of sell-side firms. We are all meeting together and having roundtables to talk about is there a better solution that would be better for the end clients and I am cautiously optimistic. Leibo, what would you add to that?

LARRY LEIBOWITZ, COO, NYSE EURONEXT: I think it is a pretty good summary. I just think that if you add up all the regulatory changes made over the last 10 years they have sort of caused just a natural competitive force that will drive more and more volume off exchange as other parties get more and more sophisticated about segmenting customer flow or recirculating flow before it gets to an exchange so that what gets to the exchange is lower and lower quality. And I think what we are really concerned about is it is not our market share. It is about what is the quality of the flow that comes to the exchange, how wide do the spreads get? Those sorts of things.

That is our main concern and we understand that this is going to be a balancing act where exchanges are going to have to give something and we are going to have to put this together in a piece that it makes natural sense for competition to find the right level.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Right, and look, we expect everyone to defend their business model and people should expect us to defend the same (inaudible). Right? Everyone is doing what they should do. So I think we are going to remaining engaged in this dialogue and we are happy to sit down with everybody and put other things on the table too if that is what it takes to strike the right compromise. Okay. Thanks.

RICHARD REPETTO: Got it. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Howard Chen, Credit Suisse.

HOWARD CHEN, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE: Good morning, everyone. Just with respect to the new global market data agreements coming into place, is your expectation still that the incremental revenue opportunity is about 10% additive on a full run rate? And if use and terminal count continue to trend a bit lower, how much does that eat into the potential upside?

MICHAEL GELTZEILER, EVP AND CFO, NYSE EURONEXT: I will take the first part of that. In terms of the run rate, we have previously said that we expect the series of changes, the new products that we are launching, the price increases and the restructuring of the global data agreements including addressing the non-display access to generate a double-digit growth. Yes.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I think it is hard to predict where that trend is going to go. Remember that that is an overall industry issue. It impacts the size of the entire CPA pie not just specifically us but we are sort of dealing with that by being more aggressive, or balanced I would say in how we charge for non-display and the proprietary products we sell ourselves because we are developing a lot more of these proprietary products. So we expect that that would offset those things.

HOWARD CHEN: Understood. Thanks, Larry. Thanks, Mike.

OPERATOR: Chris Allen, Evercore.

CHRIS ALLEN, ANALYST, EVERCORE: Good morning, guys. I just wanted to ask on the information technology segment, just given the upcoming deal with ICE and some of the recent articles in the press about the potential looking at other partners which you guys acknowledge maybe some discussions there. Is it realistic to expect any large signing of agreements in that business until kind of the dust settles on that front, people can figure out who they are going to be dealing with longer-term?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Sure. I think it is a really good question, Chris. I think what you are seeing here is an industry that is in transition. Our clients are going from buying products to trying to figure out how to rationalize large chunks of infrastructure. And the technology itself is in transition with more and more emphasis on cloud and virtualized computing and managed services, software as a service, things like that.

So to some extent, some of the hesitation you are seeing is that the things they are demanding are changing and the organizations themselves are trying to figure out the new solution. At the same time, our portfolio of solutions is changing to match that. Transitioning from the more traditional product-based to more of a solutions-based thing.

The backdrop of that, of course, is this ICE deal. So yes, I think that we are certainly going to get those questions and we would expect to get those questions. On the other hand, we are always looking to figure out what is the best combination of our portfolio with partners. That has been our way of doing things anyway, and you have a new management team in there led by Jon Robson that is really thinking about how do they provide the best solution set.

So I would expect that the industry is in transition but that we will start to see, and we are actually seeing, contracts signed. The results kind of hide some of the more traditional products are decreasing, while some of the new products are actually increasing. And we probably have to do a better job with you guys at showing the pipeline and showing that transition so you see how that transition is going, but we are signing new deals. It hasn't ground to a halt. And some of the new deals are actually larger deals and longer deals, and I would expect that that will continue.

CHRIS ALLEN: Thanks, guys.

OPERATOR: Alex Kramm.

ALEX KRAMM, ANALYST, UBS: Good morning. Maybe just to stay on the topic of what Chris just talked about on the technology business, can you maybe try to give a little bit more color on how you would break this business down or how this business breaks down in terms of what are the pieces that are actually really essential to an exchange like market data, how much do they account for?

And then on the other side when you talk to some of your customers, it seems like a lot of the pieces are not very well integrated and they don't really talk to each other as much. So do you actually think that there are some smaller components that are very easy to, I don't know, maybe throw into an auction and see some private equity holders would like to buy more? Do you think this business is actually more of a -- this has to go as a whole or stay together as a whole? Thank you.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I can help you a little bit. As Larry mentioned, where we have discussed in the past, we restructured this business into three primary -- as the chart shows you -- three primary revenue segments, content, infrastructure, and liquidity and the two largest being content and infrastructure.

So in the content area is the proprietary market data, the data fee handlers, some of the software sales. In the infrastructure we have the connectivity, the safety services and the hosting and the [NYSX] business. In the liquidity we have the co-location services some of the market solutions we are doing for other exchanges and businesses like our (inaudible) operation in Japan.

So it is a pretty diverse segment. Clearly the larger area of growth for this year we are looking at is in content because that is where the market data initiatives are coming in but we have initiatives across hosting is where a lot of these managed services deals come in.

I think Larry was talking a little bit about the co-location and the connectivity that have both news sales and also some lower renewals at times but that is really how we break the business down into those three businesses.

LARRY LEIBOWITZ: Right. I think your observation that says that we haven't integrated some of these offerings is dead on and it is actually consistent with what I was saying about moving from a product based sale to an integrated solutions based sale. Some of that reflects the industry's attitude changing and some of it reflects that we need to do a better job of that and that is exactly what John and his team are working on.

I think speculatively we are going to sell various pieces off to private equity. The honest truth is it is in our competitors' interest to sort of fan those flames so that everybody thinks that these are weak assets. The truth is that most of our competitors are in a reasonable amount of transition themselves in this arena and I think that actually creates a lot of opportunity for natural providers of these solutions like we are because we have the market, we have the connectivity, we have the market data, we have a lot of the pieces that actually naturally sort of go into that and people would like to portray this as a weak position whereas I actually view it as a strong hand.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I am going to add one more thing to that not to belabor the point. We think we have a pretty good idea of the origin of the leak last week. We actually think it was one of our competitors doing exactly what Larry just said like fanning the flame of uncertainty given the deal that is out there and then coming in behind and saying it is really hard to do something with those guys. I mean they are in a state of flux over there. It is like -- we are not in a state of flux just because a competitor says we are in a state of flux because it suits their marketing pitch.

So I am at a lot of these meetings, Larry is at a lot of these meetings. These are much more complicated discussions than a product sale. A product sale you show someone an a la carte menu they want one item or two. This is a much more comprehensive discussion about sharing infrastructure and things like that. So we are going to remain optimistic and we will remain focused and as we get closer to combining with ICE, we will be able to get the benefit of their input as well.

ALEX KRAMM: That is very helpful. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Niamh Alexander, KBW.

NIAMH ALEXANDER, ANALYST, KEEFE, BRUYETTE & WOODS: Thanks for taking my questions. If I could switch over to the clearing, so you are ahead of the deal -- even you are moving at the end of May as you previously guided. But can you walk me through how to think about the risk of clients, how easy can it be -- should it be for clients? There already is some technology overlap.

And then from the modeling perspective financially, doesn't this accelerate some of the cost savings? Does it accelerate maybe some impairments and some write-downs on some of the investment so far as well?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I will try to give you -- it is Duncan -- I will try to give you the outline on sort of what we are doing on the timeline and then Mike can talk a little bit about how that will translate to the results beginning in Q2 and what that means for what we have already spent on what we used to call Project Gemini, etc.

So as I said in my remarks, the project to move the UK derivatives piece from Liffe Clear to ICE Clear is on track to happen at the end of Q2 so it will be the end of June, not the end of May. We will be using May to sort of do member testing. We are collecting all of the Novation certificates now; that is all going very smoothly.

The nice thing about this transition is given that more than 90% of the clients who were connected to Liffe Clear were also connected to ICE Clear, there was very little migration risk. There were only a handful of clients that actually had to do a meaningful technology lift to get this done. The majority of clients were already connected and we are actually relieved that there was less work to do for them than there would have been had we proceeded down the Project Gemini route.

So we are highly confident that will happen by the end of June so we will be clearing at ICE Clear in the second half of the year and then Mike can talk to you about what that means for the kind of results going forward and what we are doing with the expenses that we had already put to work on Gemini last year and before.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: So the financial benefit of this transaction really twofold. Firstly, when we go live in the beginning of the second half, we will no longer be outsourcing the treasury and risk management with LCH and in turn we will be using ICE Clear and as we have indicated on the call, we will save annualized $30 million from that, $15 million in the second half.

The investment that we made in Gemini in our internal build last year prior to signing the ICE Clear agreement was all written off in the fourth quarter last year so there is nothing else on the balance sheet right now as it relates to that.

Secondarily we have the continental derivatives which we've talked about in the past that we today don't get any revenues or costs and we expect in the first quarter -- end of the first quarter 2014 to realize the revenues on that business and a healthy margin as we also bring that business -- execute that plan.

So two strong financial benefits second half of this year in 2014 coming from clearing.

NIAMH ALEXANDER: Okay, thank you.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: We are going to wrap it there so Stephen, any -- we are going to give you the last word -- anything you want to do to wrap it up?

STEPHEN DAVIDSON, VP OF IR, NYSE EURONEXT: Thanks everyone for joining us and see you later.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: As always, the bit team will be available for any one on ones that people need throughout the day. Thanks a lot, everybody. Have a good day.

OPERATOR: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your participation in today's conference. That concludes the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have a good day.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5C18-JXW1-DXH2-64NJ-00000-00Event Brief of Q1 2014 Alliance Data Earnings Conference Call - Final2014-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis041714sh.788Event Brief of Q1 2014 Alliance Data Earnings Conference Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Julie Prozeller - FTI Consulting,IR . Ed Heffernan - Alliance Data Systems Corp,President & CEO . Charles Horn - Alliance Data Systems Corp,CFO . Bryan Pearson - Alliance Data Systems Corp,EVP & President - LoyaltyOne

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Sanjay Sakhrani - Keefe, Bruyette & Woods,Analyst . Darrin Peller - Barclays Capital,Analyst . Brett Huff - Stephens Inc.,Analyst . David Togut - Evercore Partners,Analyst . David Scharf - JMP Securities,Analyst . Andrew Jeffrey - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey,Analyst

OVERVIEW

ADS reported 1Q14 YoverY revenue growth of 17%.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 1Q14 YoverY revenue growth = 17%.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

1Q14 Overview (C.H.) 1. Results: 1. Year started off pretty much as expected. 1. Revenue grew 17% from last year. 2. Core EPS grew 9% from last year due to incremental personnel costs needed to support growth expected in back half of 2014. 2. Dropped through some additional earnings, beating core EPS guidance of $2.70. 3. Organic revenue grew 8% driven by: 1. High single-digit organic growth at Epsilon. 2. Low double-digit organic growth at Private Label. 4. LoyaltyOne constant currency organic revenue growth essentially flat as AIR MILES redeemed dropped 4% vs. 1Q13. 5. BrandLoyalty: 1. Closed on 01/02/14. 2. Added approx. $112m in revenue. 6. Adjusted EBITDA net (reduced for funding cost and portion attributable to minority shareholders of BrandLoyalty) increased 3% vs. 1Q13, burned by higher payroll expense. 1. Estimates approx. $20m was development payroll. 1. It did not drive current period revenue; needed to support future revenue. 2. BrandLoyalty added about $14m of EBITDA, $9m net of non-controlling interest to 1Q which Co. believes will be seasonally lowest qtr. 3. Diluted share count was 66.1m. 1. Consistent with guidance. 2. With maturity of next and final tranche convertible debt in May, expects diluted share count to drop to approx. 63.1m for 2Q14.

1Q14 LoyaltyOne (B.P.) 1. Results: 1. Revenue $329m. 1. Increased 37% due to BrandLoyalty acquisition, which added $112m. 2. Fought through a couple of headwinds in core AIR MILES business as revenue declined 10% from 1Q13. 1. Canadian dollar down by about 8% from year-ago. 1. Lower translation rate dropped AIR MILES revenue by about $19m. 2. AIR MILES redeemed declined 4% from a year-ago. 1. Created revenue drag of about $6m. 3. Will likely face these kinds of headwinds throughout 2014. 3. Adjusted EBITDA: 1. 1Q14 $65m. 1. Increased 4% due to BrandLoyalty, which added $14m gross or $9m net to LoyaltyOne. 2. AIR MILES: 1. Down 10% from [1Q13]. 2. Essentially flat on constant currency basis. 4. Adjusted EBITDA margin: 1. AIR MILES, consistent between quarters at 26%. 2. BrandLoyalty 13%. 1. Believes Co. will definitely expand as year progresses. 2. AIR MILES: 1. Reward miles issued decreased 4% vs. 1Q13 due to weakness in consumer spending. 1. Some relate to timing of Easter holiday which landed in 1Q13 and doesn't actually land until 2Q14. 2. Some relate to regulatory changes, which are eliminating reward mile issuance from prescription purchases in some regions. 2. Expects full-year issuance growth to be in low-single digit rate for 2014, mostly due to: 1. Increased promotional spend. 2. Addition of new sponsors in back half of year. 3. AIR MILES redeemed decreased 4% due to reduced demand primarily for travel-related rewards. 4. AIR MILES Cash: 1. Instant reward program. 2. Gaining momentum with rollout of 300 plus IGA stores in Quebec. 3. Expects expansion of AIR MILES Cash offering to increase overall miles redeemed by approx. 3% vs. 2013. 3. Dotz: 1. 2014 priority is all about growth. 2. Excellent start to year. 1. Added 1.2m collectors. 2. Total collector count, 12m. 3. Plans to continue market expansion strategy in 2014 with target of four new markets by year-end, which would bring total market count to 13. 4. BrandLoyalty Acquisition: 1. LoyaltyOne acquired 60% stake in BrandLoyalty. 2. BrandLoyalty: 1. Based on Netherlands. 2. Employs over 400 associates in 14 offices globally. 3. Primary product offering, short-term loyalty campaigns that are run for grocery retailers in: 1. Europe. 2. Asia. 3. Latin America. 4. In the programs shoppers earn points using either digital or paper stamps for achieving spend thresholds during each shopping trip. 1. Points are then redeemed in-store for high quality merchandise that BrandLoyalty sources can distributes to retailer. 2. Through its subsidiary IceMobile, shoppers can download custom mobiles apps that add digital capability for earning and redeeming points and increasing customer engagement by targeted mobile messaging. 3. BrandLoyalty's programs are short-term in nature. 4. BrandLoyalty's turnkey programs are proven to drive increased visits to store and increased basket size, which results in measurable sales results and positive ROI for their clients. 5. Strategic benefits: 1. BrandLoyalty, one of two leading players in these types of short-term grocery promotions. 1. They have track record of double-digit organic growth. 2. Grocery retail key vertical for LoyaltyOne and BrandLoyalty. 1. Believes Co. can leverage existing relationships to grow BrandLoyalty platform in North America. 3. LoyaltyOne's advanced analytics capability and advisory services presents new product offering for BrandLoyalty customers, which will lead to future revenue synergies between organizations.

1Q14 Epsilon Review (C.H.) 1. Results: 1. Revenue $348m. 1. Increased 9%, all organic. 2. Technology led the way with 11% growth, supported by [50%] increase in database revenues fueled by expansion in both new and existing client base. 3. Email: 1. Part of technology. 2. Continues to be soft. 3. Believes next release of Harmony scheduled for 2Q14 will remedy this. 4. Harmony was recently ranked Number 1 by Red Pill Email for its features and functions; received perfect score of five in the categories of vendor security, queries and segmentation ease of use. 5. Preview of next release, which adds segmenting and multi-sound capabilities, has resulted in several new customer wins. 4. Agency: 1. Increased 9% vs. 1Q13 driven by continued strength in auto vertical. 2. In process of onboarding two new agency clients, which should contribute revenue as 2014 progresses. 5. 2014 outlook remains high single-digit organic revenue growth, supported by backlog which is up double-digits vs. same time last year. 6. Adjusted EBITDA net $55m. 1. Increased 1% vs. 1Q13 as higher healthcare cost attributable to higher associates participation rate, severance expense associated with integration of HMI and upfront expenses incurred to ramp up two potentially large new clients dampened revenue flow through to adjusted EBITDA. 7. Positive about product cross selling opportunities generated from agency and continued roll-out of Harmony platform. 1. Could have done little bit better with expense control, more labor inefficiencies than Co. would have liked. 1. Some expense could not be avoided, given strong backlog and need to staff in advance. 2. Private Label: 1. Ninth consecutive qtr. of double-digit revenue growth. 2. Revenue $562m. 1. Increased 13% driven by 15% increase in avg. card receivables. 3. Organic revenue growth, 12%. 4. Adjusted EBITDA net $244m. 1. Increased 7% as revenue flow through was dampened by 26% OpEx increase vs. 1Q13. 1. This increase was expected as Co. added about 1,000 new associates, mainly in call centers to increase core capacity and prepare for future growth. 2. Expects leveraging OpEx as year progresses and Co. ramps up new clients. 5. P&L: 1. Provision for loan losses increased 6% from 1Q13, primarily due to growth in credit card receivables. 2. Funding costs remained stable between years despite growth in receivables as Co. continues to replace maturing debt with cheaper, new debt. 6. Key metrics: 1. Total gross yields decreased 60 BP vs. 1Q13 due to impact of new programs. 1. Moving into 2Q, expects to see slight uptick in gross yields as this influence moderates. 2. Continued to pick up tender share as credit sales at core client, [meaning pre-2012 vintages] increased 7%, while overall client sales were about flat vs. 1Q13. 2. Normalized principal loss rates increased 20 BP to 4.9%, while delinquency rates increased 10 BP, both vs. 1Q13. 3. Based upon trends seen, expects stable-to-slightly improving principal loss rates for remainder of 2014. 4. Loan loss reserve: 1. Ended 1Q with 6% reserve rate; approx. 16 months of forward coverage. 5. Return on avg. assets 6.4% vs. 6.5% last year. 3. Liquidity: 1. Corporate liquidity at 03/31/14 $1.1b, after deploying over $300m on the BrandLoyalty acquisition and share buyback program in 1Q. 2. Debt levels remain modest with excellent debt service coverage ratios. 3. Had $345m convertible notes coming due in 2Q14, which Co. plans to cash settle. 1. Created little confusion in market, given that current settlement value of the convertible notes would be about $1.9b. 2. Working: 1. Co. pays $345m, face value of convertible notes. 2. Hedge counterparties pay $1.55b. 3. Noteholders receive total of $1.9b in cash. 3. Several months after debt maturity, has to settle the other side of hedge arrangement with counterparties, meaning the warrants. 1. At Co.'s current price, would issue approx. 5.1m shares to settle its obligation under warrants. 2. These shares are already included in diluted share count and [separated in apart] phantom shares. 4. Co. pays $345m in cash and issues 5.1m shares to settle convertible notes. 5. Guidance reflects all of aforementioned. 4. 2014 Capital Allocation Priorities: 1. M&A will continue to be first priority. 1. Buyback program is still important. 2. YTD, spent $115m of $400m Board authorized program.

2014 Outlook (E.H.) 1. Details: 1. 1Q14 has got a lot of puts and takes and lot of moving pieces. 1. Pleased with organic growth rate of topline. 2. Feeling comfortable that this year Co. is going to run organically at 9%, maybe 10% and that would be in at least 3x GDP, which is Co.'s goal. 2. Believes from a revenue perspective, [talking 9%, 10% organic, 20% plus layering in] BrandLoyalty, topline looks strong this year. 1. Bumping up guidance accordingly on topline. 3. Expense: 1. Getting dinged with Canadian dollar is going to cost 50 or 60 on top and probably about $0.15-0.17 on EPS. 1. Believes Co. can play through that without a problem. 4. Strong organic top. 1. Overall top, 20 plus. 2. Seeing stronger revenue growth coming out of BrandLoyalty. 3. Looking at about $0.5b of topline looks like it will already be more like $550m. 5. Epsilon running little bit stronger than Co. had thought as is Private Label. 1. Taking those three, offset a little bit of it with the Canadian dollar and that's where Co. gets an upward bias in topline guidance. 6. Balancing act Co. is trying to accomplish this year, bringing on huge book of new business at Epsilon and Private Label. 1. Going to have to ramp up significant amount of folks. 1. Added another 1,000 people just in Private Label group to handle book of business that Co. signed last year and it is signing now. 2. This bodes well for back half of this year and going into 2015. 2. Needs to absorb it now without the topline against it. 3. That's a little bit of the drag seen in first part of year. 1. Feels comfortable that it is the right bet to make at the back half. 7. Based on where revenue is going, believes that Co. is right on track with where it wants to be. 1. Trending a little bit better. 2. Going to bump up guidance from $12.20 to $12.25 which will give Co. earnings growth of 22% for this year. 1. Believes this is probably conservative rate at this point. 2. Would hope to grip that number upwards as year progresses. 2. AIR MILES Program: 1. Expects constant currency revenue to be up in low-single digits and adjusted EBITDA to be up somewhere in mid-single digits. 2. Key metric, AIR MILES. 1. Cautioned people from trying to look at it on quarterly basis. 2. Looking at last year, issuance by qtr. was minus 3%, minus 5% then plus 11%, plus 12% and ended year at plus 4%. 1. This is pretty much what is going to be seen in this year. 2. Going to see this thing jump all over the place because a lot of it is driven by promotional spend. 3. Doesn't have visibility on quarterly basis as much as Co. does on annual basis. 3. Full-year goal, around plus 4%, plus 5%. 1. There is probably a point or so risk due to some legislation in couple of provinces regarding Co.'s ability to issue for when someone buys prescription drugs. 1. This could dampen growth in that metric a little bit. 3. BrandLoyalty: 1. Trending quite a bit stronger-than-anticipated. 2. Revenues are running stronger. 1. Bumping them up 10%. 3. Would expect their organic revenue growth to grow over 20% this year. 1. 9-10% organic growth excludes organic growth (inaudible) acquisition. 2. Organic growth for Co. would be even higher than that. 4. Brazil: 1. It's all about scale. 2. Looking back at 2011, was under 2m collectors. 1. 2012 6m. 2. Last year, ended just under 11m. 3. Up to 12m this year. 4. Expects to have strong year this year. 3. Looking to expand into four new regions. 4. Rule of thumb, would need about 2.5 Dotz collectors to be equivalent to about 1 AIR MILES collector. 1. Essentially in Canada, got about 10m folks and that generates $0.25b or so of EBITDA (inaudible) . 5. Epsilon: 1. Strong story from organic growth perspective. 1. Nicely balanced. 2. Database part or the technology part was quite strong, up double-digit during qtr. and should continue that. 1. Based on large number of builds that are going on now. 2. Brought on lot of folks for record number of databases that were signed last year. 3. Lot of this is again a continuing trend with folks wanting their own loyalty platform, their ability to collect that data on the consumer that can then be used for data-driven marketing. 4. Seeing strong demand for that. 5. If Co. typically signs about 15 of these type platform builds a year, last year it did 23 plus, this year it is currently running at that rate. 6. Scrambling pretty hard to can make sure Co. got folks on board to make that happen. 3. New Harmony platform: 1. Getting good reviews. 2. Will know probably by 2Q-end. 3. Is in process of converting some clients. 6. Private Label: 1. New client growth continues to surprise. 2. Historically, tends to sign about five new clients per year, which a bit under $400m of new portfolio growth or a vintage. 1. Most of Co.'s clients start from scratch. 1. It takes three years for them to fully mature. 2. $400m vintage means three years after signing. 2. This essentially gives tremendous visibility into next couple of years. 3. In 2012, there just seemed to be massive shift of interest from number of retailers and new verticals in retail for Co.'s particular product offering, which allows closed-loop network to pull out not just who the person is, but also information down to category or SKU level. 4. In 2013, shift continued to accelerate. 1. Signed first $2b vintage. 5. In 2014, tracking to another $2b vintage. 1. Announced Virgin, Venus, DSW and IDD. 1. Just these four should be about first $0.5b, when they fully spool up. 6. Has number of signings that will be releasing over next six months. 1. It looks like its going to another huge year. 2. This allows Co. to look into 2015, 2016, 2017 as these vintages spool up and be comfortable with type of growth rates that Co. wants. 7. Continuation in tender share growth: 1. If on a typical client, 30% of their sales flow through Co.'s card, that's probably pretty decent level. 2. Once the program matures at client, tends to grow or should grow at the growth rate of the client. 3. What Co. found during holiday season in 4Q and what it is continuing to see in 1Q is that this Private Label product is really beginning to take off in terms of probably the best type of loyalty tool that the retailer has. 1. Saw that in terms of comparing growth rate in card sales against growth rate in client sales overall. 8. First three months of this year, probably saw relatively flat sales growth in retail space. 1. Against that, core sales growth is more like 7%. 9. Credit card portfolio: 1. Did about 15% in 1Q. 1. This is going to accelerate. 2. Will be running around 20% as year rolls out. 2. Principal loss rate and funding rates pretty stable. 3. Not seeing blips here or there in terms of anything on the credit quality side, it looks good. 4. Brought on a ton of new folks, 1,000 plus people onshore, which will of course hit the expenses pretty hard until Co. has those programs ramped up and the revenue flowing through. 5. Mid-to-high teens growth in revenue. 6. Double-digit growth in adjusted EBITDA. 7. Summary: 1. Ongoing shift of spend in marketing dollars from general brand spending into data-driven marketing and loyalty programs continues. 1. All three businesses continuing to see at high level of interest in every vertical. 2. Essentially has four pretty straightforward objectives for year. 1. Goal is to grow topline at 3x GDP, roughly 9%. 2. Expects overall revenue growth rate of 22% as Co. is seeing a bit stronger results on topline from BrandLoyalty, Epsilon and Private Label. 1. Got a little bit of offset with Canadian dollar. 3. Aforementioned will flow through to core EPS growth of 22%. 4. Expenses: 1. There is a lot frontloading going on both in Private Label and at Epsilon. 2. It's just the nature of those businesses that, Co. has to pay for it now and it starts flowing in a little bit later; this means that, it bodes well for future. 5. Building foundation for future, while on-boarding a record amount of new businesses. 3. Year is tracking a little bit better-than-anticipated. 1. Little bit choppy in 1H because Co. is building from 2H and into 2015, 2016 and 2017. 4. There has been a fair amount of volatility in the market to start up the year.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, the floor is now open for your questions.

(Operator Instructions)

Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

SANJAY SAKHRANI, ANALYST, KEEFE, BRUYETTE & WOODS: Just starting with Epsilon, the two new Agency deals that you guys spoke about, could you maybe just talk about when you on board the revenues are they're going to be significant incremental costs that you incur, or are most of those costs being incurred now and then the revenues come after? And maybe if you could give us a little bit more qualitative color on the nature of these two relationships, because they seem pretty sizable.

And then maybe just one on Private Label, could you just also talk about the M&A pipeline? You have a player that's going public, and obviously Wells came into the market a little bit. So maybe you could just talk about how that M&A pipeline is materializing. Thank you.

ED HEFFERNAN, PRESIDENT & CEO, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORP: Sure, let me start with the second and finish with the first. The M&A pipeline, per se in Private Label, if you looked at the clients that we've signed, probably 90% plus of the clients that we're signing, they're are starting a program from scratch. So we're not really in the takeaway game from an M&A perspective.

They will be one or two files probably per year that we will on board, and I would expect that to be the case this year as well. But for the most part, Sanjay, this stuff is coming from clients who either have had a program in the past and it's dead now and they're going to start cranking it up again, or folks that have never had one.

So I think in terms of running into the other folks, for the most, unless it's a really large file, I think we're comfortable in our sandbox. Our biggest challenge is trying to convince the prospect that the Private Label platform is the better loyalty option than other options. Of course, one of the other options is Epsilon, so it's a delicate balance there.

Speaking of Epsilon itself on the agency deals, we're beginning to see some traction in terms of selling through the stacks, so to speak. Which would be not only the creative and Agency side of it, but also allowing Epsilon to be the provider of things such as the demographic and psycho graphic data, the database build, as well as the analytics and distribution side of the business as well.

So, I'm not going to get into the specific clients themselves. But we are seeing some traction on that side. On the expense side, whenever you're in a strong -- when you're assigning a strong book of business, you're always going to have expenses that are running in front of the revenue, and that should even out as the year progresses.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Okay. And just one more on the Epsilon question, just is the opportunity to move some of those new relationships into the other lines as well? So will they materialize as revenue in database and technology as well?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, that's the game plan, or they could be a big tech client today, and we would try to sell in the Agency side.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Okay. All right, Great. Perfect. And then I just had one last one for Brian. Maybe you could just give us a little bit more of a refined window into Brazil. I guess, Ed, you mentioned the $25 million collector target to get to roughly the size of Canada. How do you guys get there from where you are right now? Because it seems like a lot of the you got thus far came from Banco do Brasil.

BRYAN PEARSON, EVP & PRESIDENT - LOYALTYONE, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORP: Yes, I think they did come from Banco do Brasil, but they also came very much from the retail partners that we have in each of the regions that we've launched, Sanjay. So I would suggest the following. Is that, we've been doing a market by market rollout. We've been trying to get and look for a national sized grocery player, which would help us penetrate the two largest markets which are basically Rio and Sao Paulo.

So remember that we're now at 12 million customers in that marketplace, and we're not in the two largest cities in Brazil. There's still a number of markets there are left. So you can think about it three ways.

One is, we continue growing into new markets, as we've been doing, and that would take us on the pace and the cadence the we're on today. The second piece would be by adding additional partners to the mix. So whether that's a big grocer or a new fuel player or a bigger electronics player, whatever it may be, those will make the program more attractive and add even more customers from the existing markets we're in, but also lend us the opportunity to do the third thing which is really grow that national presence which would bring Rio and Sao Paulo into the mix.

That's the path to daylight. I think we're quite comfortable that we can continue at the pace of growth that we've been on in the last little while, and the focus for us right now is to build a very viable program in all the markets that we're in. Which, today, the collector activation, which would be the measure of how many points they're earning, are they redeeming, how many partners are they using. Those metrics are tracking quite nicely with what the early days were in Canada, and so we feel quite confident that we're on the right track in terms of the value proposition we have for the marketplace.

SANJAY SAKHRANI: Thank you very much.

OPERATOR: Darrin Peller with Barclays.

DARRIN PELLER, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: If you could help us understand what may have surprised you with regard to your top line growth during the quarter versus your initial I think $1.25 billion guidance, maybe beyond currency? And then maybe you could just rank the key drivers enabling you to raise revenue guidance for the year, despite this quarter. And is it maybe just conservatism in the Private Label business that was going into the year, or is it that you had better than expected results in BrandLoyalty? And what other key variables should we focus on? Thanks.

CHARLES HORN, CFO, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORP: Darrin, in terms of the revenue, I'd say really came from two areas. One, FX of was a little bit worse than we anticipated, so you had a little bit more pressure coming through on LoyaltyOne. The second was, we just acquired BrandLoyalty, and initially probably were a little optimistic on terms of the revenue. But really, it's a sequencing issue, which is they're still going to hit there, as Ed talked about, we're actually going to have a very good year for BrandLoyalty revenue.

Where probably initially, we thought the revenue would be a little bit stronger in the first quarter than what it ended up shaking out. So I think it's just more of a timing issue for us, nothing more. The currency was a little more pronounced, BrandLoyalty timing issue on the revenue was still very strong for the year.

And then if you go through and look at why we feel better about the revenue stream, obviously Ed has already talked about BrandLoyalty going from $500 million to $550 million. Ed also talked about Private Label. We started the year with 15% growth on average receivables, now we're talking about 20%. So that's the upside you're seeing.

The third of it is, we did start off a little bit stronger with Epsilon, good high single-digit organic growth. Looking for some new clients to come through on Harmony, which could give a little upside to the back half of the year. And then, going back to Sanjay's point, as we do have these two to big clients ramping, if we get to a point of revenue growth where we can recognize it Q3, Q4 that gives upside to the year as well.

DARRIN PELLER: All right, that's helpful. So if we were to rank it, it sounds like it is basically the BrandLoyalty upside. Although it sounds like the first quarter was a little bit weaker, but you're still expecting that ramp up enough and see the evidence that it will ramp up enough to actually do better than you initially planned latter part of the year. Okay.

And then, Private Label, obviously you're looking at 20% versus 15%, and then those big deal still ramping in. All right, that's helpful.

Just on the credit quality side, one question. It seems like provisions were about $20 million or $25 million below your charge-off level in the quarter, which to the way we see you guys more in line or a little higher. Although, you also seem like, at least by our calculation, you're still over 100 basis points higher in terms of your allowance level than your charge-offs, which is still a really conservative cushion. Are we thinking about this correctly in the sense of how you want to keep that level going forward, or can give us a little guidance in terms of how we should think about your allowance levels for the rest of the year?

CHARLES HORN: I think you're right Darren. In terms of the spread between the reserve rates and trailing charge-off rate, 100 to 110 bips is reasonable. Like we talked about, we're still looking at about 16 months forward coverage in terms of the reserve we currently carry. So that's obviously very robust when most card companies would carry more like 9 to 12 months worth of coverage. So I think we'll continue to be very conservative, or what I'll say, appropriate in that regard. Good forward coverage, good spread, think of it being in the 100, 110 points range.

DARRIN PELLER: Okay, very helpful. All right, thanks, guys.

OPERATOR: Brett Huff with Stephens Inc.

BRETT HUFF, ANALYST, STEPHENS INC.: Hello, can you guys hear me okay? Sorry about that. One quick -- just to put a little finer point on the guidance, Charles, I wanted to make sure I understood this. What was your expectation for the Canadian headwind in the prior guided range versus the I think it's $55 million now? And I'm just trying to balance that with it seems like the benefit of an extra $50 million or so we're going to get from BrandLoyalty.

CHARLES HORN: So, when we came out with our guidance last quarter, were assuming the Canadian dollar would be about CAD0.94. Now we think the Canadian dollar will be more like CAD0.91 for the year. Now, the headwinds we face will be throughout the full year, but it's worse in the first quarter and lightest in the fourth quarter.

So what we saw was a little bit more of a negative impact in Q1 than we had anticipated. We have taken it down a little bit for the year, which is obviously included in our $12.25 core EPS guidance. But again, as the year goes on, it abates in terms of the amount of the headwinds.

BRETT HUFF: That's helpful. And can you talk about -- a little bit more on the Epsilon front-end loading? I think you called out in the press release $2 million, but it sounds like it might be a bigger project than that. And somebody already asked that question, but I just want to know a little bit more on is it $2 million, or is there more ancillary stuff in there that's harder to quantify? We thought the profitability would be better at Epsilon, and I'm trying to understand what's going on there.

CHARLES HORN: I guess I'd considered it more direct costs we're incurring to roll out the platform with these clients. Again, if it's a large client and it's technology platform in this case software we're rolling out, it takes number of months to get rolled out. During that timeframe, we're incurring the expense, the direct expense, to do the rollouts but we're deferring the revenue stream until it really gets up and ramped.

So what you're seeing now is deferrment on the expense, expense we have to incur to get the technology platform rolled out. But then when we get to the point of recognizing the revenue stream in Q3, Q4, then you can see the leveraging coming through and a little bit obviously the EBITDA margin contribution.

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, I think one of the things that we're beginning to see now given the size of Epsilon with north of 5,000 people, is that when you're signing 23 new deals a year on platforms and stuff, you've got to bring in a lot of folks. And these are what we call, folks who have the hot skills where were competing with the other folks out there, the Googles and Facebooks and stuff like that for the same talent.

And so getting those folks, getting them in the door, and getting in the size of the labor force that we need, it's becoming something that is now more of a challenge than it was when we were a lot smaller, I'll tell you that. And so, we will probably air on the side of getting a little bit more in the door sooner rather than later to make sure we have the pool available.

BRETT HUFF: And then one last question, I think, Ed, you'd talked a little bit about Private Label going forward, and it sounds like you're spending time there. And I think the last call, you had said the 2015 Private Label spots to start implementing were starting to look a little scarce. First of all, I want to make sure that I'm remembering that right. And if so, can you give us your sense of that same view today?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes, in terms of 2014, obviously, we're all booked up and it's straining the resources a little bit at this point. And so we probably -- we are drifting into slots for 2015 already, to your point. I would say we could probably launch up to at most 20 clients in a given year, given that we used to do five.

I'd say folks have done a spectacular job giving us that capacity, but I would say 20 is about it. And it goes back to the overall theme that we've been talking about which is organic top line is very strong. Revenue is very strong. We're going to flow through enough of it to give us the 20% plus earnings growth.

Our real issue this year is not going to be bringing in top line and organic growth. Our biggest issue this year is on execution and making sure that with these record books of businesses, especially at Epsilon and in Private Label, that the machine doesn't break down frankly. And that's where we're putting all of our efforts.

In terms of the year itself, I think the financials are in very good shape for the year. There may be a couple of minor tweaks as the year unfolds, hopefully to the upside. But we are 100% focused right now on just handling the two books of business that we've signed, and getting those on without things fraying at the seams.

BRETT HUFF: Great. Thanks for your time.

OPERATOR: David Togut with Evercore.

DAVID TOGUT, ANALYST, EVERCORE PARTNERS: Thank you, and good morning. Could you comment on the unit pricing outlook for Private Label, Epsilon, and LoyaltyOne for this year and next year?

CHARLES HORN: I'm not sure exactly what you mean David. I'll probably answer a little bit differently. If you were looking at EBITDA margins, we're looking probably for stable to maybe slightly up at LoyaltyOne AIR MILES. Obviously, well see some improvements coming through on BrandLoyalty as the year progresses. For Epsilon EBITDA margins, probably flat to maybe up slightly.

For Private Label, just because we'll have a little bit of a reserve build associated with the growth, you'll probably see a little bit of EBITDA margin compression in the Private Label space. Is that where you're going David?

DAVID TOGUT: That's helpful. And to follow that up, in the Private Label space, I'm curious if you're seeing any change in unit pricing as you compete for some of these new awards, or have most of these awards that you highlighted in the quarter really been sole sourced?

CHARLES HORN: I wouldn't say we're seeing really any pricing pressure in that regard. If you look through the year, we're saying that gross yields may be down as much as 40 basis points. If I take out the ramp of the new programs, the required programs, basically flat to maybe slightly up.

So that would tell me really what you're seeing is the influence of the growth, not the influence of pricing pressure coming through on re-signing some deals or some of the programs that we have. Really it's just the ramp you're seeing.

DAVID TOGUT: That's helpful. And just a quick final question on the Co-Branding side. Could you update us on your strategy in Co-Branding?

ED HEFFERNAN: Sure. I think that one of the things we're trying to do in our Private Label business is to diversify a little bit away from our traditional verticals, which would be soft goods, jewelry, home furnishings. And so Co-Brand, the choice of whether to use Private Label or Co-Brand is really up to the client.

And what we've found is there are certain verticals where Co-Brand works best, and specifically that would be T&E, hospitality. Those are the areas where there's a huge amount of interest in just having Co-Brand. So if you see an announcement in those areas, so for example with Caesar's or with Virgin America, something like that, those are going to be the Co-Brand space. The majority of our business will always continue to be Private Label, but there is a slot that's opening up for Co-Brand.

DAVID TOGUT: And then on that point, to what extent can you extract SKU level data from a Co-Brand card?

ED HEFFERNAN: Sure. It's the same gig. It's actually what you do is because we are the merchant acquirer and the issuer for Co-Brand, if the transaction takes place at that retailer, clearly, we can extract the same type of information as long as the merchant once again agrees to give us that information.

For purchases outside of the retailer, we can't get that level of information. We could probably only get where you went and how much you spent at the location. So for stuff that takes place at the retailer, we can get the same level of information, that's the deal with the merchant. And outside of that, we're stuck with just total dollars being spent.

DAVID TOGUT: What percentage of purchases on Co-Brand typically occur at the retailer on the card versus outside of that?

CHARLES HORN: I don't know David, I don't have that stat.

ED HEFFERNAN: It's all over the place.

DAVID TOGUT: Okay, thank you very much.

OPERATOR: David Scharf with JMP Securities.

DAVID SCHARF, ANALYST, JMP SECURITIES: Morning, thank you. Two areas. First, on Epsilon, wanted to follow-up on earlier questioning about cross-selling. Has there been a history thus far of moving any Agency clients to become data and technology clients, or is there a track record over the last couple of years since you've entered the Agency business?

ED HEFFERNAN: It hasn't been nearly as strong as it should be. A lot of that has to do with we really just finished, I think when you're talking about last year, the organizational changes at Epsilon. Where as before, we sold by product. So you would have someone responsible for the agency P&L, someone else responsible for technology, someone else for distribution, et cetera, et cetera.

We rearranged everything so that now the P&L is by vertical. So if you are in the auto vertical, your P&L responsibilities are now cut across all the products. And as result, your comp is cut across all the products. And we have found that when you tie your comp to that type of goal, that that tends to move the needle.

So I would say that you had a smattering of deals last year. This year, we're beginning to see much more sellthrough, and it goes both ways. It goes Agency clients, which are now going into the technology side, and technology going upstream into Agency. I would say this year and next year should be significant years for the sellthrough.

DAVID SCHARF: Got it, that's helpful. And then secondly, turning to Private Label, that was helpful commentary on the yield outlook. Maybe there's more type of question to answer, it's more qualitative or macro driven.

But setting aside the near-term headwinds on gross yields just because you're boarding on more new clients, you have to build bigger reserves. Can you give us a sense for whether gross yields are still running below ignoring the new client aspect, whether gross yield are running historical peaks just based on the percentage of your yield that's coming from late fees.

I'm just trying to understand whether or not as we think about ultimately where that portfolio can trend, whether it's still, let's say, more of a prime portfolio, or a higher credit score portfolio than you actually like? Just trying to understand what key profitability can be, and whether late fees are still representing about a third of gross yield, or if payment rates are still too high.

CHARLES HORN: I think if you take out the influence of the new program, it's right around to where it is. It is about we'd want it to be. To put it another way, we're not really trying to push it up or push it down.

You'll have some influence that's coming through there, David. Obviously, we have an APR tied to prime rates. So if you see short-term rates go up, then you're going to see the APRs go up, so you're going to see a little bit of float there naturally. The increase in APR offsetting the increase in funding costs.

The flip side of it is that, obviously, we are doing a little bit more Co-Brand than what we did in the past. Co-Brand is going to carry a little bit lower gross yield than what a typical PLCC would. So I'd say, [investing] for those will be somewhat static.

But those will have an influence on a go-forward basis that it's hard for me to really answer your question exactly. We do have a prime portfolio, we'll endeavor to keep it that way. Going back even 2007, we've kept our underwriting standards very consistent. Approval rates now are still pretty low for us, we could [exceed] them to come up over time as people repair their credit. But aside from the two [fedras] I talked about, I don't any impetus to make it to go up or down.

DAVID SCHARF: Very helpful, thank you.

OPERATOR: Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

ANDREW JEFFREY, ANALYST, SUNTRUST ROBINSON HUMPHREY: Good morning, thank you for taking the question. Ed, I appreciate the color on the pipeline, and it sounds like demand is strong across your businesses. I've been following Alliance for a while, and I certainly have less than perfect memory. But I can't remember a time when you called out 1,000 new employees in a call center, for example.

Can you just frame up for us how you balance visibility? And I think you mentioned a couple of potential large customers at Epsilon suggesting that they're not signed. Can you just frame up the balance between the front end loaded investment, and perhaps the risk on either timing of new deals coming on this year? Or the risk that you don't win the contracts that you think you're going to win, and how you frame that up in the context of your real confident second half outlook?

ED HEFFERNAN: Yes. You hit the nail on the head. It's a balancing act. What we're finding is that really especially at Epsilon and Private Label, you're just seeing more demand, more demand, and more demand, which is, as we say, a great problem to have.

I think hiring 1,000 people at Private Label, we need those folks up and running. We need the call centers built. We need the space provided well in front of these clients spooling up.

I think the messaging here is that none of this is hiring on spec. We're hiring folks based on deals that have been signed. So in the case of Private Label, as we said, we've got 20 new folks, 20 new clients spooling up this year. The backlog looks very strong, and at Epsilon we've got 23 big platform builds going on this year and getting those people in the door. That's the big challenge, and we're going to try to match delivering 20% earnings growth this year, at the same time not letting business fall through the cracks so we can have strong growth outlook for 2015 and 2016.

It's a long-winded way of saying it's a balancing act. It's a good problem to have, but it doesn't take much either way to get your expenses to shoot out of control for a quarter or two. And we want to make sure that doesn't happen.

ANDREW JEFFREY: Okay. And you guys have a good track record of forecasting your business. One last one, if I might, just with regard to the loyalty business generally. When you step back and look at the traditional AIR MILES business versus some of the other things you're doing, whether it's BrandLoyalty or the cash rewards business in Canada or certainly the growth in Brazil, would you frame that up at all as a changing of the guard or a maturation of your loyalty business generally? Or is that too dramatic a comment?

BRYAN PEARSON: Let's put it this way. The program is 22 years old. When you've got a business that's been running for that long, and you've got 70% of Canadians participating in the program, you could look at it and say is it in a maturing phase as a business overall. And I think that you could put that color on it. The reality is, that we still see a lot of opportunity in that business for growth.

Is a going to be a strong double-digit growth in the future? No. Does it have the potential to be mid- to high single-digit as you go forward? Yes. And do we have some things that we put in place that will help us get there? And the answer to that is yes.

We probably had the best year of signing new partners that we've had in years last year. If you look at that 10 million households, there's a portion of them that they're very engaged in the program, and there's a portion of them that are using some sponsors but they're not holistically engaged in the program and using it as their primary reward vehicle.

And so, we see opportunity to continue to add sponsors in categories, to continue to basically add -- to continue to add more cross sponsor activation, as we would say. In other words, a measure of engagement. And as a result of that, we think that there's opportunities with things like the cash program to change the nature of what our growth pattern has been over the last few years.

I think as much as anything, Canada has had an anemic spending environment for probably the better part of 18 months now. And I think the consumer is cautious in terms of how they're spending, and so a little bit of economic recovery and a little bit of these other strategies will get us back to a healthier outlook going forward.

ANDREW JEFFREY: That's great, thank you.

ED HEFFERNAN: Okay, I think that wraps it up, and we'll talk to you next quarter. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you ladies and gentlemen. This concludes the Alliance Data first quarter 2014 earnings conference call. You may now disconnect.
