QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

PAUL RICHARDSON, FINANCE DIRECTOR, WPP PLC: So if you can just put your hand up, say who you are and just wait for the man with the microphone, I would be very grateful. So just start on the left -- my left, your right.

CHARLES BEDOUELLE, ANALYST, EXANE BNP PARIBAS: Good morning, Charles Bedouelle from Exane. A couple of questions. The first one is do you get any inspiration from the finally positive growth from Ipsos last quarter and what it could mean for consumer insight, market research?

And the second question is for Paul. Where do you see the net debt and average debt maybe at the end of the year? Thanks.

MARTIN SORRELL, GROUP CHIEF EXECUTIVE, WPP PLC: On data, you've seen that in the first quarter it was flat. We had a stronger March. The integration of our data business with our media business, you put the two together, the combined revenues of the two businesses are GBP10b out of approximately GBP20b.

So media and data are really half of our business. Another quarter of our business, maybe a little bit more, is digital. So three-quarters of our business are media, data and digital heavily linked together. But we think that the leverage that we're getting from media and from data is quite significant.

Ipsos is -- business tends to be more custom than ours. We still see a difference between the custom business, which is much more project orientated, and the syndicated or semi-syndicated business that we have, which is built around copy testing and tracking and our panel business. Which is more, let me put it like this, a Nielsen-type business which is more syndicated. And we did see a little bit more stronger growth in March. But margins are strong and much stronger. Some of the restructuring expense that we took in 2014 and 2015, a significant part of it was directed at the data business and particularly in Western Europe. So I think we saw a little bit of improvement in March.

But one of the primary focuses is to make sure that we leverage what we are doing in data and measurement more effectively. One of the big areas is ensuring that we get maximum utilization and application that came out in Adam's and Rob's report in the area of measurement.

And being able to access the data, the sort of data that Google and Facebook are developing. And there are signs, certainly with Google and I think latterly with Facebook as well, that they're starting to free up some of the data, if not all of it, to then make available to our media operations and our data operations. And that they will be less of a walled garden, if I can put it like that in terms.

Do you want to add anything to that, Rob?

ROB NORMAN, CHIEF DIGITAL OFFICER GROUPM, WPP PLC: No, we have great relationships with all of them in terms of them feeding data into our own research and analytics models. We are still seeking more transparency from them into the real shape and nature of their audiences and the profiles of their heaviest using segments which we believe are important to advertisers to really understand the social significance of those platforms relative to other media.

And it's a tremendously productive relationship, but it's relatively tough sledding to actually get to the final datasets we want.

MARTIN SORRELL: Okay. So Paul, do you want to cover the net debt question.

PAUL RICHARDSON: So Charles, I'll talk about the average for the year, so to December 31. So last year, as you may recall, the year-to-date average was around GBP3.5b. And in terms of the average net debt to EBITDA ratio, the end of the year about 1.78.

I'm expecting the average net debt throughout the year to increase by the end of the year around GBP500m on a constant currency basis. But the ratio at the end of the year to be very consistent with what we saw last year end.

I think there are two just adjustments you need to keep in mind. Is because of the weakness of sterling, and we had the majority of our debt in euros and dollars, in terms of the gross debt number, there's around a GBP200m adjustment at 2016 rates.

It doesn't affect the leverage ratio because obviously we're going to get the benefit on the EBITDA in a similar fashion. So the ratio remains the same. But also in addition, with the completion of the STW deal, although we did not pay cash and we've been issued shares for our assets, we are taking on their balance sheet, which had on balance around GBP200m of debt as well.

So without those two adjustments, just to keep it clean and simple, it's around GBP500m higher average net debt but the ratio the same. And we're looking to have I think a more even balance to the cash generation and the cash outflows in 2016 whereas last year we were quite a heavy outflow of around GBP560m.

JULIEN ROCH, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Julien Roch with Barclays. First question on P&G. You just announced recently that they were continuing to cut how much they were paying to agencies. They've already cut by 25% which is about GBP400m. There's about another GBP200m to come. So is anybody doing it? Because I know you talked about pricing pressure. But are we talking about 35% cut, which is quite big and why is there no impact on overall agencies because if you look at the growth rate, it's pretty similar? That's my first question.

Then ISBAR this morning sent to their 450 members a standard contract because apparently there's a lot of capacity and keeping of rebates among agencies. And I'm sure that's not the case for WPP agencies, but it's the second industry body that's said ether's something wrong in media buying at D&A. So your comments on that.

And the last question is on account wins. Publicis is telling us it's going to cost them 100m, 250m of organic. And yet as the winner, you seem to have no benefit as this year growth is supposed to be like last year. So a comment on that as well. Thank you.

MARTIN SORRELL: Well let me just deal with the first one. I don't think we can talk specifically about one specific client. P&G is our third-largest client after Ford and Unilever. But I think it would be inappropriate to talk about specific clients other than to say, as you know from the analysis that we gave you, the macro and micro analysis on the slide, we do refer to pressure. And then the pricing pressure that there has been in the marketplace, the pressure on payment terms and the like. This is not a new thing. This is something that's been going on for a significant period of time.

But I come back to the general point that what we're seeing is that corporates are very focused on returning capital to shareholders.

There are others that are looking at growing the top line and ultimately I think everybody accepts, even zero-based cost budgeters, that in the longer term, they have to invest in brands and have to grow the top line to prosper. So in any particular case, any particular company will go through cycles, or go through cycles where they emphasize costs, and then having done that, and having created a much more efficient base for their operations, there'll then start to build again. Packaged goods companies in particular are very focused on advertising and promotion.

Unfortunately, we don't get often the breakdown between advertising and promotion. Promotion, by and large, if A&P rises because A is rising, obviously that's good for agencies. If it rises because of promotion or P rising, that's not so good. And similarly on the downside. So I think it would be wrong to categorize everything in the garden as being rosy.

And we've had this discussion with you before. We talked about parallel universes; you have to be optimistic if you operate in our industry. But having said that, there are pressure points, and we have highlighted consistently over a long period of time that there are these pressure points, ever since, really, Lehman. We had to snap back in 2010, but from 2011 onwards, it's almost like a square root sign you saw, the snapback, but it's with a gently sloping upward tail to the square root sign. So without, again, focusing on specific clients, that is the situation.

On ISBAR and the agencies, I haven't seen the contract. But of course, we have contracts with our individual clients. And as we've said in the case of the ANA, if any client has any issue with any of our agencies, we have a constant dialogue, not through ISBAR and not through the ANA, with each of the clients. And if they have any concerns about the relationship or the way that we operate, or indeed anybody else operates, they should do it directly with the agencies. And we do have strong dialogues all the time with all our clients.

On the new business, I'm a little bit mystified by the question because you do see the benefit of it, and you do see the benefit. You've seeing the increase in our market share in North America. We are, according to RECMA, our billings are GBP104b I think in the last RECMA survey, which was around I think 2014. I don't think they've issued the full numbers for 2015. We give you an audited number. You know that we did GBP73b of billings last year. You know that our billings are up by 8.3% reported and 6.7% constant for the first quarter of this year.

I think, coming back to your comment on ISBAR, and indeed, the ANA, a lot of the issues that are supposed to be focused on could be removed by every agency giving their billing information, every agency giving their revenue information, which they do, and every agency giving their net sales information.

We included the table in the press release, which is somewhat unorthodox, some people observed, but we put it in into the press release because we think it shows -- it highlights the difference in the data. We give you the revenues of each company for the last quarter. We show that local -- in local and revenue, because sometimes the exchange rate varies a bit, and we give an explanation of that. We gave you the growth rate. And we gave you the growth rate our revenue and net sales. And we now know that at least two, maybe three of the competitors have their own platforms, and buy media as principles.

Now we were very forthright on Xaxis and the opt-in basis of Xaxis. Omnicom then revealed that they had their own platform, Accuen, and they give a -- in response to questions they give each quarter an indication of what the impact of principle digital buying has been in the United States.

Publicis, in their last call, referred to their Apex platform, which as I understand it, from what I've been told, has been in operation for some time.

IBG say they don't act as principle.

Havas I don't know whether they do or they don't. I think from what we've heard, they possibly do.

So we think that, coming back to your question about benefit around new business wins, etc., you can see it in the numbers.

And going back to the ISBAR question, I think a lot of the question marks would be removed because it then get into the areas of barter and pass through costs. The other area that makes the difference between revenue and net sales, in our case, is not just online media buying as principle, but also the pass-through costs on data.

And obviously other people have pass-through costs. IBG in their call this quarter referred to pass-through costs yet again. So showing revenue and net sales, I think is important.

TOM SINGLEHURST, ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Good morning. It's Tom here from Citigroup. I have a couple of questions. The first one is on the convergence of agency models and the moves towards horizontality and cross-group client teams. It strikes me that the way we should think about WPP's approach is basically they have a series of concierges basically dipping in and out of the main agency brand. And the question is, given some of the big competitors are now going to full unified P&Ls, and on the face of it slightly more integrated approaches, is the concierge approach going to be enough in the context of what's happening in the world landscape? So that's the first question.

And then the second question. You mentioned the Bollore model. You didn't really talk about whether it was a good thing. And I just wanted to understand whether that's some sort of signal that we should expect you to (inaudible).

MARTIN SORRELL: I raised it as an interesting point, Tom, because I know you follow these things avidly. I just think it's a different model. It's yet to be determined whether it's a good thing or a bad thing. But I think it's probably one of the most interesting things going on in the industry, if not the most interesting thing, that you have a model that combines a telecom's platform, and it may well be that Telecom Italia company, that the network is separated from the pipework, if I can put it, or the cables.

But I think it's just very interesting that in a group, and it's a group of companies, really, minority interests, so effectively controlling interests, is being put together for the first time that I can see. I think there are some parallels in some parts of the world. I can think of one in South America.

But it's unusual to have agency services plus a telecoms platform, plus media ownership, plus content ownership being put together in this way. It does raise all sorts of interesting issues, and I think it's just interesting that convergence, and I think it is the fact we are seeing convergence in a number of areas, is just manifesting itself in a different way.

Going back to your concierge question, this is not a concierge operation. I think that's a misunderstanding or a misinterpretation. Whilst -- the point I'm making is this. If you've got one end of the spectrum is let's say vertical, and the other end of the spectrum is total integration or what we would call horizontality, we have clients that we have totally integrated, where we literally have one single P&L, where we've literally fused it and there is not a cigarette paper of difference.

And there are two or three of those that are very strong. They are effectively agencies within WPP to service a particular client. And we see that in the automotive category, in the packaged goods category. There are some clients who insist on global decentralization. I don't like that the word concierge. I wouldn't even call -- describe them as concierge, but where they're much more comfortable with let's say the vertical operating as the integrator.

The risk, I think, of going too quickly is that you disrupt your organization, and you can see it in the exit rate, in the churn rates that you can monitor, actually, increasingly. If you look at various social media, you can monitor what's going on. We monitor very closely what's happening to the churn rates, the turnover rates, between ourselves and key competitors. And that's particularly the case since the POG merger or the mooted POG merger. Since that broke apart, and we've continued to monitor that, and that shows quite clearly some differential turnover rates that are quite significant.

The point that I was making in our presentation is given the difference between vertical and horizontal, it's got to be done gradually. It can't be force fed, because it causes far too much disruption.

The brands that we have, have been in existence in one case for well over 150 years. And to force-feed people, to cram it down their throats that they're going to move to horizontal, unified model, uni-branded model in a short period of time, I think our judgement is that's highly destructive.

Others in our industry are more vertically geared and aligned, and they've used the value of their brands is greater than the benefits they will get. So this is not concierge. I react against that word, because we have models that are highly unified. We also have models that are highly decentralized. I think the trend is towards more unification. The difference I would have is the pace at which it gets done.

RICHARD JONES, ANALYST, POWERHOUSE: Hi. It's Richard Jones from Tower House. Can I just follow up on that question, just how client attitudes towards client conflict have changed over the last five, 10 years?

MARTIN SORRELL: Richard, we'll come back to the conflict, but Rob just wanted to add something.

ROB NORMAN: Yes, within the horizontality construct, I think it's interesting how it's operating in some parts of WPP. And I think of the agents Plus for Chanel. I think if they keep L'Oreal, for L'Oreal, I think of [Team Arrow] for Target in which we're taking assets across countries and across disciplines and across agencies from within GroupM even in order to build custom assets for clients whilst retaining complete sovereignty for many others in MediaCom, Mindshare and so forth.

So I think what we've got is a very flexible infrastructure and the muscle memory of collaboration in building throughout the business. It's no longer unusual, and it's much easier to do this through muscle memory than it is through dogma.

MARTIN SORRELL: Okay. Fair enough. On the conflict issue, Richard, I think broadly the answer is it has become less of an issue. And clients have accepted conflicts within structured parent companies, holding companies, as long as there's separation and there are rules of engagement, or rules of disengagement. So there are all sorts of things in relation to privacy, secrecy, confidentiality, audit, cooling off periods in relation to people working on pieces of business.

So I think generally, the issue of conflict is less prevalent. It is still probably more than, with all due respect to the investment bankers that might be in the room, or brokers who might be in the room, that the conflicts that you have to deal with are indeed consulting companies. That they are able in one brand to handle conflicts, whereas in our industry, for good reasons or bad reasons, handling conflicts in one vertical is difficult.

And that comes back to the previous question, Tom's previous question, often you have to maintain -- and this is this question about how fast you go, if you slam everything together and unify it into one, that whole conflict issue that you raised is going to become more difficult to deal with.

So there is a logic to the separation, not just about different cultures or different brands or different histories, but conflict of clients, and indeed I will add another conflict, conflict of people. Sometimes people just don't want to work with or for other people, and you have to respect that, and respect that difference. So that's another reason why going too fast can be a dangerous thing to do. But I do think generally concern about conflict has got less. And of course, if there is pressure in the system to reduce pricing, to -- on payment terms is another thing that we've discussed over time, the result is there has to be consolidation, which there has been in our industry.

And I think one of the things you're seeing, one of the questions that was previously, why is it that the industry seems to be in reasonably good health, if you look at -- and you look at GDP growth? And I think part of the reason is that the bigger agency groups are gaining share because it is more difficult, again, rightly or wrongly, for smaller or medium-sized agencies to continue to operate independently.

We were talking to one company yesterday who said that the chief reason they were interested in talking to us was because they needed more global representation, even more regional representation in the context of the US market. So the whole -- and they had been precluded from agency RFPs because they didn't have the requisite resources.

So one of the maybe unintended consequences of greater pressure on pricing, etc., is that the conflict differentiation is less necessary as a result, certainly less necessary than Don Draper would have seen -- would have known.

LISA YANG, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Good morning. It's Lisa from Goldman Sachs. My first question is on your organic growth for the full year, and how you think about the shape of it. It looks like the comps in the second half are getting tougher, yet you expect stronger growth. So any kind of comment that would be appreciated.

The second one is on Kantar. You recently announced a big reorganization. So I know it's early days, but any color you can give on how this reorganization is going, and when do you expect to achieve top line growth?

And the last one is a bit more on the topic about need to invest in your brand to grow your top line. It looks like there are more and more outside companies that grow their brands without having to invest much in traditional media if I take the example of just your traditional media you would use, etc. So I'm just wondering if you think that digital will lower the barriers to build the brand, and what are the implications for the agency?

MARTIN SORRELL: Adam, if you could just deal with that third question about the relative importance of tradition, because I think you've got some strong views on that, on traditional media and the balance. And then I'll come back on the organic second half and Kantar.

ADAM SMITH, FUTURES DIRECTOR, GROUPM, WPP PLC: Yes, in the Interaction report we've just published, one of the sections deals -- looks at specifically the amount of traditional media used by online brands to increase their market penetration, which is substantial. And to give you a specific example, in the UK, the big tech brands are growing their TV investment at double the market average. That's on the one side of the coin.

On the other side of the coin, do digital media reduce the barriers to entry? Well, one very distinct sign I see here in the UK, if you look at regional advertising, which is by definition small budgets and national (technical difficulty). The ratio of -- the cost of getting the reach is falling, because digital media are cheaper but you have to manage the data that go with it. And so earnings profile seems to be distinctly moving in the case of smaller budgets from fees and commissions and media placement to payment for data-related services, essentially. So there are still barriers to entry, although I agree that the media cost may well be cheaper.

MARTIN SORRELL: Thanks for that. Rob?

ROB NORMAN: No, I think other than to say that, as Adam points out, as regards becoming bigger and bigger investors, there is a definite need for many of these companies to achieve significant celebrity in their own mind. One of the newest clients is Max, in the US, for example, is Jet.com, which is a competitor to the other e-commerce platforms. Its a marketplace level business and it needs to drive a level of awareness so people consider jets.com versus Amazon and eBay and others, and they are pushing very aggressively into the marketplace with traditional media.

MARTIN SORRELL: And you -- Adam, just to further underline the point. In your Interaction report, you talk about TV is definitely not dead. Do you want to add anything in relation to -- and particularly one of the questions that flows from that is what's happening to the -- and Rob, you can comment on this as well, on the upfronts here and the scatter markets here. Do you want to just talk about TV and its role, Adam, a bit?

ADAM SMITH: There is this perception of TV as in some kind of crisis with the departure of younger viewers. And so we asked our networks to quantify the scale of this. And the net result is that yes, of course there's been some erosion of younger viewers, I would say typical more than 10% loss of volume. But what we buy is reach. And 10% loss of volume does not equate to 10% loss of reach. It equates to something rather less than that. So I visualize that problem as managing the problem.

We compensate for the loss of reach by using digital media where we know this audience resides. Rob's earlier points about some of the digital companies not telling us as much as we'd like to know about reach, is quite important because I think it may benefit them to be a little more open so we can establish just exactly how much reach we can pick up quite easily. I think there maybe there is an incentive there for them to be more open.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I've done some -- no.

MARTIN SORRELL: You've been told on pain of death not to say anything.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Yes. There is the [high occupation] area calling the upfront at this moment.

MARTIN SORRELL: All right, okay. So discretion is the better part of valor. Just coming back to organic. As we've said in the statement, we think on the basis of the Q1 one RF that we have, as I say, we're going to go through that in some more detail the next couple of weeks. But we think that the second half will be slightly stronger despite the stronger comparatives. So I think that's the pattern that we see.

As far as Kantar is concerned, it comes a little bit back to Tom's concierge question. If you look at Kantar, that is definitely not a concierge operation. But what Eric Salama, who runs Kantar, which is, as you know, is about a quarter of our revenues, is doing, which is no different actually to what we've been doing in other parts of the operation, but I think it's interesting, because it is emblematic of what we're trying to do elsewhere, and in fact at WPP as a whole is a, he calls it, Kantar first.

And he's building a much more integrated Kantar where in each country there is much more of a unified back office, the pipework is much more standardized, and yet you have people focusing on country and country cooperation across brands. Not losing, again, coming back to the importance of the brand, at least from our point of view, not losing their brand, not being -- not becoming uni-branded, but certainly trying to get the maximum amount of efficiency and the maximum amount of cooperation clear from what we've seen.

And it relates to the other part of the question about top line growth. What's clear is that having implemented that, there's a totally different attitude in each of the brands as they work together as to how they treat RFPs, how they treat RFPS if they can't compete with them for -- it might be Richard's question about conflict or whatever it happens to be or capability that they are much more aware of the other capabilities within Kantar and within WPP

So I think that structural -- and we're looking at it very carefully in terms of how it's implemented because it has lessons for us in what we're doing in other parts of the operation.

That 11 vertical slide which simplifies the structure with the four agency groups, GroupM, Group H, B2B, etc., gives you an idea of how the structure has been simplified. And what you've got is subgroups around function, that each and every one of them is becoming much more streamlined, much more efficient, much more back office shared service center, ERP efficient. And that's the way we think it should go. But being a little bit careful on all the issues that we talked about.

ADAM SMITH: And Kantar's reorganization is a very significant issue for the collaboration with GroupM. So I think of [Serene Wong] who leads the L'Oreal relationship with both Kantar and GroupM overall, I think of [Gera Sumenska] who I think leads the Nestle operation for both GroupM and Kantar. It's streamlining those relationships is making it easier for us to yield the data investment management dividend on media.

MARTIN SORRELL: Okay.

PAUL RICHARDSON: Right. Some of the regions last year relatively underperformed in the second half of the year, in particular Asia Pacific market sector, Middle East and rest of the world. Those are expecting quite a strong bounce back in the second half, which is logical given their performance last year.

And I'd say in terms of the discipline of the specialist businesses, it effectively gets stronger, although it's had a good start throughout the second half of the year. So there is a logic to the understanding, despite higher comps. Some of the underperformance relatively last year is being made up on the second half of this year.

PATRICK WELLINGTON, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Patrick Wellington, Morgan Stanley. Just quickly, three questions. China. Is your optimism simply based on comps as the year goes on or is there something more substantial making you feel that China is going to get better?

And just on the UK, are we seeing any Brexit effect in Q2?

Secondly, quickly, the ANA report, is that ever going to come out? There was some talk it was going to come out in April. Has it ever happened?

And thirdly, Martin, you mentioned that bigger agencies are taking share, which potentially gets us back onto the old theme of is WPP thinking of making another acquisition across those row of agencies. There's some smaller ones on the far right could easily be consolidated. Are we back on that theme?

MARTIN SORRELL: It doesn't strike me as being a quick question, Patrick. And there were four there, I noted. Your three has become four. But anyway, let me try and deal with them.

China. I think it is a comps, a comparative point. I think first quarter was pretty -- was limp, I would describe it. GDP growth I think in China is not at 6.5%. Probably most observers that we talk to think it's around 3% to 4%. But we'll have to see how it shakes out for the rest of the year. But I think it's more to do with comparatives than anything else. But we remain very strong, unabashed, not just of China, but of Brazil, despite the difficulties they're having at the moment. And I would add Russia, but that will take a longer time clearly to come through.

On the UK, to my knowledge, April hasn't finished, so I don't think we can answer your question.

I don't know whether Adam is going to add anything on the Brexit thing. But I have not seen stuff that I would associate on advertising spend with Brexit yet. I've heard clients say that Q1 generally was soft, not because of Brexit but for other reasons. One said to me even the pattern of holidays, the pattern of where Easter is, whether Easter is early or late, so there are lots of potential reasons. I do think, however, that Brexit, or the possibility of an exit, has affected other investment decisions.

So on the ANA, I don't know. You would have to ask the ANA as to -- I think I've said on a previous call, a meeting has been arranged between at least -- I think it's four of the agency holding company heads and the ANA. But that will be sometime in June. So I don't know about the reports.

On the bigger agencies, we remain very focused, Patrick, on the small and medium-sized acquisitions. We have done a public company deal which was STW. That is effectively -- it's not a nil premium merger, but it's a small premium merger. We stepped up from 21%, I think it was or 22%, to 60%, 61%, and the deal that was done was merging our remaining assets in Australia and New Zealand with STW, now being called WPP Australia New Zealand.

And when you look at the structure of that transaction, although we did pay a small premium on the value of their business in relation to ours, effectively it's a nil premium, or close to nil premium merger. So we think if we are going to do something of that nature, we get credit for doing that in that way rather than blundering in in the way that you seem to be suggesting by your fourth question.

I just think that -- just on structure, and I'm not saying we would be involved in this. But I do think since six becomes four in time, I'd still hold that view. But we shall see. The interesting thing about the Bollore model is that creates a different model. So Havas, which is the smallest of the six, is -- you can conglomerate it with the other assets that the Bollore family have, you have a very different -- it's a very different kettle of fish. So I think that in and of itself is sort of interesting.

CHRIS COLLETT, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Good morning. It's Chris Collett from Deutsche. Just two quick questions. One was on IBOPE, obviously one of the larger of the acquisitions you've done recently. Could you just comment on how that has been performing in what -- this is a difficult market?

And then secondly, it was just to pick up on a comment that was made about some of the walled gardens from Google and Facebook, the garden walls coming down a little bit. Could you just talk a little bit more about what is driving that and why, what's the incentive for them to lower their garden walls, if you will?

MARTIN SORRELL: Well, we have an expert on -- an expert gardener here. Rob, go ahead.

ROB NORMAN: Well, I think that the walls remain robust. They're fine brick and mortar. They are merely taking more stuff over the wall that they've built. And I think what they have realized, not under pressure from advertisers and us, but in quite collaborative conversations with their advertisers and us, that it's in their interest to see all the boats flow upwards of brands growing. And they know that brands will only flow upwards if there is media investment and advertising investment across channels and the attribution is more able to be considered.

I think they've grown more confident, incidentally, in their own ability to deliver certain numbers of advertising objectives to different people. And the more confident people become in the performance of their channel I think the more happy they are to share some of the data from their channel which endorses their position.

We would like it to come down further. Our own strategy is to gather up the original data we collected in WPP from Kantar Shopper and transaction level and elsewhere, and back to consumer and behavioral data with KPMG in other parts of the Group and then to append more and more data so we have some visibility across the piece and they're not entirely dependent on them.

I think we are reaching a kind of mutual status, if you like, on that data sharing where they're keeping secret what they want to keep secret, and we are making use of what we need to do to achieve is our overall goal being cross-channel demand driving business.

MARTIN SORRELL: Just to add to that and, Adam, you might want to come in as well. But I'll just ask Rob, it's not just the Google and Facebook walled gardens. There is the Amazon walled garden. There is the Ali Baba walled garden. There might even be a ClickCarts walled garden. There are a number -- the Apple walled garden -- there's a number of them.

ROB NORMAN: Well, the coincidental nature between all of the people who finish those walled gardens with are the people that are the biggest owners who want to become the virtuous first party data. So the people who have created terms and conditions for use of services, often utilities like Facebook or commerce services like Amazon, or entertainment services that come with Apple, who have acquired through their user agreement a number of rights to the use of data and targeting and so forth. And there is a clear separation between those businesses and what we think of as the rest of the traditional media sector. So that is highly significant.

And data alliance, which we created between GroupM and Kantar and Wunderman and other assets within WPP, has been absolutely focused on opening up the partnership pipes between us and all of those companies. And I'm glad to say we do have partnership rights between us and all of those companies. And the job is not to turn the fire hose on, as it were. The job is to take enough to inform appropriate decision-making. We are not unhappy with our progress in that area.

MARTIN SORRELL: Yes, and I'll just add to it, Chris, before Adam, if you want to add anything else. What's really interesting is there is a considerable amount of concern. You know the regulatory concern in Brussels with the new competitiveness, DG, invest to go in relation to Google. You know, I'm sure, that a number of people are concerned about the data that, for example, Amazon has and controls.

And in fact, the data that an Ali Baba gets through the

[Tarval] platform in terms of what's happening to movement of product and service and replication of that product and service. So there is -- the more walled gardens there are, in a way, the greater the role that we have. It's a bit like fragmentation of the media. It plays in a role that we have in not arbitrating between them, but helping our clients navigate.

ROB NORMAN: There's a general rule that businesses like ours trade quite well in environments that are characterized by strong oligopolists rather than massively fragmented markets or single monopolists. So I think that we are now moving into a phase of a number of very strong oligopolists and I don't think that's a terrible thing for us.

MARTIN SORRELL: Adam, anything you want to add before I respond on IBOPE?

ADAM SMITH: No, only that I have visualized this shift in our relationships with the big tech companies as being -- they are coming from a transactional direct response mindset to the more brand focused, intangible idea that most of our clients are pushing, where reputations are at stake. I realize part of what we do is risk management around price quality, security, context, reputation, this sort of thing. And the more collaborative our relationships are with the media vendors, I think the better the issues can be delivered.

MARTIN SORRELL: Just turning to Chris's question on IBOPE, I think it's gone quite well, actually. One of the reasons why I think, if you compare the statistics and you got the statistics, or we can supply you with the statistics of the Latin American breakdown between us and the competition, one of the reasons we might have exhibited, certainly Brazil has been tough in the first quarter for everybody, including ourselves.

But I think in the context of Brazil and Latin America, IBOPE, because of the nature of its business, gives us more stability than perhaps we would have had without it. So on balance, good. And within the region, I think becoming stronger actually, when you look at it on a market-by-market basis.

PAUL RICHARDSON: I think, Martin, that's the last of the questions. Thank you.

MARTIN SORRELL: Okay. We've got Fran Butera is over here with me and with Rob and you are there, Paul, with Chris Sweetland. So thanks, everybody, and we'll be talking to you at the end of the first half.
