urn:contentItem:5WS4-54B1-DXH2-6287-00000-00Event Brief of Q1 2020 Liveramp Holdings Inc Earnings Call - Final2019-08-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis080519sx.755Event Brief of Q1 2020 Liveramp Holdings Inc Earnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Anneka R. Gupta - LiveRamp, Inc.,Co-President

. Lauren Dillard - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,Head of Communications & IR

. Scott E. Howe - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,CEO & Director

. Warren C. Jenson - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,President, CFO & Executive MD of International

. Anneka R. Gupta - LiveRamp, Inc.,Co-President

. Lauren Dillard - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,Head of Communications & IR

. Scott E. Howe - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,CEO & Director

. Warren C. Jenson - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,President, CFO & Executive MD of International

. Anneka R. Gupta - LiveRamp, Inc.,Co-President

. Lauren Dillard - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,Head of Communications & IR

. Scott E. Howe - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,CEO & Director

. Warren C. Jenson - LiveRamp Holdings, Inc.,President, CFO & Executive MD of International

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Daniel Salmon - BMO Capital Markets Equity Research,Analyst

. Shyam Vasant Patil - Susquehanna Financial Group, LLLP, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Stan Zlotsky - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,VP

. Stewart Kirk Materne - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD

. Vasily Karasyov - Cannonball Research, LLC,Founder

. Daniel Salmon - BMO Capital Markets Equity Research,Analyst

. Shyam Vasant Patil - Susquehanna Financial Group, LLLP, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Stan Zlotsky - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,VP

. Stewart Kirk Materne - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD

. Vasily Karasyov - Cannonball Research, LLC,Founder

. Daniel Salmon - BMO Capital Markets Equity Research,Analyst

. Shyam Vasant Patil - Susquehanna Financial Group, LLLP, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Stan Zlotsky - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,VP

. Stewart Kirk Materne - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD

. Vasily Karasyov - Cannonball Research, LLC,Founder

OVERVIEW

RAMP reported 1Q20 results. Expects FY20 revenues to be $363-377m and 2Q20 revenues to be up to $86m.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 1Q20 YoverY revenue growth = 32%.

2. 1Q20 YoverY normalized revenue growth = 39%.

3. 1Q20 share repurchase = 1.4m shares for $69m.

4. FY20 revenue guidance = $363-377m.

5. 2Q20 revenue guidance = up to $86m.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

1Q20 Review (S.H.)

1. Highlights:

1. Solid growth qtr., building on last year's strong momentum.

2. Revenue up 32%.

1. Excluding lost revenue from Facebook, up 39%.

2. Subscription business up 33%, driven by enterprise and agency channels.

3. Marketplace and other up over 70%, due to continued strength of data marketplace.

3. Made continued investments to drive operational excellence and innovation, fuel durable growth and further solidify competitive position.

1. Launched Authenticated Traffic Solution (ATS) to power safe and transparent way to connect advertisers with publishers.

2. Closed acquisition of Data Plus Math to provide TV ecosystem with more effective way to buy, sell and measure data-driven television.

3. Doubled down on commitment to shareholders, buying back nearly $70m of stock as part of ongoing share buyback program since March 31.

4. Co.'s themes:

1. Business is strong, and macro trends continue to move in Co.'s direction.

2. Co.'s platform is highly defensible, and competitive moats are widening.

3. Strategic initiatives remain on track, and has a lot of conviction in path to $1b.

4. While pleased with progress, sees a lot of areas in which Co. can do even better, and plotting course to do just that.

5. Use of people-based data creates greater accountability, drives higher ROI, and powers more meaningful experiences for consumers.

1. Co. is central to ensuring open and level playing field for all participants.

6. As data protection and consumer data privacy reach a tipping point, Co. is quickly emerging as open and safe choice, safe haven that enables customers to transform data into value while honoring privacy and preferences of consumer.

7. First key focus area this year involves delighting and growing customer base, which points directly to land and expand component of model.

1. Made good progress on new logo acquisition in 1Q, adding over 25 net new direct customers across different customer verticals.

2. Co. end of qtr. with over 690 direct subscription customers; up from 585 YoverY.

3. Co. now serves more than 20% of Fortune 500.

8. Enterprise and agency channel strong, with several larger-than-avg. [ACV] deals getting signed in qtr.

1. Signed new deal with large travel and tourism co. to help enable more effective online targeting and measurement.

1. Co. is distributing their data to several media platforms for targeting, site personalization and closed-loop measurement.

2. New win with a leading fashion brand:

1. Large multinational retailer selected RAMP to help better leverage its purchase data to deliver hyper-targeted digital experiences to its customer segments.

2. Co. was originally introduced to this brand through a reseller.

3. As their data strategy became more sophisticated, they went direct with Co.

9. Net dollar retention came down from where it has trended historically.

1. While Co. signaled decline at last call, it is aiming higher and views this as opportunity to generate even stronger growth, higher customer satisfaction and reduce churn.

10. As Co. scales to $1b, upsell is going to become more important driver of business.

11. Plans to strengthen this component of growth:

1. Recently implemented field strategy function inside sales to drive greater web effectiveness and productivity.

1. This group is tasked with improving focus on sales training and enablement.

2. Strengthened selling efforts to drive greater and more advanced upsells.

3. Formed strategic growth team that owns and drives all advanced measurement, analytics and data lake use cases, and continue to invest in subject matter experts to provide overlays for Horizon 2 and 3 growth initiatives.

4. Building tighter integration and go-to-market strategies with key technology partners, agencies and consultancies.

5. More complex use cases like advanced analytics, IDL-based data lakes and data sharing strategies require significant customer expertise.

6. By working with key agencies and technology partners to develop turnkey solutions, Co. can make it easier for less-sophisticated clients to take advantage of more involved use cases.

2. Marketing Evolution partners:

1. Marketing Evolution provides multi-touch attribution platform built on IdentityLink.

2. By creating tight technical integration, and go-to-market alignment, Co. is bringing joint solution to market.

3. Partnership and approach proven to be successful.

4. Co. has pipeline of additional partnership opportunities it is pursuing.

12. To establish RAMP as trusted, best and essential industry standard for connected data:

1. Work Co. is doing inside commercial and product teams to drive ubiquity of identity, and improve extensibility of platform, directly ladders up to this effort.

2. Co. invented category of connected data and identity, and believes it has superior product.

13. Has several initiatives underway to aggressively expand addressable market.

1. Emerging business initiatives fall squarely within this effort.

2. Continues to be pleased with progress across group with growing opportunities.

14. Marketplace business grew more than 70%, excluding Facebook, driven by growing global demand for ethically-sourced people-based data and trend towards BYLD (Bring Your Own Data).

15. Continued to be encouraged by TV opportunity, which grew multiples with acquisition of Data Plus Math.

1. Integration underway and on track.

2. Excluding Data Plus Math, which will be included in results beginning in 2Q, TV business grew roughly 30% in 1Q20, driven by increase in addressable TV campaign volumes and ramping CTV business.

1. Bookings outlook for remainder of year gives even more confidence in business.

2. Seeing contract values expand as more homes become addressable.

3. Growing data enablement of CTV inventory presents strong tailwind for business.

16. Almost any co. that is doing any marketing can generate better results by utilizing Data Store.

Product Strategy (A.G.)

1. Highlights:

1. Focus inside products is to establish RAMP as trusted industry standard for connected data.

2. To do this, Co. has built defensible and extensible identity and data connectivity platform for enterprise, one that anyone everyone in industry can use as integral part of their own independent technologies.

1. Co. helps customers and partners navigate growing industry and regulatory complexity impacting their businesses.

3. Believes Co.'s unique positioning enables it to help entire industry in three important areas:

1. Identity.

2. Data stewardship.

3. Innovation.

4. Identity:

1. Today, there's proliferation in unique and proprietary identifiers including names, addresses, emails, first-party cookies, third-party cookies, mobile ad IDs, subscriber and user IDs, device IDs, and many more.

2. Concept of connected identity is essential role that RAMP fulfills for industry.

3. Co. vs. partners:

1. Co.'s goal isn't to own all identity, but rather to power every owner of identity to get greater value from their data.

2. As Co. embeds new identifiers, integration and partners into its product, customers gain access to more capabilities to configure, manage and activate their own version of identity.

3. Co.'s efforts enable ecosystem interoperability and protect participants from being held captive to any single source of identity.

4. Added number of new identifiers and increased coverage in emerging addressable channels.

1. Consumers consume content across increasing number of medium, and Co.'s customers want to talk to these consumers in omni-channel context wherever they are.

2. Customers can now reach over 55m people on connected TV, over 17m people through MVPD integration, and over 80% of US population through Co.'s premium publisher integration.

3. Customers will be able to reach people across display inventory, regardless of availability of third-party cookies or mobile advertising IDs through RAMP's ATS offering launching at end of Aug.

5. Through Smart Reach program, advertisers can broaden their identity coverage by sharing first-party identities in permissioned and non-discoverable context.

1. In last year alone, grew mobile Smart Reach contributions by 350%, offline contributions 19x, and online contributions by more than 20%.

6. Co. is taking steps to enable addressability regardless of whatever industry shifts may occur in future.

1. In last year, incorporated RAMP's IdentityLink into bidstream for programmatic display.

2. IdentityLink is the only people-based omni-channel identifier available in bidstream.

3. Co. now has billions of bid requests within IdentityLink available on which to bid.

4. Four out of Top 5 SSPs are currently committed to implementing IdentityLink in bidstream.

5. Has 11 DSPs live, who are implementing ability to bid directly on IdentityLink.

7. Through ATS, suppliers can ensure stable relationships with their customers and monetization of their traffic.

1. ATS enables IdentityLink to be directly tied to first-party identifiers so that publishers can own their first-party relationship with user and effectively make their inventory addressable to advertisers.

2. This enables publishers to build enduring business models independent of whims of Big Tech.

5. Data stewardship:

1. Consumer protection afforded by GDPR were accompanied by regulatory complexity that impacted many businesses.

2. Complexity is growing, with new regulation contemplated in many additional international markets, and many US state, and at federal level.

3. Data stewardship extends far beyond legislation.

4. Co. feels this is tremendous tailwind for RAMP, and has taken steps to ensure it provides value to ecosystem as safe trusted choice to enable companies to operate within legal and ethical parameters.

5. Co. is ensuring customers and partners are ready for regulatory change.

1. Preparing for GDPR, and being responsive to new rulings and interpretations of law, has prepared Co. really well for tackling CCPA-readiness.

6. Key areas of focus relating to CCPA-readiness:

1. Co. is updating privacy policies to ensure that California consumers understand and are informed about their rights under CCPA.

2. Reviewing contracts to ensure that all parties who interact with Co.'s network are transmitting data in privacy safe compliant manner.

3. Ensuring Co.'s products and systems recognize and support core stipulations of CCPA like perpetuating consumer opt-out downstream.

7. Co. is making it easier for ecosystem to collect and manage consumer permissions.

1. Faktor is core to effort, and its consent management platform for CCPA is set to launch later this fall.

8. Continues to serve as trusted safe haven across businesses.

1. Co. is often one of only companies that customers trust with access to their PII.

6. Innovation:

1. Increasingly, Co. sees customers collaborating with one another across RAMP's platform to create entirely new products.

2. Believes that by making products ever more modularized, Co. can unlock further innovation in ecosystem.

3. Neutral data safe haven for measurement:

1. Social media, premium publishers, search and other publisher platforms building ad-supported businesses need to be able to show ROI and enable granular optimization for advertisers.

2. Without RAMP's data connectivity, these platforms are limited to tracking only online or mobile conversions in their ROI analysis.

3. Across retail today, less than 11% of sales are online.

4. Over past couple of years, RAMP has been developing programs with publishers to bring in-store sales data from retailers safely and securely into these platforms to enable omni-channel measurement.

5. A few years ago, Co. had only handful of these programs.

6. Today, Co. enables store sales measurement into over 15 platforms and has over 50 clients leveraging one or more of these programs.

4. Modularization and seamless integration:

1. Co. is currently at tail-end of migration to Google Cloud Platform, which is critical step in scalability of its business.

2. Co. is laying groundwork today to execute on API platform strategies post migration to simplify internal platform and expose more functionality externally.

3. Many customers, both brands and platforms, are building their own identity graph, and they're looking for faster and easier ways to do identity translation within their own environment.

4. Through Co.'s efforts to modularize and expose more external API's, it is creating greater flexibility for customers to develop on top of its core identity and data connectivity capabilities.

1Q20 Financials (W.J.)

1. Highlights:

1. Business is strong, predictable and benefiting from multiple growth levers.

2. Total revenue up 32%; on normalized basis, up 39%.

1. Subscription revenue up 33%.

2. Total Co. run rate now $332m.

3. ARR approx. $240m; up more than 30% YoverY.

3. While Co. always has more to do, growth levers are working.

1. Land, expand and extend is fast becoming way of life.

2. Marketplace revenue up over 70%.

3. LiveRamp TV up approx. 30%.

4. Data Plus Math integration going extremely well.

5. B2B business up over 50%.

6. Dollar-based net retention 108%.

1. Sequential decline driven by lower upsell, bulk of which was driven by lapping of a few large customer upsells, and to lesser extent, non-regrettable churn.

7. Co. is enterprise SaaS, and serves enterprise needs of martech ecosystem.

4. Co. serves many of best brands in the world.

1. Added more than 25 net new subscription customers.

2. Currently has over 200 brands and platforms using Co.'s Data Store.

5. Subscription revenue 83% of total revenue.

1. Contributed more than 80% of total revenue since 1Q17, period in which Co. began reporting standalone results.

6. Product is differentiated and defensible.

1. Co. is middleware for customer experience economy.

2. Provides infrastructure from which ecosystem system delivers personalized, and innovative products and services.

7. Operationally, continued to tighten.

1. Product and operations:

1. Migration to Google Cloud is on track.

2. Working every day to drive higher levels of automation and innovation into platform.

2. Sales and marketing:

1. Standardizing and enhancing product offerings.

2. Working to shorten deal cycles, improve rep productivity and increase customer ROI.

3. Staff functions:

1. Largely completed build out of standalone capabilities.

4. Taken together, along with growing market opportunity, Co. is in strong position to be profitable in FY21.

8. Continued to appropriately balance investment in growth initiatives and acquisitions with returning capital to shareowners.

1. Closed Faktor acquisition and announced acquisition of Data Plus Math.

2. Since March 31, repurchased 1.4m shares for total consideration of $69m.

1. Since inception of program, repurchased over 35m shares for total consideration of more than $1b.

2. Results:

1. Closed Faktor acquisition for total consideration of approx. $5m.

2. Announced acquisition of Data Plus Math.

1. Total purchase price $150m, comprised of $120m in cash and $30m of time-based equity.

2. Deal is now closed, and should contribute approx. $5m of revenue in FY20 and $20m of revenue in FY21.

3. Opportunity increased Co.'s TAM by roughly $4b.

3. Implemented new lease standard.

1. Resulted in $23m [gross-up] in other assets and liabilities.

2. No income statement impact.

4. Capital allocation (better part of last eight years):

1. Co. is managing for long term, and future.

2. Includes appropriate investments in areas like TV, data sharing service and B2B.

3. Embedded in principle is stopping things that are not working or that are non-core.

1. Over past eight years, divested non-core assets generating roughly $2.1b in after-tax proceeds.

4. Seeks to take advantage of important and strategic acquisition opportunities.

1. Since FY12, focused acquisition capital on opportunities which leverage Co.'s core competencies.

5. Committed to appropriately returning capital to shareowners.

1. To-date, returned more than $1b to share owners.

3. FY20 Guidance:

1. Excludes items:

1. Non-cash stock comp.

2. Purchased intangible asset amortization.

3. Restructuring charges.

2. Revenue $363-377m; up 27-32%.

3. Non-GAAP operating loss $56-76m.

1. Includes approx. $13m in transition costs.

4. For 2Q:

1. Revenue up to $86m.

2. Operating loss approx. $25m; roughly $6m associated with transition spending.

3. Expects dollar-based net retention to be roughly 105% for remainder of FY.

4. Expects transition spending to be finished in 2Q.

5. On track to complete GCP migration before end of Sept.

6. 2Q should be high-watermark for operating loss, as Co. expects meaningful margin improvement in 3Q.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from Dan Salmon from BMO Capital Markets.

DANIEL SALMON, ANALYST, BMO CAPITAL MARKETS EQUITY RESEARCH: For Scott and Anneka and maybe Warren as well, just because I know you spent a lot of time on this as well, I just wanted to ask a little bit more about the International side of the business. We've continued to see the U.S. really power the results with the growth rate higher than the company overall. I know the International story is still an early one, but what are the sort of key checkpoints we should be looking for on that to see it accelerate?

And then Warren, a bit more specific for you. We see that you picked up the buyback, particularly in July. Obviously, you got past some milestones with some acquisitions and got visibility on it. Just curious if that contributed to the timing of picking up the pace in July. Or it's more you were saying something about the stock after a bit of a pullback. But lastly, would love to just to hear your updated thoughts on where you expect the pace of trends of the buyback to be in light of that elevation here lately.

WARREN C. JENSON, PRESIDENT, CFO & EXECUTIVE MD OF INTERNATIONAL, LIVERAMP HOLDINGS, INC.: Thanks Dan, this is Warren. I'm going to jump in on both the International and then the buyback. It's really been quite fascinating as we've gone through GDPR and then as we think about CCPA because I would say number one, having gone through GDPR the way we did over the past years has been incredibly beneficial. It's also been incredibly beneficial as we've even further hardened our routines internationally. So number one, this has been a big benefit to us, we believe in how we're approaching regulation in the U.S.

The second thing that I wanted to point out internationally is because of GDPR, I think we've also been incredibly innovative, and this will get to the pace of where are we focused and what -- where is International leading. And by the way, where we're leading internationally can also benefit the entirety of the company. I'd highlight 3 or 4 things that we are working on today that we think ultimately will cause us to hit the inflection point that you talked about, Dan.

Number one, what we are doing with transactional data. We have incredible partnerships with retailers, with grocers and others in both France and the U.K., that we are connecting with advertisers to where we can complete the whole entire measurement loop. This is working extremely well and will be something that we will continue to roll out across the company. So basically, connecting advertisers with actual transaction data. The second thing, which you've heard a lot about, is what we are doing on data sharing. The Carrefour platform is incredibly innovative. It has global attention. We have multiple tenants now up and running I believe on 4 -- over 4 continents.

Next, what's going on with Data Store. Obviously, overall and in terms of internationally, we had a great quarter with Data Store in marketplace. We think this will continue to benefit us internationally. And then finally, nothing per se this quarter that I wanted to talk about but you'll also see TV, I believe or we believe, become a material part of our overall International story. So a lot of things in the work -- a lot of things that are in the works, much more to come. We believe all very, very positive for us internationally.

And I guess finally, I'd put one other wrapper which also fits into our global story. Internationally, clients are turning to us for assistance. We've made a statement before that data-driven marketing is as important in Tokyo or Paris as it is in New York City, that is 100% the case.

Next, on the buyback. Just as we said in the prepared remarks, we believe we've really been walking the talk over a long period of time when it comes to capital allocation or returning capital to our shareowners. It's pretty interesting, when we were preparing that little analysis going back, when Scott started out here, we believe our market cap was somewhere around $800 million or $900 million, and we actually bought back more stock in our entire market cap since that period of time. And this quarter was another good example of that. We felt like there was an opportunity to be opportunistic. Therefore, we were in the market the way we were even after the quarter closed.

That said, we want to be consistent or we want to be appropriate and balance all of our different needs going forward. Therefore, our guidance remains the same. In the near term, we expect to be conservative in our approach just as we've outlined before. That said, depending upon the facts and circumstances, we will also, from time to time, continue to be opportunistic.

OPERATOR: Our next call -- question is from Kirk Materne from Evercore ISI.

STEWART KIRK MATERNE, SENIOR MD, EVERCORE ISI INSTITUTIONAL EQUITIES, RESEARCH DIVISION: Congrats on a good quarter. I was wondering maybe if Anneka could weigh in or Scott could weigh in just on -- when you look at to the back half of the year, given some of the changes Google is going through and CCPA, are the types of conversations you're having with customers getting -- are they longer? Meaning, are these things creating longer sales cycles? Or are customers kind of beyond that at this point in time? I just wanted to get some color around that just as we head in the back half of the year.

SCOTT E. HOWE, CEO & DIRECTOR, LIVERAMP HOLDINGS, INC.: Yes. I will tell you 2 things. Number one is we've had the benefit as Warren just mentioned of living through GDPR, and all of that experience is helping us prepare clients for CCPA and a flurry of other state and international, and hopefully someday, federal legislation. Most of the companies that we work with, enterprise companies, tend to have global businesses. So they too have been through this before. And as a result, a lot of the remediation that they perhaps had to do in Europe is going to parallel what they now have to do in the U.S.

And so we look at this as a tailwind for us in so much as it's really hard for all of our clients and partners, even the most sophisticated to stay up to speed on all of the changing regulations. That's the entirety of our business. And so now more than ever, we're being asked for our perspective on what we think, where we think things are going and importantly, what our clients and partners need to do to prepare for that future.

STEWART KIRK MATERNE: Okay. That's helpful. And maybe one for Warren, I'm going to sort of dovetail 2 together. Dollar-base retention you mentioned is right in line with your guidance of last quarter. What has to happen in the back half of the year to sort of do a little bit better than that 105% target? And I was just -- and actually, I just have one other follow-up, so why don't we just start there?

WARREN C. JENSON: Okay. You know what I'd like to do is I think it might be helpful for everyone for me just to reconcile from, call it, last quarter we were at 114% down to the 108% because what you will find, Kirk, is that the same drivers that drove it from 114% to 108% are the same drivers that are leading us to and get you to 105%.

SCOTT E. HOWE: Why don't you talk about reconciliation, and I'll jump in about what's next?

WARREN C. JENSON: Okay. Good. So within the concept of reconciliation, what we've done is -- and ask you to put up on top of your page, 115% and then we've divided sort of the reconciliation into 3 buckets. The first one is large deals, the second one is nonregrettable churn and then third is kind of all other.

So let me start with large deals. In the year ago quarter, and remember for everybody on the phone, dollar-based net retention is about a revenue cohort from a year ago. So what clients did you have a year ago generating what subscription revenue and how did that then translate to what you did in the current quarter. So in the year ago quarter, we had 3 large deals that materially contributed to upside, we were unable to repeat that performance with those large clients. That resulted in about 4 points of the decline. The second piece was nonregrettable churn, which we've also talked about. That was 1 point and everything else amounted -- everything else was 1 point. So 4, 1 and 1, 114% to 108%.

When we talk about the back half of the year, it's really more of the same, just as I mentioned in the prepared remarks. Again, I'm reconciling from 115% to 105%, about 6 points of that is large deals, about 2 points is nonregrettable churn and another 2 points is all other. Scott?

SCOTT E. HOWE: Yes. In terms, Kirk, of what we need to do to now increase it. The good news is there is no silver bullet here. It's all about execution. That's what sales is always about. And so it starts with the whole concept of just upselling, which is having conversations with all of our enterprise clients about what they are trying to accomplish, bringing them ideas. And those ideas and conversations then turn into product tweaks or new configurations, which then manifest themselves into our pipeline and then ultimately, into bookings. It's Sales 101.

Now as we generate those bookings, some of them you'll see in our net dollar retention. And that's going to be increases to our core subscription business, that upsell. Some of it, quite frankly, you won't see in our net dollar retention because it's going to go sit somewhere else in our P&L. So the things that we're doing, the things that drove, for instance, marketplace are many times with the existing book of business but those aren't factored into net dollar retention. So things like television or Data Store, which are a result of those upsell conversations won't actually show up in that dollar retention.

The second thing that we're doing which isn't a problem per se, but it's just an opportunity is really trying to manage churn or downsell from clients more effectively. So putting in place early indicators of when a client isn't having as much success and then getting back in front of those clients and evangelizing, educating them how to use our products and technologies such that they cannot not only avoid churn but actually fall into the upsell bucket. Again, not a problem for us but definitely an opportunity. As long as churn is above 0, we're never going to be happy with it.

And then the final thing that we're doing and I referenced a lot of this in my prepared remarks are really like just core accountability and sales management basics. Things like, as we've scaled our sales force, training, ensuring that we surround our core sellers with subject matter experts that can go in and help get a client across the line when they have questions. Or just ensuring -- and Anneka gave a couple of examples of this, the whole concept of partner alignments such that we're understanding what they are trying to do and tweaking our products such that the partners' products are more effective. And that's really the translation from sales to product. So the good news is all those things are underway. And I think they're all quite manageable.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Shyam Patil from Susquehanna.

SHYAM VASANT PATIL, SENIOR ANALYST, SUSQUEHANNA FINANCIAL GROUP, LLLP, RESEARCH DIVISION: Great quarter. I had a couple of questions. First one on CTV, can you talk a little bit more about how that business is ramping for you guys here in the U.S. as well as internationally? And then, just how you're thinking about Amazon opening up Fire TV, the third-party demand and just how LiveRamp fits into that?

And then second question for you, Warren, is when you look at the subscription revenue, can you talk about just how the direct revenue portion of that has been trending? And just kind of how you're thinking about that growth going forward?

SCOTT E. HOWE: Yes. So this is a Scott, and I'll start. In terms of television like our core television business, that's pre-Data Plus Math, grew around 30% for the quarter. And remember not all of the television efforts we do show up in television, it also draws a lot from Data Store, so some of it actually will sit there. But with the Data Plus Math acquisition, I will tell you that our expectations here really have skyrocketed. Our TAM has increased. And I really have to go back to our acquisition of LiveRamp to see clients as excited about a new offering in our portfolio as they're excited about Data Plus Math.

Virtually, all of our enterprise clients are doing some kind of television advertising, and we think that with Data Plus Math, it just makes them more effective at that television advertising. It extends what they might already be doing in search or display or e-mail, what have you. So we would expect that our television business for the remainder of the year is going to grow significantly, significantly faster than our baseline.

With respect to Amazon, 2 thoughts. Number one -- and both of them are good. Number one is, remember that we're one of the early partners of Amazon powering their DSP. We already have dozens of advertisers live with that. And our API, will -- goes live at the end of Q2 should make it even easier for advertisers to get on board there. So we have a really good relationship with Amazon. Moreover, we think that anything that drives awareness of advanced television of any sort is good for our business. Because remember, one of the things that LiveRamp does is we play across all of the elements of advanced television, whether it be connected television, OTT, data-driven linear, the full gamut. And so awareness in the industry means inquiries and opportunities for us.

WARREN C. JENSON: And then let me comment on the second part. And I'm going to answer the question really 2 ways. One, I'm going to talk about both our subscription revenue and then the variable part of subscription revenue, and then the second way is I'll talk about direct versus reseller.

So in terms of the variable piece of subscription, it's trending right where we thought it would be, right around 10%, 12% so kind of 11%, and we see that holding in strong. When it comes to direct versus reseller, both are up nicely. And in fact, we were hopeful, again, over the long term, to increase our reseller relationships because we increasingly see a number of the consulting firms or others very interested in partnering with us as they do their strategic work with their global clients.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Stan Zlotsky from Morgan Stanley.

STAN ZLOTSKY, VP, MORGAN STANLEY, RESEARCH DIVISION: Maybe just to start. So very strong Q1 results which is great, but then when we look through the deck, it looks like your revenue phasing for the rest of the year shifted more towards Q4 versus Q2. And also, the full year revenue guidance didn't move up despite a very strong beat in Q1. How should we think about the -- your outlook for the rest of the year? What you baked into your forward guidance and given the phasing that you are now seeing more towards Q4? And then I have a quick follow-up.

WARREN C. JENSON: Yes. I guess what I would say, first of all, obviously, we didn't change the full year. And let me come to that point first, Stan. We just think it's too early to change our full year outlook. If things change throughout the back part of the year and it warrants that we raise, we would, of course, do that. From our own internal perspective, yes, we had a solid beat materially, things have not really moved around in our own internal expectations relative to Q2, Q3 and/or Q4.

Our outlook, we continue to expect a very strong outlook for marketplace. I want to remind everybody that we are expecting a material step-up in revenue in Q3. That step-up is based about 50% of what's going on in marketplace, which we think is solid based on our current run rates and also what we expect to have happen in Q3. Our increasing subscription revenue, Q2 to Q3, is right in line with historical averages. And when we think about what we have actually committed today and in the books, well in line with historical -- well in line with historical standards.

Where we are feeling some pressure is on our subscription growth rates. And that has directly to do with the strength that we saw from these large clients in the back part of the year. That said, just as Scott did, we have a lot of growth levers, we're very optimistic about our long-term growth, but we are seeing some pressure in our subscription growth rates in the back part of the year.

STAN ZLOTSKY: Got it. And if I could just maybe go back to the discussion around the sales changes, I'm not saying -- about the adjustments that you're making as far as focusing your sales organization on net revenue retention rate. Could you maybe dive into that a little bit more, specifically around the strategy functions that you're adding about the upsell of analytics measurement, data lakes? And that's it for me.

SCOTT E. HOWE: Yes. I'd really talked about 2 changes and let me just say, this train has left the station and it has been rolling down the tracks for several years. So don't think that there's any huge strategic shifts here. This is just normal course of business. You've heard us talk before about the importance of education and evangelization. It is very difficult as a category creator going out and talking to large clients. We have to educate them around what we do, how to utilize our capabilities effectively. And so one of the things that we realized over time is that we have to surround our kind of account quarterbacks with subject matter experts. And that's increasingly true as we add more products into our portfolio.

So we have television subject matter experts, who can accompany the account owner to a meeting and help get those conversations across the line. Likewise, we spun up a group that's really focused more on measurement because the whole concept of measurement, the creation of data lakes, that's a deep subject matter expertise that not everyone in our organization has. And so there we have kind of a one to many selling relationships. Those subject matter experts work across much smaller group, works across our entire client portfolio.

The other thing that we talked about in my prepared remarks was the construct of sales excellence team. One of the things that we did, and this isn't just in sales but really throughout our business. When we went -- when we've sold the legacy Acxiom business, we've stood up LiveRamp as a public company, we really had to focus on how do we get a spotlight on everything that matters at our business. And so relative to a year or 2 ago, we have so much granularity in how we look at all the key levers of our business, the things we are measuring and tracking, the dashboards with which we can arm our teams. And so the sales excellence group was stood up really to help manage those dashboards and work across all of the sales teams to help them interpret their results, determine what to do about it and long term just manage their bulk of businesses more effectively.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Vasily Karasyov from Cannonball Research.

VASILY KARASYOV, FOUNDER, CANNONBALL RESEARCH, LLC: I wanted to go back to Data Plus Math and had a question about that and maybe Anneka can step in here too. So my question was trying to understand exactly the service and the TAM that the company has here. It would seem, and correct me if I'm wrong and I want to understand where I'm wrong, it seems like the service that they provide has to do more with direct response advertising, TV advertising, and which would imply that it's not necessarily applicable to all of the television advertising market. And so I'm assuming I'm not understanding entirely the suite of services they provide. So if you could correct me and tell me how it works with brand advertising on television, I would really appreciate that.

SCOTT E. HOWE: Yes. I would say a couple of things on this and Anneka can jump in here. Number one is it's not just for direct response advertising. It's really beneficial for accountable advertising. And in some cases, that could mean someone saw an ad and subsequently purchased, but in other cases, it's about they see an ad and visit a website. So there are opportunities to measure things that have historically been thought of as building awareness but doing it with accountability.

The second thing that our television business allows us to do is historically, traditional television has been bought on TRPs and GRPs, broad reach measures. But what we can now do is bring all of the more granular data. The more interesting data is someone in the market to purchase on the automobile in the Northeast, that tells us something far more interesting than just simply age and gender. And so even for brand advertisers to buy with those dials, it allows them to buy with much more precision than historically has been accessible to them.

OPERATOR: My apologies. I'd like to turn the call back over to Warren Jenson for closing remarks.

WARREN C. JENSON: Let me simply conclude again by thanking everyone for joining us today. And I'll close with just a few final thoughts. Again, thank you. We just finished a great quarter. Our business is strong. It's predictable. It's recurring. We are enterprise SaaS and we are Switzerland. We're pleased to have this call today with multiple growth levers in place. Our products are -- and services are in the sweet spot of martech and helping create billions of dollars in value for our customers. The great news is we have a clear path to profitability, ample liquidity to see us through our progression. And again, thank you. Our transformation at LiveRamp has only just begun.

OPERATOR: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

urn:contentItem:4D01-C3G0-01GN-63B7-00000-00Event Brief of Q2 2004 Dow Jones & Company Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final2004-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexisTranscript 071504ss.747Event Brief of Q2 2004 Dow Jones & Company Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Mark Donohue, Dow Jones & Company Inc., Director, IR . Peter Kann, Dow Jones & Company Inc., Chairman & CEO . Chris Vieth, Dow Jones & Company Inc., VP & CFO . Rich Zannino, Dow Jones & Company Inc., EVP & COO . Gordon Crovitz, Dow Jones & Company Inc., SVP, Dow Jones & President, Electronic Publishing . Karen House, Dow Jones & Company Inc., SVP, Dow Jones & Publisher, The Wall Street Journal

OVERVIEW

Excluding special items, DJ earned $0.41 per diluted share, which is up 52% from $0.27 per diluted share in 2Q03. DJ saw per issue linage at the Journal in April and May up around 7-8% while June was down 3.5%, which adds upto the 3.3% increase for 2Q04. DJ expects its excess cash flow to be about flat in 3Q04, returning sharply positive in 4Q04, which it will use to reduce its debt balance further. Q&A Focus: Electronic Publishing, US Journal, & rate increases.

FINANCIAL DATA

A. Key Data From Call 1. 2Q04 EPS before special items = $0.41. 2. YTD EPS before special items = $0.63. 3. 2Q04 revenue = $438m 4. 2Q04 OpEx = $382m. 5. 2Q04 CapEx = $15m.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY

S1. Opening Comments (P.K.) 1. Highlights: 1. DJ is pleased to be reporting EPS growth, as well as linage gains for the fourth quarter in a row. 2. Excluding special items, DJ earned $0.41 per diluted share, which is up 52% from $0.27 per diluted share in 2Q03. 3. DJ's strong operating leverage was evident once again as an 11% increase in revenue resulted in a 62% increase in operating income. 4. On the Electronic Publishing side, DJ had another strong quarter of revenue growth at Dow Jones Indexes and at Consumer Electronic Publishing. 5. Within its news wires businesses, the Co. successfully integrated its recent acquisitions of Alternative Investor Group and VWD. 6. DJ's community newspaper group, Ottaway continues to post strong revenue growth and profit, while maintaining one of the highest margins among its peers. 7. At its Print Publishing segment where revenue and profits also were up, color advertising continues to grow, up 22% in 2Q04, and up 32% for 1H04. 1. And that follows strong color ad growth of 28% in 2003 and 34% in 2002. 8. DJ has also continued to attract new advertisers. 9. Personal Journal ad linage is up more than 52% in 2004 and actually is approaching the healthy ad levels in the Co.'s very successful weekend Journal section. 10. DJ saw per issue linage at the Journal in April and May up around 7-8% while June was down 3.5%, which adds upto the 3.3% increase for 2Q04. 1. This month-to-month ad volatility has in turn been driven by inconsistent trends across major ad categories which the Co. sees continuing into 3Q04. 2. And even as DJ posts some positive gains, it is well aware that ad levels remain significantly below what it considers normal preboom, prebust levels. 11. During 2Q04, DJ was once again recognized for the quality of its products as the Wall Street Journal was honored with a number of global awards and Newswires won its second straight annual news provider of the year award from inside market data. 12. Dow Jones News plus, a 'Business Now' initiative won its first ever Cody award, and the online Journal brought home two more. 13. A few weeks ago, DJ did reach to a settlement with IAPE (Phonetic) that is the union that represents about 25% of DJ's employees, which includes many of the 'The Wall Street Journal' newspeople. 1. This agreement has the support and endorsement of the union's bargaining committee, its executive council, and Board of Directors. 2. It is going to go to the IAPE (Phonetic) membership for ratification shortly. 3. The tenant agreement represents a full and fair resolution of many difficult issues and that should enable DJ to devote its full attention, going forward to its publications, products, and customers.

S2. Financials (C.V.) 1. Highlights: 1. Before special items, 2Q04 EPS was $0.41, which is about the current First Call mean of $0.38 and 52% above 2Q03 earnings of $0.27 per share. 2. YTD through June, total revenue is up 12% and EPS before special items was $0.63 per share and 62% above 2Q03, as DJ continues to significantly leverage its cost reductions. 3. Total Co. revenue was in line with expectations of an 11% increase 2Q04, with increased revenues at Electronic Publishing and Ottaway offsetting slightly lower-than-expected advertising revenue at Print Publishing. 4. Lower OpEx across the portfolio drove the improved earnings performance vs. DJ's April guidance. 5. 2Q04 revenue increased to $438m, including roughly 3.5% of the increase from its recent acquisitions, Stockton, Technologic Partner, Alternative Investor Group, and VWD. 1. This is the last quarter that the Co. will report Stockton results separately as an acquisition, as it has now anniversaried its May 2003 purchase of the property. 6. 2Q04 OpEx of $382m were up roughly 6% over 2Q03 before special items and better than DJ's April guidance of an 8% increase, as it continues to tightly control expenses at all business units. 1. This includes: 1. Approx. 3% related to the Co.'s recent acquisitions. 2. Less than 1% for increased news print expenses. 3. 1% associated with the increase of foreign currency costs. 2. All other expenses were up only 2% over 2Q03, including a $2m charge for a small workforce reduction and circulation distribution of the Journal, part of the Co.'s 'Business Now' priority to improve circulation efficiency. 3. Nearly offsetting this charge was a nontaxable benefit of roughly $1.5m relating to accounting for the Medicare Prescription Drug Act. 4. DJ will save a similar amount in 2H04 as a result of that charge. 7. 2Q04 ending headcount, totaled about 7,150. 1. Excluding employees associated with DJ's acquisitions, comparable headcount was down 2% from 2Q03. 2. Other Key Figures: 1. Total newsprint cost in 2Q04 were up a little more than 5% with consumption down 2%, and DJ's avg. cost per ton up about 8% vs. 2Q03 levels. 1. DJ is staying at roughly $30 per ton after the Feb. price increase took hold by the time it was all said and done. 2. And as DJ has done in the past, it also used inventory where possible to mitigate some of the impact. 3. The Co.'s internal forecast also anticipates a late-summer price increase that follows the path of last year's, that is it takes a few months to stick, and when it does, not at the full announced rate. 2. Before special items, DJ's expected tax rate was 40.9% for 2Q04, and is expected to come in around 41% for the year. 3. CapEx totaled $15m in 2Q04 vs. $12m in 2Q03. 4. DJ continues to tightly manage working capital and cash flow items and cash flow and balance sheet remains strong. 5. After CapEx, dividends, investments, and all other outflows, DJ used $33m of excess cash flow plus $11m of cash to reduce its debt by another $44m in 2Q04. 6. DJ closed 2Q04 with debt of $215m, vs. a debt level of $210m in 2Q03, and $258m at the end of 1Q04. 3. Outlook: 1. With a seasonally low 3Q of ad volume at the Journal, DJ expects its excess cash flow to be about flat in 3Q04, returning sharply positive in 4Q04, which it will use to reduce its debt balance further.

S3. Detailed Financials (R.Z.) 1. In Detail: 1. In 2Q04, DJ posted significant gains in revenue, earnings, and margins in each of its 3 business segments. 1. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of such gains. 2. DJ has also posted increased advertising linage at 'The Wall Street Journal' for the past 4 consecutive quarters. 1. As a result, over these past 4 quarters: 1. Revenue is up 9%. 2. Operating income is up 53%. 3. EPS before special items is up 52%. 3. DJ's Print Publishing ad volumes and its overall earnings are being constrained by the cyclically soft B-to-B ad environment and are well below what the Co. considers normal levels. 2. IAPE Contract 1. IAPE represents about 1600 of DJ's employees including those in news, advertising sales, technology, circulation, and administrative areas. 2. These folks have been working without a contract since April 2003, and after much negotiation, DJ has agreed to pay them wage increases of: 1. 0% in 2003. 2. 2.5% in 2004. 3. 3.25% in 2005. 4. 3.5% in 2006. 3. Also, DJ will make lump sum payments totaling $2,000 to each IAPE employee. 4. In addition, IAPE members will be subject to the Co.'s new medical plan effective on 01/01/05. 1. This new plan, which other DJ employees enrolled and effective 01/01/04, incorporates design changes aimed at reducing cost for both employees and the Co., and for the first time requires employees to contribute to monthly medical premiums. 5. DJ believes that this settlement is fair to both IAPE members and its shareholders. 6. Taken together, the lump sum payments and wage increases are in line with those settled at other publishers. 7. The new medical plan, while still very generous by competitive standards, will help slow the rapid escalation in Co.'s medical costs. 8. Taken together, these items enable DJ to continue to control cost in this still uncertain revenue environment. 1. The Co. will incur one-time cost of about $4m in 3Q04 and $2m in 4Q04 for the lump sum payments, after adding in an additional $1,000 payment for each nonIAPE, nonmanagement employee to keep them whole with IAPE members. 9. With all IAPE and nonIAPE employees now subject to the new medical plan, DJ expects to save nearly $9m annually in medical and retiree health costs. 10. The agreement is subject to a ratification vote by the IAPE membership, and the Co. hopes to have the whole process wrapped up in the next 6 weeks or so. 3. Print Publishing: 1. Print Publishing's total revenue is up 8% from 2Q03. 2. Operating income more than tripled to $17m and margins grew to 6.8%. 3. DJ said that in an improving ad environment, about $0.80 of every new dollar of Journal advertising revenue flows through to the bottom line. 1. This flow-through was 60% in 2Q04, but adjusting for increased newsprint prices and foreign currency costs, this flow-through was 78%, very close to DJ's 80% target. 4. Making similar adjustments for the full year, DJ expects to hit its 80% target for the full year. 5. DJ saw continued volatility in monthly comps at the US Journal with per issue linage in April and May, each up around 7%, and in June, down 3.5%. 1. This led to an increase of 3.3% in ad linage at the US Journal for 2Q04. 6. While financial advertising has been relatively strong through 1H04, unfortunately, technology advertising has been weak. 1. Financial advertising increased 5.3% in 2Q04 as strong wholesale advertising more than offset weakness in tombstone and retail financial advertising. 1. This was the third consecutive quarter of increases in financial advertising volume and DJ is cautiously optimistic that it will strengthen a bit in 2H04 with continued strength in wholesale and improved trends in tombstone and in retail ads. 2. Technology linage was down 28% in 2Q04. 3. During 2H04, particularly in 3Q04, DJ is expecting technology ad spending to remain weak due to a combination of tough comps in 2H03 and cutbacks in ad budgets at many large B-to-B tech companies driven by their spotty profit growth and uncertain outlook for global technology spending. 7. In the Journal's general advertising category, linage was up 15% in 2Q04 on strong increases in professional services, insurance, luxury, travel, and healthcare advertising categories. 8. Auto was down a modest 4% in 2Q04. 1. However, DJ expects the auto category to rebound in 2H04 as comp fees, and the Co. sees a number of new vehicles and incentive programs launch in the fall. 9. The Journal posted an 11% increase in classified and other linage in 2Q04, driven by strong increases in real estate, recruitment, and other classified advertising. 1. Looking beyond linage to ad revenue, DJ is pleased that for the fourth consecutive quarter, ad revenue gains at the Journal significantly outpaced linage gains. 2. In 2Q04, DJ posted a 9.5% increase in advertising revenue at the Journal on a 3.3% increase in ad linage. 10. Today's Journal continues to drive positive results. 1. The expanded color capacity in Today's Journal drove a 22% increase in color ad pages and 32% increase in color ad revenue during 2Q04. 2. The Co. is averaging roughly 8 full color page equivalents per day out of its total color advertising capacity of upto 20 pages per day. 3. Color pages have nearly doubled since the Co. increased color capacity at the end of 2001. 4. DJ is also using Today's Journal in its new Personal Journal section to expand consumer advertising, to reduce its reliance on financial and tech advertising. 11. DJ's targeted consumer categories of auto, travel, healthcare, and luxury consumer goods showed linage gains of 8% and revenue gains of 13% during 2Q04. 1. Ad revenue in these categories is up about 24% since the end of 2001. 12. Elsewhere in Print Publishing, at the Asian and European editions of the Journal, total advertising linage increased 6% per issue in 2Q04 on strength in nearly all categories offset by weakness in tech advertising. 13. At Barron's, ad pages increased a healthy 21% in 2Q04 driven by very strong financial and auto advertising. 4. Electronic Publishing: 1. DJ continues to improve its profits and industry-leading margins. 2. 2Q04 revenue was up 20%. 3. Operating income was up 43%. 4. Operating margins were up 370 BP to 23.8% over 2Q03. 5. Excluding acquisitions: 1. Revenue was up 7%. 2. Operating income was up 29%. 3. Margins were up 430 BP, driven by strong revenue and profit performance at both Consumer Electronic Publishing and Dow Jones Indexes. 6. At Newswires, revenue was up 21% driven by the recent acquisitions of Tech Partners, Alternative Investors Group, and VWD. 1. The integration of these acquisitions is going as planned and the Co. is on track to meet its profit projections. 2. Revenue in Newswires core business was about flat during 2Q04. 7. At Consumer Electronic Publishing, 2Q04 revenue was up 13%, driven by a 35% increase in online advertising revenue and 4.5% increase in circulation revenue. 1. Subscribers at the end of 2Q04 were 684,000, up 2% over 2Q03, and down slightly from 1Q04. 2. Importantly, usage of the Co.'s paid site, WSJ.com as measured by unique visitors was up 13% during 2Q04. 8. At Ottaway 2Q04: 1. Revenue was up 11%. 2. Operating income was up 17%. 3. Operating margins were up 160 BP to 28.7% over 2Q03. 4. Revenue gains were driven by the May 2003 acquisition of the Stockton Record and same property revenue growth of 6.4%, which in turn, was driven by a 5.5% increase in ad linage in 2Q04 with strong auto and real estate classified linage. 5. Same property operating income at Ottaway was up 13% over 2Q03. 5. 3Q04 Outlook: 1. For 3Q04, recent trends appear likely to continue. 2. While DJ expects continued gains in financial wholesale, general B-to-B, consumer and classified advertising, and expects improved trends in auto, tombstone, and financial retail advertising, much of this is likely to be offset by weakness in technology advertising, as well as in travel advertising, as the Co. is up against very difficult post-war comps and travel ad. 3. By month, DJ expects per issue linage comps at the Journal to be down slightly in the slow summer months of July and Aug., followed by a nice gain in the busier month of Sept., all leading to 3Q04 linage up in the low single-digit range. 4. Together with continued strong gains elsewhere in the portfolio, this leverage of level of linage gain will result in 8% increase in total revenue for 3Q04. 5. On the expense line, DJ will continue to hold on to the vast majority of its cost reductions. 1. The Co. expects total operating expenses to be up about 6% in 3Q04. 2. Of this, about 4% is due to expenses for its: 1. Recent acquisitions. 2. Increased newsprint and foreign currency cost. 3. The lump sum payment related to its tentative labor contract settlement. 6. This leaves comparable expenses up only 2% over 2Q04. 7. The net of all of this is an EPS estimate before special items of about $0.20 per share for 3Q04, and this is after deducting about $0.03 per share for the lump sum payment related to DJ's tentative labor contract. 1. This is up from $0.14 per share in 2Q03. 6. Summary: 1. In 2Q04, DJ improved revenue profit margins virtually everywhere in its portfolio. 2. At Electronic Publishing and Ottaway, DJ increased its margins, which were already near the top of their peer groups. 3. At Print Publishing, the Co. got another strong glimpse of how highly leveraged its earnings growth is to an improving ad environment. 4. Going forward, DJ will continue to control everything it can to maximize its upside as the ad environment continues to improve.

QUESTION AND ANSWER SUMMARY

Q1. What is the organic revenue and operating income growth for the Electronic Publishing segment in 2Q04? (Peter Appert - Goldman Sachs)

A. (Rich Zannino) If you exclude acquisitions, revenue was up 7%, operating income was up 29%, and margins were up 430 BP to 24.4%.

Q2. And the primary driver of the margin gain is just the inherent operating leverage in the business model? (Peter Appert - Goldman Sachs)

A. (Rich Zannino) Absolutely.

Q3. Anything specific in terms of price adjustments or particular units within Electronic Publishing that is driving that margin gain? (Peter Appert - Goldman Sachs)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) I would encourage you to take a look at the leverage now that we are seeing in our online operations where the advertising increase of some 35% has continued pretty nicely. Our Dow Jones Indexes business also has very significant revenue increases and that has become a very significant margin business.

Q4. What do you think a normalized level of margin for Electronic Publishing business might be over the next couple of years? (Peter Appert - Goldman Sachs)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) I think, as Rich said, we are already toward the very top of our peer group. So, I wouldn't want to suggest that it can go a lot higher than now. We are very focused on growing the topline while maintaining these kinds of margins.

Q5. The Print Publishing business has been unprofitable for the last several years in the third quarters, is the revenue momentum you are seeing currently sufficient to get you to profitability in 3Q04? (Peter Appert - Goldman Sachs)

A. (Rich Zannino) We are going to look at that.

Q6. Specifically on tombstone advertising, why is it not better and is there somewhat of a secular change here where in a more regulatory scrutinized environment, investment banks are hesitant to take out big ads announcing deals, or is this a function of deal size? (Douglas Arthur - Morgan Stanley)

A. (Rich Zannino) First of all, pure tombstone's new issue advertising represents about 5-6% of total Wall Street Journal linage depending on the year. So, while it is a meaningful category, it is nowhere near as large and as meaningful as some of the other financial categories or as some of the tech categories or even auto. To put it in perspective, it is about the same size as our travel and professional services advertising categories. So, that gives you some dimension on our exposure to tombstone advertising. Having said that, tombstone advertising, we believe, is a function of 4 factors. Deal flow and we all see that getting much stronger. Deal size, and while deals are getting bigger, most of them are still pretty small. Deal performance would be a third factor, and deal performance has been a bit sketchy here so far this year. I think 34 out of 100 deals that have gone off this year are underperforming their offer price, their IPO price. And then finally, there has been a moratorium on the part of some of the major investment banks against running tombstone ads. So, we think those are the 4 factors that drive tombstone advertising, that are driving it in the current environment. I have not heard anything so far about the regulatory environment constraining banks in running tombstone. I think some of the larger banks have basically questioned the value of a tombstone ad, and we have lots of research that we share with them, and more and more now with the issuers on the value of tombstone ads and the value is significant. Since the people look at them, they act on them, they call the banks, and they are called to action for people to do things with the banks. So, we think research supports the value of a tombstone ad. To put other numbers against all of that, so far this year, there have been 100 IPOs priced. We have received tombstones on 22 of those so far. About 40 from the so-called moratorium banks, and the remaining 38, we'll get some of those, but many of them are too small and are underperforming. Again, 34 out of the 100 are underperforming, so we won't get those. The good news is we see the calendar strengthening in the balance of the year. We see the banks that are doing the deals. We think we are going to see increased momentum in the back half of the year and get back into positive territory again like we were in 1Q04, on tombstone advertising. Of course, nobody else is getting these tombstones. They are not going anywhere else. The Journal still has 100% market share for tombstone. And so, I think there is another 200 or so deals in the pipeline for the balance of the year, and we will get our share of those, but I think, summing that all up, it is a relatively small category. It is not all going away. We are working hard to get as many tombstones as we can by going directly to issuers with our research and to the banks with our research, and given the pipeline going forward, and the pipeline does have a few very large deals, not the least of which is google going forward. So, going forward, we think we will see positive comps again in the category.

A. (Chris Vieth) Answering Peter Appert's earlier call, Print Publishing's operating income was a negative $11.5m last year. We will make significant progress against that this year and reduce it, but it will still be negative in 3Q04.

A. (Rich Zannino) And, of course, the US Journal will be profitable in 3Q04 as it was in 3Q03.

Q7. Could you remind us what color ad is of the percentage of total Journal? You talked about low single-digit linage in the 3Q04, obviously, we saw low single in 2Q04, can we expect, I guess, a similar yield off of that linage in 3Q04 as we saw in 2Q04? Could you tell us what tech spending was up online? We saw a pretty a strong growth from CNET yesterday, and I am just wondering if the online trends are mirroring the offline and tech spending. (Christa Sober - Thomas Weisel Partners)

A. (Rich Zannino) Color represents about 30% of our total linage, and it would be a higher percentage of our total revenue, because color, a full-page sells at 27% premium to black and white and half page sells at 37% premium to black and white, but we always talk linage. So, it is about 30% of total Journal linage. As far as yield, we hope to be able to continue to have revenue growth in excess of linage growth and advertising, and would hope to see, might not be 6% in 3Q04 in terms of the spread between linage growth and revenue growth, but we would hope it would be in the 4-5% range. It will depend somewhat on mix ultimately, the mix between classified and display advertising. But color should drive it, and our new rate card should drive it, and favorable mix in some of our other categories should definitely continue to help it.

A. (Gordon Crovitz) In terms of online advertising, as you mentioned the advertising in total increased 35%. Display advertising was up 37%. Technology and financial, those two categories really dominate the online categories. Technology spending was in line with the overall percentage increase that we saw in 2Q04.

Q8. Could you give us how the yield looked in 3Q, the mix between price and color and the components, and then also, the deceleration that happened in Consumer Electronic Publishing in 2Q vs. 1Q, where that came from? Just wanted to get the mix of the yield, your 6% yield improvement in 2Q, can you break down that and its components? (Paul Ginocchio - Deutsche Bank)

A. (Rich Zannino) Between how much was driven by color vs. how much was driven by rate?

Q9. By rate increase and then the mix relative to 1Q where it was 10%? (Paul Ginocchio - Deutsche Bank)

A. (Rich Zannino) Well in 1Q, it was certainly driven more by mix, because in 1Q, display advertising, I think was actually very close to classified advertising. And in 2Q, our display advertising was up low single digits, and our classified advertising was up 11%. So, classified runs at a much lower ad rate, line rate than display. So, that would explain the difference between 1Q and 2Q, just the heavier proportion in the mix of classified in 2Q.

Q10. The deceleration of CEP, what was the driver of that from 1Q, the 13% YonY revenue growth in CEP in 2Q vs. the 18% in 1Q? (Paul Ginocchio - Deutsche Bank)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) Part of that is the fact that the subscriber is paying the full new price increase over time. Obviously, a higher percentage of them are doing that. Two-thirds of the revenue from the online Journal is from subscriptions and so, even as we see very large increases in advertising revenue, the subscription revenue tends to move more in line with volume.

Q11. Refresh my memory, what was the advertising for CEP in 1Q? (Paul Ginocchio - Deutsche Bank)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) It was in line with 2Q04, in the mid-30s.

Q12. Could we just go over the technology outlook for 2H04 again? I was under the impression that it was going to improve and I am wondering if something has changed from earlier calls and it sounds like maybe you are basing it again on some of the profit reports that have come out which would make sense. Could you just give us a sense of what you were paying in newsprint per ton in 2Q04 and the timing of when you might have paid an increase in 2Q04, and what do you expect to happen in 2H04? (Lauren Fine - Merrill Lynch)

A. (Chris Vieth) The newsprint price increase that was announced on Feb. 1 came in slowly. Some suppliers raised and put through the price increase on invoices right away, others didn't. We also used inventory to buy around some of the price increases. So, by the time it was all said and done at the end of 2Q04, we were up about $30 a ton. Traditionally, we have steered away from actually quoting the price per ton that we pay, but what we have said is that for the year, we expect newsprint expenses to be up about 11% over last year, and we expect newsprint price increase in the late summer to follow the trends of what they did last year, and all of that has remained constant with our guidance from the beginning of the year. So, we are pretty much consistent with what our expectations are.

A. (Rich Zannino) On your tech question, I would just like to clarify the way you started it. We actually said in 1Q04 that we expected tech to be soft for the balance of the year. You might be confusing us with another large daily newspaper, projecting it to be up in 2H04. But, our tech category includes tech and telecom in that category. We were up against pretty tough comps in 2H03. We were up about 13% in 2H03. So, we were up against that. We are also seeing some of the big tech guys cut back on their budgets. I mean you read in the last week or so, Microsoft saying they want to cut $1b in expense, and to do it without cutting headcount. And my guess is they are not going to cut R&D either. So, I think we are up against tough comps. People are cutting their budgets, because they are not seeing the profit growth that they want to see. They are also a little bit skittish given what people have been saying lately about future plans for capital spending on technology products. So, I think they are being cautious. Having said that, we think 3Q04 will be a much tougher quarter than 4Q04. We think we will see an improvement in trend during 4Q04, just based on some of the RFPs that are out there and some indications we are getting from some of the big tech spenders in terms of their plans for 4Q04. So, while we are saying 2H04 will be weak, we are predicting it to be much weaker in 3Q04 and then to come back somewhat in 4Q04.

Q13. In terms of global ad sales across the properties, could you give us an update on how that's going? (Lauren Fine - Merrill Lynch)

A. (Karen House) Our global advertising revenues continue to grow.

Q14. Would you say it is meeting your expectations? (Lauren Fine - Merrill Lynch)

A. (Karen House) It has actually exceeded budget this year. So, it is exceeding our expectations.

A. (Chris Vieth) We actually saw a nice improvement in ad yield in our international publications as well as this year driven in large part by the global rate program and the rate increase we put in this year to the global rate programs.

A. (Karen House) And we are growing in share in both Europe and Asia, which is obviously pleasing.

Q15. Could you actually refresh our memory on what you guys raised on the global rate and on the US Journal? (Lauren Fine - Merrill Lynch)

A. (Karen House) We raised the rate for the overseas publication, 25%.

A. (Rich Zannino) We put through roughly a 5% global rate increase, but we gave the entire 5% we are crediting to the international pubs as it should be, because they took the discount when we originally put the global rate in. So, it represents about a 25% increase in ad rates for the international publications in terms of their share of that new higher global rate. And then in the US, we put through on the rate card a 3% rate increase, but we also made some other changes to the rate card, which we hoped and, in fact, it has materialized, would drive a higher than 3% increase in yield.

A. (Peter Kann) We increased the price of color premium as well.

A. (Rich Zannino) The color premium went from 25% to 27% on a full page and from 35% to 37% on a half page.

Q16. Can you give us the annual run rate of your newsletter 'Business Now' with the acquisitions? Some of your other peers have really stepped up here recently to increase their share buybacks substantially, I was wondering what are your plans on upfront, given that your stock has pulled back? (Craig A. Huber - Lehman Brothers)

A. (Chris Vieth) With regard to share buyback, for at least the next few quarters, we will continue to direct excess cash flow to reduce our commercial paper balance, which, as I said earlier, is now down to about $215m. In the past, we have utilized share repurchase when conditions were right. That is, when we have had excess cash flow and debt capacity, when our shares are trading below their intrinsic value, when the ROI shares exceed that of alternate uses of the capital, and when we have had board authorization to repurchase shares. All of these conditions exist today except for our debt and we are making good progress here down another $44m in 3Q04. In the future, when all of these conditions are met, we could be back in the market again, but for now we are directing our cast to pay down our debt levels.

A. (Gordon Crovitz) About newsletters, we created a new division within Dow Jones Newswires as a result of our acquisition of Alternative Investor and Tech Partners last year. Our financial information services that include newsletters, databases, and events, that will have revenues. Revenues this year is in the mid-20s. I might think about this more broadly, which is about a third of all of our revenues for Dow Jones Newswires this year will be from products or sales channels we didn't have a few years ago that are not dependent on traditional market data terminals, I suppose this is another reason why there is a growing gap between the terminal count and revenue lines. We have a financial information services division, local language, wires around the world, local web site revenues, many other sources, which is why we are no longer nearly so dependent on headcount trends among our customers.

Q17. Factiva had a very healthy pickup in operating income in 2Q04, do you expect that to continue here or is it a one off? (Craig A. Huber - Lehman Brothers)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) We are very pleased with the performance of Factiva and its continued success in its market. Its operating income tripled to almost $9m. Part of that was driven by a one-time cost reduction associated with finalization of the migration this time last year to Factiva-related products, that is the (Indiscernible) of Dow Jones Interactive and Reuters Business Briefing products. Revenue growth has been sharp and consistent every month since that migration ended. The sales team at Factiva has been able to focus on net new installations rather than upgrades, and we have had net new installations in positive territory every month since Aug. 2003. So, I think you will continue to see performance improvement at Factiva. I don't think we will necessarily see operating income increases in this range every quarter, but it is a very solid business, making very strong gains in its market.

Q18. What would be the annual number for the equity line for 2004? I believe you've had a price increase on home delivery of the 'The Wall Street Journal.' I wanted to see how that is impacting your copies at this point. I mean subscription price increase? (Steven Barlow - Prudential Equity Group)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) That went in April 1, so it is too early to tell in terms of getting a reaction. But retention rates are up. Conversion rates are up. And acquisition rates are up in circulation at the Journal, but it is too early to tell the impact, I think it was $10 price increase that went into effect on April 1.

A. (Chris Vieth) As far as equity investments for the year, we haven't given guidance for 4Q04 yet, but we expect it to be modestly better than last year at this point. It will be above last year.

Q19. On the stock buyback question, where do you want your leverage to go down to? Your leverage isn't all that high to start with, and you are sort of suggesting that condition has not been met yet. (Steven Barlow - Prudential Equity Group)

A. (Chris Vieth) Our internal target, what we are shooting for right now as far as I think about it from a debt-level perspective, is about, we would like to get it down to $100m. We've had it, last year it was down to $93m and in years' past it had averaged around $150m. As you saw S&P dropped us the notch last quarter largely on the kind of volatility we have had in Print Publishing advertising revenues. So, those credit metrics are important us to and we are going to continue to dedicate our cash flow to drive down that debt level for the near term, at least the next few quarters.

Q20. On the union issue, just wondering if there are any other contracts over the near term, near-to-intermediate term with any other unions that are up for renewal? I If you look out for the full year based on the current trend lines, how big WSJ.com will be this year in terms of revenue in any margin contribution you can speak to? On the tech advertising, to try to put it in a bit more perspective, could you give us what your best guess is at the dollar run rate right now? Where was that maybe a year ago, and then where that was at the peak just for the tech category or the way you look at it, maybe tech and telecom? (William Drewry - CSFB)

A. (Rich Zannino) On the first question, the IAPE contract is far and away the most significant labor contract, and there aren't any others like that, sitting out there open.

A. (Gordon Crovitz) The online Journal, we have had strong double-digit revenue gains so far this year. We would expect that to continue for the full year as well. In terms of operating income, we don't break it down quite that way. But I would say, several million dollars worth of operating income from the online journal, and a margin that, as you know, has turned positive, and we think has got potential margin that may be closer in its dynamics to additional (Phonetic) publishing business then necessarily to advertising driven business in, as much as subscription revenues continue to be a significant part of its revenue base.

Q21. Could you just compare it either in dollar amount or either percentage terms to the print Journal, just revenue? (William Drewry - CSFB)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) The question is the percentage of revenue for the online Journal vs. the...?

Q22. Or give us the dollar volume. How much do you think it will do this year, $75m, $100m? (William Drewry - CSFB)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) I think, rather than giving a precise number, I would say it is in the range of the lower amount you just asked about.

Q23. And tech dollars? (William Drewry - CSFB)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) The run rate of technology this year compared to where it was in 2000, which was just obviously an enormous boom year, our technology linage is about a third of what it was in 2000. And, it is obviously below where it was and what we consider to be the more normal year of '98, it is probably somewhere around half of what it was in 1998. That's linage. So, the spread between revenue in those years will be a little tighter, but, that's the linage picture. We have got tremendous upside in technology linage.

Q24. That would just be tighter because you put through price increases since the peak? (William Drewry - CSFB)

A. (Gordon Crovitz) Exactly.
