urn:contentItem:53HF-88G1-DYG3-149S-00000-00Event Brief of Q2 2011 NYSE Euronext Earnings Conference Call - Final2011-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis080211sr.737Event Brief of Q2 2011 NYSE EuronextEarnings Conference Call - Final

PARTICIPANTS

. Stephen Davidson, NYSE Euronext, IR . Michael Geltzeiler, NYSE Euronext, Group EVP & CFO . Tom Callahan, NYSE Euronext, CEO, NYSE Liffe US . Duncan Niederauer, NYSE Euronext, CEO . Roger Freeman, Barclays Capital, Analyst . Rich Repetto, Sandler O'Neill, Analyst . Alex Kramm, UBS, Analyst . Patrick O'Shaughnessy, Raymond James, Analyst . Johannes Thormann, HSBC, Analyst . Howard Chen, Credit Suisse, Analyst . Daniel Harris, Goldman Sachs, Analyst . Dominique Cerutti, NYSE Euronext, President & Deputy CEO . Larry Leibowitz, NYSE Euronext, COO . Niamh Alexander, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Analyst . Chris Harris, Wells Fargo Securities, Analyst

OVERVIEW

NYX reported 2Q11 net revenue of$661,m 1H11 EPS of $1.28 and 2Q11 EPS of $0.61.

FINANCIAL DATA

A. Key Data From Call 1. 2Q11 net revenue =$661.m 2. 1H11 EPS = $1.28. 3. 2Q11 EPS = $0.61. 4. YTD CapEx =$67.m 5. 2Q11 CapEx =$31.

PRESENTATIONm SUMMARY

S1. 2Q11 Financial & Segment Review (M.G.) 1. Overview: 1. 2Q11 results characterized by increasing revenue diversification, disciplined cost control and strong capital management. 2. EPS of $0.61 on net revenue of$661.m 1. Down from $0.64 per share on$654m in net revenue in 2Q10. 2. 2Q10 trading volume benefited from strong spike in volatility from advent of sovereign debt crisis in Europe, and flash crash in US. 3. Strong non-volume-related revenue combined with weakening of dollar YoverY increased net revenue by$51,m helping to more than offset impact of declines in trading volumes across most venues. 4. Technology Services: 1. Increased revenue by 14%. 2. Operating margins 30%. 5. Expense: 1. Cost managing discipline. 2. Increased$12m or 3% to$419.m 3. On constant currency and portfolio basis, declined 3% or$14m vs. 2Q10. 6. Global headcount below 3,000, despite completing several smaller deals since middle of last year, including acquisition of Corporate Board Member and JV with APX to create NYSE Blue. 7. With strong free cash flow, retired$200m in commercial paper which reduced debt-to-EBITDA leverage ratio to 1.7 times, lowest level since merger of NYSE and Euronext. 1. Significant contributor to free cash flow has been CapEx reduction, which was$31m in 2Q, down from$70m in prior-year period. 8. Solid results YoverY against backdrop of avg. 17% decline in trading volumes across four primary venues. 2. Comparative GAAP Results: 1. Net income and EPS below prior-year, but in line with 1Q11. 2. 2Q10 results benefited from net$54m pretax gain from disposal activity, principally sale of 5% stake in National Stock Exchange of India. 3. This qtr., reported$18m charge for merger expenses and exit costs, which included$12m related to pending business combination. 1. YTD, total of$27m spent on pending merger. 3. Note: 1. Review of financial results from this point forward will exclude impact of merger expenses and exit costs, gains from disposal activities and discrete tax items. 4. Financial Results For 2Q11 & YTD: 1. 2Q11 diluted EPS $0.61. 1. Down 5% vs. prior-year's $0.64. 2. Below $0.68 in 1Q11. 2. 1H11 EPS $1.28. 1. Up 9% vs. prior-year. 3. Volumes decreased dramatically last year following 2Q volatility. 1. Believes presents favorable backdrop for 2H growth as lower volume comparables will accompany continued strength in non-volume based revenues. 4. On June 29, closed sale of 52.8% stake in NYSE Amex Options business. 1. For 2Q11, reported 100% of profits from business. 2. Had transaction closed on April 1 of 2Q, diluted EPS for 2Q would have been $0.02 lower. 3. Transaction provides facility for partners to require Co. to purchase portion of investment at specific intervals over five-year period. 4. Expects to repurchase 10% of partner's stake in 3Q. 5. Increased market share from about 6% at time Co. acquired American Stock Exchange to 15% at 2Q-end. 5. Diluted share count increased to 263m shares in 2Q due to issuance of approx. 340,000 shares, to former Amex members, in connection with sale of former American Stock Exchange headquarters. 5. Consolidated & Segment Results - Currency-Neutral: 1. US dollar weakened this qtr. vs. prior-year for both euro and pound. 2. For 2Q, 49% of net revenue denominated in either euros or pounds, and 51% in US dollars. 3. Currency impact on net revenue favorable: 1.$33m vs. prior-year. 2.$11m vs. prior qtr. 4. Currency-neutral: 1. Net revenues down 4% and operating income declined 9% vs. 2Q10. 5. Operationally, revenues for Derivatives and Cash Trading and Listings segment down 12% and 2%, respectively, and Technology segment grew 9% vs. 2Q10. 6. Positive Impact Of Non-Volume-Related Revenue: 1. Reflects increasing diversification of model. 2.$18m in incremental net revenue generated by non-volume-related activities dampened impact of lower trading volumes across most venues. 3. 2Q10 trading volume benefited from much higher levels of volatility driven by sovereign debt crisis and flash crash. 1. Incremental revenue came from variety of streams including Technology Services, Listings and other revenues like Corporate Board Member and NYSE Blue. 4. When trading volumes return to more historical norms, will get full benefit of diversification efforts which helped Co. weather down volume cycles. 5. July volumes already showing more favorable trend. 6. NYSE Euronextvolumes for US Options and European cash trading each up over 15% on July 2010 levels while LIFFE CONNECT volumes were similar, and US Cash was lower. 7. Derivatives: 1. Global Derivative volumes decreased 12% YoverY, driven primarily by declines in trading volumes in European Derivatives. 2. European Derivative volumes impacted by: 1. Lower equity futures. 2. Reduced risk capital. 3. Lower volatility. 3. Net revenues declined 6%. 4. Derivatives accounted for 32% of net revenues, 41% of operating income. 5. Increase in fixed OpEx for Derivatives segment driven by mitigation or migration to new data centers, from software upgrades being implemented this qtr. and new business development spending. 6. Avg. net rate per contract for NYSE Liffe derivatives was $0.74 per contract vs. $0.64 in 2Q10, and $0.69 in 1Q11. 1. Increase vs. 2Q10 due to weaker dollar. 2. Including favorable impact of currency fluctuations, capture would have been $0.67 in current qtr. 7. Rate per contract in US Options was $0.165 per contract. 1. In line with prior-year and 1Q. 8. Cash Trading & Listings: 1. Cash Trading and Listings net revenue were$327.m 1. Up 2% vs. 2Q10. 2. In line with [1Q10]. 3. These results achieved despite declines in US and European cash trading ADV of 35% and 11%, respectively. 2. Lackluster volumes more than offset by positive currency moves and strong non-volume-related revenues, which included growth in listings revenues and new revenue streams from Corporate Board Member and NYSE Blue. 3. Market share down slightly for US Cash in four European markets vs. prior-year. 1. Market share for both venues increased vs. prior qtr. 4. Tape A share in US was 35% and European cash share was 71%. 5. Revenue capture for US Cash trended up to $0.039 per 100 shares handled for 2Q. 1. Well above $0.030 in 2Q10. 6. Since 2Q10, implemented dynamic tiers based on overall US consolidated volumes and removed inversion of highest tier on Arca. 1. These changes, combined with higher client take-fees on NYSE, 2Q rebalances for some larger indexes and favorable mix have been driving higher capture rates. 2. Expects 2H capture rates to soften somewhat from 2Q levels. 7. Revenue capture for European cash $0.74. 1. Increased 13% vs. 2Q10. 2. Including positive impact of currency fluctuation, capture basically flat YoverY. 9. Information Services & Technology Solutions: 1. Revenue$122.m 1. Up$15m or 14% from 2Q10, primarily driven by increase in SFTI and co-location revenue and revenue growth from managed service sales from TSE, WSE and SigmaX. 2. Operating margin 30% vs. 19% in 2Q10. 3. Adjusted EBITDA margin 38%. 4. Recently announced agreement to acquire, Metabit, a Tokyo-based provider of market access services to Asian market. 1. Supports growing focus on Asian markets and strategic goal of building global liquidity network. 2. Expects to close transaction around Aug.-end. 5. YTD revenues running 10% above prior-year period. 1. Targets growth rate of 15% for full-year 2011. 10. Fixed OpEx: 1. OpEx up$12m vs. last year on reported basis. 1. 42% of expenses in 2Q denominated in either euros or pounds. 2. Adjusting for FX and impact of transaction like NYSE Blue JV and acquisition of Corporate Board Member, fixed operating costs were down$14m or 3% from 2Q10. 3. Makes good progress and focused on efficiency and productivity improvements that will further reduce OpEx. 4. YTD reported fixed costs flat vs. prior-year. 1. [Excluding] impact of currency and changes to portfolio, expenses running 4% below prior-year levels. 2. Confident of ability to meet full-year cost guidance of expenses below $1.65b on constant dollar and constant portfolio basis. 5. 1H11 costs$834.m 1. Adjusting for$19m of unfavorable FX variance vs. prior-year rate and$8m in incremental costs from March 2011 NYSE Blue JV, 1H constant dollar, constant portfolio costs were$807.m 11. Balance Sheet (as of 06/30/11): 1. Ended 2Q11 in strong financial position for combination with Deutsche Boerse. 2. Due to strong free cash flow in 1H11, retired remaining commercial paper during qtr., leaving Co. without any short-term debt as of June 30. 3. In 1H, repaid$366m of short-term debt. 1. Given extremely low borrowing cost for commercial paper, this should have minimal impact on reported interest expense. 4. With retirement of outstanding commercial paper, debt-to-EBITDA leverage ratio was 1.7 times, down from 2.2 times at 2010-end and lowest level since NYSE and Euronext merged. 5. CapEx: 1. 2Q11 remain low at$31m vs.$70m in 2Q10. 2. YTD$67.m 3. While Co. expects CapEx to pick up in 2H, on track to be well below full-year guidance of less than$200.m 6. Last week, board declared $0.30 quarterly cash dividend for 3Q11, payable on Sept. 30.

S2. 2Q11 Operations (T.C.) 1. NYSE Liffe US: 1. Already accomplished more than any other new exchange in US interest rate future space, just a little over five months into launch of new interest rate products. 2. Four core pillars of strategy, which closely relate to NYX corporate strategy of building capital markets community. 1. Based on four key objectives known internally as CODE, connect, operate, deliver, enable; these pillars strongly interrelate. 2. Connect: 1. Underpinning execution plan, strong technology platform that leverages existing connectivity for core Liffe clients. 2. Having NYX systems as cornerstone to all aspects of exchange, ensures Co. brings stable, globally distributed, high-performance platform to market. 3. Operate: 1. Strong value proposition provided catalyst for variety of customers to support new platform. 2. This helps create diverse liquid market with open interest that's growing virtually every day. 3. Most difficult hurdle for any new exchange creating consistent based liquidity; customers telling Co. accomplished that. 4. Deliver: 1. NYPC delivers one core value proposition for NYSE Liffe US, capital efficiency via single-pot margining between cash and futures. 2. At a time when capital efficiency has never been more important, this innovation is tremendously relevant. 5. Enable: 1. NYSE LiffeUS has been built through variety of partnerships. 2. Partnership with MSCI to power equity index futures complex, which was recently expanded with successful migration of MSCI EAFE and MSCI Emerging Markets indices from another exchange. 3. Semi-mutualized structure of exchange whereby NYX owns NYSE LiffeUS in partnership with six sophisticated market participants and JV between DTCC and NYX, which created New York Portfolio Clearing. 3. Launched interest rate futures on platform starting with Eurodollars on 03/21/11. 1. Strong support in Eurodollars since launch with approx. 65,000 lots of avg. daily volume. 2. US Treasury futures relaunched on July 7. 3. ADV since relaunch 30,000 lots. 4. Volume growth drivers include strong market support from diverse set of market participants, growing open interest of 29,000 lots as of July 29. 5. Open interest: 1. In both products strong and growing rapidly. 2. For rates complex now over 700,000 contracts. 6. Total exchange rapidly approaching 1m contracts with 805,000 as of July 29. 7. As evidenced by growth of open interest, has diverse range of market participants transacting volume every day on platform, with geographically diverse group of market makers, banks and end-user customers. 4. Five key areas - future growth drivers: 1. Strategy going forward starts with building on existing success Co. had on platform. 2. New customers accessing markets regularly. 3. Welcomes ABN Amro and Citi as new NYPC clearing members just this week. 4. Launches Eurodollar options in 1Q12. 5. Working to expand capital efficiencies afforded to include customers in addition to current clearing member house positions hopefully to go live in early 2012. 6. Working on variety of innovative new product ideas. 7. MSCI expansion: 1. Optimistic about potential for equity index futures complex. 2. Successfully migrated 70,000 lots in open interest from CME to Co.'s platform in June 2011 in emerging markets and EAFE futures. 3. Over t$3 in assets under management benchmarked to MSCI indices globally; quite optimistic for development of futures of these futures markets.

S3. 2Q11 Business Summary (D.N.) 1. Strategic Business Update: 1. Derivatives: 1. Successfully closed sale of stake in NYSE Amex Options business. 1. Partners in venture will be integral in helping Co. implement new order types and market structure changes that will enhance exchange and further grow market share. 2. Cash Trading and Listings: 1. Sees growing momentum in listings franchise. 2. Co., Number One globally for IPOs for second consecutive qtr. 3. NYSE won 55% of technology IPOs YTD, up from previous record high of 44% in 2010. 1. Recent big tech wins include LinkedIn and Pandora. 4. YTD, sees transfers from other exchanges with total of eight transfers YTD, including Hudson Valley Holding Corp. which began trading on NYSE on 08/02/11 and Regency Energy Partners, which will begin trading at NYSE on Aug. 9. 5. There have been no transfers going other way so far this year. 6. During qtr. and late last week, experienced several outages in European cash markets. 1. Identified root cause of outages. 2. Stabilized environment. 3. Putting in place infrastructure that will prevent these outages from occurring in future. 3. Information Services and Technology Solutions: 1. On track for full-year revenue growth of 15% and goal of $1b in revenue by 2015. 2. Will hit this target by continually expanding global liquidity network through hub expansion program and acquisitions like Metabit that was announced last week. 3. Will continue to embed itself in trading fabric of clients with initiatives like cloud launch which creates first Capital Markets Community Platform. 2. Integration Planning: 1. With strong support of shareholders behind, moving beyond votes and focusing on various regulatory streams Co. has to work through and integration planning. 2. On integration, already made some tough decisions together which have been laid out in business combination agreement. 1. Framework for operating NewCo already in place. 3. Key list of integration planning topics identified early in process and resulted in increase in synergy targets as Co. found more similarities than originally assumed. 1. Found more common ground than expected on future IT architecture. 4. Already in 2Q, formed joint and dedicated integration planning team, named senior managers in charge of running integration planning effort and established full-fledged integration teams including divisional experts and project support personnel. 1. Future management team working to set goals and priorities for integration planning process until closing. 5. With overwhelming support for transaction provided by shareholders from both companies, management attention shifted towards receiving requisite non-objection declarations from regulators, and preparing ground for swift and effective integration post-closing. 6. While integration teams will continue to drill down into synergy targets, will begin to focus on some softer aspects of integration, including setting foundation for harmonization of two cultures. 1. Complex cross-border deal. 2. Goal to create culture of performance that matches leadership position in global exchange space. 7. Given both companies' strong and rich histories of operating in international environments, and specific examples of team work as teams begin to work together, good example of which was winning overwhelming approval from shareholders of both companies, confident will be successful in integrating cultures. 3. EU Competition Review Timing & Process: 1. European Commission review process has been on-going from sometime through pre-notification discussions after Co. announced transaction and recently with final competition filing, which was submitted in late June. 1. This week, competition authorities in EU expected to complete first phase of investigation during which they collected opinions from peers, customers, competitors and other stakeholders. 2. Some views that Commission collected have already been disclosed publicly. 1. Competitors have been most vocal about concerns regarding pending business combination. 2. Expected. 3. Confidence Commission will carefully consider source of objections. 2. Expects to be notified by competition authorities later this week Co. will embark on Phase II process. 1. Runs diligent and comprehensive process in close collaboration with colleagues at DB to respond to request from Commission. 2. Putting two companies together will create tremendous benefits for all customers and end-users in terms of capital efficiency, operational simplification and cost reduction. 1. Will strengthen and improve efficiency of EU capital markets in terms of liquidity, lower volatility and cost of capital. 3. Any negative impact on competition is not significant given global nature of derivative markets, increasing competition between OTC and listed markets generally and in Derivatives specifically and simple well-known fact that NYX and DB1 do not compete against one another. 4. Only area of overlap in current business models in some single name derivatives and, Co. is only two of many players in those markets. 5. Lot of speculation driven by competitors. 1. Much focused on remedies, in particular some who have opined on whether Co. would be asked to dispose certain businesses like NYSE LIFFE or Eurex Derivatives franchises. 3. European derivatives critically important part of combination providing synergies, capital efficiencies and other significant shareholder and customer benefits. 4. Confident benefits that combination will provide to clients and market overall do and will continue to resonate with regulators. 1. Looks forward to continuing constructive discussions with Commission and case team in Brussels, still hopeful Co. will close transaction in 2011. 4. Summary: 1. Due to diversification efforts over past several quarters, business model much better positioned to weather lackluster trading volume cycles as seen particularly in this qtr. 2. Additional drivers of growth gaining traction with interest rate futures on NYSE LiffeUS and NYPC. 3. Clearing in post-trade businesses will continue to be particular area of focus as combined co. 4. Strong growth coming from Technology segment in 2011 and beyond. 5. Sees momentum in Listings franchise, securing Number One position in global IPOs for second consecutive qtr. 6. With respective shareholder votes behind, fully focused on regulatory approval process targeting close for business combination with Deutsche Boerse in 2011.

QUESTION AND ANSWER SUMMARY

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Roger Freeman.

ROGER FREEMAN, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Hi, good morning. I guess my question would be around NYSE Liffe and NYPC in total. Can you give us ballpark or quantify how much those businesses are in a negative profit position right now or in a loss position? And secondly on NYPC, can you just talk to the growing open interest versus sort of stable volumes and marketshare? What is the nature of the open interest? Is that sort of a chunky block -- block trades coming in?

MICHAEL GELTZEILER, GROUP EVP & CFO, NYSE EURONEXT: I'll take the first part about the financials and then we will turn it over to Tom. So what we have indicated in the last couple of years is that NYSE Liffe has been in investment mode and that we have lost -- reported about a $30 million operating loss for that business. Now remember, we own 58% and we have minority partners who have 42% of that business. We don't report the profitability each quarter as the interest rate business is just starting -- it is in its infancy. I think we are doing a little better than that $30 million loss that we reported last year, but we are still in a large investment position at this stage.

TOM CALLAHAN, CEO, NYSE LIFFE US, NYSE EURONEXT: In terms of the growth of open interest, we said before we even launched the platform that our success would be measured as much by our growth in OI as by our volumes because we made a strategic decision back in 2009 when we designed the platform to really have capital efficiency as the centerpiece of the new exchange.

So the fact that both our partners and our customers are recognizing that and are really making a long-term commitment to the platform by moving open interest is enormously gratifying and exciting for us. We are seeing new partners coming into our market virtually every single day and as they do, the open interest, as you can see from the chart in the deck, is steadily increasing every single day.

So 800,000 lots of open interest across the exchange, 700,000 lots at NYPC for a platform that is five months old is just great progress and great early momentum and I think it validates the strategy of delivering operational and capital efficiencies through the NYPC platform.

ROGER FREEMAN: Thanks.

OPERATOR: Rich Repetto, Sandler O'Neill.

RICH REPETTO, ANALYST, SANDLER O'NEILL: Yes, good morning, guys. I don't want to do this, but I'll stay on the topic of NYSE Liffe here since we have Thomas. You talked about the number -- I guess the loss, Michael, but we still have -- well, here is the questions. We still have the free marketmaking or at least some liquidity providers are still free until I think '12. And then -- so I am just trying to see what type of volume do you need to break even either before '12 or once the -- is it the fee -- once you start charging fees in March of '12, that could move it or how much volume do we need? And then also this relaunch of treasury, I know there was an issue with the contract and can you just remind us -- the efficient -- are there capital efficiencies with Eurodollars, as well as we know about the treasuries?

TOM CALLAHAN: Sure. So I think there might be three questions in there, so I will try to hit them one at a time. I think what you might have been referring to in terms of the fee holiday was the first three months of NYPC where there was a fee holiday on clearing fees that went from March 21 to June 21, so that has since expired.

In terms of the profitability of the overall platform, it really comes down, as you know, to the ecosystem of different types of customers because, of course, you have marketmakers all the way to end-user customers and the thing that we have been most gratified by outside of the growth in open interest that I discussed previously was the amount of end-user customers, the non-members that are coming into our platform. We have done over 300,000 lots of customer block trades from large US asset managers. So the fact that we are seeing that kind of commitment from real end-user customers really I think is a great vote of confidence in a new platform, but, of course, in terms of the rate per contract, that helps us enormously as well.

I think the final question was around capital efficiency and the Eurodollars benefit from the capital efficiencies of NYPC, the answer is absolutely. The largest source of margin at FICC is actually their repo clearing business and repos have a very high correlation with Eurodollar contracts, so there is a terrific amount of capital efficiency there. And I think that helps explain the open interest growth that we have had.

And then in terms of the relaunch of the treasury complex, when we launched the platform on March 21, the big difference between treasury futures and Eurodollar futures is, of course, treasury futures are physically delivered. Customers wanted to see that NYPC could manage its first physical delivery. It did that successfully in June and really more than anything, that helped build confidence once we got through that period into July for customers to really start increasing their level of activity. And that is why you saw when we relaunched the platform on July 7 our volume in open interest start to increase immediately.

RICH REPETTO: I think -- you are saying that all the trades were -- all the waivers for the trades were ended in June. I think on your website it still has trade fees waived for approved marketmakers till March 21.

TOM CALLAHAN: Oh, yes. That is on the exchange side, Rich, not on the clearinghouse side. Of course, for the people who make markets in our platform and sign market-making agreements, there are fee waivers and that is very standard in the futures industry. And that will, of course, continue because you always need marketmakers. But what I was referring to in terms of the end-user customers and the early adoption that we have seen, obviously those are fee-paying customers and the more of those we get, the better the balance sheet of the business will look.

RICH REPETTO: Got it. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Alex Kramm, UBS.

ALEX KRAMM, ANALYST, UBS: Hey, good morning. Just wanted to quickly shift gears to the deal, in particular that slide where you highlight the benefits for end users. Now when I look at the reduction in capital requirements, in particular, that $3 billion, I mean looking at that and talking to some, the broker folks in the industry, it sounds like people are generally very excited about this and I think they made that case heard in their antitrust submissions.

I think the big issue is to really have confidence with some of these numbers though. So hoping to see if there will be anything else that you can provide in the future. I mean if I look at that $3 billion number, I look back what CME and CDOC did in 2004, I mean I probably can come up with a number like that myself.

So I think what people struggle with, in particular on the dealer side, is can we put portfolios together, show them to you and you can tell us, hey, this is really what we are getting, in particular given that there are different regulatory frameworks between Eurex and Liffe and other challenges, but probably will take some time to put that together. So any commentary would be great there. Thank you.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER, CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: Alex, it is Duncan. I will take that one. So we certainly intend to be very transparent on that and as we get closer to closing or shortly after closing when we are talking about migration plans, combinations of clearinghouses and giving the clients a roadmap of when all that can happen, when we are one company, it will be a lot easier to go a lot deeper.

So far, obviously, we've wanted to be cautious. We came up with that number that we have quoted by doing sort of what you suggested. We went to a few big customers and we said, look, we can't really look at each other's positions right now. You know what positions you have in both places. Why don't each of us give you the data and then let's run some correlations, let's run some analyses and let's see what we come up with.

So we felt pretty good that EUR2 billion or $3 billion was a fairly good number out of the gate based on some testing that we did, but I imagine we will be able to put a much finer point to that as we get closer to the closing and into the operating as Newco. And it is a great question because it is a significant benefit to the marketplace and it is obviously in our interest to be honest about it, but also be as clear with as many as we can that that is a real savings, not an illusory one.

ALEX KRAMM: So do you think, and this is the same question, so do you think there will be any opportunity to give more detail to the participants so that they can still comment or follow up in Phase 2 during the antitrust?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Yes, I think we haven't approached it that way to date, but we can. It is a good suggestion. We have gone to several individuals and I think we would be prepared to do that under the outline of the ground rules that I just went through where we are not looking into each other's clearinghouses prematurely -- that is inappropriate -- but certainly the end-user can see that for all of their clients and do that analysis.

ALEX KRAMM: All right, very good. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Patrick O'Shaughnessy, Raymond James.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY, ANALYST, RAYMOND JAMES: Good morning. So in June, CME Group announced that they are going to start to offer the Euribor contract. I was wondering if you could comment on how you think you guys are currently competitively positioned to defend against that entry, as well as any implications that might have on the antitrust concerns with your merger.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: It is Duncan, Patrick. I will take that one. I will answer the second half of that first. I would think that it is -- in terms of the impact on the merger, it has been duly noted by the competition authorities in Brussels that there have been a few competitive efforts in the last few months either embarked upon or announced. So frankly, we think it is an example of, like other examples, that there is an opportunity to compete.

At the same time, we think what we have learned in NYSE LiffeUS and in NYPC, as Tom went through in his material and this really gets to the first part of your question, if you are going to compete, we certainly understood we had to bring an innovative solution to the marketplace. I think listing look-alike contracts and not really adding any value from the capital efficiency point of view or whatever it might be we think are fairly easy to defend against.

So when we were trying to be an attacker in the US jurisdiction, we spent a lot of time trying to think about what more it had to be than just listing Eurodollars and treasuries. We didn't think that was much of a competitive threat to the incumbent. So I think what you saw us do was spend a lot more time on something that was innovative, not just simply list a look-alike contract and attempt to compete. Tom, would you add anything to that from your point of view with your derivatives hat on?

TOM CALLAHAN: I would tell you, I mean, of course, CME is an incredibly powerful global competitor, so we are taking the threat very, very seriously. We thought it was interesting that they chose to clear the products in Chicago, which is an inverse of when Liffe, unsuccessfully back in 2004, attempted to launch Eurodollars cleared in London and that proved to be a challenge for us at the time. So it will be interesting to see how European customers react to a Chicago cleared Euribor contract. But regardless, we are staying very close to our customers and we are taking the threat very, very seriously.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY: Thank you.

OPERATOR: Johannes Thormann, HSBC.

JOHANNES THORMANN, ANALYST, HSBC: Good morning, everybody. Johannes from HSBC. One question concerning your balance sheet, please. You have successfully reduced your debt to EBITDA ratio. What is an appropriate level for your Company and will you continue to decrease or at which point do you think you will increase the dividend policy also in the light of the merger with Deutsche Boerse? Thank you.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: We have mentioned in the past that our current comfort zone and our targeted leverage is around 2 to 2.25 times, so the 1.7 is below the norm and expectation for our business. We have announced a special dividend, so clearly we are building balance sheet capacity so that when we complete the merger, we will have the necessary cash to pay the special dividend. So you shouldn't read into the strength of the balance sheet as being the way we would run our business necessarily on a standalone basis, but clearly it is part of the plan to do the merger and as I said, develop (multiple speakers).

JOHANNES THORMANN: Okay, understood. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Howard Chen, Credit Suisse.

HOWARD CHEN, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE: Hi, good morning, good afternoon. Congrats on the shareholder votes. Mike, just a quick one on the financials. Can you discuss the impact from the Amex transaction, assuming no changes in its profitability position? Just maybe what would have earnings been if the deal had closed at the beginning of the June quarter? Thanks.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: So I believe we mentioned that in our talking points. So we are saying had we closed the transaction April 1 instead of June 29, we would have reported a $0.02 less earnings per share, so the minority interest on the partner's portion of the profitability. So if volume stayed the same, that is what you can expect in the third quarter and going forward.

HOWARD CHEN: Great, thanks. Sorry I missed it.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: That's okay.

OPERATOR: Daniel Harris.

DANIEL HARRIS, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Hi, good morning, guys. Hey, Duncan, you talked a bit about the issues that you guys have been having with Euronext on the technology side with the sporadic outages and the index calculations. I was wondering if you could delve a little bit deeper into what that was, but more so also I think that as part of the merged entity, you are not going to be using UTP going forward. Can you talk about the decision process on that versus what the alternative is obviously with the Deutsche Boerse technology? Thanks.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Sure. I know you guys are everywhere, but you clearly know some things about our merger that we don't know yet because we didn't know that the decision had been made about UTP, but thanks for letting us know. We appreciate the heads up.

I think I am going to let Dominique, who is sitting here with me, talk about how we have diagnosed these issues, what we think the root cause was, what we have done about it, etc. and then I will have him kick it back to me and we will talk a little bit about how that may be impacting the discussion we are having around the common trading and clearing architecture, okay? So Dominique, what don't we start with you?

DOMINIQUE CERUTTI, PRESIDENT & DEPUTY CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: Yes, so indeed we had on the European side full incident to be clear in June and July and we take that very seriously free of the incident and the one you are mentioning are originating in a complex accord. We made -- Mike, since you are asking, we made an update on [microcore] that was mandatory on one of our software and it has created some packet loss. We have the best expert on our camp and from the vendors to analyze that and it is this change combined with high market volume and some new behaviors enabled by the new capabilities that we are offering to members that are figuring some instability in some legacy software that we still run. So that is what happened.

I don't want to go deeper; it could be quite complex. Again, we have analyzed the situation. We have taken mitigation actions in the short term and maybe more importantly, we are running the task force and we expect results in the next 30 days to check whether or not we have other vulnerabilities in our system and make sure that we will come back to our best-of-breed stability.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: All right, and then to get to the second part of your question, I think we continue to have discussions about, as I've said to some of you before at various analyst meetings, etc., we view the common trading and clearing architecture as having many components starting with what we would call the common customer gateway, to the safety network, to the trading engines, to the backend systems, to the data dissemination tools, to the clearing platforms, etc. and we continue to have very healthy dialogue with our colleagues at DB. Some of the decisions about which pieces we will be using have already been made.

I think what we have said publicly is the system we end up using won't be UTP or what DB runs right now; it will probably be an amalgam of all of the above. But I think on some of the components, we have already made the decision. Larry, do you want to add anything to that since you are on the call too as to where we are in that decision?

LARRY LEIBOWITZ, COO, NYSE EURONEXT: No, I think that is the right way to say it. We are going through a comparing functionality. The considerations really are functionality points, pain of client migration and really that matters a lot. We don't want to put the clients through a big migration here and then ultimate cost savings. And you can be guaranteed that this is going to be a best-of-breed and no matter what, best of technologists on both sides.

The problems we have been having in Europe really are related to not only microcode, but legacy systems. It has nothing to do with UTP and really haven't colored this discussion. I think it has been a very healthy discussion, not just among the technologists, but also among the businesses because the businesses are really concerned that functionality gets preserved and that their clients are not disturbed in this process.

OPERATOR: Niamh Alexander, KBW.

NIAMH ALEXANDER, ANALYST, KEEFE, BRUYETTE & WOODS: Hi, good morning. Thanks for taking my questions. If I could touch on the expenses because going back, going way back, this was officially -- the second quarter was officially the end of the integration phase for Euronext and NYX. But I am just wondering if it is kind of all solid on and behind you now or if maybe there's still some data centers, old ones that need to be run off because your expense guidance was not changed, but clearly the FX is driving it higher. Just trying to get a sense of the run rate going forward and maybe opportunities to lower it from this level.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: This is Mike. It is a challenge as we, from time to time, acquire a company or the euro or dollar fluctuate. We can keep updating the guidance. Our guidance was using 2010's average exchange rates, so we reported 1, 6, 7, 8 in costs and the portfolio we had at the end of the year, we were guiding that our costs would come below $16.50. And as I indicated on the call, adjusting for all that, we were at $8.07 in the first half. So we are clearly below our guidance, in line with our guidance. As Duncan mentioned, we continue to focus on opportunities to run our business more efficiently every day.

To your question, there are still some legacy data centers and other assets that we are exiting and there is some savings that are not going to be as large as they were the last couple of years, but there are some avenues for further cost reductions related to the transition and the integration we will start to see and experience as we get down to the end of the year.

So I think maybe at the end of the third quarter, when we will have three quarters under the belt, we can give a more precise expense number, but I think rather than trying to project which way the currency is going to move and/or we just added Metabit, we might -- whether or not we make any more acquisitions, I think a fair way to do it is to report the numbers as we do today and provide the reconciliation in our deck on how we are doing against our guidance.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Just to jump in for one second here, I think it is really important that, at a certain point, it becomes hard to figure out what is an integration savings, meaning from Euronext NYSE merger and what is just continued operating your business more effectively. And we continue to believe that we can continue to cut our costs as we move forward, even had we not done this DB deal. That is part of what you do as running your company properly and we still we think we have room to run. I think we continue to do that among the backdrop of investing in some new business and making some new acquisitions.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: Right, which is a great point, just one more follow-up on what Larry said. Our technology, our commercial technology business is not a fixed cost business. So as we aspire to have $1 billion of revenue there and we take on new managed services accounts, we are taking on costs. Our focus there is revenue growth in margin; it is not in keeping the costs fixed. So we have been able to absorb those incremental costs while continuing to bring down our overall expense base.

NIAMH ALEXANDER: Okay, that's helpful. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Chris Harris, Wells Fargo.

CHRIS HARRIS, ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES: Great, thanks for squeezing me in here, guys. Clearly, you have had some excellent success in options with Amex remutualization and growth in maker-taker, but it looks like some of that momentum is slowing a little bit here. And just wondering if you could share with us what strategies you plan on implementing and options to kind of further your share growth? And as maybe a follow-up to that, would you ever consider selling a stake in Arca options given the success you have had at Amex?

LARRY LEIBOWITZ: So I think to jump in there, this is Larry again, first, you are seeing the effect of options being very competitive and we have a lot of competitors out there who have varying models. What you're also seeing over time is a blending towards the middle between pure maker-taker, meaning the Arca model and fewer directed flow like Amex. You see them, as the directed flow guys have adopted some functionality that looks more maker-taker like and vice versa. So we are going to continue to see that and we all push to continue to try to differentiate our platforms. We think that we have some interesting developments in the works and we are going to continue to push on those. It is a competitive market, but it is also a growing market, so that is a good position to be in.

CHRIS HARRIS: Fair enough. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, that concludes the Q&A session. I would now like to turn it back over to management.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Stephen, why don't you call it a wrap since I am offsite?

STEPHEN DAVIDSON, IR, NYSE EURONEXT: Okay, thank you, everyone, for listening this morning and we will speak to you next quarter. Enjoy the summer.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Thanks, everybody.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, that concludes the presentation. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect. Have a great day.

urn:contentItem:5SX5-3951-JB20-G1CV-00000-00Event Brief of Q2 2018 ICON PLC Earnings Call - Final2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis072618sp.728Event Brief of Q2 2018 ICON PLCEarnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Brendan Brennan - ICON Public Limited Company,CFO

. Jonathan Curtain - ICON Public Limited Company,VP of Corporate Finance & IR

. Steven A. Cutler - ICON Public Limited Company,CEO & Director

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Alexander Yearley Draper - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division,MD

. David Howard Windley - Jefferies LLC, Research Division,Equity Analyst

. Donald Houghton Hooker - KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., Research Division,VP and Equity Research Analyst

. Erin Elizabeth Wilson Wright - Cr\xE9dit Suisse AG, Research Division,Director & Senior Equity Research Analyst

. Jack Meehan - Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division,VP & Senior Research Analyst

. John Charles Kreger - William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division,Partner & Healthcare Services Analyst

. Juan Esteban Avendano - BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division,Associate

. Justin Bowers

. Robert Patrick Jones - Goldman Sachs GroupInc., Research Division,VP

. Ross Jordan Muken - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD, Head of Healthcare Services and Technology & Fundamental Research Analyst

. Tycho W. Peterson - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division,Senior Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 2Q18 revenue of $641.6m, net income of $82.9m and diluted EPS of $1.51. Expects 2018 revenue to be $2.56-2.64b and EPS to be $5.98-6.12.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 2Q18 revenue = $641.6m.

2. 2Q18 revenue (excluding impact of ASC 606) = $473.9m.

3. 2Q18 net income = $82.9m.

4. 2Q18 net income (excluding impact of ASC 606) = $84.3m.

5. 2Q18 diluted EPS = $1.51.

6. 2Q18 diluted EPS (excluding impact of ASC 606) = $1.54.

7. 2Q18 YonY revenue growth = 10%.

8. 2Q18 YonY constant-currency revenue growth = 8%.

9. 2Q18 GM = 30.0%.

10. 2Q18 GM (excluding impact of ASC 606) = 40.9%.

11. 2Q18 CapEx = $8.9m.

12. 2Q18 DSO = 49.

13. Net cash at 06/30/18 = $23.9m.

14. 2018 revenue guidance = $2.56-2.64b.

15. 2018 EPS guidance = $5.98-6.12.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

2Q18 Financials (B.B.)

1. Note:

1. From 01/01/18, new revenue recognition standard, ASC 606, became effective for ICLR.

1. Having adopted cumulative effect transition method, prior-year comparatives have not been restated under this new standard.

2. Instead, Co. feels that providing comparable 2Q18 financial results under previous revenue recognition standard is the best way to evaluate its performance during this transition period.

2. Results:

1. Achieved strong gross business wins, excluding impact of ASC 606, of $720m with cancelations of $120m.

2. Net awards were a new record $600m resulting in a book-to-bill of 1.27 times; trailing 12-month book-to-bill is a very healthy 1.29 times.

1. With addition of these new awards, backlog, excluding ASC 606 impact, grew to $5.2b.

1. Up 16% YoverY.

2. Top customer represented 10.4% of this backlog; down from 11.3% at 2Q17-end.

3. Reported revenue, $641.6m.

1. Excluding impact of ASC 606, $473.9m.

1. Represents YonY growth of 10%, or 8% on constant currency basis and 2% on constant dollar organic basis.

4. Excluding ASC 606 impact, customer concentration:

1. Top customer represented 13.5% of revenue vs. 20% of revenue last year.

2. Top 5 customers represented 39.1% of revenue vs. 41.2% of revenue last year.

3. Top 10 represented 54.2% vs. 55.0% of revenue last year.

4. Top 25 customers represented 70.2% vs. 73.4% of revenue last year.

5. Reported GM, 30.0% vs. 30.6% in 1Q.

1. Group GM, excluding ASC 606 impact, 40.9%.

1. 1Q18, 41.2%.

2. 2Q17, 42.0%.

6. Reported SG&A, 12.6% vs. 13.0% in 1Q18.

1. Excluding 606 impact, 17.1% of revenue.

1. 1Q18, 17.5%.

2. 2Q17, 18.8%.

2. This was due to Co.'s continued leverage of global business support model.

7. Reported operating income before non-recurring charges of 14.7% or $94.4m vs. 14.8% or $91.7m in 1Q18.

1. Excluding impact of ASC 606, $96m and operating margin, 20.2%.

1. 1Q18, 20.1%.

2. 2Q17, 19.9%.

3. Additional Results:

1. Net interest expense, $2.3m.

2. Effective tax rate, 10%.

3. Net income reported before non-recurring charges $82.9m or 12.9%.

1. Diluted EPS, $1.51, a 6.3% increase in 1Q EPS of $1.42.

4. Excluding impact of ASC 606:

1. Net income before non-recurring charges was $84.3m.

1. Margin, 17.8%.

2. Diluted EPS, $1.54.

1. 1Q18, $1.44.

2. 2Q17, $1.31.

3. Increased 17.6%.

5. DSO, 49 days.

1. 1Q18, 51 days.

2. 2Q17, 53 days.

6. Cash generated from operating activities, [$32.7m].

7. CapEx, $8.9m.

1. At 06/30/18, net cash, $23.9m vs. $4.6m at 03/31/18.

2. At 06/30/17, net debt, $33.8m.

8. Took a restructuring charge of $12.5m, as Co. continues to improve efficiency of its operating model.

1. Restructuring plan reflected rationalization across business to improve resource utilization and office footprint.

1. GAAP EPS [$1.31] vs. $1.51 on non-GAAP basis.

2Q18 Review (S.C.)

1. Highlights:

1. Fuelled by strong outsourcing trends (inaudible) market fundamentals remain very positive for CRO industry.

1. The momentum Co. saw during 2017 has continued into 2018.

2. During 2Q, seen strong levels of market demand across all of business segments.

3. Backlog grew 16% YonY.

1. Driven by a record net business award level of $600m.

1. Delivering net book-to-bill of 1.27 times or 1.29 times on a trailing 12-month basis.

2. Backlog now stands at $5.2b, which gives a firm foundation to build upon during the remainder of the year and beyond.

4. Continues to broaden customer base with both new and existing biopharma companies seeking to leverage:

1. Operational excellence.

2. Flexible partnership model.

3. Depth of therapy expertise across global footprint.

5. Since Co.'s foundation in 1990, have strived to work as a trusted partner to its clients, collaborating, innovating and finding new ways to improve outcomes together.

6. Underpinning Co.'s business strategies a deep understanding of industry landscape enabling it to work closely with clients and allowing it to be competitive at a time when technology, regulations and client needs are changing.

1. Has global scale and flexibility to organize resources around their requirements and adapt Co.'s delivering models as the strategy dictates and evolves.

2. ICLR's ability to successfully managed projects under a variety of integrated and flexible outsourcing models has led to new opportunities for:

1. Full service.

2. Functional services businesses.

3. Pleased with continued progress being made in this area on integrated basis with other service areas and as a standalone offering.

1. Believes this is becoming another differentiator for ICLR in the market.

7. Access to patients continues to be a key challenge for industry.

1. Has developed an integrated site and patient's solution that makes it easier for site and patients to actively participate in a trial and increase the predictability and speed of enrolment and retention.

8. Leveraging Co.'s PMG network, which now includes the recently announced (inaudible) network.

1. Helping customers to enhance clinical trial feasibility, while giving patients access to a broader range of care options through clinical trials.

9. Innovating partnerships with Intel and Saama and Co.'s collaborations with TriNetX and EHR4CR and most recently practiced fusion within Life Science segment continued to be used successfully in conjunction with OneSearch data platform.

1. These partnerships are all helping to enhance engagement with sites, patients and healthcare providers to take significant time and cost from customers development programs.

10. Continues to work on a series of internal projects to evaluate the potential opportunities with:

1. Robotics.

2. Process automation.

11. Believes there are several areas in the clinical trial process, which lend themselves to further efficiencies through the use of robotics process automation starting with digitalisation of protocol and the creation of data capture tools and testing and validation of applications.

1. Believes there is application for robotics in the conduct of routine tasks within global business services environment.

1. Helping Co. to continue to leverage its spending across these key support groups.

2. Additional Highlights:

1. Consequence of Co.'s strong business development performs means that it need to ensure it has appropriate staff members in place to take it for the ramp-up in operational activity levels.

2. During the qtr. headcount grew to nearly 13,650 employees.

1. An increase in staff of over 1,300 employees YoverY.

3. Identification on the successful recruitment of best-in-class talent, Co.'s keys to ensuring continued delivery of customer's projects.

4. Upon joining ICLR, a clear on-boarding program is communicated to directly engage employees with mission, vision and values with:

1. Centre on integrity.

2. Collaboration.

3. Partnership.

4. Accountability.

5. Delivery.

5. Focused on retention of staff in longer term by engaging and helping them map out their own individual career plans in Co.'s internal career hub.

1. Provides an opportunity for each employee to create their own career framework, and how to develop their experiences, abilities and competencies over time.

2. Result of this is approx. 10% of employees will be promoted within Co. each year.

1. Recognizing their performance.

2. Skill development.

3. Increased level of experience.

4. Helping to retain them long-term for the benefit of customers.

6. (inaudible) allows Co. to continue to pursue goals of attracting and retaining best talent in the industry, ultimately driving long-term performance at an individual and co. level.

1. Proud to be included in Forbes magazine's America's best large employers for 2018.

1. Ranking by employees of the best employers across 25 industry sectors.

2. Second consecutive year that Co. has been named one of America's best employees.

1. Top ranked CRO for second year in a row.

7. YonY revenue growth 10%.

1. Management of Co.'s cost base enabled it to expand its operating margin to 20.2%.

1. Strong operational performance along with an effective tax rate of 10% allowed to grow EPS by 17.6% YoverY to $1.54.

8. Repurchased $16m worth of shares under share repurchase program, bringing the total repurchase value to-date $297.3m worth of shares at an avg. price of $85.36.

3. 2018 Guidance:
