urn:contentItem:60J5-GH11-DXH2-63PY-00000-00Event Brief of Q2 2020 Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc Earnings Call - Final2020-08-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis080520sq.714Event Brief of Q2 2020 Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc Earnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Billie Jo McIntire - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,Director of IR

. Christopher S. Ripley - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,President & CEO

. Lucy A. Rutishauser - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,Executive VP & CFO

. Robert D. Weisbord - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,President of Broadcast & Chief Advertising Revenue Officer

. Billie Jo McIntire - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,Director of IR

. Christopher S. Ripley - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,President & CEO

. Lucy A. Rutishauser - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,Executive VP & CFO

. Robert D. Weisbord - Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc.,President of Broadcast & Chief Advertising Revenue Officer

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Aaron Lee Watts - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division,Research Analyst

. Daniel Louis Kurnos - The Benchmark Company, LLC, Research Division,MD & Senior Equity Analyst

. James Davis Hebert - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Director & Senior High Yield Analyst

. John Janedis - Wolfe Research, LLC,MD & Senior Media Analyst

. Steven Lee Cahall - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Aaron Lee Watts - Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division,Research Analyst

. Daniel Louis Kurnos - The Benchmark Company, LLC, Research Division,MD & Senior Equity Analyst

. James Davis Hebert - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Director & Senior High Yield Analyst

. John Janedis - Wolfe Research, LLC,MD & Senior Media Analyst

. Steven Lee Cahall - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

OVERVIEW

SBGI reported 2Q20 diluted EPS of $3.12.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 2Q20 diluted EPS = $3.12.

2. 2Q20 diluted EPS (adjusted for non-recurring items) = $3.21.

3. 2Q20-end consolidated cash = $622m.

4. 2Q20-end total debt = $12.399b.

5. 2Q20 share repurchase = over 5m shares of common stock at avg. price of just over $16 per share.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

2Q20 Review (C.R.)

1. Highlights:

1. As Co. moved through qtr., began to see signs of improvement in the advertising market.

2. After challenging April in which core advertising for Broadcast and Other segments declined 43% YoverY, June improved to 26% decline, resulting in 2Q core advertising performance for those segments to be down 36% and in middle of guidance range.

1. Co.'s decision to give 2Q guidance on May call was driven by commitment to be as transparent as possible, while acknowledging limitations that giving guidance for entire year was impractical due to wide range of variance that could result from uncertainties in timing, pace and magnitude of recovery.

2. While Co. is still faced with many of those same challenges and changing dynamics around effects of pandemic, making forecasting more difficult than usual, it has decided to once again provide guidance for upcoming qtr.

3. Co. is starting to enter peak political season, which is still expected to be a record political year and will help mitigate weakness in core advertising space.

3. Professional sports leagues have resumed their schedules, although they are shortened.

1. It is clear that viewers are excited as well with ratings for first day of MLB season up 32% on RSNs vs. last year's opening day viewership.

2. Contracts with sports teams already contemplate scenarios where there may be shortfalls and number of live games delivered to Co.

1. In such cases, Co. is entitled to remuneration from teams for any games falling short of guarantees that are defined in contracts.

3. Co. has distributors to whom it guarantees minimum games of live games in contracts with SBGI.

4. Contrary to reports out in public at this time, Co. does not expect rebates from teams to be greater than what it pays out to distributors, given differences in way rebates are calculated in team vs. distributor contracts and other variances in contracts.

4. Sports business:

1. There are a lot of exciting things going on behind scenes of SBGI.

2. As announced several weeks ago, hired Steve Rosenberg, a highly accomplished broadcast and programming executive as President of Local Sports.

3. Steve, along with Billy Chambers, who is Local Sports COO and CFO, will report into Rob Weisbord and help fill void left by upcoming departure of Jeff Krolik, who is retiring as Head of RSN business at Aug.-end.

4. Steve Rosenberg:

1. One of his first priorities will be to use his programming expertise to help elevate non-game programming on RSNs and stadium network.

2. Majority of programming hours on these networks does not involve live games.

3. There is significant opportunity to improve viewership and revenue-generating capabilities in these time periods.

5. Scott Shapiro has taken additional role of Chief Strategy Officer of Sports, and will focus on some of Co.'s larger growth opportunities, like those associated with legalized sports spend.

6. Has other exciting developments in sports business coming up as well with a number of significant growth opportunities on horizon.

1. As consumer viewing habits continue to evolve, Co. is committed to giving them exceptional experience when and where they choose to watch SBGI.

2. Co. is expecting sports app that is in development will give viewers an experience unlike anything they've encountered in past with enhanced graphics and sound, and ability to interact with content in numerous ways, including with advertisers and free-to-play games.

3. Spent a lot of time meeting with many of major players in sports betting, and expects to be able to more fully detail its plans in this area later this year.

7. As exclusive provider of local sports content for more than half of MLB, NBA and NHL teams, believes Co. is in unique position to monetize significant sports betting opportunity that exists.

5. NEXTGEN TV launches in multiple markets, including Las Vegas, Nashville, Pittsburgh, Salt Lake City and Portland, Oregon, with another 10 or so SBGI markets targeted by year-end.

1. Its impact will be felt far beyond traditional broadcasting applications.

2. NEXTGEN TV will deliver significant enhancement to television broadcast quality, but that just scratches surface.

3. New platform gives broadcasters significant flexibility in using their broadcast spectrum.

6. In July, came to terms with Comcast to renew distribution rights for all of Co.'s businesses, including broadcast stations, Tennis Channel, RSNs, and a full launch of Marquee in time for Cubs's first game of season.

1. The narrative that has been on the street regarding fears around completing deal with Comcast, or that terms would be unfavorable to SBGI, or that broadcast stations will be dragged down by RSNs was just incorrect.

2. Co. was confident that it would reach agreement with Comcast that was positive for Co., and it is happy with outcome in all regards.

3. Deal includes launch of Marquee, and expanded viewing coverage of new RSN beyond where Cubs RSN was previously carried.

4. This is something Comcast doesn't do for its own RSN in Chicago area and didn't even in past when RSN included Cubs.

5. This was accomplished without giving up carriage of other assets in portfolio and while still achieving what Co. believes are favorable rates throughout portfolio.

6. With completion of Comcast agreement, now locked up almost 85% of RSNs total subscribers for at least two years and beyond.

7. Agreed to multi-year renewal for eight stations with ViacomCBS.

8. On sports side, agreement principle with one team expired at end of last season.

9. In June, announced Co. would be launching new headline news service in early 2021, focused on breaking new stories as they develop and sourcing them from comprehensive local news resources.

1. In its initial phase, news service is expected to be launched on approx. 50 of CW and MYTV network affiliates, and will be broadcast from 6:00 AM to 9:00 AM each weekday, and on free ad-supported app store.

10. Community:

1. Awarded annual broadcast diversity scholarship to 10 talented students who are pursuing a career in broadcast industry.

2. In July, launched new campaign with American Red Cross for urgently-needed blood donations, utilizing news production resources to create messaging and awareness of urgent need and to encourage viewers to donate blood.

1. Campaign's Day of Commitment was held on June 30, with campaign continuing through mid-Aug.

11. Capital structure:

1. Believes Co.'s securities are significantly undervalued.

2. Belief is reflected in Co.'s actions, including continued repurchase of equity during qtr.

3. Since Feb. 2020, and through to date, repurchased approx. 19m shares, representing 21% of total shares outstanding as of beginning of year.

4. While proposed exchange of Diamond's unsecured notes resulted in lower participation than Co.'s expected, believes lender's decision not to exchange indicates their belief in long-term positive value of Diamond.

5. Continues to engage with financial institutions on ways to optimize capital structure to delever and lower cost of capital.

2Q20 Financials (L.R.)

1. Note:

1. Inclusion of sports segment this year, which was not in last year's first eight-month numbers, is responsible for many of larger changes in actual results vs. same period last year.

2. Therefore, in many cases, Co. will be speaking about results vs. prior year pro forma, which is a much more meaningful comparison and assumes Co. owns RSNs in those periods.

2. Distributor and Team Rebates, and Sports Rights Amortization:

1. Pursuant to GAAP, Co. is required to accrue total estimated rebate amount owed to distributors across 2Q20-4Q20, which will reduce distribution revenue in each qtr.

1. Cash outlay to distributors is not expected to occur until after 2020.

2. On team side, rebate associated with overpayment for fewer games to be played in season, is expected to be realized in part in 3Q20 with majority in 4Q20 as lower sports rights payments.

3. Therefore, adjusted EBITDA for year is expected to reflect both team rebates to Co. and Co.'s rebates to distributors.

4. Expects rebates from teams to be greater than what Co. pays out to distributors.

5. There will be a timing as it pertains to cash flow with Co. realizing benefit of lower sports rights payments this year in advance of distributor rebates being made after 2020.

2. Sports rights amortization, which is included in media and programming production expense line and which is non-cash and not factored into calculation of adjusted EBITDA, gets recognized over applicable sports season.

1. In 2Q, there were no professional games played and therefore, sports rights amortization was minimal.

2. Expects sports rights amortization for 3Q to increase nearing high level of sports games currently scheduled in period.

3. For 4Q, sports rights amortization is expected to be much lower with baseball's regular season likely completed, and with NBA and NHL games for 2021 season likely starting later in qtr. than normal.

3. Results:

1. Consolidated media revenue up $539m due to inclusion of Local Sports segment, which was not in 2Q19 results.

1. On pro forma basis, total media revenues of $1.260b, down vs. 2Q19 media revenues of $1.710b due to a number of factors, which Co. has previously discussed, most notably, weakness in advertising market due to pandemic, absence of live sports, associated accrual for distributor rebates and absence of DISH carriage fees.

2. Media revenues came in below guidance range Co. gave on last earnings call by $119m, due to $124m of distributor rebates Co. accrued during qtr., which was not included in guidance last qtr. because at that time, it didn't know how many games the leagues were going to schedule.

1. Excluding accrued rebate, revenue would have been within guidance range.

3. Media revenues $669m for Broadcast and Other segments (excludes RSNs); within guidance range with advertising and distribution revenues coming in as expected.

1. Advertising market improved as Co. moved through qtr.

2. June ended with Broadcast and Other segments declining 26% YoverY, which was significant improvement over 43% drop in April.

3. July has seen improvement continuing, finishing down 20% for month.

4. Even as political ramps up in 3Q and is expected to displace other advertising categories, Co. still expects to finish 3Q down 15-22% in core advertising, which is improvement over 2Q performance.

2. Subscriber churn across all segments was 7% YoverY; slightly higher than trend over past few quarters, but understandable given impact of COVID on economy and number of people that are unemployed in country.

3. Consolidated media OpEx $569m; down 50% on pro forma basis vs. 2Q19's $1.139b, and that's due to absence of live games, lower sports rights amortization and proactive cost controls.

1. Focus on managing expenses during qtr. drove $11m positive variance to guidance.

4. Consolidated adjusted EBITDA increased 31% to $254m, due to inclusion of Local Sports segment.

1. On pro forma basis, adjusted EBITDA declined $391m, driven by $330m decline at Local Sports segment and $61m decline at Broadcast and Other segments.

2. Sports segment adjusted EBITDA $110m; down from 2Q19's pro forma $440m, and that's due to distributor rebate accrual, absence of DISH, which was in 2Q19 numbers, and impact of COVID on number of games.

3. Unlike GAAP results for sports segment which included minimal amortization due to no live sports being played, Local Sports adjusted EBITDA reflected continuation of sports payments made during qtr.

4. Sports segment results during qtr. reflect approval for rebates to distributors, but no benefit from expected rebates from teams, which are expected in 2H20.

5. Excluding accrued rebate, Co. beat total co. adjusted EBITDA on additional cost controls at Broadcast and Other segments.

5. Consolidated adjusted free cash flow, excluding non-recurring legal ligation COVID transaction and regulatory items of $9m, was $46m; $79m below lower end of guidance.

1. Excluding rebate accrual, exceeded guidance slightly.

2. 1H20 adjusted free cash flow $156m.

3. Using estimated share count through 08/04/20 of approx. 79m shares outstanding, that reflects additional shares that Co. bought back here in 3Q, that results in free cash flow per share of $2.11 in 1H20.

6. Diluted EPS on 81m weighted avg. common shares at June 30 was $3.12, or $3.21 when adjusted for non-recurring items.

7. Liquidity position in both credit silos is strong, with neither silo's revolver drawn, and both silos having ample cash on hand.

1. Launched exchange for all of outstanding Diamond's 6.625% senior notes, $66m of aggregate principal amount or approx. 4% of outstanding issue was exchanged for $31m of new 12.750% notes and cash payments of approx. $10m.

2. In total, transaction reduced debt by $35m.

3. While Co. would have liked to have exchanged more of bonds, feedback it received was that noteholders agreed with Co. that bonds are undervalued and so chose to hold on for future upside.

8. Repurchased over 5m shares of common stock at avg. price of just over $16 per share.

1. For 3Q-to-date, repurchased over 4m additional shares.

2. Since start of year, 21% of total shares outstanding and 29% of float have been bought back.

9. Continued to execute on plan to reduce costs with savings for short term and longer term.

1. Continued to scrutinize all spending, delaying or eliminating non-essential expenses, including open positions, media and promotional spend, T&E and CapEx, in addition to variable expenses to come with fewer games and lower revenues.

2. Continues to look for additional opportunities.

3. Confident that Co. can handle prolonged period of weakness by executing opportunities identified, and additional steps it could take, if necessary.

10. Broadcast and Other segments media revenues down 7% YoverY, as advertising revenue was significantly impacted by pandemic.

1. 36% decline in core advertising revenue was partially offset by higher political revenue and increase in distribution revenue.

2. Broadcast segment's revenue benefited from $25m in management incentive fees paid by Local Sports segment that was not in 2Q19 results and gets eliminated in consolidation.

3. Came in at middle of revenue guidance range, and $12m over high-end of adjusted EBITDA guidance.

11. Sports segment media revenues $616m; down 38% vs. pro forma results of $992m in 2Q19.

1. Much of decline was expected and was due primarily to absence of DISH, lack of advertising revenues related to postponement of games, subscriber churn and accrual distributor rebate.

2. Excluding accrued rebate, Co. was close to guidance.

12. Media expenses $106m; 84% decline to 2Q19's pro forma $659m.

1. Primarily result of minimal sports rights amortization being booked in qtr. due to no professional games being played.

2. As compared to guidance, media expenses were slightly higher due to slightly higher-than-expected production programming expenses.

13. Local Sports adjusted EBITDA $110m; below pro forma results of $440m in 2Q19, and below guidance of $190-202m, due to distributor rebate accrual.

1. If excluding rebate accrual, Co. would have beat Local Sports adjusted EBITDA guidance.

14. Distributor rebate accrual:

1. If backing that out, Co. either met or exceeded all of 2Q guidance.

4. 2Q20-End Balance Sheet:

1. Consolidated cash $622m; includes $171m at STG and $436m at Diamond.

2. Total debt $12.399b.

3. Net leverage ratio for consolidated SBGI, 6.4x.

4. Sinclair Television Group's first lien indebtedness ratio on trailing eight quarters was 2.6x, on covenant of [4.5%], and 4.5x on net leverage basis through bonds.

5. Diamond's first lien indebtedness ratio on a trailing four quarters was 6.5x, on covenant of [6.25%], which only springs if revolver is drawn over 35%.

6. On total net leverage basis through bonds, Diamond was levered 8.5x.

5. 3Q20 Guidance:

1. There is still much uncertainty around resilience of economy and COVID's impact.

1. Guidance will, therefore, be limited to 3Q.

2. Any change to expected plans in sports leagues could cause reported Local Sports results to deviate meaningfully from guidance.

3. Broadcast and Other segments:

1. Media revenue $777-805m.

1. Up approx. 6-10% from last year's pro forma $733m.

2. Driven by higher political and distribution revenue, partially offset by projected 15-22% decline in core advertising.

2. Adjusted EBITDA $187-211m, vs. $216m pro forma last year.

4. Sports segment:

1. Media revenue $718-727m.

1. Down 15-16% to last year's pro forma $858m.

2. Projections include impact from distributor rebate accrual.

2. Adjusted EBITDA $402-410m, vs. $425m pro forma last year, with decline primarily due to distributor rebate accrual, absence of DISH carriage fees and subscriber churn, offset by lower rights payments to teams.

5. There is sizable increase in GAAP media expenses in 3Q.

1. Due to MLB, NBA and NHL sports rights amortization being expensed in qtr., reflecting when games will be played.

2. While this increases expenses on GAAP basis, it is non-cash item that does not impact adjusted EBITDA, which is based on sports rights payments, not rights amortization.

3. Sports rights payments reflect offsetting benefit from teams on the fewer games with some of that partially reflected in 3Q and majority in 4Q.

6. Consolidated Co.:

1. Media revenues $1.460-1.497b.

2. Adjusted EBITDA $589-621m.

3. Adjusted free cash flow $374-411m.

4. Based on current share count of approx. 74m shares, free cash flow per share approx. $5.05-5.55.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Our first question is coming from Aaron Watts of Deutsche Bank.

AARON LEE WATTS, RESEARCH ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK AG, RESEARCH DIVISION: I have a few questions I wanted to run through quickly. I guess, first, on the television station group. Encouraged to see the improvement month-to-month in core advertising. Are you seeing any fits and starts on that in your market that are seeing some ebbs and flows of COVID cases? And also, are the bookings coming in a lot later relative to where you've kind of trended historically or at least in the prior year?

ROBERT D. WEISBORD, PRESIDENT OF BROADCAST & CHIEF ADVERTISING REVENUE OFFICER, SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.: Yes, I'll handle that. This is Rob. We are not seeing the fits and starts. It's been pretty consistent. You're correct. It's being booked a little bit later. They're holding on to it to see how the COVID is affecting the different DMAs that we're in. However, we've been encouraged through our virtual trainings, virtual sales presentations that we've been able to communicate in this new norm and being able to handle it, and that's why you're seeing the positivity and the pace moving forward.

AARON LEE WATTS: Okay. And in terms of bookings coming in later or early?

ROBERT D. WEISBORD: No, the bookings are coming in later. Growing more month-to-month than they are quarterly, semiannually or annually.

AARON LEE WATTS: Okay. Got it. And then as best as you have clarity on today, can you give us the latest on the stability of the underlying sub base for your station group and the RSNs? And has your near term, medium-term outlook for cord-cutting changed at all based on what you're seeing right now?

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER, EXECUTIVE VP & CFO, SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.: Yes. So I'll take that one. So Aaron, as we -- as I mentioned, we saw across all the platforms, subscriber churn year-over-year, down about 7%. Again, that's really coming from one primary MVPD. But we have -- what you're going to see in our guidance for Q3 is that we have pretty much mirrored that level of churn, and that's really based on some of the public commentary from the distributors themselves here recently as well as just really not having a lot of visibility as to what's going to happen with the churn. As we talked about, there's 2 schools of thought that are out there. One is that people currently may churn just because of the status of their employment and the economy. But on the other hand, right, you do have government assistance for those people. You also have the fact that, again, the TV is really the only form of entertainment that's out there right now. And especially right now with the games, people not being able to go to the games in order to watch their favorite team, local team, they would have to see those on the RSN. So 2 divergent views there. I really don't know where it ends up. So to be conservative, we have forecasted our Q3 to mirror the Q2 levels.

AARON LEE WATTS: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a couple of questions from me on the Diamond Sports side. With the Comcast renewal now inked. I assume you have a pretty large percentage of your distribution locked up over the next few years. Is that a fair statement? Do you have a percentage that you could give us of kind of what is locked in now? And for how long?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY, PRESIDENT & CEO, SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.: So 85% of the RSN subscribers are locked in for 2 years or more.

AARON LEE WATTS: Perfect. And Lucy, I just want to make sure I was clear on your comments, and I appreciate all the color around kind of the rebates and the refunds from the teams. If I'm just specifically thinking about cash in, cash out, to be clear, when do you expect kind of cash in from the teams in terms of the rebates there? And I think you said the cash out to the MVPDs will happen next year. Am I hearing that right or thinking about that right?

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Yes. So contractually, with the distributors, the -- because of the measurement periods, the cash out would occur after 2020. Each contract is different so I'm not going to get into the whens after that. But the rebates and the overpayments for -- to the teams, all occurs this year, some in Q3, but the majority really in Q4 once we get through the full season.

AARON LEE WATTS: And in the end, those cash in, cash out obviously, differences in timing, but you're saying that those should be relatively equal or even the rebates from the teams to you should be greater than what you have to pay out to the MVPDs?

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Yes. So what I'm saying is the amount that we get in will be greater than the amount that we pay out, and that's really because of the variability, the differences in how the minimum games are all calculated from one contract to the next.

AARON LEE WATTS: Okay. Perfect. And last one for me...

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Aaron, just to be clear because, again, there are -- there's a lot of misinformation on the street as it relates to this with people modeling that Diamond is going to pay more than what they get in. And as Chris said, those are just not correct. We expect to get in more than what we will pay out because of the differences in the calculations.

AARON LEE WATTS: Okay. Perfect. I'm glad. Last one for me. And again, appreciate the time. You repaid your revolver outstanding balance. It sounds like you're comfortable with liquidity. How do you think about that liquidity now going forward as you look at where your bonds are currently trading? I don't think I heard anything about more bond buybacks this quarter. I know you also still have preferred stock outstanding. How do you kind of weigh the order of importance of attacking those different opportunities? And that's it.

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Sure, Aaron. So look, so we have -- our first and foremost, right, is the priority to continue to grow Diamond, right, whether it's through acquisitions, investments for the growth opportunities. But we are also committed to strengthening the capital table, lowering our cost of capital and deleveraging, right? So as we previously have discussed on other calls, and we will continue to look for ways, right, to deploy the cash and to capital -- optimize the capital structure. So look, everything is on the table right now. We're evaluating a lot of things. So it could be anything from redeeming the preferred, additional debt exchanges, receivable financings, designating subs is unrestricted as well as looking at new acquisition opportunities and again, investing for all the growth opportunities, which is the reason why we bought Diamond. So all of those things are being evaluated and on the table.

OPERATOR: Our next question is coming from Dan Kurnos of Benchmark Company.

DANIEL LOUIS KURNOS, MD & SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, THE BENCHMARK COMPANY, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Just so we're, I guess, maybe all clear in terms of some more granularity just around Comcast and Marquee. Just -- Lucy, thanks for the color around subs, it helps all part of the equation. Just trying to understand sort of the timing of when -- Marquee, was it all just when the Comcast deal was done? I'm just trying to sort of understand the distribution delta from 2Q to 3Q on the RSN side? Or if there's some other rebate, increased rebate nuance that we might be missing?

And then on the core side, maybe, Rob, you could just give us some more color just on sort of category improvement and sort of where you're seeing the particular pockets of strength? And what gives you the confidence that we kind of continue to sequentially improve throughout the year?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Okay, Dan, I'll speak to Comcast, and Rob will speak to the core question. In terms of changes, not much changed with Comcast at all. They continue to carry all the RSNs. They previously carried all of the Tennis Channel, our broadcast stations, the only real change was Marquee, and they picked up marquee the moment they signed the agreement. And as I noted in the prepared remarks, Marquee ended up getting into new geographies that the cuts were not previously distributed on. So we're very happy with that outcome.

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: And Dan, let me just answer your question on the dollars. So with the -- so there, we do have the distributor rebate accrued in Q3. As we said, that will hit Q2, Q3 and Q4. So you are seeing that delta. As well as, remember, the RSN contract doesn't actually come up until the end of the quarter. That's when it expires. So you would not see the Comcast impact in the Q3 numbers.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: And just a side note there, so you understand, even though the RSN contract was renewed early and it doesn't actually expire until the end of September. That's because we did this all as one deal and everything will be coterminous on the other side.

DANIEL LOUIS KURNOS: Rob, before you answer, just, Chris, just on that, does that -- the TV side then is pushed back to the RSN start date now? Because I think that's a bit of nuance that might be missed there.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: No. Actually, the TV side is going forward to the RSN expiration.

DANIEL LOUIS KURNOS: Okay. And then, Rob, your comments on core?

ROBERT D. WEISBORD: Sure. Yes. On the strength, we continue to see services perform well. We have pharmaceutical that has joined the strength, and we're seeing the education category pick up as well. We expect in the back half, towards the end of third quarter going in the fourth quarter to see auto getting healthier than what we've seen it. They've had a supply chain issue. We expect that to be fixed as the plants have been reopened. And the '21s, we'll be hitting the dealerships.

So again, we've become less reliant on the auto business to drive our revenue. And as in the past, I'll reiterate that we've gone from ourselves being [generalist to] specialists, and that continues to lead to a better performances.

DANIEL LOUIS KURNOS: Got it. That's helpful. And Chris, I apologize if I missed this. Did you give us an update on where you're at with the DTC?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: No, we haven't -- that was not in my remarks. There's a lot of work going on in DTC right now, it's definitely going to be an important part of the future for the RSNs for tennis and also for broadcast. And it's too early right now to give specific guidance, but we are busy adding that feature to our new digital reboot, which will come out next year, and it will be complementary to the MVPD product that we have today.

OPERATOR: Our next question is coming from Davis Hebert of Wells Fargo.

JAMES DAVIS HEBERT, DIRECTOR & SENIOR HIGH YIELD ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: I want to ask on the current accruals and the rebates, I understand, I think, the cash flow piece. How firm are those rebate levels, I mean, to the extent MLB stops and starts or maybe further under-delivers on those live games?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Yes. So the numbers could obviously change if the number of games change. And it's really just a mathematical calculation. And the sort of hedged nature of our contracts would continue to apply as the games continue to shrink.

JAMES DAVIS HEBERT: Okay. But would it be fair to say that if there are -- if you delivered -- under delivered, it's not going to be material to what you've already accrued for?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: It shouldn't be material to our actual EBITDA at the end of the day, but it could certainly increase the amount of rebates from the teams and the amount of rebates to the MVPDs.

JAMES DAVIS HEBERT: Okay. Understood. And then on the team payment side, is all that getting taken care of this year? Or have you had negotiations with the teams to perhaps, smooth that out over a longer period of time? Or are there other negotiations going on?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: It should all happen this year to the extent some teams have issues from a cash flow perspective, we'll have to see. We have no indication of that so far. And what we've been doing is essentially withholding current payments right now to chip away the balance.

JAMES DAVIS HEBERT: Okay. And then, Lucy, you mentioned a lot of different liability management possibilities. I wondered, would a tender offer, perhaps, be in the conversations in capture discount in Diamond sports bonds, just thinking you'll be sitting on a decent amount of cash at the political, maybe that's an open win versus an exchange. But just curious your thoughts on something like that.

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Well, so the political revenues are really belong to STG. And again, we've said in the past that each silo would be self-funded. So STG's political has really gone to shareholder returns, whether it's the dividend or the share repurchases. And Diamond's cash flow is there to fund Diamond. So we would not look to pull STG's cash over to Diamond for that. But again, when you're talking as much debt as diamond has outstanding, anything we do, I think you should expect would be a bigger type transaction.

JAMES DAVIS HEBERT: Okay. And then my last question is, I believe you had a year to rebrand the RSMs. I'm just curious, the timing on that or if you got to reprieve with the COVID-19 situation.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: We have [still] more than a year on that. And the new name will be announced and released early next year.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Our next question is coming from Steven Cahall of Wells Fargo.

STEVEN LEE CAHALL, SENIOR ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: So maybe if we've learned one thing about the RSN business. It's just that the earnings power may be a little lower. And so the debt level that you originally decided was appropriate, might be a little too high. And Davis asked and, we've talked a little bit about ways to renegotiate that debt level down. Just a really big overhang on what's otherwise a really good TV broadcast business. So if you kind of step back, how do you really think about just steps that you can take to remove that overhang from the debt on the RSN business so that you can capture more of the fair value in the TV business?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, as we mentioned, we're busy looking at several alternatives for -- to delever Diamond that we think there are many options there. And as I've stated many times that we see these entities as independent and self-funding. So we don't see any reason for value or cash to be going from one silo to the other. And really, we are looking at our valuation, and should be done on some of the parts basis.

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Yes. And Steve, look, what I would add is, I think what people are missing is the investment thesis of why we bought the RSNs in the first place, right? So as we look ahead, right, you've got it -- including all the growth opportunities and the synergies, which, again, is the reason we bought the RSNs. We love the business. It is a good business. Are we -- is leverage here in the near term more elevated? Yes. I think that's probably though for just about any company that's out there in the U.S. today as a result of COVID. So we have some elevated leverage. It will take us a little bit longer to get down to our target leverage, but we are focused on getting down to the target leverage. But part of how we're going to do that is through all the growth opportunities, again, whether it's the production programming synergies, cross-promotion, cross-programming digital opportunities, legalized sports betting, rebranding and selling all of our digital impression, so much there that we haven't even started to mine with Diamond.

STEVEN LEE CAHALL: Great. And then maybe just on the retrans side, you've done some recent station renewals with Viacom, CBS and with Comcast, as you pointed out, do you feel like you have the ability to maybe give us either a qualitative or quantitative outlook on net retrans growth for 2020?

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: So as you know, we do not have full year guidance on the table. So at this point, we're not ready to put that out there. As I said, there's a lot of variability in what's happening in the pay TV universe, so -- which is a factor that would go into that. So at this point, no full year guidance.

OPERATOR: Our next question is coming from John Janedis of Wolfe Research.

JOHN JANEDIS, MD & SENIOR MEDIA ANALYST, WOLFE RESEARCH, LLC: I'll be brief. One is a follow-up on the ad side, (inaudible) ways of COVID across the portfolio. What impact are you seeing or do you expect to see on back-to-school spending? And is that typically a swing factor come into that at [later] day? I think you separately given the where we are on the political side. Increasingly, we end up seeing -- we do see a democratic sweep in the fall. How does that change the regulatory landscape and any purpose for your businesses?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: (inaudible)

ROBERT D. WEISBORD: Okay. Go ahead. Sorry.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: No, no, I was just going to say, hopefully, you heard that, John was a little muffled. But Rob, why don't you handle the back-to-school question, and I will handle the regulatory.

ROBERT D. WEISBORD: Back-to-school typically is not a large revenue driver for the company. But with COVID going on and the hybrid learnings of some markets going back, some hybrid, some school from home. We're in the midst of launching several creative non-traditional programs to generate revenue that we typically wouldn't be thinking of.

So in that space, we expect to be able to scale several concepts across our platform. So we do think we'll be able to capture revenue that we probably haven't had in the past in regards to back-to-school.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Okay. So in terms of your question around the election and the regulatory environment, I think it's worthy to note that broadcasting has significant support on both sides of the aisle. You saw that with letters from both, a very large amount of both Democrats and Republicans, supporting local media and promoting its survival is vital to the communities we serve. So we feel, as an industry in good shape with bipartisan support. So we're not concerned about a change in administration and the notion of reregulating broadcasting would be akin to picking on the little guy. I do think some of the bigger companies like [big tech] will have more regulations in the future. But our industry is so small and fragmented, it just -- it wouldn't make sense.

JOHN JANEDIS: Got it, Chris. If I could sneak in one more. Just a follow-up on Comcast. And maybe a bit more broadly, look, as you said, the market's been negative RSNs. Can you give us an update on how you're doing the landscape? Obviously, you talked about 85% of the subs being locked in, but have distributors in those negotiations -- have they taken a harder look at that business? Any change in tiering up or anything else to highlight?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Sure. So we have seen in all of our negotiations, essentially, status quo environment in terms of terms, tiering, pricing, all the various elements that go into a distribution agreement. So really -- and we've now cycled through all the major and small MVPDs. And say, for one, Dish, we found what we expected, which is that this is very valuable content to the distributors, it drives subscriptions. And we have achieved what we set out to achieve with them, which was status quo renewals.

OPERATOR: Thank you. At this time, I'd like to turn the floor back over to Mr. Ripley, President and CEO, for closing comments.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Thank you. I would like to conclude by thanking all of our employees, customers and stakeholders for their patience during this unprecedented time. We are comfortable that the actions we are taking are not only helping us manage the challenges in the short term, but are also positioning the company for continued to test in the future.

Thank you for participating on our earnings call this morning. If anyone has any additional questions, please feel free to contact us.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's event. You may disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.

urn:contentItem:5PTY-2GY1-JB20-G0V7-00000-00Event Brief of Q3 2017 NextEra Energy Inc and Nextera Energy Partners LP Earnings Call - Final2017-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis102617sg.769Event Brief of Q3 2017 NextEra Energy Inc and Nextera Energy Partners LP Earnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Armando Pimentel - NextEra Energy, Inc.,CEO of Nextera Energy Resources LLC and President of Nextera Energy Resources LLC

. James L. Robo - NextEra Energy, Inc.,Chairman of the Board, CEO, President and Chairman of Florida Power & Light Company

. John W. Ketchum - NextEra Energy, Inc.,CFO and EVP of Finance

. Matthew Roskot

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Christopher James Turnure - JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division,Analyst

. Gregory Harmon Gordon - Evercore ISI, Research Division,Senior MD, Head of Power & Utilities Research and Fundamental Research Analyst

. Julien Patrick Dumoulin-Smith - BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division,Director and Head of the US Power, Utilities, & Alternative Energy Equity Research

. Michael Jay Lapides - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division,VP

. Paul Thomas Ridzon - KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., Research Division,VP and Equity Research Analyst

. Shahriar Pourreza - Guggenheim Securities, LLC, Research Division,MD and Head of North American Power

. Stephen Calder Byrd - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,MD and Head of North American Research for the Power and Utilities and Clean Energy

. Steven Isaac Fleishman - Wolfe Research, LLC,MD & Senior Utilities Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 3Q17 GAAP net income attributable to Co. of $847m or $1.79 per share. Expects 2020 adjusted EPS to be $7.85-8.45, 2018 adjusted EPS to be $6.80-7.30 and 2017 adjusted EPS to be $6.35-6.85.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 3Q17 GAAP net income attributable to Co. = $847m.

2. 3Q17 adjusted earnings = $875m.

3. 3Q17 GAAP EPS attributable to Co. = $1.79.

4. 3Q17 adjusted EPS = $1.85.

5. 2020 adjusted EPS guidance = $7.85-8.45.

6. 2018 adjusted EPS guidance = $6.80-7.30.

7. 2017 adjusted EPS guidance = $6.35-6.85.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

3Q17 Review (J.K.)

1. 2017 Hurricanes:

1. Residents of Caribbean and southern US were recently impacted by the dangerous and deadly effects of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, Maria and Nate.

2. Hurricane Irma was the largest hurricane event Florida Power & Light has ever faced.

3. Powerful storm impacted all 35 counties and 27,000 square miles of FPL's service territory, causing more than 4.4m customers to lose power.

4. In preparation for hurricane, FPL assembled and pre-positioned the largest restoration workforce in U.S. history, which grew to approx. 28,000 at its peak.

1. This preparation and coordinated response combined with the hardening and automation investments that FPL has made since 2006 to build a stronger, smarter and more storm-resilient energy grid enabled the company to restore service to over 2m customers in one day and to complete the restoration of all 4.4m customers in 10 days.

5. Efforts of NEE team resulted in the fastest restoration of the largest amount of people by any one utility in US history.

6. Mutual aid in times of disaster is one of the hallmarks of Co.'s industry and this storm was no exception.

1. Co. is deeply grateful for the assistance provided by industry partners.

2. Hurricane Irma Restoration:

1. Based upon a methodology developed by National Center for Atmospheric Research, Hurricane Irma had an approx. 50% higher damage potential than Hurricane Wilma, and resulted in over 90% of FPL customers losing power vs. 75% for Hurricane Wilma.

2. Notwithstanding the fact that Hurricane Irma was a much stronger storm impacting a larger portion of FPL's service territory, there was approx. 80% reduction to pole damage and an 80% improvement in the time to energize all substations following the storm vs. Hurricane Wilma.

3. After day one, FPL had 50% of its customers restored, also an 80% improvement vs. Wilma restoration efforts.

1. In fact, 95% of customers impacted by Irma were restored in one week and while the avg. customer outage from Hurricane Wilma lasted for over five days.

2. Avg. outage for customers affected by Hurricane Irma was roughly two days; 60% improvement.

4. Total GDP within service territory averages over $1b per day.

1. By reducing avg. customer outage by more than three days vs. Wilma, believes the avoided economic loss to the state has more than paid for the $3b in hardening investments Co. have made since 2006.

5. Given the size and scale of this hurricane, the Florida Public Service Commission has opened a docket to solicit customer comments and to take evidence on the statewide utility response to Irma, including an analysis of the impact prior hardening activities had on restoration efforts.

6. Believes that the improvement in FPL's storm restoration efforts shows that ongoing transmission and distribution investments, together with preparation and coordinated response are providing significant value to customers.

7. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) We'll go to Stephen Byrd, Morgan Stanley.

STEPHEN CALDER BYRD, MD AND HEAD OF NORTH AMERICAN RESEARCH FOR THE POWER AND UTILITIES AND CLEAN ENERGY, MORGAN STANLEY, RESEARCH DIVISION: I wanted to check in on your excess balance sheet capacity and just generally, your balance sheet strength. You've been putting up additional wins in the renewables business, and it looks like there's also upside at the utility. When we think about using that excess balance sheet capacity, do you see significant organic opportunities at the different business units? Or do you think you're likely to still have excess balance sheet capacity through the end of the decade?

JOHN W. KETCHUM, CFO AND EVP OF FINANCE, NEXTERA ENERGY, INC.: Okay. So first of all, the excess balance sheet capacity is about $3 billion to $5 billion through 2020. And when you look at the financial plan that we have laid out through 2020 at the investor conference, the CapEx that we already have planned for the FPL business and the Energy Resources business does not take into account that $3 billion to $5 billion of excess balance sheet capacity.

So what do we do with it? We have a few options. I think our preferred option would be to find incremental capital investment opportunities that drive long-term value for shareholders and that also help to create growth post 2020, which we view as being strong, given all the potential growth platform opportunities that we have in the next decade, given where we see renewables and also given all the opportunities that FPL has on Eric's side of the business.

STEPHEN CALDER BYRD: Understood. And just shifting gears to storage. You made some interesting remarks about storage. And I guess, we're hearing that storage solicitations are now a regular part of a lot of renewable procurements. I was just curious, your opinion as to whether we're currently in the right ZIP code that you think many customers will opt for storage linked with renewables or do you think that's a few years down the road? What's your sense of the likely customer appetite over the next couple of years for storage linked with renewables and PPAs?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. Storage is very real now. And I think -- and as evidenced by the project we announced today with the 30 megawatts tied to an existing solar project, making it the largest combined solar plus storage project in the U.S. But when you look at where storage economics are, storage costs continue to come down significantly, efficiency continues to improve at a rate where we can now combine storage with solar and really beat the pricing, the existing variable costs just to operate a nuclear or coal plant, and be pretty darn competitive even with combined cycle gas facilities.

And what's the result of that? Because of that, on almost every solar procurement that we are bidding on today, counterparties are asking us not only for solar bid, but also for a combined solar plus storage bid. They clearly understand the benefits that are created by the firm dispatchability of the combined products.

So the short answer is, we're already here and things should only continue to improve as we go forward and as tax incentives phase down in the next decade, and you can combine storage, which will be even lower cost, even more efficient, with an even lower cost and more efficient solar panel and balance of system cost, we see that as a very viable product going forward, and we also are continuing to look for opportunities to combine solar with wind or storage with wind. And with that, I don't know if Armando has anything that he would like to add.

ARMANDO PIMENTEL, CEO OF NEXTERA ENERGY RESOURCES LLC AND PRESIDENT OF NEXTERA ENERGY RESOURCES LLC, NEXTERA ENERGY, INC.: Steven, real quick, recall that at the investor conference, what we laid out was the roughly $700 million of CapEx opportunities in the storage market through 2020. We continue to think that's a good number. That doesn't mean that customers aren't significantly interested in what's going on and proactively asking for bids. And even as the cost estimate comes down, we continue to believe that this is going to be a significant opportunity early part of the next decade.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Steve Fleishman, Wolfe Research.

STEVEN ISAAC FLEISHMAN, MD & SENIOR UTILITIES ANALYST, WOLFE RESEARCH, LLC: Just one question on the NEP financing for the new drops. Could you just repeat kind of the financing plan that you laid out for the new drops announced today?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes, absolutely, Steve. So for the new drops, remember, right around the time of the investor conference, we completed the $550 million convertible preferred offering at a 4.5% coupon, lowest coupon ever for a convertible offering. That will comprise the lion's share of the $812 million equity price for that acquisition. The balance will come from cash on hand. Now cash on hand is really coming from the convertible debt offering that we closed on in September at a 1.5% coupon, with the up 25% and then the cap [capped] call on top of that given a second [arm of] consideration of up 50%.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Greg Gordon, Evercore Partners.

GREGORY HARMON GORDON, SENIOR MD, HEAD OF POWER & UTILITIES RESEARCH AND FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH ANALYST, EVERCORE ISI, RESEARCH DIVISION: The first is you've reclassified a significant chunk of your wind assets from merchant to contracted, and there's a footnote that describes why. But can you go into some more detail as to what the underlying assumptions are that -- with regard to profitability of those assets and why they've shifted.

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. It's really pretty simple. So those are repowering assets that were formerly ERCOT merchant assets. And the way the economics works is that roughly 90% of the gross margin comes from the production tax credits.

So you can think of the PTC as essentially being a contractual hedge. So every megawatt-hour that we're generating, we're getting paid $24 on that megawatt-hour for 90% of the gross margin. And so given that, and also the fact that some of those projects will carry financial hedges going forward, the more appropriate classification over the next 10 years during the PTC period is as a contracted asset.

GREGORY HARMON GORDON: Well that makes a pretty underlying strong statement about the incremental IRR you're getting on the repowerings if the vast majority of your return at the hurdle rate is coming just from getting the PTCs without worrying about a substantial energy margin. Is that the right way to think about it?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Well, yes, I mean, remember too -- I mean, it's about half the CapEx and because of -- it's half the CapEx, you're getting the driver from the PTCs and then energy is the upside. That's why we've said the unlevered IRRs are a few ticks up from what we would get on a newbuild wind project.

GREGORY HARMON GORDON: Fantastic. My second question is, if you would humor us, can you delineate what the basic assumptions you were assuming are on your baseline tax case?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. I mean, it's really what came out on September 27. So you can think of it as a 20% corporate tax rate, 100% immediate expensing, and then we've made an assumption on what the interest limitation is that I'm probably not going to share on this call.

GREGORY HARMON GORDON: Fair enough. But the industry EI has been lobbying on behalf of the industry to try and achieve an offramp or an exemption on interest deductibility and bonus depreciation, correct?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: It -- well, I'll let Jim take it.

JAMES L. ROBO, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, CEO, PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF FLORIDA POWER & LIGHT COMPANY, NEXTERA ENERGY, INC.: So Greg, listen, I just think on tax reform, it's very fluid right now. Obviously, the industry has been weighing in, I've been spending a lot of time on it, and we don't even have a bill out of House Ways and Means yet. So I think it's too early, really, to say anything about where any of this stands other than you can rest assured, I'm highly engaged on this.

OPERATOR: We'll go to Michael Lapides, Goldman Sachs.

MICHAEL JAY LAPIDES, VP, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Guys, couple of questions. One, probably for Armando, which is, can you talk about, when you think about your renewable pipeline, how much of that is the counterparty of -- traditional regulated utility versus how much of it is a corporate entity, whether a big tech company or someone else?

ARMANDO PIMENTEL: So Michael, right now, for us, I'd say, 90% of what we're doing is probably the more traditional customers, and those could be the rate-regulated utilities or the munis and co-ops. And I'd say, 5% to 10% are the latter, which you asked about for the corporate entities, what we call C&I companies. We continue to see more C&I companies out there. And actually, we are engaging in that business more proactively today than we have in the past. So I would expect, for us, that 5% to 10% to go up.

MICHAEL JAY LAPIDES: Got it. And then, guys, how are you thinking about the Section 201 case and some of the recent developments and what that could do if any to solar-related demand? Really, for 2018 solar demands, but even for the next few years?

JAMES L. ROBO: So Michael, this is Jim. Obviously, this is something we're watching very closely. I think I spoke on this issue in September. We're fine in '17 and '18 because we prebought our panels when we saw this going on. '19 is probably the year we're most concerned about. That's probably where there is potentially a pinch point, depending on where the ITC comes out and where the administration comes out on this.

Post '19, I think there's going to be -- the market's going to -- the market will have time to react to whatever happens, and I think we'll get back to normal business in 2020 and beyond. But '19 is our focus, and we're working quite hard in a number of fronts. And it's something that we're watching closely, and we're highly engaged on it and the whole team is highly engaged on it across the board.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Julien Dumoulin-Smith, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

JULIEN PATRICK DUMOULIN-SMITH, DIRECTOR AND HEAD OF THE US POWER, UTILITIES, & ALTERNATIVE ENERGY EQUITY RESEARCH, BOFA MERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: Let me start real quickly on the 201 issue there if I can. What are you expecting when you talk about 2019 and really beyond that in terms of market reaction? I mean, what's your kind of playbook as far as you see this playing out right now? And then secondly, what is your expectation in terms of the positioning of parties and thinking about how this could actually play out over the next few months? Is a settlement possible, et cetera, to make this a little bit more palatable?

JAMES L. ROBO: So Julien, it's Jim again. I just think it's too early to tell what's going to happen here. And I think, honestly, there's a pretty broad range of potential outcomes on this, and I wouldn't care to speculate on what's going to happen. I think we'll see. We're -- and what we're doing is frankly scenario planning across a variety of different outcomes and making sure that we're going to be prepared in case of any potential outcome.

JULIEN PATRICK DUMOULIN-SMITH: Excellent. Well -- and looking beyond the current 2020 period, you guys have done a fantastic job in the repowering side thus far. I'm curious, how are you thinking about repowering opportunities under kind of a sub-100% PTC, call it, 80%, 60%? I mean, you've been pretty forward looking before across the industry, and this seems like an opportunity to pivot. Are you engaging with parties on that front? I mean, do you have an expectation for an ability to use those PTCs that are expired 2000 -- say, '12, '13 and '14 vintage projects as they come off in the early part of the next decade and repower those?

ARMANDO PIMENTEL: Armando...

JULIEN PATRICK DUMOULIN-SMITH: So I'm just thinking in the longer term.

ARMANDO PIMENTEL: Yes. Look, most of what -- not most, just about everything of what we're doing today is to make sure that we can grab the -- as many of these repowering opportunities through 2020, having safe harbored a good part of that equipment in order to get the 100% Production Tax Credits. There's already been one entity out there, which I'm sure you've seen, that has announced the project where they would be getting 80% Production Tax Credits and that the economics work for them under that scenario.

Our expectation is that when the Production Tax Credit goes down to 80%, that there are actually going to be some repowering opportunities that are going to work, maybe not necessarily for the reasons that some might believe. When we're looking at repowering opportunities, one of the things that we're looking at is, how close is the old asset, if you will, to the end of its PTC life, right? And if it's 9 or 10 years into its life, 100 -- taking the asset down and repowering it and putting it up and getting 100% PTCs for 10 years might work. But if it's at the end of 2020, if it's only gone through 7 years, let's say, you wouldn't necessarily want to repower the asset at that point and lose 3 years of the old PTCs.

But if you wait another year, now you're 8 years or 9 years, it may actually make sense to give up 1 year of the old PTCs and get 10 years of the 80% PTCs. So that scenario planning is something that we are spending a little bit of time right now. We certainly have a lot of assets that would be subject to that. But I do believe that there are going to be repowering opportunities that work with 80% PTCs.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Paul Ridzon, KeyBanc.

PAUL THOMAS RIDZON, VP AND EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST, KEYBANC CAPITAL MARKETS INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: John, I think on the second quarter call, you said look for most of the second half growth to hit the fourth quarter. I'm just trying to calibrate. We saw a 6.5% growth in the third quarter here. Did some of that growth shift quarters? And then just how do I think about the sub-par wind resource you had in the quarter? How does that figure into the numbers?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. So by the time of the second quarter call, we were pretty well into July, which was, well, not a terrific wind resource month. Things -- we were concerned about the trend for the rest of the quarter. For August and September, August ended up kind of following suit with July, and we're a little bit surprised because September rebounded a little bit more than we had expected. I think that September ended up being about 95% of normal. And now we've seen October has truly rebounded so far this month. That was part of it.

We had a little bit better performance out of other miscellaneous parts of the business, none worth pointing out individually that, when added up, put us in a little bit better position than what we were expecting for the quarter, including some origination activity that we had on the business.

PAUL THOMAS RIDZON: Should we think about that incremental positive as essentially being offset in the fourth quarter by the refinancings that you talked about?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. And so the fourth quarter -- that's why I think I made the comment that growth will be down a little bit in the fourth quarter. We have really been focused on liability management. When you look at our portfolio -- one of the things I made a comment on at the investor conference is, if you look at our financing portfolio, we have one of the longest average tenors combined with one of the lowest average interest rates of any of our peers. And that's because we constantly look at the portfolio for refinancing activity opportunities. And that -- those are the opportunities we're looking to execute on in the fourth quarter.

The remarks were that the MPV could be as high as $150 million. Obviously, those come with some prepayment penalties that do have some book impacts associated with them, but we're just trying to continue our trend of being very mindful that we're in an attractive low interest rate environment and looking at the balance sheet as we always do, to be opportunistic, and that's what you can expect would be reflected in the fourth quarter results.

PAUL THOMAS RIDZON: And you don't treat those kind of onetime -- make holes or anything as unusual items?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: No. We flow them through.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Shar Pourreza, Guggenheim Partners.

SHAHRIAR POURREZA, MD AND HEAD OF NORTH AMERICAN POWER, GUGGENHEIM SECURITIES, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Just a quick follow up on the battery storage comments, John. Did Dania filings that you filed for show that the asset was materially more economical than battery storage and solar, even in the 2022 time frame? So I'm curious on sort of how that fits in with your viewpoint that batteries plus solar could be economical with the CCGT?

And then just a follow-up on Dania, is -- looking at FP&L's gas assets, there are other plants that fit the similar economics as sort of the plant that you're converting. So I'm kind of curious if the Dania plant's a one-off. And do you see any opportunities thus far?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. I think we'll just tackle the Dania piece first. The Dania piece first is, one, you got to consider its location. I mean, it's in South Florida, it has a transmission advantage given its location. If you look at the economics on the reduced O&M on improving the fuel efficiency of that facility, given its location, that's why that one works.

We continue to look for other opportunities. We have the 50-megawatt battery storage pilot program in Florida where we will look to do a lot of the same things we've done on the Energy Resources side, including the project we announced today where we can actually combine our storage capability with newbuild solar in Florida.

And that -- those opportunities will come about not only through the 8 facilities we're currently building within the 1,600 post 2018. Where exactly that will end up will depend on where they're located in the overall economics of those facilities. But it's a terrific opportunity for Florida to take advantage of the same opportunities that our regulated customer base outside of Florida are looking for.

JAMES L. ROBO: And Shar, this is Jim. I just -- one other thing on storage and renewable competitiveness is we see storage and renewables being -- really competing very well against inefficient, old operating nuclear and coal plants where you look at those -- you look at the economics of those sites, they're anywhere from $0.04 to

$0.05 on a cash, cash cost per kilowatt basis to operate. These new CCGTs, particularly in a constrained place like Dania Beach, are very, very cost-effective and super fuel-efficient. And typically, you wouldn't see renewables and storage competing with that just yet.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Chris Turnure, JPMorgan.

CHRISTOPHER JAMES TURNURE, ANALYST, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: Given -- you guys probably have maybe 6 or so months to go to kind of finish out the '17 to '18 bucket of renewable backlog, could you just give us an update on how you might fall out within that 4-gigawatt range? Are you coming up on the bottom now? Will any of it kind of spill into 2019? In terms of your maybe original expectations, has anything changed in the last 3 to 6 months?

JOHN W. KETCHUM: Yes. So first, we're already there on solar. Not only there on solar for '17 and '18. We're pretty darn close to a range for '19 and '20. And we'll look to continue to add to that obviously going forward. And then on the wind side, given the 760-megawatt total portfolio today, the wind additions that were part of that, we're within striking distance on wind. And I'll let Armando fill in the details with kind of his viewpoint.

ARMANDO PIMENTEL: So for wind, and this has been the case for a long time, right, the -- when folks are looking for wind, they're looking out much shorter -- at a much shorter time period. One of the things that I'm honestly most happy about so far in the cycle is we have almost 900 megawatts of wind signed up all ready for 2019 and

'20.

But when you're focused on '17 and '18 and particularly, on wind, there's the current -- there's the -- just the recent history that we announced today of signing 560 megawatts of 2018 wind. And I can tell you that we are working on a pretty decent backlog for additional 2018 wind right now.

Whether that happens or not, it depends. Customers understand that if they wait a little longer, that the prices could be a little cheaper. And so you're always fighting that. But I was very pleasantly surprised with the 566 megawatts we signed for 2018 this past quarter. And my expectation is that, that number in 2018 will continue to go up just as it has in the past, just because wind has a shorter time frame.

CHRISTOPHER JAMES TURNURE: Is it fair to say that just kind of the higher half or the upper half of the range is still achievable for '17 to '18?

ARMANDO PIMENTEL: It's -- I think honesty, all of the numbers in that range are achievable. And if all I wanted to do was to meet the higher end of the range on wind for '17 and '18, I'm -- we could probably do that. But that's not necessarily always the right thing to do, right?

I mean, you may be talking customers into building something in 2019 and 2020 because it's better economics for us honestly than it could be for 2018. So every situation is different. Again, I'm happy at this point that we've signed almost 900 megawatts for '19 and '20 and that we still have a pretty decent backlog of '18 opportunities that we have been shortlisted on.

CHRISTOPHER JAMES TURNURE: Okay, that's helpful color. And then maybe, John or Jim, given the stock performance has been a strong as it has year-to-date, just kind of maybe going back to an earlier question on cash return versus dividend or incremental investment opportunities versus buybacks, does the stock performance kind of lower the hurdle to deploy capital into other investments or to return cash to shareholders through a bigger dividend increase maybe than previously expected?

JAMES L. ROBO: So Chris, this is Jim. Listen, we remain very disciplined in how we evaluate all our incremental opportunities. We're looking hard at a lot of different things to continue to deploy that excess balance sheet capacity very profitably for us going forward and that's going to be our focus.

But as always, we're not going to do dumb stuff either. We're going to be very disciplined about it. And we'll -- on the dividend, we'll be -- we just had a discussion with the board about the dividend in October. We'll have another one in December, and we'll be coming out with our post-2018 dividend policy in February once we -- once the board finalizes where they're going to come out on that. So more to come on the dividend.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, that will conclude today's question-and-answer session. Thank you for your participation. You may disconnect at this time.

urn:contentItem:5SH2-K5H1-JB20-G1CX-00000-00Event Brief of Q3 2018 Palo Alto Networks Inc Earnings Call - Final2018-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis060418sb.780Event Brief of Q3 2018 Palo Alto Networks IncEarnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Amber Ossman - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Director, Investor Relations

. Kathleen Bonanno - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,CFO & Executive VP

. Mark D. McLaughlin - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Chairman & CEO

. Mark F. Anderson - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,President

. Nikesh Arora - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Chairman and CEO

. Amber Ossman - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Director, Investor Relations

. Kathleen Bonanno - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,CFO & Executive VP

. Mark D. McLaughlin - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Chairman & CEO

. Mark F. Anderson - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,President

. Nikesh Arora - Palo Alto Networks, Inc.,Chairman and CEO

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Andrew James Nowinski - Piper Jaffray Companies, Research Division,Principal & Senior Research Analyst

. Gabriela Borges - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division,Equity Analyst

. Jonathan Frank Ho - William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division,Technology Analyst

. Keith Weiss - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,Equity Analyst

. Kenneth Richard Talanian - Evercore ISI, Research Division,Analyst

. Matthew George Hedberg - RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division,Analyst

. Michael Turits - Raymond James & Associates, Inc., Research Division,MD of Equity Research & Infrastructure Software Analyst

. Philip Alan Winslow - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Robbie David Owens - KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., Research Division,Senior Research Analyst

. Saket Kalia - Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Shaul Eyal - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc., Research Division,MD and Senior Analyst

. Walter H Pritchard - Citigroup Inc, Research Division,MD and U.S. Software Analyst

. Andrew James Nowinski - Piper Jaffray Companies, Research Division,Principal & Senior Research Analyst

. Gabriela Borges - Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division,Equity Analyst

. Jonathan Frank Ho - William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division,Technology Analyst

. Keith Weiss - Morgan Stanley, Research Division,Equity Analyst

. Kenneth Richard Talanian - Evercore ISI, Research Division,Analyst

. Matthew George Hedberg - RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division,Analyst

. Michael Turits - Raymond James & Associates, Inc., Research Division,MD of Equity Research & Infrastructure Software Analyst

. Philip Alan Winslow - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Robbie David Owens - KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc., Research Division,Senior Research Analyst

. Saket Kalia - Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Shaul Eyal - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc., Research Division,MD and Senior Analyst

. Walter H Pritchard - Citigroup Inc, Research Division,MD and U.S. Software Analyst

OVERVIEW

PANW reported 3Q18 revenues of $567.1m and GAAP net loss of $46.7m or $0.51 per basic and diluted share. Expects FY18 revenues to be $2.240-2.250b and non-GAAP EPS to be $3.86-3.89. Expects 4Q18 revenues to be $625-635m and non-GAAP EPS to be $1.15-1.17.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 3Q18 revenue = $567.1m.

2. 3Q18 GAAP net loss = $46.7m.

3. 3Q18 non-GAAP net income = $95.1m.

4. 3Q18 GAAP loss per basic and diluted share = $0.51.

5. 3Q18 non-GAAP diluted EPS = $0.99.

6. 3Q18 YoverY revenue growth = 31%.

7. 3Q18 non-GAAP GM = 76.2%.

8. 3Q18 non-GAAP OpEx = $316.6m.

9. 3Q18 non-GAAP CapEx = $28.8m.

10. 3Q18 DSO = 58.

11. 3Q18-end cash, cash equivalents and investments = $2.2b.

12. FY18 revenue guidance = $2.240-2.250b.

13. 4Q18 revenue guidance = $625-635m.

14. FY18 non-GAAP EPS guidance = $3.86-3.89.

15. 4Q18 non-GAAP EPS guidance = $1.15-1.17.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

Annotation (A.O)

1. Events:

1. Will be participating in:

1. Bank of America 2018 Global Technology Conference on 06/06/18 in San Francisco.

2. 2018 William Blair Growth Stock Conference on 06/13/2018 in Chicago.

3Q18 Review (M.M.)

1. Management Change:

1. Nikesh Arora will succeed Mark McLaughlin as Chairman and CEO this week.

2. Mark McLaughlin will remain with Co. as Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors.

2. YoverY Highlights:

1. Revenue $567.1m; grew 31%.

2. Billings $721m; up 33%.

3. Non-GAAP:

1. Operating margin 20.3%.

2. EPS $0.99.

4. Sees strong global demand for Security Operating Platform due to ever-accelerating and rapidly-evolving threat landscape, and resulting significant consequences to businesses that lose customers' trusts.

1. Co.'s competitive advantage is increasingly evident.

2. Ecosystem leverage of Co.'s platform is growing rapidly.

3. Co. continues to capture market share at high rates and at large scale.

3. Customer Additions:

1. Strong qtr. of new additions.

1. Now serves approx. 51,000 customers around the world.

2. In addition to robust new customer acquisition, continued to rapidly increase wallet share in existing customers.

3. Top 25 customers, all of which made purchase this qtr., spent a minimum of $28.7m in lifetime value in 3Q, 43% increase over $20.1m in 3Q17.

4. Customer Wins and Competitive Displacements:

1. Co. beat Cisco to become security standard in a global leader in hospitality and entertainment industry, and a leading cloud-based provider of benefits and HR solutions.

2. Check Point replacement in a data center of one of EMEA's largest defense system manufacturers.

3. Competitive win against Check Point and Cisco to become public cloud security standard for one of the largest US healthcare providers.

4. Competitive wins against Symantec to become end-point security vendor on tens of thousands of workstations to secure US state-wide education system and Zscaler with Co.'s new GlobalProtect cloud service to secure more than 15,000 stores of a large US-based retailer.

5. Annual Ignite User Conference:

1. Hosted a record crowd of over 4,000 customers and partners recently at annual Ignite user conference in Anaheim.

2. Showcased continued strong momentum around Co.'s platform capabilities including the third evolution, which is Application Framework.

3. Had over 30 companies like Microsoft, ServiceNow and Proofpoint, and leading highly innovative startups like Phantom, which Splunk just acquired, preview their applications.

4. Application Framework marries security innovation and ease of consumption, which is a compelling value proposition for a customer base, and is helping to drive purchases of foundational elements of Security Operating Platform in the network, on endpoints and in cloud.

6. Network:

1. Introduction of PAN-OS 8.1, in addition to new hardware [delivered over past 15 months] including most recent PA-3200 series, PA-5280 and ruggedized PA-220, allows Co. to reach new customers while driving expansion sales and opening new use cases in existing customers.

7. Endpoints:

1. Released Traps version 5.0 in March, which brings a new level of functionality to Co.'s Advanced Endpoint Protection offering.

1. Customers can now utilize Co.'s cloud-delivered management service, which allows for easier deployment in day-to-day management.

2. With addition of Linux support, Traps now plays a major role in securing cloud applications.

3. Co. continues to see strong momentum with Traps and is receiving market validation as a leading endpoint security vendor.

4. In April, NSS Labs' independent evaluation of Advanced Endpoint Protection offerings, Traps [acquired] a recommended rating.

1. Report evaluated 20 different vendors looking specifically for protection against a variety of malware, exploits, blended threats and evasions.

2. Traps blocked 100% of evasions and exploits with zero false positives.

3. Report identified Traps as having the most favorable rating when weighing overall effectiveness and total cost of ownership.

2. Announced acquisition of Secdo in April.

1. Secdo brings leading endpoint detection response capability to Traps.

2. Secdo's unique threat level approach to data collection and visualization goes beyond traditional EDR methods and will also feed into Co.'s Logging Service giving applications running in Application Framework greater precision to detect and stop cyberattacks across entire platform.

8. Cloud Security:

1. [Protects all applications in all platforms] through combination of inline, host and API-based security, which Co. does through VM-Series, Traps and Aperture offerings.

2. Acquired Evident.io, a leader in public cloud infrastructure security.

1. With Evident, Co. now provides continuous monitoring of public cloud deployments, cloud storage protection, and compliance validation and reporting.

2. Saw good traction already with Evident in terms of customer interest and pipeline.

3Q18 Financials (K.B.)

1. Note:

1. Except for revenue and billings, all financial figures are non-GAAP and growth rates are compared to prior-year period, unless stated otherwise.

2. Results:

1. Drove robust topline growth with new and existing customers adopting offerings across full breadth of Security Operating Platform.

2. Delivered market-leading revenue growth in combination with YoverY operating margin expansion and EPS growth.

1. Looking to remainder of FY18, Co. is well positioned to deliver strong finish to year.

3. Revenues:

1. 3Q18 $567.1m.

1. Grew 31%.

2. Geographical growth:

1. Americas 29%.

2. EMEA 35%.

3. APAC 37%.

3. Product $215.2m.

1. Grew 31% YoverY.

4. SaaS-based subscription $192.5m.

1. Increased 38%.

5. Support $159.4m.

1. Increased 25%.

6. Subscription and support $351.9m.

1. Increased 32% YoverY.

2. Accounted for 62% share of total revenue.

4. Billings:

1. 3Q18 $721m.

1. Increased 33%.

2. Recently announced acquisitions were not material for revenue and billings in qtr.

5. Qtr.-end deferred revenue $2.2b.

1. Increased 34%.

6. GM 76.2%.

1. Declined 20 BP YoverY.
