urn:contentItem:60GF-PP21-DXH2-618Y-00000-00Event Brief of Q3 2020 Visa Inc Earnings Call - Final2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis072820sw.732Event Brief of Q3 2020 Visa Inc Earnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Alfred Francis Kelly - Visa Inc.,Chairman & CEO

. Mike Milotich - Visa Inc.,SVP of IR

. Vasant M. Prabhu - Visa Inc.,Vice Chairman & CFO

. Alfred Francis Kelly - Visa Inc.,Chairman & CEO

. Mike Milotich - Visa Inc.,SVP of IR

. Vasant M. Prabhu - Visa Inc.,Vice Chairman & CFO

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Craig Jared Maurer - Autonomous Research LLP,Partner, Payments and Financial Technology

. Darrin David Peller - Wolfe Research, LLC,MD & Senior Analyst

. David John Koning - Robert W. Baird & Co. Incorporated, Research Division,Associate Director of Research & Senior Research Analyst

. David Mark Togut - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD

. Harshita Rawat - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC., Research Division,Senior Research Associate

. James Eric Friedman - Susquehanna Financial Group, LLLP, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Lisa Ann Dejong Ellis - MoffettNathanson LLC,Partner

. Matthew Casey O'Neill - Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., Research Division,Research Analyst

. Tien-Tsin Huang - JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Craig Jared Maurer - Autonomous Research LLP,Partner, Payments and Financial Technology

. Darrin David Peller - Wolfe Research, LLC,MD & Senior Analyst

. David John Koning - Robert W. Baird & Co. Incorporated, Research Division,Associate Director of Research & Senior Research Analyst

. David Mark Togut - Evercore ISI Institutional Equities, Research Division,Senior MD

. Harshita Rawat - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC., Research Division,Senior Research Associate

. James Eric Friedman - Susquehanna Financial Group, LLLP, Research Division,Senior Analyst

. Lisa Ann Dejong Ellis - MoffettNathanson LLC,Partner

. Matthew Casey O'Neill - Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., Research Division,Research Analyst

. Tien-Tsin Huang - JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division,Senior Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 3Q20 net revenues of $4.8b.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 3Q20 net revenues = $4.8b.

2. 3Q20 YoverY net revenue decline = 17%.

3. 3Q20 YoverY net revenue decline in constant dollars = 16%.

4. 3Q20 non-GAAP, non-OpEx = $118m.

5. 3Q20-end cash, cash equivalents and investment securities on hand = over $17b.

6. YTD share repurchase = 36m shares for $6.5b at avg. price of approx. $180.

7. 3Q20 share repurchase = 5.2m shares for almost $900m at avg. price of $180.47.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

3Q20 Review (A.K.)

1. Highlights:

1. Past few months certainly continued to be challenging.

1. Focus has and will always remain on well-being of employees, clients and communities in which Co. operates.

2. Even with significant impacts to economies worldwide, many aspects of Co.'s business have proven to be resilient.

1. Continues to invest to propel Co.'s growth well into future; in consumer payments, new flows and value-added services.

3. Net revenues $4.8b.

1. Down 17% or 16% in constant dollars.

4. All business drivers were significantly impacted by pandemic.

1. Payments volume declined 10% globally or 9% excluding China.

2. Cross-border volume, excluding Intra-Europe which drives international transaction revenues, declined 47% on constant dollar basis, driven primarily by lack of travels.

1. Including Intra-Europe, volume down 37%.

5. Processed 30.7b transactions or over 337m per day on Co.'s network.

1. Down 13% YoverY.

6. In each case, business drivers improved each month throughout qtr. meaningfully for payments volume and processed transactions, and only marginally for cross-border volume.

7. New flows:

1. Visa Direct grew global transactions in [mid-60s] YoverY, and value-added services revenue grew in mid-teens YoverY.

8. Effectively managed expenses, which declined 5%.

1. This was achieved without affecting investments in primary growth initiatives.

9. Non-GAAP EPS declined 23%.

10. While COVID-19 certainly impacted performance, there are many trends that are accelerating demand for consumer payments, new flows and value-added services, which will help business as Co. looks ahead.

2. Consumer Payments:

1. Even with all success Co. has had in electronifying payments, there is still $18b transacted in cash and check globally.

2. In today's environment, people are sensitive to touching surfaces, including cash and check.

1. Co. is seeing this manifested interest in usage and tap-to-pay, which Co. knows helps to digitize cash at low-ticket level and has historically increased transactions by avg. of 20% over time in mature markets globally.

3. From 2Q-3Q, Co. had nearly 50 countries improved tap-to-pay penetration by more than 5 percentage points, and over 10 countries increased by 10 percentage points or more.

4. Co. has helped more than 55 countries to increase tap-to-pay limits, reducing share of transactions that require consumer contact by more than 40% in several of those countries.

5. In US, added more than 80m contactless cards in first six months of calendar year 2020 as number of financial institution partners accelerated their issuance schedules.

6. Tap-to-pay is likely to accelerate post-COVID, especially as consumers start going back to office, where they tend to conduct smaller transactions for their commute paying for public transit fares and buying food and drinks.

7. Another positive trend has been shift to e-commerce.

1. This works in Co.'s favor because its share of digital commerce, where cash is not an option, is approx. three times greater than physical point of sale.

2. In US, Visa credentials active in e-commerce, excluding travel, were over 12% higher in June than in Jan.

3. Total spend per active credential increased during that time by over 6%, which is notable considering new adopters typically spend less than those used to shopping online.

1. When isolating active credentials who tend to be more significantly engaged in e-commerce, spend per active credential increased by over 25%.

8. Aforementioned trends are not unique to US.

1. During this period, in UK active e-commerce credentials increased 16%, while spend per active credential increased 3%.

9. In Brazil, active e-commerce credentials increased 11%, while spend per active credential increased 12%.

10. In markets where e-commerce is not as developed, they are examples of dramatic changes in adoption.

1. Argentina experienced active e-commerce card growth of over 100%, and Romania 70%.

3. New Flows:

1. Continued focus on addressing $185t opportunity.

1. In B2B, opportunity is across card-based, AP and AR and cross-border payments.

2. While B2B volume is down during this work-from-home and limited travel period, continuing to build out capabilities and relationships to fuel future growth.

2. Recently established global partnership with UK fintech Conferma Pay, which enables companies to provision virtual Visa commercial cards to employees digital wallets, enabling tap-to-pay and simplifying expense reimbursement.

3. For large ticket cross-border B2B solution (Visa B2B Connect) continues to build network out.

1. Many banks are in implementation phase.

2. When they are all live by year-end, Co. will be processing cross-border transactions in half of 80 markets, where its B2B Connect capability is available.

4. In US, P2P is up almost 80%.

5. In Latin America, saw progress with P2P apps in Peru, where there was nearly 400% increase in transactions vs. 2Q.

6. Excited to announce global partnership with PayPal, including its Venmo, Braintree, Xoom, iZettle and Hyperwallet brands.

1. This is extension of long-standing regional partnership with PayPal.

2. This new global agreement will allow PayPal and all of its brands to offer fast Visa Direct-enabled domestic and cross-border payments, and expand PayPal's real-time transfer capabilities globally.

7. In gig-economy food and grocery delivery category, saw nearly 50% growth in transactions from pre-COVID levels and has continued to add new program launches like Instacart for shopper earnings payouts in Canada.

8. G2C, government-to-consumer, use cases are gaining momentum employing Visa Direct and prepaid cards.

1. In US, Treasury distributed nearly 4m economic impact payments via Visa prepaid cards.

9. Worked with CaixaBank in Spain on three projects, issuing 330,000 prepaid Visa cards with government-allocated funds to support vulnerable families across region.

10. In France, Natixis partnered with Co. to issue 15,000 cards as thank you to frontline hospital workers financed by government.

4. Value-Added Services:

1. Saw more clients turn to Co. for help.

2. As e-commerce has expanded and new sellers are looking to offer omni-commerce payment capabilities that are safe and secure, Co.'s CyberSource and fraud and risk capabilities have seen growth.

1. Recent win in Saudi Arabia with Al Rajhi Bank; largest acquiring bank in country will leverage CyberSource to enable e-commerce payments platform for all Saudi Arabian government services through centralized interface with country's Ministry of Finance.

2. Buying online, picking up in-store has become popular among consumers, and is key way for sellers to operate in this environment.

1. This use case does bring higher potential for fraud.

2. One home improvement partner chose Decision Manager, Co.'s CyberSource fraud offering to quickly review online orders for fraud risk and meet customer expectations for two-hour pickup.

3. This resulted in massive increase in Decision Manager transactions in May alone at this merchant.

3. Across all CyberSource risk products, saw nearly 50% YoverY growth in transactions.

4. Interest has grown in authentication products.

1. CardinalCommerce, which provides network agnostic product for sellers and issuers to leverage 3-D Secure standard have seen accelerated growth in transactions YoverY.

2. 3-D Secure is making steady progress in Europe, where ecosystem is ramping up in advance of secure customer authentication mandate beginning in Dec. for most of Europe.

3. Continues to work with ecosystem participants as deadline approaches, given that some are not ready for deadline.

4. [EMVC] 3-D Secure transactions has grown over 100% sequentially.

5. Data and consulting continue to be valuable to clients as they navigate this environment.

1. Clients utilized consulting services at accelerated rate with almost 60% more projects completed YoverY.

2. Co. plays critical role in providing data analysis to help clients manage their business through pandemic.

1. Client activity on Visa Analytics Platform increased 60% sequentially.

5. New Deals:

1. Made good progress.

2. Momentum in Europe continues.

1. Renewed with one of the largest banks in Nordics, Nordea, to grow debit portfolios across region.

2. Expanded partnership with Permanent TSB; large issuer in Ireland with over 800,000 cards in (inaudible), making Visa the primary card in most wallets in Ireland.

3. Recently extended partnership with UBS in Switzerland to debit.

3. Co. is winning processing.

1. In Spain, secured significant deal to expand processing capabilities for domestic transactions.

2. Banco Caminos will migrate their issuing and acquiring volumes from their local processor to Visa.

4. Europe was certainly not exception in developing and renewing partnerships.

5. In Singapore, renewed partnership with second largest debit issuer OCBC Bank to remain preferred debit card issued to OCBC Bank's personal savings and current account customers.

6. In Korea, recently secured renewal with South Korea's biggest issuer, Shinhan Card.

7. Renewed credit and debit partnership with Banco de Bogota, Co.'s largest issuer client in Colombia.

8. Recently won and started issuance with Kaspi Bank, one of the largest retail banks in Kazakhstan.

1. Bank is moving 100% to Visa over next few years.

9. Co-brand:

1. Leadership position in co-brand continued.

1. This qtr. Co. renewed and expanded strategic partnership with Best Buy, including extended My Best Buy co-brand relationship.

2. Ford and V collaborate on Ford's new FordPass Rewards.

1. Visa card available to their 4m FordPass Rewards members and other Ford customers.

3. Another recent co-brand win was with Verizon to launch of Visa credit card that provide savings on Verizon's industry-leading products and services, along with benefits for every day and essential purposes.

4. Signed co-brand deal with Tiki, one of the leading e-commerce platforms in Vietnam.

10. Fintechs:

1. Key component to building issuance and acceptance is with fintechs.

1. This qtr., secured many wallet and neobank wins globally.

2. Careem, biggest ride-hailing app in Middle East and Africa, will offer driver payouts with Visa Direct and credentials to over their 35m user base.

3. Hong Kong's digital transit card, Octopus, will accept Visa wallet top-ups, allowing commuters to pay for transport and pay in 35,000 retail outlets.

4. In Saudi Arabia, signed strategic partnership [Halal], rising challenger bank that has potential to penetrate an unbanked population of up to 7m people.

5. Neobank, Vivid Money, announced its official launch in Germany, offering Visa debit cards in all-in-one mobile application, including innovative savings and cash back solution.

6. In US, US-based Chime, with over 8m accounts, launched access to new Visa-secured credit card, which allows consumers to build credit, while spending on everyday purchases like groceries and monthly subscriptions.

11. Partnerships are fundamentals to Co.'s business model.

1. Aforementioned renewals and new deals will certainly help drive growth into future.

6. Race Situation:

1. For four centuries black and African/American women and men have experienced many forms of social injustice and discrimination.

1. It is offensive, it is frustrating and unacceptable; it must stop.

2. At Co., it is committed to do its part.

1. Recently announced next steps in Co.'s journey to drive inclusion and diversity across V.

2. Announced number of actions, including (Technical Difficulty).

3Q20 Financials (V.P.)

1. Highlights:

1. (Technical Difficulty) significantly accelerated secular shift to e-commerce.

2. Card-not-present spend, excluding travel, has grown over 25% every week since mid-April, which is two times pre-COVID growth rate.

3. Card-present spending improved steadily through qtr. as reopenings went into effect from declining almost 50% in early April to declining in high-single digits by late June.

1. There has been little improvement since.

2. It is too early to tell what all underlying causes of this recent stabilization are.

3. Recovery trajectories for card-present volume are relatively similar across states.

4. US spend by category:

1. Excluding Visa Direct, performance can be summarized in three groups based on COVID impact, and recovery Co. has seen to-date.

2. Each group represents roughly a third of US payments volume.

1. First group includes categories like food and drug stores, home improvement and retail goods; these categories have consistently grown at or above pre-COVID growth rates, in high teens or even higher every week since mid-April.

2. Second group includes categories that experienced spend declines between 10-50% in April, and then all recover to growth by June-end; these segments include automotive, retail services, department and apparel stores, healthcare, education, government and business supplies.

3. Third group includes categories that are hardest hit by this pandemic, travel, entertainment, fuel and restaurants; these categories declined over 50% in April and are still declining YoverY, although each improved by between 20-45 points during qtr.

3. Travel remains most impacted category; still down over 50%.

4. Fuel gallons purchased are growing again with spend is down more than 15% in July, driven by lower prices.

5. Within restaurant category, card-present spend is still declining, whilst card-not-present spend continues to grow significantly with quick service restaurants outperforming.

2. International Payments Volume:

1. Declined over 12% in constant dollars.

2. Similar to US, debit significantly outperformed credit with debit down only 3% and credit down 20%.

3. Card-present spend improved through qtr. as countries reopened.

4. Card-not-present, excluding travel spend, remained elevated.

5. Performance across categories was broadly similar to US.

6. Co.'s best-performing region continues to be CEMEA, which declined 5% in constant dollars.

1. Within CEMEA, Russia, Eastern Europe and Central Asia had positive growth, fueled by rapid recovery after April declines and client wins.

7. Europe payments volume declined 10% in constant dollars.

1. Central and South Eastern Europe, which include Poland, Czech Republic and Hungary recovered rapidly to post positive growth.

2. UK returned to growth in June, driven by consistently strong card-not-present growth.

3. Italy is almost back to prior-year levels in June, following one of the strictest lockdowns within Europe.

4. Canada, declined 15%.

5. Latin America declined 13% in constant dollars.

6. Brazil spend decline early in qtr. was one of the shallowest; recovery has also been slow.

1. Brazil is now back near 2019 levels of domestic spending, fueled by strong card-not-present growth.

8. Asia-Pacific payments volume declined 16% in constant dollars.

1. Reopening of Asian economies has been gradual with multiple phases depending on country.

2. Two of the least impacted countries were Korea and New Zealand, both of which were close to flat.

3. Domestic spending in Japan and Australia was back to 2019 levels by late June.

4. India remains one of the most impacted markets globally.

9. Processed transactions declined 13%.

1. Although this lagged volume growth due to mix shift, trajectory of processed transactions recovery is similar, improving from 24% decline in April to 4% decline in June.

1. Growth in July through 21 is flat.

2. Domestically, mix of spend has shifted from lower-ticket to higher-ticket categories.

10. Cross-border transactions are holding up better than volumes, due to mix shift from high-ticket travel-related spending to lower-ticket non-travel e-commerce.

1. Constant dollar cross-border volume, excluding volume within Europe, declined 47%.

2. Volumes declined 51% in April and improved marginally in May to decline 45%.

1. There has been little improvement since.

2. For month of June and in July though 21, rate of decline has stayed at 44%.

3. Constant dollar cross-border volume, including volume within Europe, declined 37%.

4. Cross-border volume, excluding volume within Europe, drives Co.'s international fees.

5. Cross-border spend decline is driven by travel.

1. Travel-related spend, which includes card-present and card-not-present in travel categories, represented roughly two-thirds of pre-COVID cross-border volume, excluding volume within Europe.

2. Travel-related spend declined 78%, and was still declining over 70% at June-end.

6. To have recovery in cross-border travel, one has to have reopening of borders.

1. At this point, border remain largely closed.

2. World Tourism Organization reported at June-end that out of 217 countries, 189 or 87% had completely or partially closed their borders to foreign visitors.

3. Of remaining 28 countries, 10 had completely or partially suspended flights.

4. Several other countries like UK required quarantines and rest had imposed visa restrictions or demand medical certificates.

7. While no one corridor drives large portion of volumes, some of Co.'s most important corridors remain closed.

1. Borders have to reopen before Co. can get sense of what cross-border recovery trajectory might be.

2. In few corridors where cross-border travel is now possible, saw some significant recoveries.

3. Americans are traveling again to Mexico and Caribbean; since April low, these corridors have seen cross-border card-present volume recovered by 30-40 points.

4. Travel, to and from Switzerland, to France and Germany is almost back to normal.

5. Russian travel to neighboring countries has picked up.

6. Travel from Europe to UAE is gaining momentum.

7. Vast majority of cross-border travel spend is on personal cards and not for business travel.

8. Consumer travel demand for visits to friends, relatives and for vacations is more likely to remain intact post-COVID, perhaps even enhanced.

9. Consumer travel recovery is likely to start with people going to countries within their geographic zone of comfort; this is already evident as Co. looks at short-haul cross-border travel, which it define as less than 3,000 miles.

10. Short-haul air travel is recovering faster than longer-haul corridors.

11. Drive-through hotels are doing better, as are leisure hotels vs. business hotels.

8. Growth in cross-border e-commerce spend, excluding travel, has been consistently in high-teens to low-20s since mid-April.

1. Strong growth is fueled by retail spending, which is growing about 30% since mid-April and drove majority of non-travel e-commerce spend.

9. In most countries, saw that once consumer decides to buy something online rather than go to local store, there is higher likelihood the purchase becomes cross-border with little regard of where item is shipped from.

10. Strength in retail is offset by declines in entertainment, education and government, some of which are tied of travel and represent meaningful portion of card-not-present non-travel spend.

1. Aforementioned are excludes volume within Europe.

11. Within EU, borders have largely reopened.

1. Intra-Europe cross-border card-present spend is up 40 points from trough in April through three weeks in July; another indication of the possible trajectory of cross-border recovery when borders do reopen.

3. Results:

1. Net revenues declined 17% or 16% in constant dollars.

1. Service revenues were flat YoverY.

1. Reflects last qtr.'s volumes.

2. Data processing revenues declined 5%, supported by strong value-added services growth and acquisition-related revenue.

3. International transaction revenues decreased 44%; in line with decline in cross-border volumes, excluding volume within Europe.

4. Other revenues declined 8% YoverY, due to value-added services impacted by pandemic.

1. Value-added services impacted by pandemic include lower use of travel-related card benefits, lower marketing-related services for clients as many slowed marketing activities and fees Co. waived on certain services, which surged at outset of pandemic.

5. Had Co. reported service fees without lag, service fees would have declined 11% and reported net revenues would have dropped additional 4.5 points to approx. 21.5%.

1. These no service fees will impact reported revenues next qtr.

4. Note:

1. Value-added services revenues captured in P&L:

1. Total value-added services revenue grew in mid-teens, including acquisitions.

1. Approx. two-third of value-added services revenues are included in data processing, as many of them are transaction-based revenue streams.

2. These value-added services grew in mid-teens, driven by strength in US debit and prepaid issuer processing, CyberSource and authentication and fraud services.

3. Remaining value-added services revenue is split roughly evenly between service fees and other revenue.

2. Value-added services and service fees grew in mid-teens.

1. Value-added services recorded in other revenues grew in mid-single digit due to acquisitions, increased use of data products and consulting, offset by declines in usage of card benefits and marketing services.

3. Client incentives declined 2% YoverY, and 23.8% of gross revenue.

1. As indicated before, vast majority of incentives are tied to payments volumes.

2. Incentives declined less than gross revenue, pushing up incentives as percent of gross revenue.

4. Incentives are generally tied to total payments volumes and only selectively to cross-border volumes, as declines in cross-border volumes have been deeper than total payments volumes and cross-border volumes have higher yields, incentive declines lag gross revenue declines.

5. Heavy renewal activity like Co. had in FY19 causes incentives to grow faster than gross revenue.

1. Thereby, decline in incentives lags gross revenue on way down.

6. Offsetting aforementioned factors to some degree is service fee lag.

1. Service fee lag mitigated gross revenue decline reported; this will impact negatively next qtr.

5. Other Financials:

1. GAAP and non-GAAP OpEx declined 5% as Co. was able to execute additional cost management initiatives, particularly in areas of marketing, and G&A.

1. These expense reductions were achieved, while sustaining investments in longer-term growth initiatives.

2. Acting early and decisively has helped Co. to reduce expenses fast.

2. Non-GAAP, non-OpEx was $118m.

3. Interest income was lower, due to sharp drop in interest rates.

4. Interest expense was higher from $4b debt issued.

5. Non-GAAP tax rate 19%.

6. 4Q20 Perspectives:

1. Forecasting revenues remains challenge in this environment.

1. It is difficult to predict when borders will reopen, and what trajectory of cross-border travel recovery will be post reopenings.

2. Domestic volumes have bounced back nicely in most countries.

1. Inevitably, rate of recovery will slow.

3. Other uncertainties include impact of recent spike in infections, and economic impact of stimulus payments tapering off or ending altogether worldwide.

4. Had Co. reported service revenues without lag, 3Q net revenue would have declined additional 4.5 points.

1. This will cause 4Q reported net revenue growth to be lower than 3Q, absent change in trend on key business drivers.

5. Continued recovery in domestic payments volumes and transactions will improve data processing revenue trend, but not reported service revenue.

1. This will be partially offset by higher incentives, related to increasing volumes.

2. As such, most important variable that would improve 4Q net revenue growth rate is cross-border volume, excluding Intra-Europe.

6. If cross-border recovery remains sluggish through 4Q, revenue mix shift away from cross-border will persist.

1. Adding in impact of service fee lag, incentives as percent of gross revenues are likely to increase by 2-3 points over 3Q levels.

1. This percentage should normalize as cross-border volumes improve and domestic volume recovery stabilizes.

7. Non-GAAP OpEx:

1. Expected to decline, roughly in line with reductions Co. delivered in 3Q.

8. Non-GAAP, non-OpEx:

1. Expected to be around $140m.

9. Even with significant COVID-19 impact, expects to generate healthy level of free cash flow this year.

7. Others:

1. Ended qtr. with over $17b of cash, cash equivalents and investment securities on hand.

2. With access to commercial paper market on favorable terms and $5b revolver, liquidity position remained strong.

3. Bought back 5.2m shares for almost $900m at avg. price of $180.47.

1. YTD, bought back 36m shares for $6.5b at avg. price of approx. $180.

4. Dividend policy remains unchanged.

5. Crisis created risks and opportunities.

1. Co. has moved fast to mitigate risks by ensuring strong liquidity, reducing expenses while sustaining key growth investments and closely monitoring network performance, security, daily settlement, fraud and other key metrics.

6. Crisis accelerated many favorable secular trends.

1. Digitization of cash.

2. Shift to e-commerce.

3. Penetration of tap-to-pay.

8. Summary:

1. Visa Direct momentum has remained strong.

2. Value-added services have continued to grow in mid-teens.

3. Focus remains on helping all stakeholders, cardholders, clients, government regulators and own associates as they navigate through these unusual times.

Additional Comments (A.K.)

1. Details:

1. Future is going to have uncertainty associated with it.

1. Co. continues to believe in strategy and growth prospects.

2. There were things that declined in qtr.; net revenue, EPS, overall payment volume, cross-border volume, and processed transactions.

3. Saw growth in number of important areas.

1. Growth in:

1. Debit.

2. E-commerce volumes.

3. Visa Direct transactions.

4. Tap-to-pay.

5. Advances and quick to pay enablement.

6. Value-added services revenue.

4. Demonstrated ability to reduce expenses, while continuing to invest in future.

5. Returned capital to shareholders at historic levels and retained dividend.

6. Net-net, believes Co.'s business model is resilient.

1. Has lot of confidence in efficacy of global network of networks strategies.

Additional Details (V.P.)

1. Highlights:

1. Debit has bounced back about 30 points.

1. Now growing at about 25% in first three weeks of July.

2. Credit recovered by less than that, and is still declining 9% through first three weeks of July.

3. Reasons for debit growth:

1. Economic impact payments going directly into checking accounts helps debit.

2. In times of economic uncertainty, consumers do shift spending away from money they have borrowed to money they have in bank.

3. Shift to online has caused lot of everyday spend categories to move to e-commerce, which is favored debit, because normally debit is used for everyday purchases.

4. Affluent customers; to use credit for discretionary purposes like, travel, entertainment and restaurants, which have been especially hard hit in times like these.

5. Economic impact payments were distributed using Visa prepaid cards in 20 states, including unemployment benefits which lifted debit growth in May and June.

6. Visa Direct, which helps debit numbers, up over 75%, as whole bunch of use cases performed really well.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Lisa Ellis from MoffettNathanson.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS, PARTNER, MOFFETTNATHANSON LLC: All right. Hopefully, you can hear me, I guess.

VASANT M. PRABHU, VICE CHAIRMAN & CFO, VISA INC.: Yes, we can.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: So I'm going to hit a topic you did not cover on the call. Al, question for you about big tech. The big tech companies are now facing elevated regulatory pressure, obviously very present right now in the U.S., also in Europe, related to some of their competitive practices. Can you comment on how this regulatory scrutiny you see affecting, one, those firms' initiatives in payments? Like in particular, are there anything -- any practices that they're doing that you at Visa or Visa would view should be scrutinized? And then also, do you view this sort of regulatory scrutiny on big tech as a plus for the payments ecosystem and for Visa or as potentially a negative?

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY, CHAIRMAN & CEO, VISA INC.: Well, Lisa, as you might imagine, we have relationships with all of the companies that you would consider big techs. Some are a bit more extensive than others, but we certainly have relationships with all of them. I certainly can't comment and wouldn't comment on regulatory scrutiny that they are experiencing. But if it involves payments and we can be helpful to them or helpful to the government in either advocating or explaining what's going on, we will jump into that. There was a case with a payment initiative that we had going with Facebook in Brazil in the last month where we did just that, as an example.

I think that these big techs are -- certainly have attracted lots and lots of users and have developed relationships with them. And some of those relationships are going to require money movement or payments capability. And we certainly want to be there and be the partner to work with them on those particular things. And we'll leave it to them to figure out and deal with any of the regulatory issues that they're facing. And we're a phone call away if we can be helpful. But I think, in most cases, it's kind of up to them to resolve them.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Matt O'Neill from Goldman Sachs.

MATTHEW CASEY O'NEILL, RESEARCH ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: I was hoping you could provide some anecdotal views on what I think is probably the next leg of the sort of secular catalyst here, the sort of silver lining of this pandemic, if there is one, which is obviously the e-com growth has been robust. But how are the bank partners and merchant partners sort of thinking about the move back into brick-and-mortar commerce in what will inevitably be a significantly greater demand for contactless payments?

And then if I could just have a quick unrelated follow-up. I was just wondering if there's any update on the Plaid acquisition and any comments around the lawsuit there.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: Well, interestingly enough, as you probably could see in some of our charts, as card-not-present has -- I'm sorry, as card-not-present has started to work its way back, it lagged obviously, card-not-present, it was impacted much more greatly by the pandemic. Card-not-present volumes have held up, so we're not seeing any declines there. And I think that what all issuers and anybody who's rooting for economies around the world to come back would love to see a situation where both card-not-present and card-present both bounce back, and that bricks-and-mortar commerce on main streets and communities around the world continue to grow.

I think the case for contactless, Matt, has been made. We have seen consumers and governments and merchants voting through their actions, and contactless has had -- or tap to pay had tremendous momentum kind of going into COVID. And if anything, COVID had accelerated the momentum of tap to pay even in the United States, which we know has been further behind, but as I cited, we've added 80,000 -- or I'm sorry, our issuers have added 80 million credentials that are tap to pay-enabled in the first 6 months of the year. Something like 80% of the merchant volume is -- that is occurring in the face-to-face world is occurring at terminals that are enabled for tap to pay. So I think it's going to just continue to grow everywhere around the world. And I believe that the COVID situation will help accelerate the growth here in the United States at a perhaps faster pace than it might have happened otherwise.

As for Plaid...

VASANT M. PRABHU: Al, I might add a couple of things. One, crisis fosters innovation as you know. And if anything, this has made more and more merchants focus on omnichannel commerce, which CyberSource is very much in the middle of. And increasingly, merchants are getting better and better at serving customers seamlessly across bricks-and-mortar as well as e-commerce. It has also made a lot of categories that never used e-commerce become a lot better at e-commerce. And that's -- you've seen that in a lot of everyday spend categories. You've seen that with restaurants.

And more broadly across retail, people have come up with more innovative ways like curbside delivery has been perfected in many ways. And that, we think, is going to be here with us, which is really a way where you order online, but you may pick up physically. So you have one more delivery option, you can get it delivered after a day or 2 delay, or you can get it right away by going and picking it up.

So there's a lot going on. And I think the most important point that Al made was that even as we've seen card-present improve from minus 50 to minus high single digits, card-not-present has stayed very robust, continuing to grow at those mid-20s levels for quite a while now. So lots of changes underway.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: Matt, let me address your Plaid question. It's still pending regulatory approval. And we certainly are expecting to close by the end of the calendar year and are doing everything we can to comply with any request from the regulators that are looking at it. We are as excited about the Plaid acquisition today as we were back in January when we made the announcement. And we really believe we got the asset we wanted. And all of the various benefits that we have articulated in prior calls, we believe, are still there. Everything from the depth of their integration with fintechs, the fact that they are most attracted to a lot of fintechs, that they're positioned in terms of how far along they are, we believe they have the best team. And we see it as the best way to integrate into Visa. So we're -- we remain very excited about Plaid and hopeful to close by the end of the year.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Darrin Peller from Wolfe Research.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER, MD & SENIOR ANALYST, WOLFE RESEARCH, LLC: Just a couple of quick ones, first on the fourth quarter, fiscal fourth quarter comments. Just to clarify, I think you guys are saying that the -- just the lag effect of services versus prior quarter volume would impact that line by 4 points. But I guess we're just wondering if the -- just given the trends we're seeing on transactions processed flattening out, shouldn't those trends be enough to offset that when it comes to growth in fiscal Q4?

And then, Al, just bigger picture, when we think about the services, all these other value-added services you guys are doing well with, I mean, do you see these sticking around post-COVID in terms of the demand you're seeing for analytics and potentially the card-not-present service fees or CyberSource?

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: So why don't I let Vasant answer the first piece, and I'll come back and address the second piece?

VASANT M. PRABHU: Sure. So if you look at the various lines on the revenue line, service fees, as you indicated and as we told you in the comments, are known already. They're going to report service fees based on our volumes in the third quarter. And the volumes in the third quarter was hopefully the low point. And as we said, had we not done a lag, our service fees would have been down 11%, and total net revenue would have been down, as you said, in that 4, 4.5% range. So that is going to happen. That's a known fact. And even if volumes improve on the domestic front and transactions improve, the service fee number isn't going to change next quarter. So that's locked in. So when volumes do improve, which we expect will be the case on domestic volumes and transactions, transactions revenues will definitely go up.

Value-added services revenues will definitely go up. But the other thing that goes up is the contra-revenue line, incentives. Incentives will go up to reflect the higher volumes because we don't book incentives with a lag. Incentives will go up, but the benefit of that revenue from the higher incentives, we won't get on the services line -- service fee line, we will get it on -- we will definitely get it on the processing line.

So there's something of an offset there. I just want you to be aware of that. But the biggest variable is going to be cross-border. If there's a change in trend in cross-border and it improves, then that would be the single biggest reason to expect Q4 trends to be better than Q3, recognizing that you've got pressure going in the other direction from the service fee lag.

So there's some complexity created by these things because of the turbulent times we're in. We've tried to help you with it. And hopefully we can help you some more, if you like, answer more questions later on.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: And Darrin, on your second question, I'm very bullish on what's going to happen with value-added services in a post-COVID world. First of all, 2/3 of our value-added service is a platform-type services, CyberSource, issuer processing, risk and fraud. The need for those is going to continue. And if anything, the volumes and transactions that will run through those will go up.

Where we've seen some declines are in travel-related card benefits, which is going to get better as travel comes back. We've also waived some fees because of the pandemic. And once we're past the pandemic, we won't waive those fees as readily, so that volume will go up. Travel-related benefits will go up, as I said, as travel comes back. So I see value-added services being very well positioned coming out of COVID and feel very good about the contribution they'll make and how they'll continue to diversify our revenue profile over time.

VASANT M. PRABHU: Yes. I think the other things to add there, 3 of our largest value-added services, we think, are going to sustain their growth, which has already accelerated. Our issuer processing business, which is directed towards debit. Debit has become the engine for cash conversion right now. Debit growth rates, as you saw, are 25% in the first 3 weeks of July. So as long as debit growth rates are at an accelerated level, the issuer processing business will clearly have high growth rates.

CyberSource always benefits from the shift to e-commerce. And now with their focus on omnicommerce, CyberSource clearly is benefiting from the shift.

And then finally, our risk and fraud services certainly benefit as things move more to e-commerce, which is where fraud is an area that we can really help a lot on. So they're reasons to believe that higher growth rates can sustain post-COVID.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from James Friedman from Susquehanna.

JAMES ERIC FRIEDMAN, SENIOR ANALYST, SUSQUEHANNA FINANCIAL GROUP, LLLP, RESEARCH DIVISION: Al, in your prepared remarks, you shared some P2P growth characteristics. You were going kind of quick there. I -- that disclosure was new, at least to me. But I was wondering if you could repeat what you said and also, at the same time, share some use cases about how you're seeing the P2P applications develop.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: Well, what I said in my remarks was that P2P is up almost 80% in third quarter, and in Latin America -- that was in the United States, I'm sorry, up 80% in the third quarter. And in Latin America, there we saw progress with 2 different apps -- P2P apps in Peru where we saw a nearly 400% increase in transactions in Q3 over the prior quarter Q2.

We've got this tremendous track record of working with P2P providers. And as we said in the past, we were heavily skewed toward the United States and Russia. But we're -- and where we have relationships with most of the big P2P providers, Square Cash, Venmo, Zelle, et cetera. I think that now we're seeing our P2P capability through our Visa Direct platform becomes something that people are looking to us for as P2P applications are developing in other countries around the world.

VASANT M. PRABHU: Since we had some issues earlier, we'll run longer. So we'll probably go for at least 10 minutes past the hour.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Craig Maurer from Autonomous Research.

CRAIG JARED MAURER, PARTNER, PAYMENTS AND FINANCIAL TECHNOLOGY, AUTONOMOUS RESEARCH LLP: I was hoping, Vasant, you could comment on if we see cross-border -- the cross-border recovery continue to stagnate into next year and domestic volume continue to pick up, intra-Europe cross-border continue to pick up, where should we be thinking about incentives as a percentage of gross revenue going. What's the risk to next year in terms of upside from that percentage?

And then perhaps, Al, maybe a comment or 2 on the renewal of the Durbin Amendment version 2 or 3, whatever we're at, at this point, and EPI in Europe.

VASANT M. PRABHU: Yes. In times like these, I think it's not easy to make long-term projections clearly. In terms of cross-border and its recovery, yes, it's possible, I suppose, that it remains sluggish. It all depends on borders reopening. Wherever borders have been opened or the restrictions have not been significant, we've seen some pretty quick recoveries. So to the extent that there are borders reopening, it may not be globally, but there could be corridors opening up as we're already hearing, Australia, New Zealand, you've seen that it's mostly open across the EU. It's starting to open in other geographies within regions. So it's not black and white, I think, in terms of the cross-border recovery. You could see some changes in travel patterns because of how countries open up. But if cross-border remains depressed, certainly the mix won't help us. And that will cause the percentage of incentives to gross revenue to stay higher than what you might call -- what it would might have been normalized mix of earnings -- of revenues.

The other factor that's influencing it is probably most acute in the fourth quarter, which is the service fee lag. Normally, our service fees from one quarter to another don't have such significant swings because our business tends to be quite stable, so that service fee lag effect will moderate. So I think the best way to describe it is it will probably normalize from the levels you see in the fourth quarter. It will certainly normalize because of service fee stabilizing. It will probably normalize some because the cross-border business will recover in corridors, but we'll wait and see how fast cross-border normalizes.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: Let me address your other 2 questions you asked about Durbin. Visa is fully compliant with all the requirements of the Durbin Amendment. And we don't have any rules or requirements or other restrictions that inhibit a merchant's ability to select their routing decisions, make the routing decision of their choice. And merchants are free and often do route to various unaffiliated networks enabled on a debit card. So that would -- I think we're in good shape as it relates to Durbin.

EPI, we have a history of dealing with either regions or groups of countries or countries developing their own scheme or intra-market network. It's something that we're very, very used to dealing with. We do know though that developing a network is not an inexpensive thing to do, and it's not a onetime investment. You have to continue to push and invest and innovate and be creative to stay ahead as it relates to all the elements of security, fraud prevention, risk, authentication, et cetera.

And so we will continue to monitor and engage constructively with regulators and banks in Europe on EPI. But on the other hand, we're going to continue to invest heavily behind our various networks to make them as good as they could possibly be. And we will be continuing to focus on making sure that our clients know the benefits that they can obtain by doing business with us and running on our networks.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang from JPMorgan.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG, SENIOR ANALYST, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: I just want to ask on the spread in U.S. debit and credit, I know you went through it a couple of times, Vasant. But it's wider than what we saw in '08, '09. So is there a way to try and quantify how much of the debit outperformance we can attribute to secular versus stimulus benefits?

And curious also, I just want to make sure, any impact on yield differences between the 2 products. I don't think so, but just wanted to make sure.

VASANT M. PRABHU: Yes. There are some modest yield differences depending on parts of the world and so on. I don't think you should view that as a huge factor.

In terms of the reasons that might stick as we go ahead, I think we went through 6 -- 5 reasons. One, the economic impact payments and unemployment benefits being distributed on Visa prepaid cards, clearly, that's linked to the crisis and probably is not something that will continue. Affluent customers putting off some discretionary items like travel, entertainment and restaurants, which has hit credit in particular, that probably normalizes over time, so that, you can attribute to COVID. The propensity for people to spend money -- spend the money they have versus money from -- borrowed money, that is something you do see in times of uncertainty. And then some of the economic incentive impact payments going into checking accounts clearly has helped debit.

But there's a few others that are clearly sticking. The fact that Visa Direct is still going very strong, that has been helping debit for a long time, and we'll continue to do that. The fact that debit has become the mechanism for cash conversion to digital in everyday spend categories and in just about -- in most categories, which have seen a big increase in e-commerce, has benefited debit, I think some of that sticks.

So I think the best way to describe it is that the acceleration of cash conversion has disproportionately helped debit, and that is most likely going to stick.

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: And Tien-Tsin, it's Al. I would only add that I think the -- if I look back, same observation you do about the 2008/2009 time frame. But e-commerce is just much, much bigger, and it just appears that people who are doing card-not-present e-com nontravel are using their debit cards much more than their credit cards.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from David Togut from Evercore.

DAVID MARK TOGUT, SENIOR MD, EVERCORE ISI INSTITUTIONAL EQUITIES, RESEARCH DIVISION: Could you parse out some of the drivers of the 36% decline in international transaction revenue yield? I imagine a lot of that's just the big drop in cross-border travel. But if you could help us think through the drivers in terms of how much might be inter-European versus debit? And how should we think about international transaction revenue yield going forward?

VASANT M. PRABHU: Yes. So I think it's very important to continue to point people to the decline of cross-border volumes excluding intra-Europe volumes. The decline was roughly -- was 47% in cross-border constant dollar volumes excluding intra-Europe. So the revenue decline is roughly, as you can see, in line with that. The reason being that -- and if you look at total cross-border volume, that includes intra-Europe, intra-Europe looks more like a domestic transaction. In fact, in our international revenue line, the contribution from intra-Europe transactions is very small. The international revenue line is driven almost entirely by volume excluding intra-Europe.

Now there's a few other things there that can have an impact. Exchange rate shifts can. Changes in currency volatility can. So that explains -- and then some small changes in mix in terms of which corridors are doing better than others because of some yield differences across corridors.

But that explains the 44% decline in revenues versus the 47% decline in volumes ex intra-Europe. But as you can see, watching that volume line ex intra-Europe is the best indicator, and that's what you should focus on.

DAVID MARK TOGUT: Got it. And just as a quick follow-up, could you just comment on the 10% growth in processing transaction yield year-over-year and thoughts going forward?

VASANT M. PRABHU: Right. There's 2 factors driving it. One is that cross-border transactions have held up a little better than cross-border volume. So the mix has helped a bit because cross-border transactions for processing have a higher yield.

And the second is we have value-added services and some acquisitions in that line. And as you heard, value-added services are growing in the mid-teens in that line. So those 2 things have helped data processing yields go up.

OPERATOR: Our next question comes from Dave Koning from Baird.

DAVID JOHN KONING, ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH & SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, ROBERT W. BAIRD & CO. INCORPORATED, RESEARCH DIVISION: And I guess following up on that last question, you said that the ex intra-Europe volume down 47%, but 44% revenue decline. Is that gap going to change much? I know FX volatility probably helped a little bit in Q3 to make revenue a little better than the volume decline. But are there any other kind of yield factors in there other than FX volatility to think about?

VASANT M. PRABHU: The variables that can make a difference there, first of all, the 44% to 47% is a relatively small delta. There'll always be some differences between the 2. They won't match each other precisely.

But you're right, currency volatility is one factor. Another factor would be mix. Certain corridors can have better yields than others. So if the recovery of cross-border favors higher-yielding corridors, you can have something of a difference. But other than that, it should track pretty closely to volumes ex intra-Europe volumes.

OPERATOR: Our last question comes from Harshita Rawat from Bernstein.

HARSHITA RAWAT, SENIOR RESEARCH ASSOCIATE, SANFORD C. BERNSTEIN

& CO., LLC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Al, can you expand upon your recent conversations with regulators and governments? Now on one hand, some merchants are lobbying for lower fees in this crisis, and I understand that's not a new phenomenon. But then there are very real benefits of digital payments, especially in this current environment. So just -- can you just talk about how your conversations with regulators and governments are evolving in this crisis?

ALFRED FRANCIS KELLY: Look, I think like many people, governments are finding themselves in uncharted territory here. And they're all well intentioned, trying to figure out the right things to do.

Our biggest piece of advice to governments as it relates to core payments is to do no harm at the moment. I mean right now, I think the less amount of moving parts as we're fighting through this pandemic is the best answer for everybody. This is not a time for any kind of changes.

Governments are also increasingly talking to us in terms of looking for information that we have in terms of trends because they're trying to understand what's happening in their economies. And in many ways, we could get them real-time picture of what's going on, faster than they can get it themselves.

And the last thing I would say is that there's a lot of interest in the form of governments to become more role models in terms of what they want to see in their countries from a digital adoption point of view. And so as they are -- have genned up stimulus programs, unemployment programs, thank-you programs and all kinds of other things, they're looking to Visa to help advise them on how they could distribute funds digitally as opposed to cutting checks.

So I think my view at the moment is that governments have -- are being very, very thoughtful and reasonable in terms of what they're saying, and they're also being good listeners. And so we're going to continue to do our job to provide them with whatever information they need and to provide them with whatever advice and counsel we can provide to be helpful to them, both in their role as governments and setters of laws as well as in their role as potential clients for various Visa services.

Before we close out, one of the things I gather that did not -- when we had a little blackout with -- in terms of the transmission was I did before I closed make a comment about the race situation in the country and around the world. And I'd like to just cite that again.

For 4 centuries, Black and African-American women and men have experienced incredible forms of social injustice and discrimination. And it's offensive, it's frustrating and it's unacceptable, and it has to stop.

At Visa, we've committed to do our part. We recently announced the next steps in our journey to drive inclusion and diversity across our company. We announced a number of actions, including the establishment of a Visa scholars and jobs program. But very importantly, last week, we announced that we're committing to increase the number of underrepresented U.S. vice presidents and above by 50% in the next 3 years and increase the number of underrepresented U.S. colleagues within Visa overall by 50% in the next 5 years.

We want to do our part to eradicate the social injustice in the world. It's way past time that, that has to be the case.

With that, thank you to everybody. Mike, did you want to...

MIKE MILOTICH, SVP OF IR, VISA INC.: Yes. Thank you, Al.

So yes, once again, I apologize for the technical challenges. We will make sure that the replay that's on our website as well as the transcript reflect everything. And if you have additional questions, of course feel free and reach out to us here, on the Investor Relations team, and we're happy to help you. So thanks so much, and have a great day.
