urn:contentItem:5MT1-0BS1-JB20-G1DP-00000-00Event Brief of Q4 2016 Koninklijke KPN NV Earnings Call - Final2017-02-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis020117so.709Event Brief of Q4 2016 Koninklijke KPN NV Earnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Wouter Stammeijer - Koninklijke KPN NV,Senior IR Officer

. Eelco Blok - Koninklijke KPN NV,Chairman of the Board of Management and CEO

. Jan Kees de Jager - Koninklijke KPN NV,CFO

. Joost Farwerck - Koninklijke KPN NV,COO

. Frank van der Post - Koninklijke KPN NV,CCO

. Wouter Stammeijer - Koninklijke KPN NV,Senior IR Officer

. Eelco Blok - Koninklijke KPN NV,Chairman of the Board of Management and CEO

. Jan Kees de Jager - Koninklijke KPN NV,CFO

. Joost Farwerck - Koninklijke KPN NV,COO

. Frank van der Post - Koninklijke KPN NV,CCO

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Josh Mills - Goldman Sachs,Analyst

. Polo Tang - UBS,Analyst

. Keval Khiroya - Deutsche Bank,Analyst

. Frederic Boulan - BofA Merrill Lynch,Analyst

. Guy Peddy - Macquarie,Analyst

. Luigi Minerva - HSBC,Analyst

. Ulrich Rathe - Jefferies,Analyst

. Usman Ghazi - Berenberg,Analyst

. Josh Mills - Goldman Sachs,Analyst

. Polo Tang - UBS,Analyst

. Keval Khiroya - Deutsche Bank,Analyst

. Frederic Boulan - BofA Merrill Lynch,Analyst

. Guy Peddy - Macquarie,Analyst

. Luigi Minerva - HSBC,Analyst

. Ulrich Rathe - Jefferies,Analyst

. Usman Ghazi - Berenberg,Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 4Q16 results.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

4Q16 Business Review (E.B.)

1. Takeaways:

1. Finalized first wave of Simplification program ahead of target.

2. Delivered on outlook set for 2016.

3. Returned a large amount of cash to shareholders.

2. Highlights:

1. Continued investments in networks.

2. Brought fiber closer to customer premises; deployed innovative technologies in network.

3. Recognized efforts regarding sustainability in 2016.

1. Co. was rewarded with inclusion in Dow Jones Sustainability World Index for fifth consecutive year.

2. Received CDP Climate Leadership Award.

3. One datacenter has been awarded most sustainable in EMEA due to innovative approach to use its heat as renewable, emergency power supply.

4. Strong market position in consumer delivered continued success in growing fixed mobile bundles, and further growth of high-value subscriber base.

5. Business segment:

1. Acknowledged challenging environment.

2. Aims to stabilize revenues in medium term.

6. Encouraged by continued strong performance of multi play product, improved order intake at large enterprises and corporates, and strong increase in Net Promoter Score in business.

7. Set out updated strategic vision in March 2016 with three pillars of simplify, grow and innovate.

1. Made good progress in all fronts since then.

1. Most KPIs and financial scorecards showed sustained positive improvement over year.

2. Has strong portfolio of innovative services.

1. Earlier this year, started with second leg of Simplification program.

2. Will lead to even higher quality of service for customers and improve time-to-market.

8. On track with key priorities set out at Capital Markets Day last year.

3. Accelerate Up & Cross-Sell in Bundles:

1. Convergence strategy in consumer is paying off.

1. Sees continued growth in fixed mobile bundles.

2. Had 74,000 fixed-mobile net adds over qtr., reaching penetration of 37% of households.

2. Postpaid customer base:

1. Added 122,000 mobile customers to fixed mobile base, reaching 43% of postpaid customers for all brands.

1. At 56%, KPN brand is already well ahead.

3. Sees continued growth of convergent offering as Co. recently started to cross-sell high-value fixed brand, XS4ALL with KPN Mobile.

4. At Telfort, focus is fully on convergence.

5. As Co. [gave EUR5 discount on complete offering, growing convergence first comes at cost].

1. Longer term, there are benefits outweighing this initial expense.

6. Sees much higher customer satisfaction, lower churn and as such Co. is able to reduce marketing expenses considerably.

1. With this, fixed mobile convergence remains important pillar in Co.'s strategy from customer proposition perspective and operational and network perspective.

4. Mobile:

1. Disciplined approach towards convergence and emphasis on value per customer resulted in growing committed ARPU level.

2. Postpaid net adds entirely driven by KPN brand, reflecting competitive environment in lower end of market.

3. Sees customers moving towards higher data allowances and more expensive handsets and as such see higher bundle value for customers.

1. Despite higher SAC/SRC per sub, this translates into higher customer lifetime value.

1. This is key performance metric, allowing Co. to track current financial performance and performance it expects to deliver over near future.

5. Growth in TV:

1. TV platform delivers best customer experience as reported by largest Dutch consumer organization.

2. Due to high-quality digital infrastructure in Netherlands, high broadband speeds are rule rather than exception.

1. Speed is not key differentiator in fixed landscape where TV is.

3. Three items of paramount importance.

1. Stability and image quality of non-linear TV services.

2. Watch everywhere, seamless integration on all devices.

3. Has personalized content easily and widely accessible for everyone.

4. One key aspect in delivering aforementioned items is high-quality content delivery network.

1. Saw widely-used content at more than 100 Metro Core locations throughout country, thereby offloading core entrants per network.

2. Has selective range of exclusive content that mainly focus on content aggregation through smart partnerships.

1. Ensures customers have access to rich content package, including music, sports, movies and entertainment.

3. Confident that high-quality interactive TV platform and recognition by customers will further drive personalized and on-demand TV consumption.

6. Business Segment Transformation:

1. Through history of connectivity, built strong relationships with majority of Dutch businesses.

1. For many of them, Co. is vital partner in their digital transformation.

2. In midst of migrating customers to integrated solutions and new technologies across all business segments.

1. Migration brings Co. strengthened and deepened customer relationships and presents Co. with up and cross-sell opportunities in longer term.

1. Today, this has significant impact on revenue trends.

3. Saw all major revenue buckets performed in line with previous quarters, except for customized solutions.

1. Traditionally, there was positive impact on revenues from customized work in 4Q, but shift to more standardized solutions have [shaved off seasonal peak].

4. 2016 business revenues down 7.6%.

1. Small improvement in trend vs. 2015 when revenue was down 8.6%.

5. SME:

1. Saw migrations to integrated service KPN1 accelerating to 27,000 additional multi play seats; more than twice the number of additions in [3Q].

2. Mobile base remained relatively stable throughout year.

3. When looking at revenue breakdown from product view, sees customers migrating from SME mobile-only services to SME multi play and to large enterprises and corporate integrated services.

4. Sees continued price pressure in mobile market.

5. In business mobile, has clear focus on value driven by high-quality network and service.

1. Will not necessarily chase every tender in market available.

6. Large enterprises & corporate segment:

1. Sees impact of migrations.

2. Revenues from network and IT services declined 11% YonY as customers are rationalizing and migrating away from legacy network services to new technologies.

1. Migrated from legacy VPN network to fully cloud-controlled software defined network.

3. Flexible and scalable solution Co. offers can be adjusted to customer requirements.

4. Following migration, customer will pay for actual network capacity use, instead of flat fee.

1. For Co., this presents opportunity to increase share of wallet for such customer.

5. Sees shift to more standardized solutions.

6. Sees sharp growth in KPN1 seats in large enterprise segment.

7. Comforted by decent pickup in order intake with large orders from several Dutch leading organizations.

7. Business:

1. Further strengthening market position along three main routes.

1. Further strengthening infrastructure by deploying similar hybrid access strategy as Co. uses in consumer.

2. Launched own managed hybrid cloud service; wants to be trusted partner with carrier and cloud-neutral colocation services.

3. Expanding scale and capabilities in growth areas by selective acquisitions like DearBytes acquisition, which strengthens Co.'s market-leading security proposition.

2. Financial performance illustrates impact of migrations away from traditional services; positive impact of up and cross-sell through integrated solutions takes time.

3. With clients moving to more standardized products, has opportunity to significantly reduce portfolio and simplify organization.

4. Reduced indirect costs 5.1% in 2016.

1. Further reducing cost base in business will be one main focus point in 2017.

1. Already implemented necessary actions to execute on this.

5. Sees Simplification efforts lead to improving quality at lower cost level.

6. NPS in business segment improved to minus 3 vs. minus 10 last year.

2016 Financials (J.K.J.)

1. 4Q16 Results:

1. Progress Co. is making to simplify operating model and expand network, which is one main driver for expense reduction.

2. Revenue trends improved further during 4Q16 with adjusted revenues for Netherlands down 1.9% YonY vs. minus 2.4% for full-year 2016.

3. Business remains challenging, but sees strong development in consumer driven by clear focus on convergence and high value customers.

4. Wholesale revenues benefited mainly from take-up of VULA services in fixed and increased data usage in mobile.

5. Regardless of lower revenues, posted solid growth in adjusted EBITDA.

6. Cost of goods and services improved nicely due to lower SAC/SRC resulting from relatively low-end of contract base.

7. Personnel expense lower YonY mainly due to strong reduction of external personnel.

8. IT/TI expenses increased marginally YonY due to customer-driven investments from higher order intake in business.

9. Other OpEx was lower mainly due to less marketing and communication, reduced housing expenses and lower costs related to billing and collection.

2. Results:

1. Sees reductions across all cost buckets, which is more than compensating for 2.4% decline in revenues.

1. Personnel expenses down 4.9%, IT/TI costs 2.6% lower and other OpEx decreased 13% YonY.

1. Simplification program brings cost savings and higher quality of service.

2. More efficient IT platforms enable Co. to enrich and unify customer experience, while Co. can turn off legacy systems and reduce personnel.

1. Improved billing system and simplified invoices have led to increased customer satisfaction and lower churn.

1. Debt enables Co. to reduce marketing expenses.

3. As Co. starts second wave of Simplification program, sees sufficient scope for further quality improvements in processes.

1. These should lead to further reduced spend level.

3. Operating Model Change:

1. First wave of Simplification program persisted of creating digital and uniform omni-channel (inaudible) system for consumer segment, allowing Co. to decommission legacy systems.

2. In fixed, decommissioned 20 IT systems; in mobile, consolidating 40 different IT systems.

1. Significant simplification of IT brings Co. substantially faster time-to-market, while saving money.

3. Second wave of program consists of similar IT integration for business segment.

4. Will start to simplify network interaction layer.

1. Expects further quality improvements for customers.

5. At first, must account for additional investments and restructuring charges.

6. Ended first wave of Simplification program ahead of target.

7. Realized EUR460m in run-rate savings at year end, which is well above original target of EUR300m.

1. Second wave is continuing seamlessly and will realize annual run rate savings of at least EUR300m by 2019-end.

4. Network:

1. Has been virtualizing legacy networks and has removed around 45% of installed base of 2010.

2. In coming years, will complete all IP transformation by modernizing Co.'s remaining legacy networks like PSTN and all [transformation techniques like SDH].

3. Consolidating transport and IP core networks.

4. Already integrating backbone network for fixed and mobile access.

1. Only final part of network is either fixed or mobile.

2. Result is all-integrated and largely fiberized network to-the-home, to-the-curb, to the business park or to-the-mobile site.

5. Decentralizing content at 161 Metro Core locations.

1. As customers are shifting to more personalized and on-demand TV consumption, this leads to strong growth of traffic volumes in core network.

1. With content delivery network storing data closer to customer, will result in enhanced customer experience through higher video quality and faster responsiveness.

6. Change network to prepare for fertilization:

1. Network fertilization will bring lots of benefits.

2. As operator, fertilization will enable Co. to run multiple services on same generic hardware.

1. Capacity will be used and handled much more efficiently at lower costs.

3. Furthermore, it will be easier to scale network to cope with rapid traffic growth.

5. Access Network:

1. Currently, almost 80% of Dutch households have fiber connection to-the-home or to-the-curb.

2. Approx. half of Co.'s customers are within roughly 300 meters over street cabinets, while roughly 80% is within 600 meters.

1. With vectoring, can reach 100-megabits per second, which is ample speed to cover current demand.

1. If demand changes, can easily upgrade to higher speeds with technologies like bonding and Vplus.

6. CapEx:

1. Increasing coverage is much more capital intensive than increasing capacity.

1. As consequence, position created by investing in fiber gives Co. flexibility to lower CapEx and increase capacity at same time.

2. While CapEx will come down further over coming years, keeps making significant investments in network.

3. Following deregulation of fiber-to-the-office, sees further potential to increase coverage in Dutch business [box].

4. Will roll out fiber-to-the-home in new-built areas.

5. Starting second phase of Simplification program, CapEx budgets for this year include [initial] CapEx, which are expected to come down thereafter.

7. Free Cash Flow:

1. Operational free cash flow performing strongly.

1. Grew 10% YonY.

2. Free cash flow EUR683m.

1. Excludes dividend received from Telefonica Deutschland and (inaudible) from cash optimization actions already presented at 3Q results.

1. Grew 24% YonY.

3. Interest paid and CapEx came in lower YonY.

1. Saw higher working capital level due to accelerated expense reductions throughout year.

4. In 2017, expects to see a similar pattern, lower cash interest and lower CapEx, partly offset by negative impact from working capital, although expected to be small vs. last year and restructuring cash out related to second wave of Simplification.

1. Aforementioned investments will lead to structurally-lower cost level and further free cash flow growth.

8. Financial Position:

1. Net debt-to-EBITDA decreased slightly to 2.8 times vs. 3Q.

2. In Jan., redeemed EUR720m bond as it expired.

1. Financed redemption from available cash and with coupon of 4.75%.

1. Should lead to another EUR34m lower cash interest into 2018.

3. Saw solid financial progress in 2016 with cost reductions outweighing revenue decline.

4. Rigorous cost discipline and execution of Simplification program is delivering quality improvements at significantly-lower cost base.

2017 Outlook (E.B.)

1. Details:

1. As Co. starts second wave of Simplification program, it is fully focused on continued successful delivery in 2017.

2. Adjusted EBITDA:

1. In line with 2016.

2. Includes negative impact of roaming regulation, which is expected to be around EUR40-50m.

3. CapEx roughly EUR50m lower at around EUR1.15b.

4. Intends to pay regular dividend for 2017 of EUR0.11 per share.

1. Up 10% YonY.

2. It's Co.'s current expectation that it will pass through dividend it received from Telefonica Deutschland to own shareholders as KPN did last year.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Good afternoon. Thank you. I've got three questions, please, on the business market. The first one is, since you are losing a bit of market share in mobile in business, I just wanted to get your view there who is taking share, what's happening.

The second question is on the slight deterioration we saw in Q4 from customized solutions. I just wanted to ask you what's happening exactly there and is it a one-off or should we expect more of that to -- in 2017?

And my last question, obviously related to a big profit warning from one of your peer in enterprise blaming the public sector. I just wanted to get your view on the public sector in the Netherlands. Is it declining faster than the private corporate markets or is it declining more than 8% year on year? Thank you.

EELCO BLOK, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF MANAGEMENT AND CEO, KONINKLIJKE KPN NV: Okay. Frank will take the first and third question and Jan Kees the second one. Frank, will you start?

FRANK VAN DER POST, CCO, KONINKLIJKE KPN NV: Yes. Good afternoon. On the market share, mobile, what we see obviously is there's quite some price pressure in the market there. Secondly, we move quite a few into multi-play propositions from single-player wireless. The -- and as I said, the price pressure in the market, you see some shift.

On the public sector, what -- that was the third question. On the public sector, we see that the revenues have been stable in 2016. And actually we haven't seen much movement there, nor do we expect it.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Yes. Are you losing market share in business or mobile or is the market share flat and it's just pricing pressure?

FRANK VAN DER POST: It's predominantly pricing pressure on the moment, where you see that some of the competitors are going in with very low pricing, which puts everything under pressure, predominantly in the large enterprise and corporate segment.

EELCO BLOK: Jan Kees, will you take the second question about deterioration of customized solutions in the fourth quarter.

JAN KEES DE JAGER, CFO, KONINKLIJKE KPN NV: Yes. So for several years already we see that -- well, traditionally, in Q4 we always have, even also now this quarter, a positive impact in Q4 on revenue coming from customized solutions because that has a pattern that tends to be larger to revenue in Q4 customized solutions. However, there is a trend, which you also saw in Q4 2015 already, that is less customized solutions and more a shift to standardized products.

So overall, we see a shift from customized solutions to standardized products. So whilst there is still a slight positive impact of customized solutions in absolute terms in the fourth quarter comparing Q4 2016 to Q4 2015, we have a negative impact because customized solutions are less, and more standardized solutions, and standardized solutions have a more gradual pattern throughout the year. But also in Q4 2015 you already also saw that same impact compared to Q4 2014.

So it's a trend, a trend which we'll also see probably in Q4 2017, a more gradual approach throughout the year because there's more an uptake of standardized solutions and less customized solutions.

JOSH MILLS, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Hi there. It's Josh Mills at Goldman Sachs. I've got two questions, the first to follow up on the B2B point. So compared to your guidance at the Capital Markets Day for stabilization in B2B revenues, how are the trends that you're seeing at the moment comparing to your initial expectations?

And second to that, when you as a management team look at that guidance and forecast that stabilization, are the metrics that you focus more on related to the large enterprise order book, which clearly we don't have as much information on, or is it something you can really model out with the multi-play improvements that we can see?

The second point, second question rather, would be on cost cutting. So your three-year simplification guidance of EUR300 million implies that there is a lower cost opportunity now than there was three years ago. Is that fair to say? Are there other opportunities? And how confident are you in being able to exceed that EUR300 million target?

EELCO BLOK: Will you take the first question about the trend?

JAN KEES DE JAGER: Yes. So in March 2016 at the Capital Markets Day we said in a three-to-five-year time, the medium term, we expect revenue inflection in business, in business-to-business market. Plotting the current trends, that could be easily -- well, according to our expectations because we see underlying also corrected, for example the customized solutions, as I just mentioned. Underlying, we see an improving of the trend, so there's less decline also in 2016 in business compared to 2015.

So the -- and also, very importantly, everything that we are doing in business in converged multi-play and also our growth in multi-play, in Q4 we see two times as much multi-play net adds in KPN One than in Q3, for example. So that's a doubling of the number of KPN One customers. We see demand in cloud and securities also -- security taking up.

So -- and also looking at the examples, but also looking at the revenue trend, it's safe to say that this is compatible with our earlier given indication of revenue inflection of three to five years, yes, counting from March 2016.

EELCO BLOK: Jan Kees, will you take --?

FRANK VAN DER POST: Frank.

EELCO BLOK: Frank. Yes, sorry.

FRANK VAN DER POST: No problem. Yes, if you look at the metrics, obviously, we're steering very closely on lines. Jan Kees mentioned already the seats we have in the SME market. In the large enterprise and corporate market, you look at the order intake and at the funnel. Order intake was up 14% in -- last year. Clearly, we have some really aggressive targets for the salesforce for this coming years -- for this coming year.

And secondly, what you do is you look at the funnel, so on a weekly basis I review the funnel with the team. You look at the quality of the funnel, you look at what's in there. Is it telco business, IT business? Is the right focus there? You look at the lead times on the funnel. And from that -- obviously, that feeds the order intake, and from that you gain confidence that the guidance we've given in the Capital Markets Day is certainly possible.

EELCO BLOK: Joost, will you take the question about the EUR300 million?

JOOST FARWERCK, COO, KONINKLIJKE KPN NV: Yes. So three years ago we started our first wave in the simplification program. We guided, three years ago, a spend reduction of EUR300 million. During the process, we accelerated the simplification and spend reduction, so we moved up finally this [close] the spend reduction of EUR450 million and we ended the year above that on EUR460 million. So now, we are facing the next three years in simplification. Again, we launched a start of spend reduction of EUR300 million at least. And of course, we aim to again accelerate this program and if we can find more benefits, we will for sure grab them.

But we start like we started three years ago with the ambition of a new program, or not a new program but the next wave in a program. Again, we go for EUR300 million and every now and then we give you an update.

POLO TANG, ANALYST, UBS: Hi. It's Polo Tang from UBS. I just have three different questions. The first one is just in terms of your equity free cash flow guidance for this year. You've guided towards growing equity free cash flow but is there any reason why you didn't give a range? And are you comfortable that you can meet consensus expectations of around about EUR740 million for this year?

The second question is really about the competitive environment mainly in consumer. Can you maybe give some color in terms of what you're seeing in terms of both fixed and mobile? And can you comment in terms of T-Mobile? They appear to be a bit aggressive in terms of their unlimited data offer.

And my final question is really just in terms of how we should think about the levers of growth for the consumer business, because your KPIs in terms of broadband net adds, mobile net adds have been a bit softer in recent quarters. So is the level of growth mainly in terms of ARPU and pricing or should we think about it as both volume in terms of net adds and pricing?

EELCO BLOK: Jan K, so you start with answering the question on the free cash flow guidance.

JAN KEES DE JAGER: Yes, we are very confident about growing free cash flow, feel very strong about it. We see, of course, about EUR100 million less interest spend, we see CapEx coming down approximately EUR50 million net. Even with the initial startup phase of the new simplification program and CapEx spend to that.

Also in 2016, we had a tax benefit cash, whilst in 2017 we expect to pay around EUR25 million EUR30 million cash tax. But taking all that into account we still are very confident in growing free cash flow. And we do not feel uncomfortable for any consensus that I've seen on free cash flow.

EELCO BLOK: Frank, will you take the second and third question?

FRANK VAN DER POST: Yes. So the second question was on the competitive environment in fixed and mobile. They're both slightly different I may add. In fixed what we obviously have done the last year is we've put a good price increase through in the market of EUR2.50. And despite that, we've seen growth in both broadband and ITV customers. At the same time, we also refrained from heavy discounting in the last year.

Unfortunately, the competitors didn't quite follow. We saw that Ziggo for example, did not put a serious price increase through. And they have been very aggressive in the below the line promotions. If you were a TV customer, they would add a broadband line for EUR10 for example. They have a below the line offer to six-months discount in order to get to some of their numbers. We wanted to refrain from that.

At the same time, we've seen Vodafone being extremely aggressive and they had an offer out there for 12 months for EUR21, And clearly that takes away a little bit of the bottom end of the market from that perspective. And we've been really trying to focus on the converged. We've tried to focus on high value. And even the commercial focus for Telfort, for example, was mainly driven around getting fixed and mobile customers in that base.

If you look at the [MPS] and you look at the satisfaction in both Telfort access for all as well as KPN that is clearly working. Also, the churn is very low at below 5%.

If you look at the mobile market most of the battle still is in the bottom end, so you're talking about EUR10 a month for a gig, some are offering that for even less. And the strategy we have, which I think has showed to be very good is to play with the four brands we have, or in mobile the three brands we have, and make sure that we have a value play in there.

We did 92,000 net adds over the year of which 157,000 were KPN subs. And what we do in the KPN subs is we try to steer the customers towards higher bundles with higher values. And that is working very well.

Also, because we see that two things happening there it locks them in -- well it makes it easier for them to make that step to become also a fixed customer. The second thing we see is that a lot of fixed customers are now bringing in second and third SIMs into their fixed mobile offering. So I think we are very well positioned in the mobile market as well.

If you look at T-Mobile, I think which was your last comment if you look at T-Mobile unlimited package, yes, at the end of the day that is for a SIM-only at a very high price point of EUR35. We see that the majority of our customers and the majority of our net adds are in the five and one gig bundles. If you are a Compleet, customer you get automatic doubling of your data so you go to two and 10. The average usage at the moment, although it's increasing, I think it's increased 50% versus last year, but the average usage is about 2.1 gig. I think there is plenty of room to grow for people.

And I think the interesting thing is in the Netherlands is that, and that's what our research confirms, is that people don't want to pay for something they don't use. So it's paying EUR35 for something you're never going to use in a long time I think is something we don't necessarily have the offer right now, our largest bundle is 10 gig. And that is very competitively priced. And if you're, again if you're a Compleet customer that's 20 gig.

So I think we are very well positioned there in that market with the current data bundles we offer. Back in September, we both included EU roaming into the offer and we made sure that all our offerings were handset credit legislation proof.

That was a long answer but --.

KEVAL KHIROYA, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Thanks. Keval Khiroya from Deutsche Bank. Could I ask a question on the IT NTI OpEx base? So in Q3 we saw quite a sharp production given the IT simplification. But in Q4, as you mentioned, you saw a bit of an increase in that cost line. Can you talk a little bit about what drove that given I thought you would have seen further savings there? And how should we think about this line going into 2017? Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: Jan Kees?

JAN KEES DE JAGER: Yes, so underlying we still see a declining trend also in the ITTI costs that's going forward, that's moving forward also in -- going in 2017 we see the same. But there is also now somewhat more cost made related to revenue for large customers that we started in Q4 so there's some cost related to -- revenue cost related in Q4. But underlying looking at the cost of running the Company, we see also a decline in Q4.

FREDERIC BOULAN, ANALYST, BOFA MERRILL LYNCH: Good afternoon. Frederic Boulan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch. A quick question on your CapEx outlook. So if I look at your guidance for 2017 of EUR1.15 billion still puts you pretty high versus your mid-term outlook you presented in March of 15%, 17%. So could you explain a little bit the path for CapEx in the next three/four years? In particular, around your tech choices on the high-speed broadband. You talked about it a little bit but it seems there's a bit more fiber coming up in the mix. So where should we see that CapEx line developing in the next years? Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: Joost, will you take this question?

JOOST FARWERCK: Yes, so indeed we invested heavily compared to others over the previous years. As you know, we invested in the transition of our core networks. Like Eelco and Jan Kees already highlighted, we built the core network and the decentralized content delivery network. We did a lot in access networks, covering 80% of the Netherlands on fiber either to the home or to the curb, 80% of our mobile sites are on fiber. So that's a lot of investment. And for the coming years this CapEx will go down.

Having said that, we will still invest in the quality and transition of our company. So first in the simplification we are focusing on rebuilding our operating support systems and customer process support systems on the B2B side. That's hand-in-hand with cost reductions, but we have to invest in the simplification over there.

Of course, we will always very carefully look at monetizing our access networks. So now we build this new network every mobile site is on the radar screen and every street cabinet is more or less on the radar screen to see where we can further upgrade, where to invest with respect to the value in the country.

Of course, there is customer CapEx related to the new business we want to do on the B2B and consumer side. So, all in all, we see the trend of CapEx moving down, having said that, we will keep on investing in the growth and the simplification of our company.

EELCO BLOK: Given Joost's explanation we are confident that we will meet the guidance we had given at the Capital Markets Day of a 15% to 17% range for CapEx over sales in the medium-term. So that's -- well given what we know today and given what we have put in place for our long-term CapEx planning still our guidance.

GUY PEDDY, ANALYST, MACQUARIE: Hi. It's Guy Peddy from Macquarie. One quick question going back to the business segment, in your -- Eelco, when you stood up you mentioned that in the consumer side actually TV was a point of differential in your product offering. Do you have any points of differential in the business segment? Because my fear is, I've been following KPN for nearly two decades now for my sins; the Dutch market is always competitive. I'm always fearful that when you use the word standardization the next word you're going to use is commoditization i.e. we don't get any pricing power. So can you give us what you're feeling is so we don't end up in that constant spiral down.

And secondly, on your cash flow outlook that you've just suggested there you're already delivering about 11% free cash flow margin on your revenues, which is very high. So to grow that, bearing in mind you're not going to grow any revenues next year, by definition you're look at continually to improving your free cash flow margin. But I think from a big picture perspective to grow free cash flow margin from an 11% number does seem a real challenge in the mid-term, because that just implies you're going to make super-normal returns. Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: I'll take the first question. Yes, the KPN One product for large enterprise and SME, which gives us the opportunity to offer integrated services fixed, mobile, broadband, voice, and IT services, cloud services, workplaces. And we believe that we will see a similar impact in the business market of this product as we have seen of the integrated product in the consumer market.

And also, looking at, well, first results of KPN One, the customers we have connected already in the beginning of the KPN One, we see really higher ARPUs on a month-to-month base given this easily cross and up-sell opportunity we have. So we are really confident that this will be one of the pillars of our transition in the business market.

Jan K, so you take the free cash flow question?

JAN KEES DE JAGER: Yes. Again, looking at the moving parts in free cash flow, it's very important to note that [we will] break down interest cost, interest spent again EUR100 million lower this year. CapEx comes down approximately at least EUR50 million this year.

Tax, whilst compared to last year that was because we had a tax benefit in 2016, the delta is still not positive but still we have sizeable DTA of almost EUR1.1 billion. So for the next coming years we do not pay cash taxes or very, very few in the region of -- probably somewhere EUR25 million EUR30 million or something like that so few cash taxes out.

And then EBITDA margin also starts to improve, as we also indicated on the Capital Markets Day that we see at least 300 basis points in a few years' time EBITDA margins to improve.

So with an improving EBITDA margin now also seeing proof points, interest spend, CapEx coming down and also coming down even further for the medium-term, as already indicated by Joost and Eelco, towards the 15% to 17% ballpark figure over sales, we are confident that we can grow free cash flow and thus also, yes, free cash flow margin if you want to look at it that way, absolutely.

LUIGI MINERVA, ANALYST, HSBC: Good afternoon. It's Luigi Minerva from HSBC. One question about the consumer EBITDA performance, which was, I think, particularly good in this quarter. If you can give us a bit more color on what has driven it and whether we can extrapolate that performance.

And second question is more a medium-term one on network virtualization what that implies in terms of CapEx and whether you believe that increasing the software component in your network takes you to a stage where you risk giving up some control on your network towards the big tech companies like, say Google just to mention a name. Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: Frank, will you take the first question about the consumer EBITDA and Joost, you about the network virtualization, any potential impact.

FRANK VAN DER POST: Yes, on the consumer EBITDA basically that is a result of the higher base -- of the base growth and the higher base including the price increases we've put through, so we've created value there. But at the same time, we've been very disciplined on costs. There was a little bit less SAC costs because of lower end of contract base, but also our market costs and payroll costs were lower in the last quarter due to some of the actions we've taken earlier in the year and that has helped improve the performance there.

EELCO BLOK: Joost on the network virtualization.

JOOST FARWERCK: Yes. So in the medium term indeed we are moving and we are currently building this by the way to a more software defined network approach, and we are virtualizing network functions. So that means that we run our network more from a centralized point of view from a software point of view instead of moving in hardware all the time.

So your question was are you more dependent on vendors when you move to a virtualized network. I would say the opposite is true. Today the traditional way of upgrading your network is moving more hardware in the country. And there's always one or two vendors at the next supporting you there. While moving to a more virtualized environment, as we are constructing today, gives us the opportunity to move it -- to run it in firstly in a far more efficient way. And secondly, we have the options between more partners than we have today and that's what we are currently making decisions on and doing proof of concepts in the field.

ULRICH RATHE, ANALYST, JEFFERIES: Ulrich Rathe, Jefferies. I have two questions, actually two and half. The first one is on the B2B order intake. That looks rather encouraging. I'm just wondering would you be able to share book to bill. Is that still below 1? Also what percentage of revenues is actually caught by orders? I suppose there are some buckets that don't come through orders but come in other ways.

And also is there an element in this order intake uplift from this shift that you talked about from SME to large enterprise? I think you talked about some revenue shifts there because of the way your products work. That was my first question.

And the second question is more a clarification on the VAT issues going back and forth in terms of you and your trends in the consumer business. Do you have any visibility what might happen in 2017 or even just in the first quarter? Is there more of that sort of stuff coming based on the conversations you are having with the tax authorities?

And then my last one, any news on the MTR process? Is that coming through this year? And do you have any sense of where that might end up and what it might cost you if any? Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: Okay, Frank, will you take the first question, Jan Kees, the second one and, Joost, the third one.

FRANK VAN DER POST: Yes, so the order intake is encouraging as you said so we are quite pleased with that. Obviously, order intake is for revenues contracted for the next two to three years and is obviously mainly for the LE and corporate market. In SME it is predominantly the [KPN One] machine, which we have turned on and moving customers towards.

If you look at the split between telco and IT obviously, we are very focused on driving more IT revenue. Certainly, the new order intake the focus is very much on IT whereas at the same time clearly, we want to maintain existing customers and maintain their telephony, the fixed so we renew that business as well.

EELCO BLOK: Jan Kees on VAT?

JAN KEES DE JAGER: Yes, as to the VAT benefit that changed throughout recent years the through the tax administration, tax regulations. So of course, there's always uncertainty attached to that. For this quarter, we expect the same approach as we have seen in recent quarters, also -- so also to record the benefit. But there are ongoing discussions with the tax authority about this, and there is always discussion about -- because it is very complex situation. But for now, we are recording the benefit, also looking forward in this first quarter.

How this can change in the future? Well, I know because of my background as former Finance Minister there is nothing as uncertain as taxation, so that's difficult to assess. But for now looking at what's more likely than not we record the benefit also in this quarter.

EELCO BLOK: Joost, progress on the MTR.

JOOST FARWERCK: On MTR and FTR by the way in the Netherlands our regulator drafted a decision be implemented May 1 this year. We are now in a so-called consultation phase. That means that we and the other players in the markets can get feedback on what we think about the process and how this decision is built up.

So we have -- we are working on that answer and we will send it to our regulator this week and then we will discuss the outcome of what we think they think. But it's their ambition to implement it late this year.

And maybe to add to that, the impact of the decision was already in our plans for a long time. So we anticipated on the outcome of the decision of our regulator for the coming years.

USMAN GHAZI, ANALYST, BERENBERG: Hi. It's Usman from Berenberg. I had three questions please. The first question was just on mobile pricing again. We recently noticed Vodafone with pretty aggressive 50% off promotions, at least on their website I don't know what it's like in the offline channels but on the website, you see 50% off handsets, 50% off SIM-only. Are you seeing them becoming more aggressive or reacting to T-Mobile at all?

The next question was just on business mobile. Is this something new where you've seen competition pick up in the fourth quarter in business mobile for pricing or is this just ongoing trend that you've been seeing?

My third question was on the SAC and SRCs I think you made a comment that part of the benefit in the COGS that you saw in Q4 was because SAC and SRCs were lower in absolute terms. I know that you were in the middle of a big renewal volume cycle in 2016. This is that kind of -- has that peaked? Thank you.

EELCO BLOK: Frank will take the first two questions and Jan Kees the third one about the SAC (inaudible).

FRANK VAN DER POST: On the mobile pricing I think there's a couple of things happening, that's why the market is moving. Per January 1 was new legislation, which is the handset credit model. Basically, with the handset credit model there's a couple of things you need to do in order to ensure that you have the right proposition, which is legal. We implemented those in September because we wanted to be ahead of the market. And I think the other ones are now starting to follow.

But the handset -- the credit model basically what it does is that you need to give -- you need to be -- it gives transparency to the customer. You need to ensure that the cost of the device is given to the customer without any interest. And you can't cross-subsidize anymore. So you can't cross-subsidize with a lot of SAC the devices. So the alternative there is to move your pricing on the actual bundle a little bit.

The second thing, which is happening in the legislation there is that any credits above EUR250 need to be registered at the Credit Registration Bureau. For a customer, that can have negative impact because it will limit their borrowing power for mortgages and anything else because it now becomes part of your overall credit profile.

So there's a couple of things I think happening. First of all, we believe that less people will take more expensive devices and less people will be willing to borrow more than EUR250. So they either need to pay more upfront or they will keep their devices longer and not go into an automatic cycle of replacement every two years.

So I think there's a couple of different things in that dynamic, which are going to change. And what you will see is that because you can't cross-subsidize devices anymore, operators will have to change the pricing in their bundles.

However, in the legislation or what you need to make sure is that your SIM-only pricing on the bundle is equal to your pricing when you link it to a handset. And that again, the transparency will have a few of the operators I think thinking and scrambling. We have been ready for this since September, so the effects of this are fully incorporated in the fourth quarter and I think we are in a very strong position to benefit there.

Your second question was around the mobile pricing in the business market. I don't think we've seen any unusual trends peaking in the fourth quarter. I think it's just that it's an ongoing repricing in the mobile -- I the business market specially in large enterprise and corporate. SME I don't think we see the effects as much; it's just that we had quite a few of the contracts coming up in the fourth quarter.

And I think there were one or two questions.

EELCO BLOK: Yes, Jan Kees.

JAN KEES DE JAGER: So, yes, the absolute level of SRC declined because we were at the bottom of a cycle of retention. So that's why we have less retention costs. So the end of contract cycle was lower in Q4 2016 compared to Q4 2015. That explains the absolute lower levels of SAC/SRC.

However, it's good to note that we do have in Q4 we have noted a higher SAC/SRC level per sub. But that also has a silver lining because that is a result of the higher value we took in. We took in 33,000 net adds on KPN brand minus 14,000 on our [challenging] brands so net plus 19,000 net adds.

But an important shift in customer lifetime value and even ARPU level, so if you're looking at ARPU, the committed ARPU has grown by EUR1 per month. So that's actually a good thing. That is the explanation of a higher SAC/SRC per sub. But because of the end of contract cycle, the total level is down compared to Q4 2015.

WOUTER STAMMEIJER, SENIOR IR OFFICER, KONINKLIJKE KPN NV: Any more questions? No. Okay, then we would like to thank you very much for coming and have a good day and evening. Thank you very much.

urn:contentItem:5N68-VFM1-DXH2-647C-00000-00Event Brief of Q4 2016 Moody's Corp Earnings Call - Final2017-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis021717si.778Event Brief of Q4 2016 Moody's CorpEarnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Salli Schwartz - Moody's Corporation ,Global Head of IR and Communications

. Ray McDaniel - Moody's Corp,President and CEO

. Linda Huber - Moody's Corp,EVP and CFO

. Rob Fauber - Moody's Corp,President, Moody's Investors Service

. Mark Almeida - Moody's Corp,President Moody's Analytics

. Salli Schwartz - Moody's Corporation ,Global Head of IR and Communications

. Ray McDaniel - Moody's Corp,President and CEO

. Linda Huber - Moody's Corp,EVP and CFO

. Rob Fauber - Moody's Corp,President, Moody's Investors Service

. Mark Almeida - Moody's Corp,President Moody's Analytics

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Alex Kramm - UBS,Analyst

. Joseph Foresi - Cantor Fitzgerald,Analyst

. Bill Warmington - Wells Fargo Securities, LLC,Analyst

. Manav Patnaik - Barclays Capital,Analyst

. Toni Kaplan - Morgan Stanley,Analyst

. Warren Gardiner - Evercore ISI,Analyst

. Andre Benjamin - Goldman Sachs,Analyst

. Peter Appert - Piper Jaffray & Co.,Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 4Q16 revenue of $942m, adjusted operating income of $424m and adjusted EPS of $1.23. Expects 2017 revenue growth to be in mid-single digit percent and EPS to be $5.15-5.30.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 2016 revenue = $3.6b.

2. 4Q16 revenue = $942m.

3. 2016 adjusted operating income (excluding settlement and restructuring charges, and depreciation and amortization) = $1.6b.

4. 4Q16 adjusted operating income (excluding settlement charge, and depreciation and amortization) = $424m.

5. 4Q16 adjusted EPS = $1.23.

6. 2016 YoverY revenue growth = 3%.

7. 4Q16 YoverY revenue growth = 9%.

8. 2016 adjusted operating margin = 45.5%.

9. 4Q16 adjusted operating margin = 45%.

10. 2016 adjusted OpEx = $2.1b.

11. 4Q16 adjusted OpEx = $551m.

12. 2016-end total cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments = $2.2b.

13. 2016-end outstanding debt = $3.4b.

14. 2016 share repurchase = 7.7m shares for $739m or an avg. cost of $96.38 per share.

15. 4Q16 share repurchase = 558,000 shares for $60m or an avg. cost of $107.48 per share.

16. Expects 2017 revenue growth to be in mid-single digit percent.

17. 2017 EPS guidance = $5.15-5.30.

(Operator Instructions)

We'll go first to Alex Kramm with UBS.

ALEX KRAMM, ANALYST, UBS: Hey, hello everyone.

I think my questions are mainly for Linda today. Starting with the expenses, I think the margin guidance was a nice surprise relative to what you've said before. Could you walk through the puts and takes a little bit more, how should we think about what's driving the upside?

Is it the way you've ended in terms of being soft on hiring this year? What about legal expenses that might be coming down post the settlement? And maybe any color on variable compensation, how we should be expecting there for the year. Thank you.

LINDA HUBER, EVP AND CFO, MOODY'S CORP: Hey, Alex. Glad you're happy, and I have a couple of points to make about that. We did do better in 2016 due to some pretty rigorous expense control measures that we took back in February of last year. So we did better at the conclusion of 2016 even than we had expected.

Those controls will continue going into 2017. So we feel pretty good about guiding to approximately 100 basis points of margin expansion.

Some of that does come from saving some legal costs, but the majority is what we're doing in terms of hiring. We have slowed the pace of hiring for the corporation.

MA continues to move a little bit faster than the rating agency and shared services. Looking at 2016, over 2015, MIS is actually down in headcount, and shared services is approximately flat. All those things have helped us, just with good general housekeeping and some discipline.

In terms of incentive compensation, let me find the right page here and we'll talk about that. As what sometimes happens, we noticed that in the fourth quarter, because our performance was a good deal stronger in 2016, Alex. The quarters had gone in 2016 for incentive compensation about $32 million, $35 million, $42 million, and then, as sometimes happens, the fourth quarter was $59.6 million in incentive compensation.

For 2017, probably the right thing to model there is somewhere between $40 million and $45 million per quarter of incentive compensation. And does that hit most of what you wanted?

ALEX KRAMM: I think that got everything. Secondly, similar on cash flow, I guess, how should we be thinking about the settlement, and how you will actually end up paying for that, and the timing of all of that? If you can run through the buybacks, are those going to be more third quarter or fourth quarter?

How about, are you going to draw on the revolver or the commercial paper program? What's the interest rate we should be thinking about? I don't think you guided on interest expense.

Just think about, you have a lot of cash overseas. You generate decent cash here, but maybe not enough, so how should we be thinking about that?

Lastly, related to that, you how do you think about leverage in general? If you need to raise a little bit more debt for this, I think you're hitting some of your initial targets, are those targets changing? How do you think about being a rated Company yourself?

Anything we should be thinking about here. Thank you.

LINDA HUBER: Okay. Alex, that's about all the questions.

Let me try to start with the DOJ settlement. So the happy news is we're done. Or we're just about done.

The payments have been made. Those were largely completed. And the way we did that was cash on hand, US cash on hand.

You'll recall back in 2016, we reduced share repurchase guidance from $1 billion to $750 million. And then also, for those who have within paying close attention, we have re-entered the commercial paper market. We have about $600 million of commercial paper outstanding right now, about an average maturity of 60 days, and we're paying about 1.2% on that commercial paper.

So we're very happy with the receptivity of the commercial paper markets, and that's how we have financed the payment of the settlement. So again, that's done. Going forward, we've guided to

$500 million of share repurchase for the rest of the year.

That's subject to many things, as we've discussed already, but some of it is how cash flow comes in for the year for the Company. So we'll see. As we announced, the settlement -- one of the other rating agencies that looked at us did provide a little bit more leverage room for us under its measure, which is now 1.5 to 2 times, rather than the 1.5 times that you had seen before.

However, with very much like our rating category that we have right now, and we don't like to run right up to the edge of our leverage level. We feel that we have some dry powder, we're happy about that. We have at least $500 million of dry powder, something like that, as we look at what we might want to do for 2017.

So we like the leverage levels. We have a bit of room. Share repurchase about $500 million, and again, we just want to be thoughtful, given everything that we've just had to deal with, and we don't like to be too close to the edge in terms of the leverage levels.

I don't know if Ray had anything else he wanted to add. I think that's of most of it.

RAY MCDANIEL, PRESIDENT AND CEO, MOODY'S CORP: I want to underscore both -- this is implied both in the question, and then addressed directly by Linda's answer. Between our cash on hand and our various borrowing options, we feel we have quite a bit of flexibility. And so we are going to be making decisions according to market conditions as we go through the year, and as I imagine you would expect, we're going to pay close attention to what we think are the best opportunities.

LINDA HUBER: Alex, one final point which may not have been taken into account by everyone looking at their models. We did do some financing in 2016. So you'll see in 2017 the roll-forward effect of that interest expense.

Secondly, we do have the $600 million of CP, and we are considering the term market at this time. And we'll see what we decide to do about that.

But, again, if we take that 1.2% rate we're paying for the CP and we term that out, I think it would be fair to say that we would expect that, that interest expense would be a little bit heavier. So we're considering that right now, and that's one of the reasons why everything doesn't flow fully down to EPS.

ALEX KRAMM: Very helpful, as usual. Thank you.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Joseph Foresi with Cantor Fitzgerald.

JOSEPH FORESI, ANALYST, CANTOR FITZGERALD: Hi. My first question is, just any thoughts on issuance given the new administration, I'm sure you're predicting that one. What could that do to your current projections, any internal scenarios you're setting up for.

LINDA HUBER: Joe, what we'll do, I'll go through what we usually do regarding our views that we're hearing from the investment banks, and then we have an exciting new feature. Rob Fauber is going to add a little bit of color in terms of what the rating agency is noting in the marketplace.

So starting with the US view and again, this is coming from the investment banks, and it's an averaging of what we're hearing from the different banks. Investment grade right now is running very, very strong. January was $200 billion in issuance -- a strong month is

$100 billion.

This is record January supply. Financials have dominated, as well as significant issuance from TMT companies. For the year, we're looking at about $1.2 billion of US investment grade issuance. That's about flat year-over-year.

The pipeline is robust as corporates exit their blackout periods and potentially look to get ahead of Fed rate hikes later in the year, which might be June, could be March, and then potentially again toward the end of the year.

We note that many issuers were hearing from the banks prefunded in favorable 2016 issuance environment. That might serve as a bit of an offset to 2017. And we're thinking about the M&A pipeline, which is bouncing around a bit.

For US high yield, $35 billion issued so far, $250 billion expected for the year, which is up 5% year-over-year, 2017 has started on a positive tone. Large cash inflows to high yield, recovering commodity prices and attractive yields are very constructive. More constructive default scenarios and energy price outlooks are helping with the backdrop, and we think that will support 2017 high yield bond issuance.

Leverage loans so far $120 billion. That is a torrid pace. $400 billion expected this year.

The year is expected to be down 15% year-over-year. But for right now, stability in the macro backdrop is aiding the leverage loan market with potential interest rate increases.

The floating rate view is preferred for investors, and we continue to have CLO formation, and that will support leveraged loan activity. Not enough, though, to surpass the elevated levels of 2016.

Now moving to Europe. What we've heard from the banks investment grade in Europe, volumes were higher than usual in January as issuers took advantage of the good conditions and low rates. The ECB and Bank of England continue to buy bonds and support the market, and there's a strong pipeline as issuers look to go to market ahead of key political events in Europe and potential ECB tapering.

We're about two months away from the French election; that's the first major event. High yield in Europe and the leveraged loan market remain in robust shape. ECB bond buying has indirectly supported the high-yield market and should help maintain rates at all-time lows.

Macroeconomic and geopolitical risks continue to be a key focus, though, in Europe, particularly for the speculative grade market. And now I'll invite Rob to make any further comments that he might want to offer.

ROB FAUBER, PRESIDENT, MOODY'S INVESTORS SERVICE, MOODY'S CORP: Linda, that was pretty thorough. I don't have too much to add to that. I might just talk about a little bit of the upsides and downsides in general to you how we're thinking about issuance.

Certainly, higher economic growth leading to more capital investment and in turn debt financing would be a positive. Some sort of infrastructure stimulus, either privately funded or in the municipal market. More constructive M&A environment.

Certainly, Linda touched on that. And I think importantly, a pull forward of these 2019 to 2021 maturity walls. We think we're seeing some pull forward now, but if we see more pull forward, that could provide some upside.

Things we're thinking about as potential headwinds, I think you mentioned potentially unfavorable tax changes. There's been a lot of discussion around that, around corporate interests, tax deductibility, repatriation of foreign cash. Interestingly, we did see in January some very large issuance from some big tech players who have large cash balances offshore.

And we're looking at trade developments that could disrupt markets, stall investment. Obviously watching the election calendar in the EU. Strengthening of the US dollar would also be something that would have an impact on us as well.

LINDA HUBER: Not that we're supposed to ask the questions, but Rob, you had mentioned one of the pieces of research we released last week on the refinancing law.

ROB FAUBER: I don't want to confuse people, because I don't have the global numbers handy, but we just put out some research last week. I know in regards to the US spec rate maturity wall, we're looking at the five-year maturity wall is now over $1 trillion for the first time. That's up about $100 billion from the study this time last year.

JOSEPH FORESI: Got it. So, any color, though, on real-time, what the clients are telling you given the new administration? Are you seeing a wait-and-see approach or any pull forwards? I'm just wondering if there's anything outside of what you laid up from the issuance side of things.

RAY MCDANIEL: No, this is Ray. Obviously, conditions were very strong in January, and the markets remain active in February. We really don't expect to see the January kind of numbers in the loan and high yield sectors continue at that pace, but market conditions remain good.

All of that indicates that issuers are taking advantage of a tight-spread environment. They may be moving ahead of uncertainty later in this year, whether it's policy uncertainty here in the US or the potential implications of unexpected outcomes in the European elections. So the pull forward is, I think, both a recognition of good market conditions and potential uncertainties later in the year.

JOSEPH FORESI: Okay. And then the last one from me.

On the regulatory side we've heard about some repeal, maybe, at some large institutions. Just wondering if you have any thoughts about that impact on your Analytics practice? Thanks.

RAY MCDANIEL: I'll let Mark comment on how they're thinking about that, and I'll add any color if appropriate.

MARK ALMEIDA, PRESIDENT MOODY'S ANALYTICS, MOODY'S CORP: I'd say that we're not seeing any meaningful impact to any of the talk about pullback on banking regulation, for example. We're still seeing very good demand for our products, for regulatory requirement as well as some of the accounting rule changes that are coming through, both IFRS 9 and the current expected credit loss CECL program that's coming in the US. So nothing meaningful from our standpoint.

JOSEPH FORESI: Thank you.

MARK ALMEIDA: It continues to be strong on both fronts. We're running in the mid-[90%s] on customer retention, pricing is solid. We're seeing good upgrade activity.

BILL WARMINGTON: Last question on ERS. You mentioned the GGY acquisition which you're going to be anniversarying, and then also what looked like very strong software license revenue. MARK ALMEIDA: Well, you're right, we had a good year in 2016 because we had very good performance in the business. We also had help from the GGY acquisition, so that was all good. Linda also referred to the fact that we are making good progress on our transition in the mix of the business, as we've been talking about for a while.

So the impact of that will flow through to 2017 revenue in the sense that we had a revenue -- a deliberate revenue decline in the services segment of the business, and so you're going to see that flowing through to revenue growth in 2017.

So we're guiding toward mid-single-digit revenue growth in ERS. OPERATOR: We'll go next to Manav Patnaik with Barclays.

MANAV PATNAIK, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Hi, good afternoon. Linda, just us to follow up on the expense commentary. Can you give us the ramp that you usually guide us to from now to the fourth quarter?

LINDA HUBER: Sure. Manav, the first question's a little bit easier, and maybe I'll let Mark think a little about what he wants to say on your second question. This year, we're hoping that the ramp will be a little bit flatter than it's been in previous years.

Now, we've had pretty significant margin work in MIS and some pretty strong cost controls in shared services in 2016. That reduces the run rate increase for 2017. And Mark's continuing to focus on margin by at his higher-margin businesses, as we said in the prepared remarks.

MARK ALMEIDA: Yes, I mean, I would only observe, consistent with what we've said before, that I think we are making good progress with the MA margin. So we believe we're making good progress. We think that progress is only going to get better over the coming years. But it is going to be difficult to see it on the MA standalone P&L, just given the way we treat overhead expense.
