MANAV PATNAIK: Okay. And then, just one on the rating side, maybe Rob can add some color here. I think you guys have put out some pieces around tax reform and the impact on issuance. It sounds like for Moody's companies specifically, obviously the lower tax and repatriations are positive.

Just on the broader tax reform piece, I guess it sounds like the view is it should be a negative, but how should we think about timing and how that impacts issuance and the Company's decision making? Any help or color there would be helpful.

RAY MCDANIEL: This is Ray. When we look at potential changes in taxes, it's really -- there are a number of puts and takes. Certainly to the extent that there are impacts from changes in interest deductibility, you have to count that as a negative. But to the extent that debt financing is still a low-cost form of financing, you would have companies that have more available cash.

It would probably be a stimulus for economic growth and so I would hope and anticipate we would see more new money borrowing. So the quantification of whether it ends up being a net negative or a net positive is difficult to assess without having more detail about what the actual changes in tax law would be. And as we see that, we will obviously communicate it.

MANAV PATNAIK: Got it. All right. Thanks a lot, guys.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Toni Kaplan with Morgan Stanley.

TONI KAPLAN, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Hi. Good morning.

RAY MCDANIEL: Good morning.

TONI KAPLAN: In 2016, your transactional revenues, ratings revenue growth, was up about 0.5%, while your biggest competitor was up about 6% in transactional rating. Was do you think the key drivers are that explain the delta there? Just given that, historically, you've been a little bit more in terms of transactional mix shift, just wanted to figure out what we should be thinking about.

LINDA HUBER: Toni, it's Linda. This is one of the most difficult types of questions for us to answer because we can see what goes into that view for us, but of course we don't know what goes into that calculation for our competitor. Makes it pretty hard for us to judge.

I'll ask Rob if he wants to make any other comments on this, but that wouldn't -- we don't have as much clarity on that as you might think, and it's a little hard for us to parse. Rob?

ROB FAUBER: The only thing I think I can surmise would be some shift in the mix.

MARK ALMEIDA: Just to add onto that, our transaction versus recurring revenue splits remain fairly constant in 2016 versus 2015, so we didn't see any big shifts there.

TONI KAPLAN: Okay. Great. And I guess related, can you just talk about the pricing environment within MIS?

LINDA HUBER: Sure, it's Linda. We had spoken about, at Investor Day back in 2016, that we felt pretty good about the pricing environment. I think that continues, I think I had noted then that we expect to be closer to the 4% end of the range we had said of 3% to 4%.

We are very interested in providing appropriate value for what we do, and we think we've made some significant investments in what the team has been able to do in terms of ease of use and otherwise a very strong value proposition which I'll let Rob talk about. But we're feeling okay about pricing. Rob, anything else you want to mention?

ROB FAUBER: I think that's it.

TONI KAPLAN: Great. And then your long-term framework calls for EPS growth in the teens. This coming year, you're expecting mid-single-digit MIS growth environment.

Why only 5% on the EPS increase excluding the tax benefit? I think you did mention perhaps the higher interest expense before rolling into 2017 from the actions you took in 2016, but are there other pieces that we should be thinking about as well?

LINDA HUBER: Toni, you might want to note the new accounting provision is helpful to us, but the UK has a couple of laws that's going to limit the interest deductibility piece to 30% of EBITDA. And that is costing us about 160 basis points on the tax line. The tax line is, in this climate, one of the more challenging things for us to predict.

If we do see a change in tax policy, I would note, which might be helpful to you, that a 1% change in the ETR, that's 100 basis points, gives us $0.07 to $0.08 in EPS, which is a lot. So we're quite sensitive to what happens to that tax line, but you know that we've guided to 31% to 32%. We'll see what happens with that.

And there's obviously some variability around it. So we're taking a prudent view on this, given what we know now, and if we have adjustments, we'll be happy to discuss those with you on future calls. Ray, I don't know if you want to --

RAY MCDANIEL: The only other thing I would direct you to is the fact that we do have higher financing cost this year than we did of last year. Part of that is the roll-forward of financing that we did during the year last year.

And part of it is the fact that we've done some financing and we'll continue to do some financing as a result of the settlement with the Department of Justice and the payments that were made there. So that's just giving us an increase in that line that we normally wouldn't see.

TONI KAPLAN: Thanks a lot.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Warren Gardiner with Evercore.

WARREN GARDINER, ANALYST, EVERCORE ISI: Thanks. On the margin and analytics in the quarter, it sounds like there were a couple of moving parts there with GGY and some FX. In any sense you could parse that out for us, give us what you think the core margin would be for that business?

RAY MCDANIEL: Well, I can tell you that if we ignore the additional overhead expense that we absorbed, and we ignore the impact of the acquisition, for the quarter, the margin would have been flat to 2015.

I should also note that we had a couple of million dollars of nonrecurring expense in the fourth quarter of 2016 that we won't have going forward. And so you probably -- if you want to look at, on a run rate basis, you want to back out a couple million dollars for that as well.

WARREN GARDINER: Okay. I guess, then, on expenses, overall -- for Linda, maybe -- in the past you guys have -- this is kind of been asked a little bit. In the past you guys have given us a sense of what you might have to pull back on if things got choppy. Any sense what that level of flexibility would be for 2017?

LINDA HUBER: I think I'd stick to what we said in 2016. We always tell you guys we can achieve $50 million of expense savings, and voila, we achieved $50 million of expense savings. So there's probably another $50 million in there across the Company.

I would note that we are being very thoughtful about expenses. We note that both operating expenses and CapEx, CapEx is looking to be up about $100 million as we go through 2017. We've had a little bit of lightening up in terms of our real estate projects.

We had taken two floors in One World Trade Center in 2016, and as you know, we're making some investment in our technology. But we expect that to lighten up a little bit in 2017. So we're guiding to

$100 million, as we had said.

Just across the board, we're being really careful with what we're doing and considering every cost. We have a procurement group that's done a really nice job on some of our expenses such as T&E. We're managing very, very closely.

We'll think about maybe flexibility for another $50 million for 2017.

WARREN GARDINER: Thanks a lot.

OPERATOR: Next to Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.

ANDRE BENJAMIN, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Thanks. Good afternoon.

I guess I wanted to come back to the ERS growth, and the assumed deceleration of mid-single digits from double digits the last three years. I know you called out the mix shift of going towards products away from services. One, I just want to confirm for similar, I guess, offering, I'm sorry, the implication that it's a lower price, I just want to confirm if that's right for one.

And then two, how much of it is that versus just you being conservative? The last couple years, I think you've guided to mid-single digits and put up something much healthier than that.

RAY MCDANIEL: Andre, a couple of things. First, as Linda said earlier, she noted that trailing 12-month sales in ERS are up 4%, and then she decomposed that. She said that product sales, again trailing 12 months, products sales are up 13%, and services are down 16%.

So if you just start with trailing 12-month sales for ERS up 4%, that flows through to our mid-single-digit revenue guidance for 2017. Because we've got sort of the lag on revenue recognition. So that's how we get to the guidance.

The mix shift, again, is designed to deliver more margin. I think you're right in talking about fees, you're right in the sense that over the last number of years we've done some very large projects for customers where we charged many millions of dollars for the services work that we did. So in that respect that -- not doing projects of that scale and charging those kinds of fees for services will put some -- will put a bit of a drag on top-line growth.

But we think that because the product is more mature, it is more scalable, it meets more needs for more customers, we think we'll be able to sell more. We're going to make it up -- to some degree, we're going to make it up on volume. We'll be able to, as we get through this transition, we'll be able to get through a better growth rate over time.

And then the other thing to keep in mind here is that decline, that 16% decline in services sales in 2016, was kind of a one-time phenomenon. Our expectation is that we'll hold that line flat going forward. So you won't see a big contraction there.

We'll be holding that flat while the product line continues to grow at a double-digit rate. We're going to get, on balance, we'll get to a much healthier overall growth rate in ERS. Which is why you say it's helpful to think of 2017 as a transition year for the business.

ANDRE BENJAMIN: That's helpful. I guess, just a follow-up on the margin question, a couple other people asked. Definitely makes sense that you're getting more overhead.

You've been talking about that for a while now. It's just explicitly to make sure we modeled it right. Should we assume that margins for that business are up next year as you work through this transition or is getting to the mid-[20]s more back-end loaded?

RAY MCDANIEL: Again, we don't give specific margin guidance by line of business, but I will tell you, again, if we were to -- you ignore the GGY acquisition, you ignore the additional overhead that we attracted in 2016. And if you ignore that couple of million dollars that I mentioned, that nonrecurring expense that we had in the fourth quarter, we would have seen over 100 basis points of margin expansion in MA from 2015 to 2016. And I would expect that trend to continue.

ANDRE BENJAMIN: Thanks.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Peter Appert with Piper Jaffray & Co.

PETER APPERT, ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY & CO.: Thanks. Ray, what's left on the legal front?

RAY MCDANIEL: Fortunately, not much. If we step back and look at all of the crisis era litigation, we've now disposed of better than 90% of what we were facing globally. So very little left in terms of numbers.

PETER APPERT: And then, Linda, I understand their rationale in terms of a lower pace of share repurchase in 2017. Should we anticipate, then, that in 2018, maybe get back to more of the $1 billion run rate you've been doing in recent years?

LINDA HUBER: Peter, it's hard for us to guide that far ahead in terms of share repurchase. We do look at market conditions. We do want to reinvest in our businesses, and share repurchase oftentimes is sort of the last number that we look at given that.

We thought it was best to be prudent for this year. Yes, we would like to return to more vigorous share repurchase but we're going to have to see. It's too early to tell where that will go.

RAY MCDANIEL: I think the fairest thing we could say looking out that far is we believe we certainly would have the capacity to do so, and we'd make those decisions nearer the date.

PETER APPERT: Got it. Lastly, Rob, just on the trends in the structured finance market, which seems like it's basically come back to life.

Any commentary in terms of changes you're seeing in the market that might give you more confidence in the sustainability of volumes there? And any commentary on competitive dynamics? Because it does seem there's more competitive pressures in that market than you see elsewhere. Thanks.

ROB FAUBER: Maybe I'll focus primarily on the US. That's obviously the largest market. So in the ABS sector, got off to a bit of a subdued start as folks were still adapting to the Reg AB2 loan level reporting requirements.

But the pipeline's certainly heating up, and activity is heating up in February on some very strong demand there. In terms of CMBS, we saw a very weak start. That was due to a pull-forward of deals from the risk retention deadline at the end of the fourth quarter of 2016, and I would I say that CMBS hasn't weathered risk retention quite as well as the CLO market.

We've only seen two risk-retention compliant deals get printed since the deadline at the end of December. That said, there is a pipeline building in CMBS. And in CLO, we've seen some very strong issuance continuing into the first quarter of 2017.

So obviously, you saw in our results, there was very strong issuance in the fourth quarter due to a real pull forward from 2017 into 2016 in advance of that risk retention deadline. I would note that much of the early volume in the first quarter in CLOs is refi as spreads have come in.

We are starting to see some new CLO formation come into the March pipeline as the CLO market seems to have found some structures that work within the risk retention framework. Just in terms of -- from a competitive standpoint, our coverage continues to be strong, and we actually have seen some nice gains in our coverage in Europe.

OPERATOR: We'll go to Tim McHugh with William Blair & Company.

TIM MCHUGH, ANALYST, WILLIAM BLAIR & COMPANY: Thanks. Just on the margin question, obviously 2017's better.

Are you finding things that you didn't expect? Or are we seeing some of the expected margin expansion that you talked about at Investor Day, in terms of the path towards 45%, just come faster than you would have otherwise expected?

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes, I think it's a couple of things. We have taken actions in 2016 that were somewhat accelerated against our original expectations, and we're getting the benefits of those. We've also got a little bit, as you might imagine, better position on the legal side now than we had last year.

We are still anticipating that we can move to the mid-40%s margin overall. Again, subject to the mix of the two different businesses. But, yes, you've got an acceleration of what we were identifying earlier in the year last year. Linda, I don't know if there was anything else you wanted to add to that.

LINDA HUBER: We were very pleased with the progress we made in 2016. I think we even surprised ourselves, frankly, Tim. We did a $12 million restructuring charge. The genesis that was split half-and-half between the rating agency and shared services.

We're being very careful with what we're doing in headcount. And in shared services, we're very thoughtful about our use of lower-cost locations. Those are our own employees we're using in those lower-cost locations. We've gotten the run rate down, and we're very happy about that. We're being really careful about what we do going forward.

I think it's good housekeeping, and Ray and I encouraged our colleagues to think hard about the margin line. And everybody really got the message and did a great job, and we expect that, that will continue. We run the business in a very disciplined way. We've been very careful in terms of adding new headcount and even backfilling.

So we're pleased with what we're seeing, and we're doing a little bit better than we even thought. So we're very happy with all that. There's no magic to it -- it's day-to-day hard work and good discipline.

TIM MCHUGH: Okay, great, thanks. Just a follow-up on the tax benefits from the new stock comp rules, I guess. Does that cause more seasonality in the tax rate that we should expect?

I know there's timing differences sometimes, and when you'll recognize the benefit associated with that part of it. I don't know if the UK rule has similar --

LINDA HUBER: Sure. The US rules probably will see seasonal effects. And we've estimated about $0.15, but there are a number of factors that go into that which could move around. So we would urge everybody to think about that as an approximation.

A lot of that might come into the first quarter when our restricted stock awards vet. And there are a bunch of factors there.

One is, what is the exercise price? Second is, what is the pace of that exercise pricing? The timing, the number, and any number of other factors.

So we would expect that, that effect might be heavier in the first quarter, particularly given, very happily, where the stock price is right now. So we'll see how that lays out. This is new to us, and we'll give more information as we see what we get in the first quarter.

TIM MCHUGH: Thank you.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Craig Huber with Huber Research Partners.

CRAIG HUBER, ANALYST, HUBER RESEARCH PARTNERS: Great. Thank you.

I have just a broad question on the tax policy potential changes we could get out of Washington. If they do get rid of interest expense deductibility in the US as part of overall tax reform, could you guys base case that would hurt potentially high-yield issuance much more so than investment grade issuance? That's my first question.

RAY MCDANIEL: I think it would probably have more of an impact on high-yield. Again, though, just trying to weigh the puts and takes on that. It's also high-yield companies that are going to probably want to take most advantage of having additional cash on-hand.

And so that gives them more flexibility. It might cause them to engage in different behaviors, whether it's from an M&A standpoint or business expansion. So I do think the premise of your question probably leans against high-yield more than it leans against investment grade -- there's pluses and minuses in both cases.

CRAIG HUBER: Ray, I assume you would say that probably even more so, if the interest expense deductibility was limited to only up to 30% of EBITDA. Similar to what you talked about in the UK, I guess Germany has as well, as opposed to getting rid of 100%.

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes. And again, there's what it does in an absolute sense, but then it's also, relatively, what is still the more or less attractive ways to raise capital. And so even if it's less attractive, if it's still the most attractive, you would expect firms would make rational economic decisions.

CRAIG HUBER: And then Ray, as a follow-on to that, if you just isolate -- I know this is hard, but if you just isolate, if the corporate tax rate, the US Federal rate goes from 35% to 15% or 20% or thereabouts. What is your general sense on what that could do to debt issuance in terms of -- obviously it should be more pro-growth out there?

What do think it would do for debt issuance from an M&A perspective, and investing in backing companies, et cetera? (Multiple speakers) debt issuance.

RAY MCDANIEL: I don't have a quantification of that for you, Craig, but again, the pluses and minuses that we've outlined in a couple of our comments throughout the call indicate that we don't expect dramatic change in what is happening around our business.

But it's going to have some impact. Whether it's at 15% or 20% or 25%. And we're just going to have to see.

CRAIG HUBER: Linda, a couple quick housekeeping questions. Maybe I missed this. What percent of your cash hoard is outside the US right now, if you would, please.

LINDA HUBER: 78% is offshore now, Craig. The numbers are -- US is roughly $500 million, international is roughly $1.7 billion. That totals to $2.2 billion, a little bit more.

But 78% overseas. And that's because we use some of the US cash as we dealt with the DOJ situation. But as we noted, the very vast majority of the settlement payments have already been made.

RAY MCDANIEL: And as has been the case in the past, a substantial fraction of our foreign cash is also held in US dollars.

CRAIG HUBER: Lastly, Linda, if I could ask, given the concerns, ongoing concerns around Brexit. For your ratings business, was your revenues out of the UK for full year 2016 roughly 7% to 8% of your ratings revenue gap? Fair number to think about.

LINDA HUBER: Offshore, offhand -- excuse me, Craig, I'm not certain. We're puzzling and looking at Rob to see if he has any further information.

ROB FAUBER: It's not as straightforward as you might hope, Craig, because we do both UK-entity-based ratings out of the UK, but we also do European-based ratings, EU-based ratings out of the UK. And the companies that are issuing into the EU may be filed from any one of a number of offices.

So both how the revenue gets apportioned and then how the expense base supporting that revenue gets apportioned are subject to some interpretations of what's in and what's out. The UK is not a large part of our overall European business, but I don't have a fraction I can give you.

CRAIG HUBER: Okay. Thank you.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Jeff Silber with Bank of Montreal.

HENRY CHEN, ANALYST, BMO CAPITAL MARKETS: Good morning, guys. It's Henry Chen on for Jeff.

I had a question on MIS. I'm just curious, from a commercial sales perspective, now with the business stabilizing, are there any new markets or geographies that you're looking at to potentially expand your coverage in?

MARK ALMEIDA: In terms of markets that we are looking to expand in, we have been active, as you have seen. In emerging markets including India, increasing our stake in Korea, growing business coming out of China has been growing very nicely.

With the liberalization that is being proposed and discussed in the Chinese market, we would anticipate that, that should create some opportunities. We've also been concentrating on building out the business in Latin America and Middle East. So Rob, I don't know if there's anything else you wanted to add to that.

ROB FAUBER: We opened an office last year in Sweden. We've been building out presence as well in the Nordic region.

HENRY CHEN: Okay, that's helpful. Just on MIS, as a follow-up comment, in terms of the different products, is there any margin changes when one increases as a percentage of the whole, say, when structured increases as a percentage? Does that impact the margins of the business?

ROB FAUBER: The margins in the MIS business for all of the fundamental areas are roughly the same. The structured finance margin is more variable. It's a more transactionally oriented business. And so in periods of high volume, you get higher margins, and low volume, lower margins.

It's also susceptible to how intense the monitoring to activity has to be. In periods of greater stress, there is greater allocation of resource to having to be on top of the monitoring. That's simply because in periods of stress, there are more assets that have to be scrutinized more closely, so you get some swings there as well. That's the only line of business I would say has substantial variability in margin.

HENRY CHEN: The monitoring for the structured, or just overall?

ROB FAUBER: Monitoring for structured in particular, because of the large number of assets that underlie those pools.

HENRY CHEN: Got it. Thanks so much.

OPERATOR: We'll go next to Patrick O'Shaugnessy with Raymond James.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY, ANALYST, RAYMOND JAMES & ASSOCIATES, INC.: Good afternoon. Quick CLO question for you. Does the CLO refinancing create the same revenue opportunity for you guys as a CLO issuance?

RAY MCDANIEL: No, new issuance would be a higher revenue opportunity than refi.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY: Got it. And then, follow-up question. The acquisition that you just announced the other day, this structured finance data and analytics business of SCDM, is that going within research data and analytics? If so, can you talk about how much of the high-single-digit revenue growth target for that segment in 2017 is going to come from the acquisition?

MARK ALMEIDA: The answer to your first question is yes, it is part of RD&A. But it is a very, very small acquisition. It's a good acquisition. It makes a ton of sense.

We've done this a number of times before where we've acquired businesses where -- in this case we didn't acquire any people. We essentially bought a product that is very similar to an existing product of ours. We're going to transition their customers from the legacy product to our product.

So essentially, we bought that business without buying any expense, frankly, that would come along with it. So I think it's a very good transaction for us. But it is, honestly, it's tiny.

Strategically, it's a nice fit, but it's not going to turn the dial on financial performance for RD&A.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY: Smaller than the GGY acquisition of last year?

MARK ALMEIDA: That's correct.

RAY MCDANIEL: Significantly.

PATRICK O'SHAUGHNESSY: Thank you.

OPERATOR: We have no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Mr. Ray McDaniel for closing comments.

RAY MCDANIEL: Okay. Thank you all for joining the call today, and we look forward to speaking with you again after the first quarter. Thanks.

OPERATOR: This concludes Moody's Corporationfourth quarter and fiscal year-end 2016 earnings call. As a reminder, a replay of this call will be available after 3 PM Eastern time on Moody'sIR website. Thank you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RHB-HX41-JB20-G3NG-00000-00Event Brief of Q4 2017 Alliance Data Systems Corp Earnings Call - Final2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:28ZLexisNexis012518sz.751Event Brief of Q4 2017 Alliance Data Systems CorpEarnings Call - Final

CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS

. Charles L. Horn - Alliance Data Systems Corporation,CFO and EVP

. Edward J. Heffernan - Alliance Data Systems Corporation,CEO, President and Director

. Edward Sebor

CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS

. Andrew William Jeffrey - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, Inc., Research Division,Director

. Darrin David Peller - Barclays PLC, Research Division,MD

. David Mark Togut - Evercore ISI, Research Division,Senior MD, Head of Payments, Processors & IT Services Research and Fundamental Research Analyst

. David Michael Scharf - JMP Securities LLC, Research Division,MD and Senior Research Analyst

. Jason Scott Deleeuw - Piper Jaffray Companies, Research Division,VP & Senior Research Analyst

. Sanjay Harkishin Sakhrani - Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc.,Research Division,MD

. Vincent Albert Caintic - Stephens Inc., Research Division,MD and Senior Specialty Finance Analyst

OVERVIEW

Co. reported 2017 revenue of $7.72b and core EPS of $19.35. 4Q17 revenue was $2.1b and core EPS was $6.26. Expects core EPS to be $22.50-23.00.

FINANCIAL DATA

1. 2017 revenue = $7.72b.

2. 4Q17 revenue = $2.1b.

3. 2017 core EPS = $19.35.

4. 4Q17 core EPS = $6.26.

5. 2017 YoverY revenue growth = 8%.

6. 4Q17 YoverY revenue growth = 15%.

7. 2018 core EPS guidance = $22.50-23.00.

PRESENTATION SUMMARY -

2017 Financials (C.H.)

1. Highlights:

1. Revenue:

1. 4Q17 $2.1b.

1. Up 15%; strong.

2. 2017 $7.72b.

1. Up 8%, slightly soft to guidance due to hurricanes Harvey and Irma negatively impacting revenue at Card Services by approx. $80m.

2. Core EPS:

1. 4Q17 $6.26.

1. Up 34%.

2. 2017 $19.35.

1. Up 14%.

3. Excluding net tax benefit:

1. 4Q17 $5.24; up 12%.

2. 2017 $18.33; up 8%, better than guidance of $18.10.

3. Recently enacted tax reform lowered provision for income tax for 4Q17 and full-year by reducing net deferred tax liabilities, essentially reducing cash taxes that Co. would have had to pay in future.

1. Benefits this moving forward, as Co. expects its effective tax rate to drop to 26-27% in 2018 vs. 33% in 2017 prior to adjustment.

2. Anticipates cash benefit to approximate $100m to cash flow in 2018.

4. Year-end net corporate debt approx. $5.9b, while corporate leverage ratio ended the year at 2.7 times, consistent with last several years.

2. LoyaltyOne:

1. Mixed year.

2. AIR MILES made expectations.

1. Restored profitability of the level Co. anticipated.

3. BrandLoyalty results were unexpectedly poor.

4. Entered the year knowing that Co. needed to retool AIR MILES business model following break assumption reset at 2016-end.

1. Successful in introducing small changes that allowed AIR MILES EBITDA margins to return to mid-20s range.

2. AIR MILES issued came in short of expectations, down 4%.

1. Softness and promotional activity, especially in grocery vertical caused shortfall.

2. Will need to stimulate promotional activity in 2018 in order to drive issuance growth.

5. BrandLoyalty:

1. Revenue decreased 12%, weakness is due to:

1. Key markets Germany and Russia were off to absence of events like EuroCup and Olympics, which reduced number of programs executed.

2. North American expansion into US did not manifest as it is taking longer to establish the [foothold] here than anticipated.

3. Rollout of Disney product offering was delayed to 2018.

2. Backlog for 1H looks good in 2018.

3. Epsilon:

1. Goal for Epsilon entering 2018 [represent] top and bottom line growth.

2. Strong finish to 2017 allowed Co. to hit 5% revenue growth target.

3. On apples-to-apples basis, achieved 5% adjusted EBITDA target.

4. Difference to reported decline of 1% is restoration of $29m in incentive compensation vs. zero last year, essentially it is one year grow over that Co. had to play through that it needed to restore bonuses in order to maintain highly competitive compensation packages going forward.

5. Faster than expected stabilization of technology platform business, which finished strong with 7% revenue growth in 4Q17, as offering stabilized through the sale of more packaged offerings and record volumes through Harmony, digital messaging platform.

6. Other two big drivers of growth Auto and Conversant CRM finished 4Q17 and year with double-digit revenue growth.

1. Auto continues to benefit from ongoing penetration to new OEMs.

2. Conversant CRM [cross selling efforts] continue to gain traction, in particular as its digital capabilities are now embedded in auto and technology platform offerings.

4. Card Services:

1. Facing headwinds of second year of credit normalization, Card Services still delivered with double-digit growth in revenue and adjusted EBITDA.

2. Credit sales increased 6%, with apparel brand partners showing consistent improvement as the year progressed, culminating in strong holiday performance.

3. Tender share growth:

1. 4Q17, more than 160 BP.

2. 2017, more than 100 BP.

4. Avg. receivables increased 15%.

1. Growth rate in 4Q17 gets slightly to 13%, as Co. divested approx. $100m of non-core program receivables in Dec., which hurt receivables growth by about 2%.

5. OpEx up 7% vs. revenue growth of 13%; strong expense leveraging.

6. Net loss rate 6%; up 90 BP over 2016.

1. 60 BP of the increase is due to lower recovery rates.

2. 30 BP due to higher gross losses.

7. Gross loss rates stabilized as 2017 progressed, as Co. reached end of credit normalization cycle.

8. Delinquency trend or wedge, closed within 10 BP at year-and, excluding transitory impact of hurricanes.

9. Overall, credit sales increased 8% with strong performance from Co.'s recent vintages.

1. On a comparable brand basis, credit sales up 5% YoverY.

1. Growth was fueled by continued non-store spend, up 11%, which includes digital and web channels.

2. Non-store sales growth was driven by increase in buyers and spend per buyer; 3% and 2% respectively.

1. Growth came from an increase in omnichannel buyers reflecting Co.'s continued strategy to help brands engage customers in all relevant channels.

10. Card Services continue to expand and diversify portfolio of brand partners, standing nearly $3b vintage in 2017.

11. New partners Co. has signed this year has been a great reflection of where the market is growing and what consumers' value.

1. Brands like Ikea and Viking Cruises has being valued for product and experiences they provide and Build.com being a strong e-tailer in a growing category for ADS.

12. Key initiative for 2018 is to develop a consumer direct funding program for Utah bank.

1. Would allow Co. to take savings accounts and other non-demand deposits, which diversifying its funding sources and helping funding rates.

2017 Review (E.H.)

1. Highlights:

1. Epsilon:

1. Goal for the year was mid-single digits top and bottom.

1. On an apples-to-apples basis, believes Co. accomplished that.

2. Delta between reported number for EBITDA and 5% growth rate is restoration of incentive comp or bonus program.

1. Prior year, there was zero payout, which Co. doesn't believe is sustainable in this market.

2. Wanted to make sure Co. was highly competitive as moving into 2018.

3. Exiting the year to plus seven topline is a good signal as moving into next year.

1. Believes Co. is getting to handle on that sort of mid-single-digit growth rate.

2. Card Services even with 90 BP increase in loss rates, still managed to deliver EBITDA to net of all these provision costs and funding costs and everything else up double digits.

3. EPS:

1. Had guided to roughly $18.10, came in at $19.35.

1. Over performance would have brought Co. in at $18.33, ahead by $0.23.

2. Little over $1 coming from tax benefit, which consisted both of benefit itself less about $12m that Co. allocated to non-executive bonuses coming out of tax reform act.

2. LoyaltyOne:

1. Consists of Canadian business AIR MILES.

1. After the crisis last year, stabilized model with number of changes that Co. made and specifically, came in mid-20% EBITDA margins, which was its goal.

3. Wanted to make sure coming out of crisis that Co. retained its clients and had 100% retention rates.

4. Wanted to get the folks excited about the program again; comes through with active collectors.

1. Active collectors are all the way back to pre-crisis levels by 4Q.

5. Probably there a couple of things that Co. still need to work on.

1. Model stabilized, but it has not yet kicked into adding to growth rate at ADS; wants to move it back now that it's been stabilized into growth rate mode and that's a job for 2018.

2. The one goal where Co. came at short was promotional spend from clients, which represents about a third of all miles that it issues was quite soft and that's something that it is working on right now to make sure that it's not just every day spend that gets rewarded, but it wants a big chunk of promotional spend.

2. BrandLoyalty unfortunately had a poor year.

1. Believes Co. got a little bit comfortable with three straight years of strong double-digit growth of topline and EBITDA.

1. Just had it fell off a cliff in 2017 and had poor results.

2. Now has visibility on fact that Co. has had a huge book of business for 2018 and it looks like it's more like an air pocket.

3. Looking forward to having a very robust snapback from BL in 2018.

3. Epsilon:

1. Mid-single-digit organic top and bottom line is what Co. is looking for and that's what it brought to table, that's what it is looking to continue into 2018 and start building up a level of consistency that people feel comfortable with.

1. 2016-end, that's when there was a big question on Co.'s largest chunk of business with technology platform, which is about over a qtr. of all of Epsilon conversant and that was a bit of a melting iceberg at that point, it's down 13% YoverY in 4Q16.

1. Team did a wonderful job of turning it not only getting pricing at a level Co. wants, setting up office in India, also moving from a customized model where things take 15, 17 months to get to market to a more standard package where it is talking about 2-3 months.

2. Thereby, saw steady progress and actually exited year at plus 7% growth for that business.

2. Two big growth areas digital CRM and Auto offerings both up strongly double-digit.

1. There was a bit of a concern in 3Q whether digital CRM, which had fallen off in terms of growth rate.

1. Whether that was an air pocket, fortunately it was and thereby, saw a nice pick up in 4Q.

3. It's a bit more from a macro perspective, has got a lot of folks and it's both a tech offering, but it's also a services offering.

1. Going to be watching carefully the impact of tight labor market for hard skills.

1. Lot of folks competing for this type of talent and Co. wants to make sure it is on top of the list.

4. Wants to have more consistent better visibility on financial results.

1. Believes 2017 was a good start, but there is still works to be done there.

4. Card Services:

1. Fabulous wedge that Co. put out on 15 months ago, which is Co.'s best predictor of future losses.

1. Up YoverY about 50 BP and that's where Co. believes losses will be up about 50 BP.

2. By year-end, it should have closed that would have been a nice finish to the year, unfortunately Co. came within 10 BP.

1. Had some noise from hurricanes, but trends are friend at this point and it's effectively closed.

3. Outlook for 2018 gives Co. comfort that stable loss rates will follow.

2. Book of business growth rate 15%; quite strong.

1. Believes that's a good number for Co. to shoot for on yearly basis.

2. Looking back the last five years, numbers closer to 20%.

1. Believes 15% is a solid number, that gives Co. a lot of flexibility when it comes to signing new clients and being very selective on renewals.

3. Had a record new vintage this year, close to $3b.

1. Taking all signings that Co. did over the past year whether it was an existing file or whether it was a file starting from scratch and it takes three years to ramp up, after three years all of these clients together will add roughly $3b to portfolio.

2. Has number of vintages each year that are spooling up.

3. Looking at clients, it's interesting that they differ across verticals and across physical presence vs. strictly e-commerce, obviously Signet, Build.com, Viking, Guess, Diamonds, Adorama and Ikea represents what Co. is beginning to seeing now which is different from more traditional model of mall-based soft good apparels.

1. Sees interest coming from many different areas and that gives Co. a lot of comfort on what it is going to do going forward.

4. Double-digit adjusted EBITDA growth, includes absorbing 90 BP increase in losses.

5. Missed third-party recovery market.

1. Thereby, it lowered recovery rates dramatically.

2. Looking at 90 BP increase in net losses, Co. thought it would be more like 50 BP, what it turned out to be was gross losses were only up 30 BP.

1. Lost it on recovery side when market cratered.

5. Results:

1. Revenue up 8%.

2. Core EPS up 14%.

1. Tax [beni] up 8%, excluding the beni.

3. Leverage at corporate level at 2.7 times; modest.

1. Includes impact of funding over $1b for buybacks and capital for growth in portfolio.

2. Good generation of free cash flow for Co.

4. Stabilization of credit loss rate were there after two years of absorbing increases.

5. Poised now to return to mid-to-high teen's core EPS growth rate in 2018, which is Co.'s long-term model.

1. It's been a bumpy couple of years and Co. is right where it wanted to be for slingshot for 2018.

6. Raising cash dividend 10% to $0.57 per share starting in 1Q18.

6. 2018 Guidance:

1. Revenue looks quite strong.

1. Looking at double-digit revenue growth of roughly 12%.

2. Against that there is an accounting adjustment that does not affect cash flow or EBITDA or EPS, it's merely geography, but it does change recognition of roughly $350m in business in Canada.

Accounting Adjustment (C.H.)

1. Details:

1. Revenue has been out there for quite a while, but it was really in Dec. when AICPA came out with a white paper that basically said that if loyalty program doesn't take inventory risk, meaning Co. doesn't own it, it doesn't carry inventory into point of redemption, it should record it net (gross revenue minus the cost of product redemption to get to a net revenue).

1. LoyaltyOne travel has definitely fit that threshold.

1. What it forces Co. to do is to look at travel-related redemptions going into 2018, recognize will now have a net recordation for it.

2. No impact at all in terms of any of earnings metrics, obviously it bumps up EBITDA margin appreciably, but it's purely shifting to a net presentation.

1. Came very late in year, not anticipated it early, not a big impact overall for ADS in terms of revenue and no impact to profitability.

2018 Guidance (E.H.)

1. Core EPS:

1. 12% topline core EPS.

1. Even with big bump up in 2017 from $18.10 to $19.35, still looking at 16-19% growth.

2. Going back to original guidance, wanted to do $18.10 this past year, bumping up to $21.50 for next year.

1. New guidance is Co. came in at $19.35 and going to bump up to $22.50-23.00 a share, representing 16-19% growth.

2. Tax Bill:

1. Will provide Co. with roughly $100m a year in additional free cash flow; roughly $1.78 per share.

1. Going to take that $100m and obviously flow through roughly two-thirds of it and going to take between 30-33% and pile that back into Co.

2. Going to put it back into Co. in three different buckets:

1. To accelerate some existing projects that Co. has on board.

2. To establish an innovation fund to make sure Co. is on leading edge of various digital payment products that are out there.

3. To bolster some employee benefits, whether it's getting 401(k) participation rate up or holding down any increases on benefits, the premiums on various healthcare packages for employees Co. wants to help out there.

3. Trying to live the spirit of agreement and what Co. believes is the appropriate thing to do.

3. LoyaltyOne:

1. BrandLoyalty:

1. Expects high single-digit revenue, low double-digit adjusted EBITDA growth.

2. AIR MILES has stabilized.

1. Now Co. would like to see it begin to return to incremental growth.

3. BrandLoyalty usually runs at a solid double-digit top and bottom.

1. Had a poor year in 2017.

2. Expect strong snapback in 2018, believes the World Cup, the Olympics and the Disney deals that Co. has, it's already looking like the number of deals it has signed is going to be a record.

4. Epsilon:

1. Consistency.

2. Wants to see minimum of mid-single-digit top and bottom.

3. Expects tech platform, now, that it's turned to actually turn into growth along with Auto and Conversant CRM.

1. Those three businesses are almost 70% of Epsilon Conversant.

5. Card Services:

1. Expects roughly 15% growth on avg. credit card receivables.

1. Looking at signings from 2015-2017, those signings are ramping and combined, they add about $2.5b to growth rate in 2018 plus the core Co. expects to be in modest growth mode add another $1b.

1. At $3.5b and Co. has budgeted about $1b of what it consider folks that either are going bankrupts or it doesn't believes the renewal process is favorable to ADS.

2. Has put in a fair amount of squish there to get Co. to 15%, it could be a tad bit higher; it is right at 15%.

2. Credit:

1. Stable delinquency rates.

2. Best predictor of future losses.

3. Started 2017 at about 55 BP higher.

1. By 4Q17, it get rid of hurricane noise, it's just about close to 10 BP.

4. Expects stable delinquency rates and that will lead to stable loss rates.

5. Gross loss rates up only 30 BP last year and better than 50 BP Co. had initially forecast.

1. Consumer is quite healthy, seeing good behavior from consumer, but really where the 90 BP increase came from two-thirds of it came from third-party recovery market, which fell off cliff.

6. Recovery market for sales of written off counts got to be challenging for Co.

1. Delinquent, recovery process for next 180 days; has always done that 100% in-house, it's certainly one of Co.'s advantages.

2. Post write offs, so after 180 days, after Co. writes off account, sells some of that paper to third-party, that market collapsed.

3. Normally recovers between 22-25% of gross losses.

4. In 2016, 1.8% meant to roughly 26% of gross losses were recovered.

5. In 2017, received much less when Co. sold those accounts, recovery rate fell to 16% and it added 60 BP to net loss rate or two-thirds of total.

6. Similar to past, can do better in-house that process started in earnest in late fall and will be complete by 2Q18.

7. 1Q18 will be noisy and will be elevated.

8. Final hurricane flow through will cause gross losses to be elevated, while Co. will be refraining from any third-party sales of written off accounts, which would normally have lowered and which will lower recovery rates vs. prior year.

1. Co. wants to recover those itself.

2. It will come a little bit later in year, expects an elevated loss rate in 1Q18, this is noise only.

9. Delinquency flow suggests stable gross losses.

10. In-house recovery process will be done by 2Q18.

11. After an elevated 1Q18 to aforementioned transitory items, 2Q18 through 4Q18, expects flat to better vs. prior year on loss rates and to make up for 1Q18 noise with favorable comps in 2Q-4Q.

6. Summary:

1. Two-year credit normalization process is over.

2. Back as a co. to mid to high-teens earnings growth.

3. Free cash flow will be very robust with over $1.5b.

1. Right now, has only allocated roughly $500m of that to support regulatory capital and dividends.

2. Over $1b of unencumbered free cash flow.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from the line of Darrin Peller with Barclays.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER, MD, BARCLAYS PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Let me just start off on the card business. From an outlook perspective, the -- I know you're talking about mid-teens receivables growth, or the like again. And I know the year ended off with a slightly slower growth rate. I think it was closer to 10% in the December month. I just want to understand where the confidence is coming from in terms of the portfolio growth and the underlying trends in retailers you're seeing right now. And then just a quick follow-up on the BrandLoyalty -- on the LoyaltyOne business after, please?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN, CEO, PRESIDENT AND DIRECTOR, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORPORATION: Yes, sure. What we do is, obviously, we've got roughly 160 clients. Actually, a lot of the core clients that we had wound up doing a bit better in Q4 and holiday than, I think, a lot of people had anticipated. So we are seeing a little bit of traction there. Also what we do is we look at, Darrin, the vintages that we signed not just in '17, but '16 and '15 and see how they're ramping up and when they're going to layer into the '18 growth pipeline. And so you sort of wrap it all together and what we're seeing is even factoring in at roughly $1 billion that could go away due to a client going bankrupt or renewals that we don't want to pursue, we've looked back -- oh gosh, if you went back prior 5 years, our average growth rate has been 22%. If you layer in the vintages, what you're seeing with the ramp-ups of the IKEAs and stuff like that, the 15% looks certainly doable.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER: Okay. So it's really organic. I mean, in terms of the strength you're seeing, it's actually organic addition -- additional clients.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes. We have not factored in any acquisitions of portfolios in 2018.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER: Okay. I was just going to ask about -- I appreciate that. On the LoyaltyOne side, just to be clear, I mean, I understand BrandLoyalty has a ton of different new business coming on -- World Cup, Olympics, Disney, et cetera. Just give us more color on the overall confidence on that business, not just -- I mean, on loyalty and the AIR MILES side, specifically, in terms of the overall guidance, high single-digit revenue. What do you need for the AIR MILES business to do for that business overall -- LoyaltyOne, to deliver the guidance you're giving, high single-digit revenue growth and -- I mean, can you give us a little more confidence on what you're seeing there to give you the conviction in that?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Sure. I think the Canadian business, we've set the bar, I think, at a reasonable level. So the goal for '17 was stabilize, get the margins back to the mid-20s. For '18, frankly, Darrin, we're talking 2% to 3%-type growth, which should certainly be doable. The BrandLoyalty, frankly, is going to be the engine driving this bus. And based on what we're seeing in terms of the number of programs signed versus the folks who decided to take a pass last year and sort of wait for the Olympics and World Cup and everything else, it looks pretty robust.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER: Okay. All right. Charles, just last question and I'll turn it back to the queue. But on the tax side, it's great to see your guidance unchanged, backing out now the tax benefit implicit in your '18 guidance. Just curious in terms of the assumptions for the tax benefit. I mean, I think we had estimated a little bit higher than the $1.50-or-so you're guiding and I know there's a $0.50 reinvestment. But even with that, is there any other items we should just be aware of in terms of conservatism in your tax adjustments or tax estimates for the year?

CHARLES L. HORN, CFO AND EVP, ALLIANCE DATA SYSTEMS CORPORATION: Sure. So if you look at 2017, our effective tax rate was 33%. We're guiding to 26% to 27% effective tax rate in '18. To Darrin's point, it does assume that we'll get a little pressure from the States. You've read what's going on in New York, New Jersey, California. They could -- the states could look to grab some of that federal savings. So there is little bit of conservatism built in, in that the state rate could go up in 2018 versus '17, which is why we set the bar at 26% to 27% effective tax rate '18.

DARRIN DAVID PELLER: All right. So it's maybe another 100 basis points or so above what it otherwise would have been. Or...

CHARLES L. HORN: I can't quantify it, Darrin.

OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

SANJAY HARKISHIN SAKHRANI, MD, KEEFE, BRUYETTE, & WOODS, INC.,RESEARCH DIVISION: Maybe this goes back to the spirit of some of Darrin's questions. But Ed, maybe you could just talk about where you see the largest risks to your outlook. I know there's a lot of positive things happening underneath it all, but maybe you could just talk about what you're worried about to the extent that you are worried about anything. And then as far as tax reform, can that help Card Services and Epsilon as consumers benefit from that and businesses look to reinvest? I'm just trying to think through the impacts.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes. I think they're fair questions. Look, we don't -- the areas that we need to continue to show consistency, that would be Epsilon/Conversant. We've had a good run in '17. Frankly, I think we need to demonstrate we can do that again in '18 before people get really comfortable. From what I'm seeing, it looks pretty good. Obviously, the BrandLoyalty thing was probably the thing that took us all by surprise. And I can -- I see the number of programs we signed based on prior year. We know how that will flow into earnings growth. I don't think we're going to say much more until we actually just print the numbers because we missed so badly during '17. If there's one place of risk at the overall level, it's certainly not with the consumer. What we're hearing out of the thousands of folks who are in our collection areas is that the consumer is quite strong, quite healthy. So I would say, Sanjay, the only thing that would pop up to me, of our 160-or-so card clients, we're assuming a handful, and we watch them pretty closely, are going to have a very difficult time. A couple may even head towards bankruptcy. To the extent, on the retail side, that estimate is off and there's another handful that we haven't thought about, I don't think it will hurt '18, per se, but what it will do is it will make for a tough grow-over for '19. So from a macro perspective, it's more retailer-specific, a handful we've sort of identified. It's no more than that handful.

CHARLES L. HORN: And on the tax reform, Sanjay, we would say, you've seen many companies come out announcing they're going to put more money in the hands of their associates, which could lead to card holder spending more money in 2018, which could be beneficial to our card operations.

SANJAY HARKISHIN SAKHRANI: How about Epsilon? Are businesses looking to reinvest some of the upside?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes. I think from some of the reinvestments, I would call out probably 2 areas. The first in terms of reinvestment would be -- we have always -- given the size of the card business today, it was a lot easier when the file was a couple billion as opposed to heading towards $20 billion. We will be rolling out and launching a new source of funding, which will be on the consumer deposit side out of our ILC facility in Utah. And obviously, that requires a consumer platform. It requires marketing. We'll have to come up with some fancy slogan or catchy slogan, I guess, that will get people excited about what's in their purse. And then the other area would be with the CRM business at the Conversant side of it. Given the growth rates there, we will probably -- not probably, we will absolutely be ramping up the size of the sales force effort and, perhaps, focusing even more on not just the large clients, but also mid-market. So those would be the 2 big areas I would see initially for investment.

OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Caintic with Stephens.

VINCENT ALBERT CAINTIC, MD AND SENIOR SPECIALTY FINANCE ANALYST, STEPHENS INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: So first, I have to ask a question on credit. But on the in-house collection efforts that you've had so far, so I know it's early days, but given the 60 basis point headwind you had in 2017, what are you seeing so far in your experience that maybe can give us some encouragement? And then also, how you think about the level of credit reserves that you keep. We've had some good provision performance recently, but just kind of wondering how you think about credit reserves.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Sure. Great question. Yes, we went through this whole recovery in-house versus selling to third parties post great recession, where we raised the same type of issue and we had to bring things back in-house. All right, it's pretty simple math. At a certain level, it's more profitable to push it outside. What we have found, so far, because we're about 6 months into this process, is that much like we had anticipated, if I were to put a number on it, the recovery rates internally are probably somewhere around 20% to 22% of your gross loss rates. So against a marketplace that was paying us 25%, it certainly made sense to go outside. However, that 25% dropped all the way down to 16% during '17. So as we gradually move that up to the 20%, 22% in-house, that's what we're seeing. And that's why I think we feel very good about where the net loss rate trend is going to be this year. From a gross loss perspective, it's going to be flat.

CHARLES L. HORN: In terms of credit reserves, we tend to carry 11 to 13 months in terms of forward loss coverage based upon the trends we see in losses. Beginning back in 2015, we carried up to 13 months coverage all the way through the third quarter of this year. We trimmed it back to 12 based upon favorable trends. Fourth quarter, we kept it at 12 months forward coverage, which is likely where we'll stay until we see it stabilized and potentially drop lower. The key thing to keep in mind in looking at the reserve quality or the reserve coverage, if the Signet file came on late in the year, close to $1 billion, the losses embedded with the file recorded net, so there is no reserve attributable to it. So you always had to focus on the reserve divided by the reservable AR, which would not include the bulk of Signet in that number.

VINCENT ALBERT CAINTIC: Okay. Got it. That makes sense. And then separately on the -- I mean, the loyalty programs and kind of the loyalty updates, you talked about 15% AR growth in the card side and the signings' activity that you're getting there. I'm just kind of wondering how also that might translate into some growth on the Epsilon side. It seems like -- there seems to be more engagement on the overall loyalty offering that you have and if you can just give more perspective on that.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Sure. Yes. I mean, 100% of our card clients are on the loyalty platform developed by Epsilon. The various digital distribution channels, such as email, our card clients would use the Epsilon. We are, right now, beginning a bigger push to get the unique sort of identification platform that is Conversant CRM into the hands of our card clients. So we would expect that to be a big area for us to push. I would say, across the board, our card clients are asking not only for the type of insight into their existing customers, but they also want to be able to say, "Let me take a look at my best customers. How do I go out and find people similar to that, that may not be customers today?" And that's the beauty of what Conversant can do with its unique ID. We can take all those characteristics and then go find these folks and, on behalf of the clients, get something really exciting that could motivate them to show up, either online or in-store at our clients. And that's sort of a new area that we're really beginning to expand. So it's not just taking care of the existing best customers. That's obviously job #1. But it's now moving into, "Help me take a profile of my best customer and then go out into space there and find someone similar and then get them all excited about the brand." And that's -- that is an area that's getting our clients very excited because it's going to drive sales, and that's sort of the bottom line. So that's the big push.

OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Deleeuw with Piper Jaffray.

JASON SCOTT DELEEUW, VP & SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, PIPER JAFFRAY COMPANIES, RESEARCH DIVISION: So I just want to be clear on the credit recoveries. Sounds like we have some noise with the hurricanes maybe in the first quarter. But taking it in-house and then the changes you've made, I mean, shouldn't the recovery rate -- shouldn't there be a tailwind to your net charge-off rate? Or are you expecting that still kind of flat versus the 2017 level?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: That's absolutely going to be -- when it's fully up and running, it should be -- you should think 20%, 22% versus 16% that we did in 2017. So from that perspective, if you had flat delinquencies, which we have, and you're going to see flat gross loss rates and you've got this tailwind on the recoveries, as the year progresses, it certainly suggests that we're going to be in decent shape.

JASON SCOTT DELEEUW: Good. And then just on Epsilon. The technology platform revenue, it grew 7% in the quarter, so it was a nice improvement on the growth rate there. Can we sustain that level? And can you just help us understand kind of the drivers of that and then kind of the margin profile of that revenue versus the rest of Epsilon?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Sure. I'll let Charles do the margin. In terms of the product itself, what we basically had there was the traditional Epsilon product release, big iron-type databases and loyalty platforms that were highly customized for each and every client. And they were just massive, right? They dealt with tens of millions of customers of clients, all the bells and whistles in the world. And they were, frankly, pretty cool. The problem was they cost an awful lot of money. And it took anywhere between 9 to 15 months for this thing -- for these things to be delivered and cranked up for the customer. That just wasn't feasible anymore. We were frankly a bit slow to make the pivot to transition to a lower cost, quicker delivered product. And that's what took us a full year, maybe 15 months to do. We opened a large office in India, which helped with the price point. It brought us very competitive with some of the SaaS-based solutions out there. In addition to that, we, frankly, could no longer sit there and spend 6 months getting all the bells and whistles on these platforms. And we said, "Here's what we can deliver in a 2-month time frame." And so we sort of marginalized the offering. And lo and behold, with the new price point and the time to market being brought from 10 months to 2 months, we found a very receptive audience because a lot of these folks, frankly, don't want to run the things in-house. There's a big market for companies that want to run and they get SaaS-based solutions and they hire IT staff and they go do their thing. So it's also a very big market as long as we can hit the price point and we can deliver in a timely fashion, where they're saying, "Look, I don't want to be the ones responsible for figuring out how the watch is made. I just want to know the time." And so that's why I think this is something that, right now, certainly seems sustainable based on the book of business we've signed.

CHARLES L. HORN: Yes, Jason, from an EBITDA margin standpoint, think of technology platform being in the 18% to 20% range.

OPERATOR: Your next question is from the line of David Togut with Evercore ISI.

DAVID MARK TOGUT, SENIOR MD, HEAD OF PAYMENTS, PROCESSORS & IT SERVICES RESEARCH AND FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH ANALYST, EVERCORE ISI, RESEARCH DIVISION: Could you drill down a little bit more into the mid-teens portfolio growth assumption for '18 for Card Services? More specifically, could you talk about your assumption for same-store credit sales and what the breakdown of that would be between expectation for same-store sales of your existing retailers versus expected wallet share gain?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: You bet. I think, David, it's -- we are taking a fairly conservative view based upon what we've seen over the last year or so. So for the core clients, the folks who've been with us for 3 or more years, what we have seen is they've gone from probably negative 2% or 3%, to the last quarter, they were probably -- it just broke the surface of the water, probably 0% to 1%. So we're assuming same-store sales are probably not going to be better than 1% for those core retailers. With tender share, we should be able to get to somewhere between about 4% -- 4% to 5% in terms of sales that will -- sales growth on our cards from those core. And so as you know, you go back half a dozen years or so, that 5% used to be closer to 8% or 9%. But it looks like factoring in same-store sales of about 1 point, we'll get tender share, of course, and so we're thinking 4% or 5% and then the rest will come from the big books of businesses that we've signed in '17, '16 and '15.

DAVID MARK TOGUT: Got it. And then just a follow-up on capital allocation. Charles, you highlighted $1 billion of unencumbered free cash flow. How are you thinking about capital allocation priorities with your stock at its current price, let's say, balanced against potential acquisition and/or divestiture opportunities?

CHARLES L. HORN: I'd say, David, we're going to be flexible on how we use that. I'd say, right now, M&A is probably pretty low on the radar screen. We could use some for buyback. We could use some to pay down debt over the course of the year. Really, the focus Ed and I have is to make sure that all 3 of our segments are firing and back on track. And based upon those trends, we'll determine how we deploy that capital. So I'd say, conservatively, expect it can go to just pay down debt, delever a little bit. Even though we're in a very good shape now, it makes sense. We could do a modicum of buyback. Obviously, we have the dividend that's there as well. What I would say is just expect M&A to be a relatively low priority at this point. Really, the focus, as I said, is to get all 3 of our segments back firing.

OPERATOR: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

ANDREW WILLIAM JEFFREY, DIRECTOR, SUNTRUST ROBINSON HUMPHREY, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Really nice to see Epsilon back in the mid- to high single-digit range. I'm wondering if you could provide just a little more color. Auto has been really strong. CRM is doing well. So I guess, a couple of questions. First, on auto, could you characterize how you think about the cyclicality of those -- of that end market versus sort of structural demand? And then within the CRM offering, are there any verticals, in particular, that you'd call out as being important drivers? And again, I'm just trying to get a sense for the sustainability of the growth in those 2 really important drivers of Epsilon.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes, good questions. On the auto side, what's interesting is the bulk of the work that we do, both for the OEM and for the various dealerships, the thousands and thousands of dealerships, really is more after the sale is made. So it's much more in terms of service. So that doesn't have the type of variability you'll have with everything is driven off of sales, new car sales. So we're the folks who will sit there and, hopefully, use predictive analysis and more and more of the telematics, the data that comes out of the dashboard that basically will say, let you know through a text or an email or a big card in your mailbox that says, "Hey, Andrew, it looks to me like you're about 1.5 weeks away from when it's time to get your oil changed. Come on over to the dealership and we'll give you a great deal." That's the type of stuff that we'll be doing. As more and more data comes from the telematics side of it, we'll be able to bug you all day long about your transmission level and all these other things that we'll be making sure you don't break down out there in California. So that's sort of it on the auto side. From the CRM side -- so the auto side shouldn't all be that cyclical. From the CRM side, look, the huge verticals, thus far, have been retail. Auto is certainly looking bigger. What else, Charles?

CHARLES L. HORN: Financial.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes, financials, the banks for sure. There's a couple other verticals we're beginning to look at that hold promise. So we want to take the offering and move it from just sort of a retail-type offering to auto financial services. CPG looks promising. Those are the verticals we'd be focused on.

ANDREW WILLIAM JEFFREY: Okay. And just one quick one, if I may. In technology, to the extent you're winning more there and your win rates look better, are there -- are you -- are these competitive takeaways? Or are they buy versus build decisions that you're swaying?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: I would say it's less competitive takeaways. I think it's -- the market continues. It's a very -- it's a growing market, right, as you know. It's really -- comes down to the CMO needs to decide whether she wants to have the thing built in-house and have a big tech stack, meaning let's get a SaaS-based solution and surround it with 100 tech people or now that we can have a similar price point to that offering and do it ourselves, is it okay to give up controls of the guts of this thing and just have the results pour through into her shop so he or she can just have a bunch of analysts to look at the results? So that's -- the sandbox itself is getting bigger and bigger, so I would say the vast majority of it are more and more folks who are getting into the whole concept of,

"Hey, we can use this data in loyalty platforms to understand my customers and market to them." It's huge.

OPERATOR: Your last question comes from the line of David Scharf with JMP Securities.

DAVID MICHAEL SCHARF, MD AND SENIOR RESEARCH ANALYST, JMP SECURITIES LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: First question on the card side. Just a point of clarification. Ed, when I look at the components of your portfolio growth guidance this year, is the $1 billion subtraction for retailers that ultimately may become noncore, non-growing, is that just a guess and a cushion? Or are there specific programs you've identified?

CHARLES L. HORN: Yes, I think it's a case. Think of it, David, we divested $800 million in December, so you know for the full year, in terms of average, that's going to be part of it. So basically, it means that there's another $200 million potential over the course of the year that we could look at and evaluate, either do a held-for-sale or could be a retailer that goes away. So said simply, the bulk of it was the divestiture we made at the end of December.

DAVID MICHAEL SCHARF: Okay. Got it. And the mid-teens, Charles, that's a year-over-year -- that's a 12/31 versus 12/31 guidance apples-to-apples, that's average.

CHARLES L. HORN: Average '18 over average '17.

DAVID MICHAEL SCHARF: Got it. And then lastly, shifting to Epsilon, you noted the tightening labor market. Curious, you obviously took a lot of initiatives in recent years on the off-shoring side to address that. Do you feel like, based on the mix of skill sets that are needed, the composition of Epsilon as it exists today, is off-shoring as an option pretty much run its course? Or are there additional opportunities there?

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Yes. Again, we view it a little differently as from off-shoring. It's actually an office that we built over there. These are Alliance Data employees just like the folks here. So it's very much keeping it within the family-type approach. I would expect we're going to have 2,000 folks over there. And no, I don't think it's run its course in terms of the cost model itself. The proportion that -- of our associate base that's over there versus here is probably getting to be at the point where we find it's comfortable. And I don't think there'll be a huge shift, either way, going forward. But in terms of the benefits on working across, both India and here in the states, we're just beginning to see that. So I would expect, while there's a nice chunk that we've picked up thus far, there's probably another chunk to go.

DAVID MICHAEL SCHARF: Okay. That's helpful. And just last question quickly on the AIR MILES business. You've noted, obviously, for several quarters the challenges in issuance growth associated with the grocery segment. Is there something structural that's changed among a number of the large sponsors in terms of how much they're willing to spend on promotional activities? Or did you feel like 2017 may have just been a breather on their part as they assess maybe the fallout from the expiry events? Trying to get a sense for visibility there.

CHARLES L. HORN: Yes. I think, David, it's hangover from what took place in the fourth quarter of '16 around the expiry. I think that's really what it was. Obviously, we had a number of things come on this year. We need to get Bank of Montr\xE9al renewed, which we did around the third quarter; that should help. And I do think in the grocery vertical, we just need to get them back satisfied, get the consumers back in their stores and that, by itself, will lead to getting promotional activity back. But I would attribute it to purely hangover from the Q4 '16 event.

EDWARD J. HEFFERNAN: Okay. Thanks, everyone. We'll see you after Q1.

OPERATOR: This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.
